subsection.text: In this division the following words have the meanings indicated.
“County” means a county of the State or Baltimore City.
“Department” means the Department of Business and Economic Development.
“Person” means an individual, receiver, trustee, guardian, personal representative, fiduciary, representative of any kind, partnership, firm, association, corporation, or other entity.

paragraph.text: “Qualified distressed county” means a county with:

subparagraph.text: an average rate of unemployment for the most recent 24–month period for which data are available that exceeds:

sub-subparagraph.text: 150% of the average rate of unemployment for the State during that period; or
the average rate of unemployment for the State during that period by at least 2 percentage points; or

subparagraph.text: an average per capita personal income for the most recent 24–month period for which data are available that is equal to or less than 67% of the average per capita personal income for the State during that period.

paragraph.text: “Qualified distressed county” includes a county that:

subparagraph.text: no longer meets either criterion stated in paragraph (1) of this subsection; but
has met at least one of the criteria at some time during the preceding 24–month period.

subsection.text: “Secretary” means the Secretary of Business and Economic Development.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, “state” means:

subparagraph.text: a state, possession, territory, or commonwealth of the United States; or
the District of Columbia.

paragraph.text: When capitalized, “State” means Maryland.

subsection.text: In this division the following words have the meanings indicated.
“County” means a county of the State or Baltimore City.
“Department” means the Department of Business and Economic Development.
“Person” means an individual, receiver, trustee, guardian, personal representative, fiduciary, representative of any kind, partnership, firm, association, corporation, or other entity.

paragraph.text: “Qualified distressed county” means a county with:

subparagraph.text: an average rate of unemployment for the most recent 24–month period for which data are available that exceeds 150% of the average rate of unemployment for the State during that period; or

an average per capita personal income for the most recent 24–month period for which data are available that is equal to or less than 67% of the average per capita personal income for the State during that period.

paragraph.text: “Qualified distressed county” includes a county that:

subparagraph.text: no longer meets either criterion stated in paragraph (1) of this subsection; but
has met at least one of the criteria at some time during the preceding 24–month period.

subsection.text: “Secretary” means the Secretary of Business and Economic Development.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, “state” means:

subparagraph.text: a state, possession, territory, or commonwealth of the United States; or
the District of Columbia.

paragraph.text: When capitalized, “State” means Maryland.

section.text: There is a Department of Business and Economic Development, which is a principal department of the State government.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall appoint the Secretary of Business and Economic Development with the advice and consent of the Senate.
The Secretary is the head of the Department.

subsection.text: Before taking office, the appointee shall take the oath required by Article I, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.

paragraph.text: The Secretary serves at the pleasure of the Governor and is responsible directly to the Governor.
The Secretary shall advise the Governor on all matters assigned to the Department and is responsible for carrying out the Governor’s policies on matters assigned to the Department.

subsection.text: The Secretary is entitled to the compensation provided in the State budget.
The Secretary:

paragraph.text: is responsible for the operation of the Department; and
shall establish guidelines and procedures to promote the orderly and efficient administration of the Department.

subsection.text: The Secretary may establish, reorganize, or abolish areas of responsibility in the office of the Secretary as necessary to fulfill effectively the duties assigned to the Secretary.

section.text: The Secretary shall have a seal.

subsection.text: With the approval of the Governor, the Secretary shall appoint a deputy secretary.
The deputy secretary:

paragraph.text: serves at the pleasure of the Secretary; and
is entitled to the compensation provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The deputy secretary shall have the duties provided by law or delegated by the Secretary.
In accordance with the State budget, the Secretary may employ a staff and retain professional consultants in the office of the Secretary.
The Secretary may designate a staff assistant to be in charge of a particular area of responsibility in the office of the Secretary.

paragraph.text: Each staff assistant in the office of the Secretary in charge of a particular area of responsibility and each professional consultant is appointed by and serves at the pleasure of the Secretary.

Unless otherwise provided by law, the Secretary shall appoint and remove all other employees in the office of the Secretary in accordance with the provisions of the State Personnel and Pensions Article that govern skilled service or professional service employees with the exception of special appointments.

subsection.text: The appointment or removal of personnel by a unit under the jurisdiction of the Department is subject to the approval of the Secretary.
The Secretary may delegate the approval authority under subsection (a) of this section to the head or governing body of the unit.
The Secretary shall adopt regulations for the office of the Secretary.

paragraph.text: Subject to § 2-206 of this title, the Secretary shall review regulations of a unit under the jurisdiction of the Department.
The Secretary may approve, disapprove, or revise regulations of a unit.

section.text: The Secretary is responsible for the budget of the office of the Secretary and for the budget of each unit under the jurisdiction of the Department.

subsection.text: The Secretary is responsible for the coordination and direction of all planning activities that the office of the Secretary initiates.
The Secretary shall keep fully apprised of and may approve, disapprove, or modify the plans, proposals, and projects of units under the jurisdiction of the Department.

section.text: The Secretary may not remove an appointee to a particular office in the Department without first obtaining the Governor’s approval if the law provides that:

paragraph.text: the Secretary is required to make the appointment with the consent of the Governor; and
the appointee:

subparagraph.text: serves at the pleasure of the Secretary; or
may be removed by the Secretary with or without cause.

section.text: The Secretary may call a meeting of any unit under the jurisdiction of the Department to consider any subject.

subsection.text: This section does not apply to a power, duty, responsibility, or function that is granted to the Maryland Economic Development Commission under Subtitle 2 of this title.
The Secretary may exercise any power, duty, responsibility, or function of any unit under the jurisdiction of the Department.

section.text: Except as otherwise provided by law, each unit under the jurisdiction of the Department shall report to the Secretary or to the Secretary’s designee as provided in the regulations or written directives of the Secretary.

subsection.text: In accordance with the State budget, the Secretary shall set the compensation of Department employees.
The Secretary of Budget and Management shall determine position categories for special appointments in the Department.
This section does not apply to a unit under the jurisdiction of the Department to the extent that the unit is authorized by law to employ its own legal counsel.
The Attorney General is the legal adviser to the Department.
The Attorney General shall assign to the Department the number of assistant Attorneys General that are authorized by law for the Department and its units.

paragraph.text: The Attorney General shall designate one of the assistant Attorneys General assigned to the Department as counsel to the Department and may not reassign that individual without consulting with the Secretary.
The counsel may only:

subparagraph.text: advise the Secretary, the Maryland Economic Development Commission, and any other official of the Department as they require;
supervise the other assistant Attorneys General assigned to the Department; and
perform for the Department the other duties that the Attorney General assigns.

paragraph.text: The other assistant Attorneys General shall perform for the Department the other duties that the Attorney General assigns.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided by law, the Secretary:

paragraph.text: shall determine the organizational structure of the Department; and
may create or abolish units in the Department.
The Governor or the Secretary may establish advisory or decision-making units for the Department.
The units shall advise and assist the Secretary on the policies, programs, and activities of the Department.
The Governor or the Secretary shall determine the size, qualifications, method of appointment, terms, compensation, manner of removal, and method of filling vacancies of the units.

section.text: To attract and encourage business development and serve the needs of business, the Department shall:

paragraph.text: advance the economic welfare of the public through programs and activities that develop in a proper manner the natural resources and economic opportunities of the State;
promote and encourage the location and creation of new industries and businesses in the State and encourage the retention and expansion of existing industries;
support the creation of new businesses and the growth of existing businesses in the State by improving their quality, productivity, and competitive position in the global marketplace;
assist the growth and revitalization of small businesses;
support the growth of the State and regional economies by providing consulting, technical assistance, and liaison activities on business and economic development issues;
promote the development of international trade activities;
assist businesses and employees through training and other employment services;
promote regulatory reform and coordinate efforts with other State and local units; and
foster and develop employment opportunities for residents of the State.

section.text: The Department shall:

paragraph.text: investigate and assemble information about the economic development, industrial opportunities, and economic resources of the State, including raw materials, power and water resources, transportation facilities, markets, labor, banking and financing facilities, industrial sites, and other fields of research;
encourage location and development of new businesses in the State and the retention and expansion of present enterprises in coordination with local governments and local economic development units;
encourage formation of local and sectional development committees and cooperate with local civic groups and other local, State, and federal development units;
disseminate information in the interest of industrial development in the State, by publication, advertising, and other means;

assist businesses in the areas of technology development and commercialization, small business development, workforce development and productivity, manufacturing modernization, and defense conversion;
serve as an ombudsman for businesses affected by State policies and programs;
coordinate business assistance service delivery to individual companies;
link groups of businesses to address regional and industry specific needs;

broker information exchange and entrepreneurial services that enhance economic development through partnerships with businesses, not-for-profit organizations, professional groups, local economic development entities, and local governments;
assist in developing and conducting regional strategic planning and coordinating State investments with regional economic development entities;
collect and assemble information and data available from other State units;
monitor economic conditions, release reports, and maintain interindustry models of State regulations and local economies;
use community colleges in the State to help deliver services;
administer the programs in the Department; and
coordinate its efforts and activities with the Apprenticeship and Training Council and Apprenticeship and Training Program in the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation.

subsection.text: The Department shall support industry-led regional technology councils that help private enterprises attempting to establish or expand manufacturing and technology-based businesses.
The Department may:

paragraph.text: select an entity as the regional technology council for a particular region; and
determine the geographic areas that constitute a region for purposes of this section.

subsection.text: The Department may support a regional technology council through grants, loans, in-kind assistance, advice, or other assistance.
To the extent practicable, the Department shall use pertinent data obtained from units of the State when collecting and assembling information.
Except to the extent that disclosure is prohibited by law, the Department has access to all records, data, information, and statistics of other units of the State.
The Department may establish a consolidated publications account.
The Department may place in the account excess revenues that remain at the end of the fiscal year that are derived from publications of the Department or its units.
The Department may only use the account to produce, distribute, and promote publications, including free publications, of the Department and its units.

paragraph.text: Any unexpended money in the account at the end of a fiscal year not exceeding $40,000:

subparagraph.text: does not revert to the General Fund of the State; but
shall be maintained as a special fund.

paragraph.text: Any unexpended money in the account at the end of a fiscal year exceeding $40,000 reverts to the General Fund under § 7-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Commission” means the Maryland Economic Development Commission.

subsection.text: There is a Maryland Economic Development Commission in the Department.
The purpose of the Commission is to establish economic development policy in the State and oversee the Department’s efforts to support the creation of, attract, and retain businesses and jobs.

subparagraph.text: The Commission consists of not more than 25 voting members appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.
The Secretary is a nonvoting ex officio member of the Commission.

paragraph.text: The geographic representation of the Commission shall cover the entire State and shall include at least one representative from:

subparagraph.text: the upper Eastern Shore;
the lower Eastern Shore;
Calvert County, Charles County, or St. Mary’s County;
Allegany County or Garrett County; and
Carroll County, Frederick County, or Washington County.

paragraph.text: When appointing Commission members, the Governor shall consider geographic and industry representation.
The members appointed shall reflect the racial and gender diversity of the population of the State.

subsection.text: The appointed members of the Commission shall have substantial interest or experience in business or knowledge of business and economic development.
The Commission and its members are subject to the Maryland Public Ethics Law.

paragraph.text: The term of an appointed member is 3 years.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member appointed after a term has begun serves only for the remainder of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
The terms of the members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Commission on October 1, 2008.
A member may be removed by the Governor with or without cause.

subsection.text: The Governor shall designate a chair or co-chairs from the voting members of the Commission.
The Commission may elect an executive committee from its members to exercise the powers and functions of the Commission between meetings of the Commission.

paragraph.text: The Commission shall meet as often as its duties require, but not less than quarterly.
The chair or co-chairs shall designate a time and place for meetings of the Commission.

subsection.text: A majority of the voting members of the Commission is a quorum.
A voting member of the Commission:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Commission; but
is entitled to reimbursement in accordance with the Standard State Travel Regulations as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Department shall provide staff support to the Commission.
The Commission may:

paragraph.text: adopt bylaws for the conduct of its business;
hire consultants; and
do anything necessary or convenient to carry out its powers and the purposes of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Commission shall:

paragraph.text: develop and update an economic development strategic plan for the State;
seek ideas and advice from each region of the State to develop the economic development strategic plan;
incorporate into the economic development strategic plan the Maryland Port Administration strategic plan developed for the Helen Delich Bentley Port of Baltimore;
recommend to the Governor the program and spending priorities needed to implement the economic development strategic plan;
review the allocation of financing incentives;
participate in marketing the State and encouraging new businesses to locate in the State;
seek contributions from the private sector to supplement economic development programs and financial incentives to business; and
carry out other economic development activities that the Governor requests.

subsection.text: The Commission may spend money raised under subsection (b) of this section only in accordance with the State budget.
Departmental regulations that pertain to financing programs shall be approved by the Commission before adoption.
On or before January 15 of each year, the Commission shall report to the General Assembly, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, on its activities during the previous year.
The report shall include a review of initiatives taken by the Commission and the Department to implement the economic development strategic plan.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Commission” means the Maryland Advisory Commission on Manufacturing Competitiveness.
To support manufacturing in Maryland, it is the policy of the State to follow these seven principles:

paragraph.text: the State must make a long-term institutional commitment to improving the competitiveness of existing and emerging manufacturers;
the State’s support for manufacturing must be industry-driven, with governmental and educational efforts focused on priorities set by businesses;
to have a noticeable impact on the State and regional economies, the State’s efforts to support manufacturing must be organized in ways that address the level of need;
the State’s support of manufacturing must be held accountable to measurable outcomes that result from the State’s business assistance activities;
to be competitive, all manufacturers must deploy the latest advances in technology;
to develop a competitive manufacturing base, the State should target its limited resources to those key manufacturing industries that have a strong presence or healthy growth prospects; and
the State’s business assistance services for existing and emerging manufacturers must be:

subparagraph.text: comprehensive, ranging across marketing, technology, financing, job training, and other needs of manufacturing; and
readily available across all regions of the State.

section.text: There is a Maryland Advisory Commission on Manufacturing Competitiveness in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Commission consists of:

subparagraph.text: two members appointed by the President of the Senate of Maryland;
two members appointed by the Speaker of the House of Delegates;
the Secretary or the designee of the Secretary;
four other ex officio members representing units of State government:

sub-subparagraph.text: the Secretary of the Environment or the designee of the Secretary of the Environment;
the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation or the designee of the Secretary of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation;
the State Superintendent of Schools or the Superintendent’s designee; and
a representative of the Maryland Higher Education Commission; and

subparagraph.text: the following 16 members appointed by the Secretary with the approval of the Governor:

sub-subparagraph.text: one representative of an educational institution in the State;
two representatives of organized labor;
12 representatives of manufacturing enterprises; and
one representative of business organizations.

paragraph.text: The members appointed under paragraph (1)(iv) and (v) of this subsection shall reflect the racial and gender diversity of the population of the State.
The members appointed under paragraph (1)(v)3 of this subsection should generally reflect representation from:

subparagraph.text: varied geographic regions of the State;
varied sectors of manufacturing, balancing technology-related and traditional manufacturing industries; and
the mix of manufacturing enterprises in the State, including those that employ 500 or more employees and those that employ fewer than 500 employees.

paragraph.text: The term of a member appointed under subsection (a)(1)(v) of this section is 3 years and begins on July 1.
The terms of the members appointed under subsection (a)(1)(v) are staggered as required by the terms provided for the members of the Commission on October 1, 2008.
A member may be reappointed, but after serving two consecutive 3-year terms, a member may not be reappointed until at least 1 year after the end of the member’s previous tenure.

subparagraph.text: A vacancy shall be filled immediately for the remainder of the unexpired portion of a term.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor has been appointed.
A member appointed by the President of the Senate or the Speaker of the House serves at the pleasure of the appointing officer.
A member appointed under subsection (a)(1)(v) of this section may be removed at any time by the Secretary, with or without cause.

section.text: The Secretary shall designate a chair from among the private sector members of the Commission.
The Commission shall meet at least 4 times each year.
A member of the Commission who is a member of the General Assembly may not vote on a matter before the Commission that relates to the exercise of a sovereign power of the State.
The Commission shall advise the Secretary on the best methods to implement the policy directives of the action plan for manufacturing competitiveness in the State, including:

paragraph.text: encouraging the development of new manufacturing enterprises and the expansion and retention of existing manufacturing enterprises;
encouraging and facilitating training and education of individuals for manufacturing jobs;
producing a climate conducive to the growth and viability of manufacturing enterprises;
supporting research necessary to evaluate, plan, and execute effective promotion of manufacturing enterprises; and
encouraging, assisting, and coordinating the activities of local, regional, and national public or private organizations that promote manufacturing.

section.text: The Commission shall submit a report each year to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly on the progress of the Commission in implementing policies to assist manufacturing in the State.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Advisory Board” means the Maryland Life Sciences Advisory Board.
“Life sciences” includes the fields of biotechnology, pharmaceuticals, biomedical technologies, life systems technologies, food sciences, environmental sciences, and biomedical devices.
There is a Maryland Life Sciences Advisory Board in the Department.

The purpose of the Advisory Board is to recommend State and federal policies, priorities, practices, and legislation to expedite the creation of private sector jobs through the commercialization of life sciences research.
The Advisory Board consists of the following 18 members:

paragraph.text: the Secretary;
a representative of the Maryland Technology Development Corporation, designated by the Maryland Technology Development Corporation; and
the following members appointed by the Governor:

subparagraph.text: three representing federal agencies located in the State with life sciences missions;
seven with executive experience in life sciences businesses located in the State, at least four of whom represent small businesses;
four representing institutions of higher education located in the State, one of whom shall represent a community college;
one with general business marketing experience in a life sciences business located in the State; and
one member of the general public.

subsection.text: The composition of the Advisory Board shall reflect the racial and gender diversity of the population of the State.

paragraph.text: Except for the Secretary, the term of an Advisory Board member is 2 years.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove a member of the Advisory Board for incompetence, misconduct, or failure to perform the duties of the position.
The Governor shall select a chair from among the members of the Advisory Board.
The Advisory Board may act with an affirmative vote of eight members.
A member of the Advisory Board:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Advisory Board; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Advisory Board shall assist the Department in:

paragraph.text: developing a comprehensive State strategic plan for life sciences;
promoting life sciences research, development, commercialization, and manufacturing in the State;
promoting collaboration and coordination among life sciences organizations in the State;
promoting collaboration and coordination among research institutions of higher education in the State;
developing a strategy to coordinate State and federal resources to attract private sector investment and job creation in the life sciences;
developing a strategy to support federal life sciences facilities located in the State, including support for education, transportation, housing, and capital investment needs; and
making recommendations to address critical needs in the life sciences, including access to venture capital and capital construction funding.

subsection.text: In performing its duties, the Advisory Board shall give due consideration to the business, scientific, medical, and ethical aspects of the life sciences industry.
The Advisory Board shall report to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly on or before December 15 of each year.
The report shall include any recommendations from the Advisory Board and a summary of the activities of the Advisory Board during the preceding year.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Office” means the Office of International Trade.

subsection.text: There is an Office of International Trade in the Department.
The purpose of the Office is to promote the development of international business activities and opportunities in the State.
The Office may enter into contracts or make grants:

paragraph.text: consistent with this subtitle; and
subject to the approval of the Secretary or the Secretary’s designee.

subsection.text: Procurement by the Office for services to be performed or supplies to be delivered outside the State shall be consistent with, but not subject to, Division II of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

section.text: With special emphasis on exports, the Office shall encourage businesses in the State to increase international trade activities by:

paragraph.text: channeling trade leads and providing a list of prescreened foreign intermediaries;
providing informational and consultative services on the international trade process, including:

subparagraph.text: market research and selection;
marketing techniques and risks;
foreign trade laws; and
the availability of private or public financing;

paragraph.text: developing publications to facilitate the exchange of information on products and services between businesses in the State and foreign businesses;
initiating and organizing foreign trade missions to and from foreign countries and participating in trade fairs, in cooperation with local governments and the private sector;

establishing an outreach program for small-sized and medium-sized businesses that have export potential to provide counseling and to use experienced private-sector exporters and other qualified persons; and
assisting, as appropriate, with acquisition of export-related financing through the Maryland Industrial Development Financing Authority and federal, local, or private programs.

section.text: The Office shall encourage and facilitate participation by businesses in the State in barter, counter trade, and joint venture transactions, as appropriate, by:

paragraph.text: providing informational and consultative services, including the necessary components and laws involved in these transactions;
facilitating the commercial relationship between Maryland businesses in the State and counterpart foreign businesses involved in these transactions; and
providing, in cooperation with the private sector, a listing of potential barter and joint venture opportunities.

subsection.text: The Office shall coordinate its programs with the State Department of Agriculture, the Department of the Environment, the State Department of Transportation, the University System of Maryland, other appropriate federal, State, and local units, and private organizations.

In overseas offices of the State, and with other State units, the Office shall participate, as appropriate, in providing informational and marketing services to support international trade efforts of the Office.
The Office shall encourage and facilitate regional efforts to develop local and regional international trade programs and expertise, consistent with other State efforts, through:

paragraph.text: technical assistance; and
matching grants to public or private regional entities.

subsection.text: The Office shall encourage the location of new international industrial or commercial enterprises in the State, in cooperation with local governments and other entities.

section.text: The Office shall engage in any other activity reasonably necessary to achieve the purposes of this subtitle.
The Office shall report at least twice each year to the Maryland Economic Development Commission on the status of the State’s international activities.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the Partnership for Workforce Quality Advisory Board.
“Fund” means the Partnership for Workforce Quality Fund.
“Program” means the Partnership for Workforce Quality Program.

section.text: There is a Partnership for Workforce Quality Program in the Department.
The purpose of the Program is to provide training services to:

paragraph.text: improve the competitiveness and productivity of the State’s workforce and business community;
upgrade employee skills for new technologies or production processes; and
assist employers located in the State in promoting employment stability.

subsection.text: The Secretary or the Secretary’s designee shall direct the Program.
The Secretary may not provide training assistance under the Program except at the specific request of an employer or group of employers.
To identify employers that need assistance, the Secretary shall use local advisory groups, including private industry councils and joint apprenticeship committees.
Subject to §§ 3-405 and 3-412(c) and (d)(1) of this subtitle, the Secretary shall establish eligibility criteria and priorities for assistance under the Program.

The Secretary shall submit a report each year on the operation and performance of the Program to the Governor, the Maryland Economic Development Commission, the Governor’s Workforce Investment Board, and, in accordance with § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly.

paragraph.text: An employer receiving assistance under the Program shall be located in the State.

In order to receive assistance under the Program, an employer shall request training assistance in job-specific skills to upgrade or retain existing Maryland-based employees covered under Title 8 of the Labor and Employment Article.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall give priority to employers that are:

paragraph.text: manufacturers; or
threatened by the pressure of increased foreign or domestic competition.

section.text: The Program shall provide business assistance services that:

paragraph.text: determine whether the employer’s specific needs are best met by training, other types of assistance, or a combination of services;
identify the availability of existing training programs that may be adapted to meet the employer’s needs;
identify the resources the employer may provide to support the training, including:

subparagraph.text: equipment;
facilities; and
materials;

paragraph.text: identify or develop appropriate curricula; and
determine the most cost-effective approach to meeting training needs.

subsection.text: The Secretary may award a grant for job-specific training assistance to an eligible:

paragraph.text: business;
community college;
private career school;
State-accredited training agency;
trade association; or
union-sponsored training program.

subsection.text: Training shall be approved by the employer of those being trained.
Under the Program, job-specific training may not exceed 1 year.
There is a Partnership for Workforce Quality Advisory Board in the Department.
The Board shall advise the Secretary.
The Board consists of the following 15 members:

paragraph.text: one member of the Senate of Maryland appointed by the President of the Senate;
one member of the House of Delegates appointed by the Speaker of the House; and
the following members appointed by the Governor with the advice of the Secretary and the chair of the Governor’s Workforce Investment Board:

subparagraph.text: five representatives of business, of which three shall represent employers with fewer than 100 employees;
three representatives of organized labor;
one representative from the Maryland Higher Education Commission;
one representative from the State Department of Education;
one representative from the Governor’s Workforce Investment Board; and
two representatives of the general public.

paragraph.text: The term of a member appointed under subsection (a)(3) of this section is 3 years.
The terms of the members appointed under subsection (a)(3) of this section are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on October 1, 2008.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: A member of the Board:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Board; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations.

subsection.text: The Governor shall designate the chair of the Board.
The Board shall:

paragraph.text: submit recommendations to the Secretary concerning overall policy for the Program;
recommend a system to evaluate requests for assistance under the Program, including eligibility criteria and priorities for assistance;
develop criteria to assess and evaluate Program performance and advise the Secretary of the criteria;
consult regularly with the Governor’s Workforce Investment Board and the Maryland Economic Development Commission concerning the activities of the Program;
submit a quarterly report on the Program to the Governor’s Workforce Investment Board; and

advise the Secretary on coordination of cooperative activities at the State and local level between the Department, employers, labor, and other public and private entities involved with workforce quality.

subsection.text: In recommending a system for evaluating requests for assistance, the Board shall consider the equal distribution of assistance to all subdivisions of the State.
There is a Partnership for Workforce Quality Fund in the Department.
The Secretary shall manage and supervise the Fund.

paragraph.text: The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to reversion under § 7-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Treasurer shall hold the Fund separately and the Comptroller shall account for the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: money appropriated by the State to the Fund;
money made available to the Fund through federal programs;
private contributions to the Fund;
an application or other fee paid to the Program in connection with processing a request for financial assistance; and
any other money made available to the Fund.

subsection.text: The Department may use money in the Fund for:

paragraph.text: grants to defray the cost of workforce training; and
administrative, actuarial, legal, and technical services for the Program.

subsection.text: Any investment earnings shall be credited to the Fund.
The Program may provide business assistance services under § 3-406 of this subtitle at no cost to the employer.
Program money may be used for costs associated with the direct delivery of instruction, including:

paragraph.text: curriculum development;
course materials; and
instructors’ salaries and expenses for training.
At least 60% of the money available to the Program shall be reserved for employers with 150 or fewer employees based in the State.
Up to 20% of the money available to the Program may be provided to an employer with more than 500 employees based in the State, if the employer:

subparagraph.text: is primarily engaged in manufacturing or in a technology-based business;
agrees to increase purchases of goods produced in the State and services from suppliers based in the State; and

agrees to provide the workforce training to the number of employees based in the State, as determined by the Program, of smaller employers located in the State that supply goods or services to the employer receiving the money.

paragraph.text: An employer may not receive more than $200,000 a year from the Program.
The Program may not contribute more than 50% of direct training costs for job-specific training assistance.
Program money may not be used for:

subparagraph.text: capital equipment for an employer; or
trainee wages.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Division” means the Division of Tourism, Film, and the Arts.
There is a Division of Tourism, Film, and the Arts in the Department.

paragraph.text: With the approval of the Governor, the Secretary shall appoint a director of the Division.
The director serves at the pleasure of the Secretary.
Removal of the director by the Secretary is final.

subsection.text: The director shall have demonstrated interest and experience in tourism, film, and the arts.
The director shall operate the Division under the direction of the Secretary.

section.text: The director of the Division is entitled to the compensation provided in the State budget.
In accordance with the State budget, the director of the Division may employ a staff and retain professional consultants.
The Division shall:

paragraph.text: stimulate development of tourism business in the State;
promote business and job opportunities in the State;
encourage development of recreational areas and facilities;
make the public aware of the State’s heritage and historical development;
advertise and disseminate information about the State;
encourage the promotion and development of amateur and professional sports in the State;
encourage the advancement of and participation in the performing, visual, and creative arts; and
administer those programs assigned to the Division by law or designated by the Secretary.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the Maryland Tourism Development Board.
“Fund” means the Maryland Tourism Development Board Fund.
“Office” means the Office of Tourism Development.

section.text: It is the policy of the State to guide, stimulate, and promote the coordinated, efficient, and beneficial development of travel and tourism in the State so that the State can derive the economic, social, and cultural benefits of travel and tourism to the fullest extent possible.
There is a Maryland Tourism Development Board in the Department.

subsection.text: The Board consists of the following 24 members:

paragraph.text: 11 members appointed by the Governor in consultation with the Secretary and with the advice and consent of the Senate;
three nonvoting members appointed by the Governor who are directors or chief executive officers from among the destination marketing organizations officially recognized by the Office;
five members appointed by the President of the Senate of Maryland as follows:

subparagraph.text: at least two members of the Senate; and
at least two members from the private business community; and

paragraph.text: five members appointed by the Speaker of the House of Delegates as follows:

subparagraph.text: at least two members of the House of Delegates; and
at least two members from the private business community.

subsection.text: In appointing members to the Board, the Governor and, with respect to private business community members, the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House shall:

paragraph.text: ensure that each geographic region of the State is represented equitably;
give due consideration to the recommendations of representatives of the tourism industry; and
provide balanced representation of the lodging, food service, transportation, retail, and amusements and attractions sectors of the tourism industry.

subsection.text: A member of the Board who is a member of the General Assembly may not vote on a matter before the Board that relates to the exercise of the sovereign powers of the State.

subparagraph.text: The term of a member is 3 years and begins on July 1.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for the members on October 1, 2008.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve only until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member may be reappointed, but after serving for two consecutive 3–year terms, a member may not be reappointed until at least 1 year after the end of the member’s previous tenure.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

paragraph.text: A member of the General Assembly appointed by the President of the Senate or the Speaker of the House serves until a successor is appointed.
A member appointed by the Governor may be removed by the Governor with or without cause.
A private business community member appointed by the President of the Senate or the Speaker of the House may be removed by the appointing officer with or without cause.

subsection.text: Each year the Board shall elect a chair, five vice chairs, and a secretary–treasurer from among its members.
Of the five vice chairs, there shall be one representative each from the lodging, food service, transportation, retail, and amusements and attractions sectors.
The director of the Office is the Executive Director of the Board as part of the regular duties of the director of the Office.
The director may not receive additional compensation for serving as Executive Director of the Board.
The Board shall meet at least 4 times a year, at times and places the chair determines.
A member of the Board:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Board; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Office shall provide staff for the Board.
The Board shall use the facilities, equipment, and supplies of the Office to conduct its business.
The exercise of the powers and duties of the Board under this subtitle is subject to the approval of the Secretary.
The Board may:

paragraph.text: adopt regulations to carry out this subtitle;
enter into contracts and agreements;
obtain services;
ask any other unit of the State for assistance and data that enable the Board to carry out its powers and duties;
accept federal money for any purpose of this subtitle; and
accept gifts, donations, or bequests for any purpose of this subtitle.

section.text: The Board shall:

paragraph.text: protect, preserve, promote, and restore the natural, historical, scenic, and cultural resources in the State;
generate revenue through the sale of goods and services related to tourism in accordance with § 4-215 of this subtitle; and
publish and submit to the Maryland Economic Development Commission and the Secretary an annual report and other material that the Board considers appropriate.

section.text: The Board shall:

paragraph.text: draft and implement a 5-year strategic plan for the promotion and development of tourism in the State; and
submit the strategic plan to the Maryland Economic Development Commission for its review.

subsection.text: The Board shall:

paragraph.text: draft and implement an annual marketing plan consistent with the strategic plan developed under § 4-211 of this subtitle; and
submit the marketing plan to the Maryland Economic Development Commission for its review.

subsection.text: The Board shall establish an annual operating budget consistent with the marketing plan.

section.text: The Board shall:

paragraph.text: encourage the development of new tourism resources, products, businesses, and attractions in the State;
facilitate the movement and activities of tourists to, from, and within the State through signs, information aids, and other services;
improve the safety and security of tourists in the State;
encourage and facilitate training and education of individuals for jobs in the tourism industry;
provide a healthy environment for the development of human resources in tourism businesses;
encourage residents to pursue careers in tourism businesses;
produce a climate conducive to small tourism business growth and viability;

review existing and proposed taxes, fees, licenses, regulations, and regulatory procedures affecting tourism and the tourism industry in the State and evaluate their impact on the ability of the tourism industry to create employment and generate income;
support research necessary to evaluate, plan, and execute effective tourism programs;
cooperate with other public units and private organizations to develop and promote the State’s tourism and travel industries; and
encourage, assist, and coordinate the tourism activities of local and regional promotional organizations.

section.text: The Board shall:

paragraph.text: set policies for spending money on tourism advertising, written and graphic materials, cooperative and matching promotional programs, and other tourism and travel developmental and promotional activities for the State;
spend money of the Fund to plan, advertise, promote, assist, and develop the tourism and travel industries in the State; and
provide grants to destination marketing organizations for the purpose of attracting visitors to the State of not less than:

subparagraph.text: $2,350,000 in total for fiscal year 2011; and
$2,500,000 in total for fiscal year 2012 and for each fiscal year thereafter.

subsection.text: There is a Maryland Tourism Development Board Fund in the Department.
The purpose of the Fund is to finance programs relating to the planning, advertising, promotion, assistance, and development of the tourism industry in the State.
The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to reversion under § 7-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: money appropriated in the State budget to the Fund; and
money that the Board accepts under § 4-209 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Expenditures from the Fund may be made only by the Board in accordance with an appropriation.

paragraph.text: The Treasurer shall invest the money of the Fund in the same manner as other State money may be invested.
Any investment earnings of the Fund shall be credited to the General Fund of the State.
In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.

“Tourism tax increment” means the amount, if any, by which the tourism tax revenues collected in the fiscal year 2 years before a particular fiscal year exceeds the tourism tax revenues collected in the fiscal year 3 years before the particular fiscal year.
“Tourism tax revenues” means sales and use tax revenues collected on the retail sale of tourist–oriented goods and services, as determined by the Comptroller under subsection (c)(3) of this section.
For each of fiscal years 2011 and 2012, the Governor shall include in the annual budget bill a proposed General Fund appropriation to the Fund of $5,000,000.

For fiscal year 2013 and each fiscal year thereafter, the Governor shall include in the annual budget bill a proposed General Fund appropriation to the Fund in an amount not less than $6,000,000 for each fiscal year.
On or before August 1 of each year, the Comptroller shall calculate the amount of the qualifying tourism tax increment for the current fiscal year in accordance with paragraph (2) of this subsection.
The qualifying tourism tax increment is:

subparagraph.text: if the tourism tax increment exceeds 3% of the tourism tax revenues collected in the fiscal year 3 years before the current fiscal year, one–half of the amount of the tourism tax increment above the 3% increase; or
if the tourism tax increment does not exceed 3%, zero.

paragraph.text: The Comptroller shall:

subparagraph.text: determine the classification codes that shall be included in tourism tax revenues under this subsection after consulting with the Department; and

on or before August 1 of each year, report the amount of the qualifying tourism tax increment to the Governor, the Department, the Department of Budget and Management, and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall consider whether to include the amount of the qualifying tourism tax increment in the appropriation to the Fund in the proposed State budget for the next fiscal year, in addition to the amount to be included in the budget bill under subsection (b) of this section.
This subsection may not be construed to require funding in the State budget of the qualifying tourism tax increment.

If the proposed State budget for a particular fiscal year includes an appropriation to the Fund under this subsection, it is the intent of the General Assembly that the total annual funding appropriated to the Fund in any fiscal year not exceed by more than $5,000,000 the sum of:

subparagraph.text: the portion of the qualifying tourism tax increment that the Governor included in the proposed State budget for the fiscal year immediately preceding the particular fiscal year; and
the amount stated in subsection (b) of this section.

subsection.text: On or before October 1 of each year beginning in 2012, in cooperation with the Board and the Maryland Association of Destination Marketing Organizations, the Department shall report to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly on the effectiveness of the funding provided under subsections (b) and (c) of this section in increasing visitor attendance and visitor spending in Maryland.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Office” means the Maryland Film Office.
There is a Maryland Film Office in the Department.
The Office may:

paragraph.text: ask any State or local governmental unit for assistance and information to carry out this subtitle;
accept a gift, bequest, or grant from a public or private source for any of the purposes of this subtitle;
spend money made available in accordance with the State budget for any of the purposes of this subtitle; and
do any other act necessary to carry out this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Office shall implement a program to promote the production of motion pictures and television programs in the State.
The Office shall:

paragraph.text: prepare and distribute promotional and informational materials that address:

subparagraph.text: desirable locations in the State to produce motion pictures and television programs;
the benefits and advantages of producing motion pictures and television programs in the State; and
the services and assistance available from State government, local government, and the motion picture and television industry;

paragraph.text: assist motion picture and television companies to secure location permits and other services in connection with motion picture and television production; and
facilitate cooperation from federal, State, and local governmental units and the private sector in locating and producing motion pictures and television programs.

section.text: The Office shall coordinate its activities with activities of similar local governmental units in the State for any of the purposes of this subtitle.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Arts” includes dance, drama, music drama, architecture, painting, sculpture, graphics, crafts, photography, design, film, television, and creative writing.
“Council” means the Maryland State Arts Council.
The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: many of the residents of the State lack the opportunity to enjoy or participate in and develop a greater appreciation of the arts, including theatrical performances, concerts, opera, dance and ballet performances and recitals, art and art exhibitions, fine examples of architecture, and creative writing;
with increasing leisure time, the practice and enjoyment of the arts are of increasing importance;
many of the residents of the State possess artistic and creative talents that cannot be utilized fully under existing conditions;

the general welfare of the residents of the State will be promoted by recognizing that the arts are a vital part of the culture and heritage of the State and are an important means to expand the scope of the State’s educational program for children and adults;
interest in the arts will provide employment for artists in all fields and encourage residents to participate in the arts;

increased activities in the arts will increase employment in the State by encouraging the production of artistic events in various communities of the State, thus utilizing the talents and services of many residents;
the standards of performance of the arts will improve because of the encouragement of increased resident participation and a demand for higher standards for more residents; and
implementing and exhibiting artistic programs, constructing performance facilities, and increasing tourism from these programs will increase employment and help the economy of the State.

subsection.text: It is the policy of the State to:

paragraph.text: strive to create a nurturing climate for the arts in the State and join with private patrons, institutions, and professional organizations concerned with the arts;
promote the role of the arts in the life of the residents of the State; and
ensure that the arts play an ever more significant part in the residents’ welfare and educational experience.

subsection.text: The General Assembly intends that the activities of the State to carry out the policy set forth in subsection (b) of this section:

paragraph.text: encourage and assist artistic expression; and
not limit freedom of artistic expression, which is essential for the well-being of the arts.

section.text: There is a Maryland State Arts Council in the Department.

subsection.text: The Council consists of the following 17 members:

paragraph.text: 13 members appointed by the Governor in consultation with the Secretary and with the advice and consent of the Senate;
two members appointed by the President of the Senate of Maryland, at least one of whom shall be a member of the Senate; and
two members appointed by the Speaker of the House of Delegates, at least one of whom shall be a member of the House of Delegates.

subparagraph.text: The term of a member who is not a member of the General Assembly is 3 years and begins on July 1.
A member of the General Assembly appointed to the Council serves until a successor is appointed.

paragraph.text: A member may be reappointed, but after serving for two consecutive 3-year terms, a member may not be reappointed until at least 1 year after the end of the member’s previous tenure.
The terms of members appointed under subsection (a)(1) of this section are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Council on October 1, 2008.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor has been appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: In appointing members, the Governor shall:

paragraph.text: consider recommendations of civic, educational, and professional organizations concerned with or engaged in the production or presentation of the arts; and
provide balanced geographic representation.

section.text: Each year the Council shall select a chair, a vice chair, and a secretary-treasurer from its membership.
A member of the Council:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Council; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Council shall meet at least four times a year.
The chair or the Secretary shall call the meetings.
The exercise of the powers and performance of duties of the Council under this subtitle is subject to the approval of the Secretary.
The Council may:

paragraph.text: adopt regulations to carry out this subtitle;
enter into contracts and agreements;
obtain services;
ask any other unit of the State for assistance and data that enable the Council to carry out its powers and duties;
accept federal money for any purpose of this subtitle;
accept gifts, donations, or bequests for any purpose of this subtitle; and
carry out this subtitle.
With the approval of the Secretary, the Council shall appoint an Executive Director of the Council.
The Executive Director may not be a member of the Council.
The Executive Director serves at the pleasure of the Council, subject to the concurrence of the Secretary.
The Executive Director is a special appointment in the State Personnel Management System.

subsection.text: Subject to the policies of the Council and the administrative supervision of the Secretary, the Executive Director:

paragraph.text: is the administrative officer of the Council staff;
shall appoint and remove employees of the Council; and
shall direct, administer, and supervise the activities of the Council staff.

subsection.text: The Council may:

paragraph.text: conduct a statewide survey of resources and needs in the arts;
determine the extent to which existing resources can fill the needs;
design new or expanded programs in the arts on its own or with arts organizations;
encourage and assist in the formation and activities of community arts councils;
provide technical and consultative assistance to arts organizations throughout the State;

provide logistical and financial assistance to encourage the touring of outstanding professional performances and exhibitions of art, from inside and outside the State, to communities throughout the State;
make awards for excellence in the arts;
make grants to arts organizations and individual artists;
cooperate with educational institutions and organizations to establish a higher level of education in and appreciation of the arts by students throughout the State;
explore the feasibility of regional arts programming in neighboring states and program exchange with other states, and implement the programs the Council considers advisable;
make recommendations to the Board of Public Works concerning appropriate aesthetic decorations, embellishments, accessories, and ornamentation to State projects, buildings, and property; and
conduct other programs consistent with this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Council:

paragraph.text: shall publish an annual report; and
may publish other material.

section.text: In exercising its powers and performing its duties under this subtitle, the Council may not interfere with:

paragraph.text: freedom of artistic expression; or
established or contemplated arts programs in any community.

subsection.text: The Council is entitled to funding in accordance with the State budget.

The Council may treat nonstate, nonfederal contributions for programs of assistance to the arts as a special fund that is not subject to reversion under § 7-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Commission” means the Maryland Commission on Public Art.
“Fund” means the Maryland Public Art Fund.
“Program” means the Maryland Public Art Initiative Program.
There is a Maryland Public Art Initiative Program.
The purpose of the Program is to promote the installation of artwork in public facilities for the enrichment of the public.
Program money shall be used to:

paragraph.text: acquire public art to be owned by the State;
preserve public art assets, including assets of the Commission; and
make grants to local governments.

subsection.text: There is a Maryland Commission on Public Art.

paragraph.text: The Commission consists of the following 11 members:

subparagraph.text: as designated by the chair of the Council, either the Executive Director or a member of the Maryland State Arts Council established under Subtitle 5 of this title;
as designated by the chair of the Trust, either the Director or a member of the Maryland Historical Trust established under Title 5A, Subtitle 3 of the State Finance and Procurement Article;
as designated by the State Archivist, either the State Archivist or a member of the Commission on Artistic Property established under Title 9, Subtitle 10 of the State Government Article;
the Comptroller or the Comptroller’s designee; and
seven public members appointed by the Secretary with the approval of the Governor.
The Secretary shall include as public members representatives of the artistic community who have professional expertise as artists, curators, art historians, art educators, or architects.
A public member serves at the pleasure of the Secretary.

subsection.text: With the approval of the Governor, the Secretary shall designate a chair from among the public members of the Commission.
A member of the Commission:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Commission; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Maryland State Arts Council shall provide staff to the Commission.

section.text: The Commission shall:

paragraph.text: work with the Department of General Services, the State Department of Transportation, and the University System of Maryland to ensure that new public facilities constructed by State units include the installation of artwork;
allocate money from the Fund to commission artwork for installation at public facilities around the State;
establish selection panels to recommend artists and artwork to be funded by the Fund; and
make final recommendations concerning the disbursement of money allocated to the Program.

subsection.text: There is a Maryland Public Art Fund.
The purpose of the Fund is to provide money to carry out the Program.
The Commission shall administer the Fund.

paragraph.text: The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to reversion under § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Treasurer shall hold the Fund and the Comptroller shall account for the Fund.
The Fund consists of:

subparagraph.text: money appropriated in the State budget for the Program; and
any other money accepted for the benefit of the Fund from any other source.

paragraph.text: Any investment earnings of the Fund shall be paid into the Fund.

subsection.text: It is the intent of the General Assembly that for each fiscal year, the Governor shall include in the operating or capital budget an appropriation not to exceed $1,000,000 for the Program.
The Treasurer shall invest the money of the Fund in the same manner as other State money may be invested.
Money in the Fund may only be spent:

paragraph.text: to carry out the purposes of this subtitle; and
in accordance with the State budget process.

subsection.text: Before a grant is awarded to a local government under this subtitle, the local government shall provide and spend a matching fund.
A matching fund of a local government may not consist of:

paragraph.text: money provided, directly or indirectly, from appropriated or unappropriated State money;
real property;
in kind contributions; or
money spent before June 1, 2005.

subsection.text: The Maryland State Arts Council shall adopt regulations to carry out the Program.
The regulations shall address:

paragraph.text: procedures for artist and art selection;
composition of selection panels;
budget allocations for each project;
local community involvement; and
conservation and maintenance concerns.

subsection.text: All artwork funded by the Program is the property of the Maryland Historical Trust.
In cooperation with the Department of General Services, the Maryland Historical Trust is responsible for the inventory, maintenance, and preservation of all artwork acquired through the Program.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Artistic work” means an original and creative work that:

paragraph.text: is created, written, composed, or executed; and
falls into one of the following categories:

subparagraph.text: a book or other writing;
a play or performance of a play;
a musical composition or the performance of a musical composition;
a painting or other picture;
a sculpture;
traditional or fine crafts;
the creation of a film or the acting within a film;
the creation of a dance or the performance of a dance;
the creation of original jewelry, clothing, or design; or
any other product generated as a result of a work listed in items (i) through (ix) of this paragraph.

subsection.text: “Arts and entertainment district” means a developed district of public and private uses that:

paragraph.text: is distinguished by physical and cultural resources that play a vital role in the life and development of the community and contribute to the public through interpretive, educational, and recreational uses; and
ranges in size from a portion of a political subdivision to a regional district with a special coherence.

subsection.text: “Arts and entertainment enterprise” means a for-profit or not-for-profit entity dedicated to visual or performing arts.
“Political subdivision” means a county or municipal corporation.
“Qualifying residing artist” means an individual who:

paragraph.text: owns or rents residential real property in the county where the arts and entertainment district is located;
conducts a business in the arts and entertainment district; and

derives income from the sale or performance within the arts and entertainment district of an artistic work that the individual wrote, composed, or executed, either alone or with others, in the arts and entertainment district.

section.text: This subtitle does not apply to:

paragraph.text: the creation or execution of artistic work for industry–oriented or industry–related production; or
tailoring services, clothing alteration, or jewelry repair.

subsection.text: The following political subdivisions may apply to the Secretary to designate an arts and entertainment district:

paragraph.text: a political subdivision for an area within that political subdivision;
with the prior consent of the municipal corporation, a county, on its own behalf or on behalf of a municipal corporation, for an area in the municipal corporation; or
two or more political subdivisions jointly for an area astride their common boundaries.

subsection.text: The application shall:

paragraph.text: be in the form and manner and contain the information that the Secretary requires by regulation;
contain sufficient information to allow the Secretary to determine if the proposed district qualifies under §§ 4-701(c) and 4-704(a) of this subtitle; and
be submitted for a political subdivision by its chief elected officer or, if none, its governing body.

subsection.text: The Secretary may designate an area as an arts and entertainment district only if the area is a contiguous geographic area that is wholly within a priority funding area as provided under § 5-7B-02 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

paragraph.text: Within 60 days after a submission date, the Secretary may designate one or more arts and entertainment districts from among the areas in the applications timely submitted.
A county may not receive more than one arts and entertainment district designation in a calendar year.

subsection.text: The designation of the Secretary is final.
At any time, a political subdivision may reapply to the Secretary to designate as an arts and entertainment district an area that is not so designated.

A political subdivision may apply to the Secretary to expand an existing arts and entertainment district in the same manner as the political subdivision would apply to designate a new arts and entertainment district.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding subsection (a) of this section and § 4–704(a) of this subtitle, in Queen Anne’s County, the governing body may establish an arts and entertainment district composed of noncontiguous areas in the county, including noncontiguous areas within a municipal corporation in the county, subject to the Secretary’s designation of the district as an arts and entertainment district in the county.

In applying for the establishment of an arts and entertainment district in accordance with paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Queen Anne’s County governing body shall comply with the provisions of § 4–703 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: In an arts and entertainment district:

paragraph.text: each qualifying residing artist is eligible for the income tax subtraction modification under § 10-207(v) of the Tax - General Article;
the property tax credit under § 9-240 of the Tax - Property Article applies; and
the exemption from the admissions and amusement tax under § 4-104 of the Tax - General Article applies.
On or before July 1 preceding the effective date of its establishment, the Secretary shall notify the Comptroller that an arts and entertainment district is established.

The subtraction modification under § 10-207(v) of the Tax - General Article applies to each taxable year beginning after December 31 of the year in which the Secretary provides the notice required by paragraph (1) of this subsection.

section.text: The Secretary shall adopt regulations on application procedures and criteria to designate arts and entertainment districts.

subsection.text: In this section, “Fund” means the Special Fund for Preservation of Cultural Arts in Maryland.
There is a Special Fund for Preservation of Cultural Arts in Maryland.
The purpose of the Fund is to provide supplemental grants to cultural arts organizations in the State that qualify for general operating support grants from the Maryland State Arts Council.
The Secretary of Business and Economic Development shall administer the Fund.

paragraph.text: The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The State Treasurer shall hold the Fund separately, and the Comptroller shall account for the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: revenue distributed to the Fund under § 2–202(a)(1)(ii) of the Tax – General Article; and
any other money from any other source accepted for the benefit of the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund shall be used to provide supplemental grants for operating and programmatic improvements that strengthen the organizational capacity and financial stability of cultural arts organizations in the State that qualify for general operating support grants from the Maryland State Arts Council.

paragraph.text: The State Treasurer shall invest the money of the Fund in the same manner as other State money may be invested.
Any investment earnings of the Fund shall be credited to the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: For each appropriation to the Fund, the Governor may:

paragraph.text: include the funds in the State budget subject to appropriation by the General Assembly; or
transfer the funds by budget amendment from the Fund to the expenditure account of the Maryland State Arts Council.

subsection.text: Supplemental grants made from the Fund are supplemental to and may not take the place of funding that otherwise would be appropriated for qualifying organizations.
The Department shall administer the State’s economic development and growth funds to facilitate the attraction, creation, expansion, and retention of businesses and jobs in the State.
The Department shall encourage local governments to develop, and assist local governments in developing, strategic plans for economic development.

section.text: The Department shall administer the State’s economic development and financial assistance programs and funds including:

paragraph.text: the BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone Program, under Subtitle 13 of this title;
the Enterprise Fund, under Subtitle 6 of this title;
the Enterprise Zones Program, under Subtitle 7 of this title;
the Maryland Economic Adjustment Fund, under Subtitle 2 of this title;
the Maryland Economic Development Assistance Authority and Fund, under Subtitle 3 of this title;
the Maryland Industrial Development Financing Authority, under Subtitle 4 of this title;
the Maryland Small Business Development Financing Authority, under Subtitle 5 of this title;
the Appalachian Regional Development Program, under Title 13, Subtitle 1 of this article;
jointly with the Department of Housing and Community Development, the Community Development Block Grant for Economic Development; and
any other programs or funds designated by statute, the Governor, or the Secretary.

subsection.text: This section applies notwithstanding any other law.
Subject to subsections (d) and (e) of this section, the Secretary may transfer money among any of the accounts that are:

paragraph.text: in the Department or subject to its control; and
used to provide financial support of any kind.

subsection.text: Subject to subsections (d) and (e) of this section, the Secretary may transfer money to the Economic Development Opportunities Program Account established under § 7–314 of the State Finance and Procurement Article from any of the accounts that are:

paragraph.text: in the Department or subject to its control; and
used to provide financial support of any kind.

subsection.text: A transfer under this section from the Industrial Development Fund shall comply with § 5-432 of this title.
A transfer under this section shall comply with the amendment process for appropriations established by § 7-209 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Secretary may:

paragraph.text: invest in a specialized small business investment company created in accordance with the federal Small Business Investment Act of 1958; and
to the extent allowed by federal law, do anything necessary or convenient to fully participate in the formation and operation of a specialized small business investment company.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other law, the Secretary may use money to finance a specialized small business investment company from accounts within:

paragraph.text: the Enterprise Fund established under Subtitle 6 of this title; and
the Maryland Small Business Development Financing Authority established under Subtitle 5 of this title.

section.text: When deciding whether to provide financial assistance for a business project, the Department shall consider whether the project will be located:

paragraph.text: in an enterprise zone or a focus area as designated under Subtitle 7 of this title; or
in a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone as designated under Subtitle 13 of this title.

section.text: The Secretary shall designate a unit in the Department to be the single contact for issues relating to realignment and closure of military installations in the State.

The Department may take all reasonable actions to protect the interests of the Department in its investments, collateral, loans, grants, and other property or interests relating to financing transactions, including expending funds from its general and special funds to acquire, dispose of, operate, protect, enhance, or maintain collateral or liens.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Fund” means the Maryland Economic Adjustment Fund.

paragraph.text: “Working capital” means money for current operations of a business.
“Working capital” includes money for supplies, materials, labor, equipment, rent, software, marketing, insurance, and fees for professional services.

subsection.text: Financial assistance from the Fund may be approved by the Secretary or the Secretary’s designee.
The exercise by the Department of the powers granted under this subtitle is the performance of an essential governmental function.
There is a Maryland Economic Adjustment Fund in the Department.

paragraph.text: The Department shall administer the Fund.
The Secretary may:

subparagraph.text: delegate to any unit in the Department the underwriting, closing, monitoring, and workout functions for Fund loans; or
contract with another entity to perform these functions.

subsection.text: The Maryland Economic Adjustment Fund is a special, nonlapsing revolving fund that is not subject to reversion under § 7-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

paragraph.text: The Fund consists of:
