subparagraph.text: federal money allocated or granted to the Fund, including adjustment implementation grant money designated for the Fund under the Defense Conversion and Defense Economic Adjustment Program of the Economic Development Administration of the United States Department of Commerce;
private money donated or granted to the Fund;
money appropriated by the State to the Fund;

premiums, fees, interest payments, and principal payments on loans made under this subtitle, including a loan financed by the Economic Development Opportunities Program Fund under § 7-314(f) of the State Finance and Procurement Article;
proceeds from the sale, disposition, lease, or rental of collateral relating to loans under this subtitle; and
any other money made available to the Fund.

paragraph.text: This subtitle does not require an appropriation to the Fund from the General Fund of the State, regardless of the availability of other funding sources for the Fund.
The Fund shall be used to:

subparagraph.text: make loans to new or existing companies with 50 or fewer employees;
make grants to local or regional governmental or not–for–profit economic development revolving loan funds in the State; and
pay all expenses and disbursements authorized by the Department for administering the Fund.

paragraph.text: A loan to an eligible company under this subtitle may include:

subparagraph.text: advances of loan proceeds for loans; and

to the extent allowed by the regulations of the federal Economic Development Administration of the United States Department of Commerce, money for expenses for administrative, legal, actuarial, technical, and other services.

paragraph.text: Subject to the restrictions of this subtitle, the Department may make a loan from the Fund to an applicant only if:

subparagraph.text: the applicant meets the qualifications under this subtitle; and
the applicant meets any additional requirements imposed by the source of the money to be loaned.

paragraph.text: The Treasurer shall invest the money of the Fund in the same manner as other State money may be invested.
Any investment earnings of the Fund shall be credited to the Fund.
The Treasurer shall submit a report each year to the Department on:

subparagraph.text: the status of the money invested under this subtitle;
the market value of the assets in the Fund on the date of the report; and
the interest received from investments for the Fund during the reporting period.

section.text: The Department shall adopt regulations to carry out this subtitle.

subsection.text: An applicant for a loan under this subtitle shall submit to the Department an application on the form that the Department requires.
The application shall include:

paragraph.text: a detailed strategic business plan;
the amount of money required for the activities described in the strategic business plan;
the money available to the applicant without financial assistance from the Department;
the amount of financial assistance requested from the Department;
information relating to the financial status of the applicant, including, if applicable:

subparagraph.text: a current balance sheet;
a profit and loss statement; and
credit references; and

paragraph.text: any other relevant information that the Department requests.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, the Department may set the terms and conditions for loans and grants made under this subtitle.
The Department shall:

paragraph.text: determine whether to approve loan requests from qualified applicants for loans under this subtitle;
set the terms and conditions for loans made under this subtitle; and
determine that the applicant was unable to obtain the financing necessary for the activities on affordable terms through the normal lending channels.

subsection.text: The maximum amount of a loan made with money from the Economic Development Administration of the United States Department of Commerce may not exceed the limit it sets by regulation.

The proceeds of a loan may be used for working capital, equipment, furnishings, fixtures, or the construction, rehabilitation, or purchase of real property for the activities that the Department approves.
The Department may authorize a flexible repayment schedule for a loan under this subtitle.
The Department shall prepare the loan documents for loans under this subtitle.
The loan documents shall include:

paragraph.text: the interest rate on the loan;
the amount of the loan;
repayment provisions for the loan; and
any other provision that the Department determines is necessary, including a provision on taking liens and security interests in real or personal property.

subsection.text: If a recipient of a loan under this subtitle violates any provision of the loan documents or ceases to meet the requirements of this subtitle, the Department may, on reasonable notice to the loan recipient:

paragraph.text: withhold further advances of loan proceeds until the loan recipient complies with the agreement or requirements; or
exercise any other remedy provided in the loan documents.

If a loan made under this subtitle is in default, the Department may foreclose on a mortgage or deed of trust held as security for the loan in the manner provided under the Maryland Rules for foreclosures in private transactions.
The Department may take title in the Department’s name to any property foreclosed and convey title to a bona fide purchaser.

subsection.text: A person may not knowingly make or cause to be made a false statement or report:

paragraph.text: in an application or document provided to the Department; or
to influence Department action affecting financial assistance, whether or not the assistance already has been extended.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or a fine not exceeding $50,000 or both.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Aquaculture project” means a project that encourages innovation, expansion, and modernization of the seafood processing industry or aquaculture industry.
“Arts and entertainment district” means an area designated by the Secretary as an arts and entertainment district under Title 4, Subtitle 7 of this article.
“Arts and entertainment enterprise” means a for–profit or not–for–profit entity that is:

paragraph.text: located in an arts and entertainment district; and
dedicated to the visual or performing arts.

subsection.text: “Arts and entertainment project” means a project that promotes or enhances the development of an arts and entertainment district.

paragraph.text: “Associated development and carrying costs” means costs that are associated with the acquisition and maintenance of an asset.
“Associated development and carrying costs” includes:

subparagraph.text: settlement costs;
insurance;
interest;
taxes;
government fees;
utilities; and
the costs of managing and securing the asset.

subsection.text: “Authority” means the Maryland Economic Development Assistance Authority.

“Brownfields Revitalization Incentive Program” means the program in the Department that provides financial assistance from the Fund for the redevelopment of qualified brownfields sites, as provided in Part VI of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: “Brownfields site” means a property that:

subparagraph.text: is located in a county or municipal corporation that elects to participate in the Brownfields Revitalization Incentive Program in accordance with § 5–336 of this subtitle; and
is:

sub-subparagraph.text: an eligible property, as defined in § 7–501 of the Environment Article, that is owned or operated by an inculpable person, as defined in § 7–501 of the Environment Article; or
a property where there is a release, discharge, or threatened release of oil, as defined in § 4–401 of the Environment Article, that is subject to Title 4 of the Environment Article.

paragraph.text: “Brownfields site” does not include property that is owned or operated by:

subparagraph.text: a responsible person as defined in § 7–201 of the Environment Article; or
a person responsible for the discharge, as defined in § 4–401 of the Environment Article.

subsection.text: “Child care facility” means a facility that is required to be licensed as a child care center under Title 5, Subtitle 5, Part VII of the Family Law Article.
“Child care special loan” means a direct loan to expand or improve child care services at a child care facility, as provided in Part VII of this subtitle.
“Corporation” means the Maryland Economic Development Corporation.
“Financial assistance” means a grant, loan, or investment provided under this subtitle.
“Fund” means the Maryland Economic Development Assistance Fund.
“Local economic development fund” means a revolving, nonlapsing fund that one or more local governments establish for economic development in the areas under their jurisdiction.
“Local economic development opportunity” means a project that:

paragraph.text: is determined by the Department or Authority to provide a valuable economic development opportunity to the jurisdiction in which the project is located; and
is a priority for and endorsed by the governing body of that jurisdiction.

subsection.text: “Local government” means:

paragraph.text: a county;
a municipal corporation;
a designated agency or instrumentality of a county; or
a designated agency or instrumentality of a municipal corporation.

subsection.text: “Qualified brownfields site” means a brownfields site that is determined by the Department to be eligible for financial assistance under this subtitle.
“Qualified distressed county project” means a project that a local government or the Corporation carries out in a qualified distressed county.
“Responsible person” has the meaning stated in § 7–201 of the Environment Article.

“Significant strategic economic development opportunity” means a project that is determined by the Department or Authority to provide a valuable economic development opportunity of statewide, regional, or strategic industry impact.
“Specialized economic development opportunity” means:

paragraph.text: an aquaculture project;
an arts and entertainment enterprise;
an arts and entertainment project;
the redevelopment of a qualified brownfields site; or
a project to create or expand a child care facility.

subsection.text: “Working capital” means money to be used for current operations of a business.

section.text: Assistance for a qualified distressed county project is available to a qualified distressed county under this subtitle only if:

paragraph.text: the county has developed a local strategic plan for economic development in consultation with the municipal corporations located in the county, if any;
the county has submitted the plan to the Secretary for approval; and
the Secretary has approved the plan.

section.text: There is a Maryland Economic Development Assistance Authority in the Department.

subsection.text: The Authority consists of the individuals serving as members of the Maryland Industrial Development Financing Authority under § 5-406 of this title.
The members of the Authority shall be appointed in accordance with § 5-407 of this title.
The members of the Authority may act concurrently in their capacities as members of the Authority and of the Maryland Industrial Development Financing Authority.
The members of the Authority shall carry out the powers and duties of the Authority under this subtitle whether acting:

paragraph.text: concurrently as members of the Authority and the Maryland Industrial Development Financing Authority; or
as members of either authority alone.

subsection.text: The members of the Authority shall conduct the business of the Authority and of the Maryland Industrial Development Financing Authority under Subtitle 4 of this title.

section.text: There is a Maryland Economic Development Assistance Fund in the Department.
The purposes of the Fund are to:

paragraph.text: expand employment opportunities in the State by providing financial assistance to businesses that are engaged in eligible industry sectors, including financial assistance for:

subparagraph.text: aquaculture projects;
arts and entertainment enterprises;
arts and entertainment projects; and
creation and expansion of child care facilities;

paragraph.text: provide financial assistance for the redevelopment of qualified brownfields sites;
provide financial assistance to local governments and the Corporation for economic development projects; and
provide grants to local economic development funds.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall administer the Fund.

paragraph.text: The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to reversion under § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Treasurer shall hold the Fund separately and the Comptroller shall account for the Fund.

subsection.text: Any investment earnings of the Fund shall be credited to the Fund.

section.text: The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: money appropriated in the State budget to the Fund;
money made available to the Fund through federal programs or private contributions;
repayments of principal and interest from loans made from the Fund;
proceeds from the sale, disposition, lease, or rental of collateral related to financial assistance provided by the Department under this subtitle;
application or other fees paid to the Fund to process requests for financial assistance;
recovery of an investment made by the Department in a business, including an arrangement under which part of the investment is recovered through:

subparagraph.text: a requirement that the Department receive a proportion of cash flow, commissions, royalties, or license fees;
the repurchase from the Department of any of its investment interest; or
the sale of an appreciated asset;

paragraph.text: repayments received from recipients of conditional grants from the Department;
money collected under § 9–229 of the Tax – Property Article;
repayments on or recoveries from financial assistance provided from the former:

subparagraph.text: Brownfields Revitalization Incentive Fund;
Child Care Facilities Direct Loan Fund;
Child Care Special Loan Fund;
Maryland Industrial and Commercial Redevelopment Fund;
Maryland Industrial Land Fund;
Maryland Seafood and Aquaculture Loan Fund; and
Smart Growth Economic Development Infrastructure Fund; and

paragraph.text: any other money made available to the Fund.

subsection.text: The Department may use money in the Fund to:

paragraph.text: provide financial assistance to eligible applicants; and
pay expenses for administrative, actuarial, legal, and technical services for the Fund.

subsection.text: The Department periodically shall review its portfolio in an effort to ensure:

paragraph.text: the equitable distribution among the counties of money from the Fund;
adequate funding for qualified distressed county projects; and
that no particular qualified distressed county benefits disproportionately from financial assistance to qualified distressed counties under this subtitle.

section.text: Before January 1 of each year, the Department shall report to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly on the number, amount, use, and economic benefits of financial assistance provided under this subtitle.
Financial assistance is deemed authorized under this subtitle if it was provided, or approved to be provided, from the following programs that have been incorporated into the Fund:

paragraph.text: the Brownfields Revitalization Incentive Fund;
the Child Care Facilities Direct Loan Fund;
the Child Care Special Loan Fund;
the Maryland Industrial and Commercial Redevelopment Fund;
the Maryland Industrial Land Act;
the Maryland Seafood and Aquaculture Loan Fund; and
the Smart Growth Economic Development Infrastructure Fund.
Financial assistance from the Fund not exceeding $2,500,000 may be approved by the Secretary.
Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, financial assistance from the Fund exceeding $2,500,000 requires approval by the Authority.
For a qualified distressed county project, the Secretary may approve financial assistance exceeding $2,500,000.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (a)(3) of this section, with respect to requests for financial assistance exceeding $2,500,000:

paragraph.text: the Department shall evaluate the requests; and
the Authority shall:

subparagraph.text: evaluate the requests that have first been evaluated by the Department;
determine whether to approve the requests; and
set the terms and conditions of the financial assistance.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, financial assistance provided to a local government or the Corporation for a project shall be approved by a formal resolution of:

subparagraph.text: the governing body of the jurisdiction in which the project is located; or
if the recipient of the financial assistance is the Corporation, its board of directors.

paragraph.text: If the recipient of the financial assistance is the Corporation for a qualified distressed county project, the financial assistance shall be approved by formal resolutions of both the board of directors of the Corporation and the governing body of the jurisdiction in which the project is located.

A project that is funded by a grant from the Fund to a local government or the Corporation, and carried out by the local government or the Corporation, shall be consistent with the strategy or plan for economic development of the county or municipal corporation in which the project is located.

If the Department provides financial assistance to a local government for a project, an interest in that project is later transferred to a third party, and the transfer of the interest is financed by the local government:

subparagraph.text: the local government may assign the financing documents to the Department as a repayment of or return on the Department’s financial assistance to the local government; and
the assignment may not be considered a new financing under this subtitle.

subsection.text: For a local economic development opportunity, the local government of the jurisdiction in which the project is located shall provide:

paragraph.text: a formal resolution of the governing body of the jurisdiction in which the project is located that endorses the financial assistance to be provided from the Fund; and
as determined by the Department or Authority to evidence the support of the local government for the project:

subparagraph.text: a guarantee, secured by the full faith and credit of the county or municipal corporation in which the project is located, of all or part of the financial assistance to be provided by the Fund;
the financing of part of the costs of the project equal to at least 10% of the financial assistance to be provided from the Fund; or
both.

subsection.text: To be eligible for financial assistance from the Fund, an applicant shall be:

paragraph.text: a local economic development fund that meets the criteria set forth in Part V of this subtitle; or
an individual, private business, not-for-profit entity, or local government, or the Corporation that intends to use the requested financial assistance for a project that:

subparagraph.text: except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, is in an eligible industry sector under § 5-321 of this subtitle; and
has a strong potential for expanding or retaining employment opportunities in the State.

subsection.text: A project need not be in an eligible industry sector if the applicant:

paragraph.text: is located in a qualified distressed county; or

subparagraph.text: is a local government or the Corporation; and
does not intend to use the financial assistance to carry out a project that benefits a particular private sector entity.

subsection.text: In form and content acceptable to the Department, an applicant for financial assistance from the Fund shall submit to the Department an application that contains:

paragraph.text: the information that the Department or Authority considers necessary to evaluate the request for financial assistance; and
for a qualified distressed county project:

subparagraph.text: a marketing plan designed to market the project to prospective businesses;
a statement of planned marketing expenditures as a percent of the total financial assistance amount requested; and
a plan for the project that is consistent with the county’s local strategic economic development plan as to the location and type of project.

paragraph.text: After consulting with the Department and the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation, each year the Maryland Economic Development Commission shall:

subparagraph.text: evaluate the potential employment and economic growth of Maryland’s industry sectors; and
recommend eligible industry sectors to the Authority.

paragraph.text: Each year the Authority shall:

subparagraph.text: consider the recommendation of the Maryland Economic Development Commission; and
establish a list of industry sectors that will be eligible for financial assistance from the Fund.

paragraph.text: In determining whether an applicant is engaged in an eligible industry sector, the Department shall consider the definitions set forth in the North American Industry Classification System.
For the purpose of providing financial assistance under this subtitle, the following are deemed to be in eligible industry sectors:

subparagraph.text: aquaculture projects;
arts and entertainment enterprises;
arts and entertainment projects;
redevelopment of qualified brownfields sites;
creation or expansion of child care facilities;
projects in areas that are declared to be federal disaster areas within 1 year before the Department receives an application for financial assistance under this subtitle; and
feasibility studies.

paragraph.text: The requirements specifically imposed on significant strategic economic development opportunities and local economic development opportunities under this subtitle do not apply to the items listed in paragraph (1) of this subsection.

subsection.text: Financial assistance from the Fund may be used only to finance costs incurred for:

paragraph.text: construction or acquisition of a building or real property, and associated development and carrying costs;

construction, acquisition, or installation of equipment, furnishings, fixtures, leasehold improvements, site improvements, or infrastructure improvements, including rail line enhancements on or to the site of an economic development project, and associated development and carrying costs;
working capital for significant strategic economic development opportunities, arts and entertainment enterprises, or arts and entertainment projects;
redevelopment of qualified brownfields sites;
subject to § 5-325(b)(3) of this subtitle, construction, purchase, or renovation of real property, fixtures, or equipment related to a child care facility;
if supported by a resolution adopted by the governing body of the jurisdiction in which a project may be located, feasibility studies;
subject to § 5-325(b)(4) of this subtitle, preparation of a county’s or municipal corporation’s strategy or plan for economic development; and

a project intended to assist businesses in areas that are declared to be federal disaster areas, but only if the Department receives an application for financial assistance within 1 year after the declaration of the federal disaster area.

subsection.text: Financial assistance from the Fund may not be used to refinance existing debt.

section.text: Financial assistance from the Fund may not exceed the lesser of:

paragraph.text: 20% of the Fund balance.

subsection.text: Each subsection of this section is subject to § 5–323 of this subtitle.

If the Department or Authority determines a project to be a significant strategic economic development opportunity, the Department or Authority may provide a loan from the Fund for the project to an individual, private business, not–for–profit entity, or the Corporation in an amount not exceeding $10,000,000.

If the Department or Authority determines a project to be a local economic development opportunity, the Department or Authority may provide financial assistance from the Fund for the project to an individual, private business, not–for–profit entity, or the Corporation in an amount not exceeding:

paragraph.text: $5,000,000 for a loan or investment; and
$2,000,000 for a grant.
Financial assistance provided to a local government or the Corporation to finance a project may be:

subparagraph.text: in the form of a grant, loan, or investment; and
except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, in an amount not exceeding $3,000,000.

paragraph.text: Financial assistance for a qualified distressed county project may be in an amount determined by the Department.
A grant to a local economic development fund is subject to the requirements of Part V of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Financial assistance for a specialized economic development opportunity may be:

paragraph.text: provided to an individual, private business, not–for–profit entity, or local government, or the Corporation;
in the form of a grant, loan, or investment; and
in an amount determined by the Department or Authority.

subsection.text: Subject to the restrictions of this subtitle, the Department or Authority may impose the terms and conditions on financial assistance from the Fund as either considers appropriate.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2), (3), or (4) of this subsection, financial assistance from the Fund may not exceed 70% of the total costs of the project being financed.
Financial assistance from the Fund may constitute 100% of the total costs of the project being financed if:

subparagraph.text: the recipient is the Corporation; or
the financial assistance is for:

sub-subparagraph.text: an arts and entertainment enterprise;
an arts and entertainment project; or
a qualified distressed county project.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, financial assistance from the Fund:

sub-subparagraph.text: may be used to finance up to 50% of the costs of construction, purchase, or renovation of real property, fixtures, or equipment related to a child care facility; but
may not be used for working capital, supplies, or inventory related to a child care facility.

subparagraph.text: Financial assistance from the Fund may be used to finance up to 20% of the costs described in subparagraph (i) of this paragraph incurred by a business that has received or will receive a day care loan insured by the Maryland Industrial Development Financing Authority.

paragraph.text: Financial assistance for preparation of a strategy or plan for economic development of a county or municipal corporation may not exceed:

subparagraph.text: 50% of the costs of preparation; or
$50,000 in a 3-year period.

paragraph.text: A loan from the Fund shall bear an interest rate below the market rate of interest, as determined by the Department, if the loan is for:

subparagraph.text: a significant strategic economic development opportunity; or
a specialized economic development opportunity.

paragraph.text: A loan from the Fund for a qualified distressed county project shall bear an interest rate determined by the Department or the Authority.

A loan from the Fund shall bear an interest rate not exceeding one-eighth of 1% plus the net interest cost of the most recent State general obligation bond issue preceding the approval of the loan if the loan is:

subparagraph.text: for a local economic development opportunity; or
to a local government.

paragraph.text: A loan from the Fund may not bear an interest rate of less than 3% unless:

subparagraph.text: the project funded by the loan is located in an area of high unemployment; or
the Department determines that the borrower is carrying out a compelling economic development initiative.

paragraph.text: The Department may waive interest during the first 2 years of the term of a loan from the Fund.
If a borrower defaults on a loan from the Fund, the Department may impose an interest rate that exceeds the limits set forth in subsection (c)(1) or (3) of this section.

subsection.text: The term of a loan from the Fund may not exceed:

paragraph.text: for working capital, 3 years;
for financing equipment, furnishings, or fixtures, the lesser of 15 years or the useful life of the asset, as determined by the Department;
for financing the construction or acquisition of buildings and real property, 25 years; and
for financing the redevelopment of a qualified brownfields site or a qualified distressed county project, a term approved by the Department or Authority.

subsection.text: In this section, “minority business enterprise” has the meaning stated in § 14-301 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

paragraph.text: This section applies to financial assistance that exceeds $100,000.
This section does not apply to financial assistance that is used solely to acquire real property or structures on real property.

If a local government that receives financial assistance has a program for promoting procurement opportunities among minority businesses that is acceptable to the Department, the local government shall apply the requirements of that program to procurement made with the proceeds of financial assistance.
If the local government does not have a program that is acceptable to the Department under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the local government is subject to subsection (d) of this section.

An entity other than a local government, or a local government in accordance with subsection (c)(2) of this section, that receives financial assistance shall agree to include in the agreement providing the financial assistance a provision acceptable to the Department that would encourage the procurement from minority business enterprises of goods or services purchased with the proceeds from the financial assistance.
In negotiating the provision required under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Department shall take into account relevant factors, including:

subparagraph.text: the intended use of the proceeds from the financial assistance; and
the feasibility of obtaining the required goods or services from minority business enterprises.

subsection.text: The Department may require a recipient of financial assistance to submit to the Department a list, or an updated list, of the minority business enterprises from which goods or services were procured and the nature and cost of the goods or services.
A local government may apply to the Department for a grant from the Fund to a local economic development fund.
In determining whether to approve a grant to a local economic development fund, the Department or Authority shall consider and determine:

paragraph.text: the average rate of unemployment for the local jurisdiction in comparison to the average rate of unemployment for the State;
whether the local government currently administers a local economic development fund;
the ability of the local government to leverage private money;
the level of financial commitment provided by the local government; and
any other factors that the Department or Authority considers relevant.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, to qualify for a grant from the Fund, a local government shall provide at least an equal and matching grant of money to the local economic development fund.

A local government that is, or is located in, a qualified distressed county may qualify for a grant from the Fund by providing a grant to the local economic development fund in an amount equal to at least 50% of the grant from the Fund.
During each fiscal year the Department may not grant more than $2,000,000 under this part.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, during each fiscal year a county may not receive more than $250,000 under this part.
For purposes of the limitation under paragraph (1) of this subsection:

subparagraph.text: any money received under this part by a municipal corporation or designated agency or instrumentality is deemed to be money granted to the county within which the municipal corporation, agency, or instrumentality is located; and
if more than one county administers or capitalizes a local economic development fund, each county may receive the maximum authorized for a county.

subsection.text: A local government shall use a grant under this part:

paragraph.text: to provide loans or loan guarantees, or to subsidize the interest rate on loans, for financing economic development projects; or
to provide loans to small businesses.

subsection.text: The Department may require that money from a grant under this part be returned to the Department if the local economic development fund is inactive for more than 2 years after the grant is made.
There is a Brownfields Revitalization Incentive Program in the Department.
The Department shall develop a program of financial assistance, including low-interest loans and grants, to assist persons who participate in the Brownfields Revitalization Incentive Program.

section.text: A county or municipal corporation may elect to participate in the Brownfields Revitalization Incentive Program by:

subparagraph.text: submitting to the Department a list of potential brownfields sites in the county or municipal corporation, ranked in the order of priority for redevelopment that the county or municipal corporation recommends; and
updating each year the list submitted under item (i) of this item; or
enacting legislation granting property tax credits in accordance with § 9-229 of the Tax - Property Article; and
notifying the Department of the legislation.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, the Department may provide to a person, including a responsible person, a low-interest loan or grant to conduct the environmental site assessment of a potential brownfields site that is required to participate in the Voluntary Cleanup Program under Title 7, Subtitle 5 of the Environment Article, if the person:

paragraph.text: has not already applied to participate in the Program;
is otherwise eligible to participate in the Program; and
meets the eligibility requirements that the Department sets.

subsection.text: The information contained in an environmental site assessment is:

paragraph.text: the property of the State, if the assessment is financed wholly or partly by:

subparagraph.text: a grant from the Department; or
a loan that is in payment default; or

paragraph.text: the property of the person who contracted for the assessment, if the assessment is financed by:

subparagraph.text: a loan from the Department; or
a grant that is repaid.

subsection.text: Eligibility for a loan or grant for an environmental site assessment under this section does not constitute eligibility for:

paragraph.text: any other financial assistance under this subtitle; or
the tax credits provided under § 9-229 of the Tax - Property Article.

subsection.text: The recipient of a grant under this section shall repay the grant if, within 12 months after receiving the grant, the recipient does not receive approval from the Department of the Environment to:

paragraph.text: participate in the Voluntary Cleanup Program; or
implement a corrective action plan under Title 4 of the Environment Article.

subsection.text: A low-interest loan provided under this section shall convert to a market rate loan if, within 12 months after receiving the loan, the recipient does not receive approval from the Department of the Environment to:

paragraph.text: participate in the Voluntary Cleanup Program; or
implement a corrective action plan under Title 4 of the Environment Article.

subsection.text: The Department may establish procedures and eligibility requirements for the approval of requests for loans and grants under this section.
The Department shall determine whether a brownfields site is a qualified brownfields site based on whether the property:

paragraph.text: is located in a densely populated urban center and is substantially underutilized; or
is an existing or former industrial or commercial site that poses a threat to public health or the environment.

subsection.text: When reviewing qualified brownfields sites for financial assistance under this part, the Department may consider:

paragraph.text: the feasibility of redevelopment;
the public benefit to the community and the State through the redevelopment of the property;
the extent of releases or threatened releases at the brownfields site and the degree to which the cleanup and redevelopment of the brownfields site will protect public health or the environment;
the potential to attract or retain manufacturing or other economically significant employers;
the absence of identifiable and financially solvent responsible persons; or
any other factor relevant and appropriate to economic development.

subsection.text: A person may submit a request to the Department to determine whether the person qualifies for financial assistance for the potential redevelopment of a brownfields site when the person:

paragraph.text: applies to participate in the Voluntary Cleanup Program under Title 7, Subtitle 5 of the Environment Article; or
receives approval from the Department of the Environment to implement a corrective action plan under Title 4 of the Environment Article.

The Department shall notify the person whether the person qualifies for financial assistance for the redevelopment of a brownfields site within 30 days after the Department receives a request under subsection (c) of this section if:

subparagraph.text: the Department of the Environment approves the participation in the Voluntary Cleanup Plan or a corrective action plan; and
the Department or Authority approves the financial assistance.

paragraph.text: The notice shall specify which of the criteria in subsection (b) of this section that the person meets.

subsection.text: When evaluating potential qualified brownfields sites, the Department shall consult with:

paragraph.text: the Department of the Environment, the Department of Planning, and relevant local officials;
the neighboring community and any citizens groups located in the community;
representatives of State and local environmental organizations;
public health experts; and
any other person the Department considers appropriate.

section.text: This part does not affect:

paragraph.text: the planning and zoning authority of a county or municipal corporation; or
any provision of the Environment Article.

subsection.text: In addition to providing money from the Fund to assist in creating and expanding child care facilities in the State under other provisions of this subtitle, the Department may use federal or other money provided for the purpose to make child care special loans.
Child care special loans may be made to finance the expansion or improvement of child care services at child care facilities in the State, in accordance with this part.
All money received by the Fund for making child care special loans shall be accounted for separately, including:

paragraph.text: federal money allocated or granted for child care special loans, including child care and development block grant money;
private money donated or granted to the Fund for child care special loans;
premiums, fees, interest payments, and principal payments on child care special loans made with federal money;
proceeds from the sale, disposition, or lease of collateral that relates to child care special loans;
any other money made available for child care special loans; and
any federal money for child care special loans that are used by the Department to pay costs of administering the child care special loans.

section.text: In making child care special loans, the Department shall consider:

paragraph.text: community need;
community income, with priority given to those communities with the lowest median family income;
care for children with teenage parents in school or training;
care for children with special needs; and
infant care.

subsection.text: An applicant for a child care special loan shall submit to the Department an application that contains the information that the Department requires.
The application shall include:

paragraph.text: a detailed description of the proposed or existing child care facility;
an itemization of known and estimated costs;
the total amount of money required to expand or improve child care services at the child care facility;
the money available to the applicant without a child care special loan from the Department;
the amount of money sought from the Department;
evidence of the inability of the applicant to obtain the financing necessary for the child care facility on affordable terms through normal lending channels;
information that relates to the financial status of the applicant, including, if applicable:

subparagraph.text: a current balance sheet;
a profit and loss statement; and
credit references; and

paragraph.text: a lease, option to buy, deed, or evidence that the applicant is legally entitled to remain at the child care facility for at least the term of the loan.

subsection.text: The applicant for a child care special loan shall agree to:

paragraph.text: operate the child care facility for at least the term of the child care special loan; and

repay the outstanding child care special loan in full on the loss of license, termination of lease, or transfer, sale, or refinancing of the child care facility, as applicable, before the end of the term of the child care special loan.

section.text: The Department may make a child care special loan to an applicant if:

paragraph.text: the applicant meets the qualifications required by this part;
the applicant meets any additional requirements imposed by the source of the money to be loaned; and
the child care special loan will be used for an authorized use under § 5-348 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Except as provided in this part, the Department may set the terms and conditions for child care special loans.
The term of a child care special loan may not exceed 10 years.

paragraph.text: The minimum amount of a child care special loan is $1,000.
The maximum amount of a child care special loan is $10,000.

subsection.text: If the Department makes a child care special loan to an applicant, the Department shall prepare loan documents.
The loan documents shall include:

paragraph.text: the rate of interest on the child care special loan;
the amount of the child care special loan;
a requirement that before each disbursement of loan proceeds is released to the applicant, the applicant and the Department cosign the request for the money;
provisions for repayment of the child care special loan; and
any other provisions that the Department determines are necessary, including provisions to take liens and security interests in real and personal property.

subsection.text: The child care special loan documents may provide for penalties for an applicant who fails to operate the child care facility for the entire term of the child care special loan.
The proceeds of a child care special loan may be used:

paragraph.text: to assist the applicant in meeting applicable State and local child care standards;
to pay for minor renovations, and to upgrade child care facilities, to ensure that applicants meet State and local child care standards; or
to purchase and install equipment and furniture, including equipment needed to accommodate children with special needs.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (a) of this section, the proceeds of a child care special loan may not be used:

paragraph.text: to purchase or improve land; or
to purchase, construct, or improve a building or facility.

subsection.text: A mortgage or deed of trust held as security for a child care special loan made under this part that is in default may be foreclosed by the Department in the same manner as the Maryland Rules provide for foreclosures in private transactions.
The Department may take title in its name to any property foreclosed under this section as well as to convey title to that property to a bona fide purchaser of the property.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Authority” means the Maryland Industrial Development Financing Authority.

paragraph.text: “Authorized purpose obligation” means an evidence of obligation issued, offered for sale, or delivered by any person or public body for any purpose that the Authority determines will accomplish the purposes of this subtitle.
“Authorized purpose obligation” includes:

subparagraph.text: a bond;
a note;
a certificate; and
any other evidence of obligation.

paragraph.text: “Bond” means a bond or note that is issued and sold by a public body, unit, or instrumentality of the State to finance a facility or refund an outstanding bond.
“Bond” includes:

subparagraph.text: a bond anticipation note;
a note in the nature of commercial paper or other instrument;
a certificate;
a bond issued under this subtitle or Title 12, Subtitle 1 of this article (Maryland Economic Development Revenue Bond Act); and
any other evidence of obligation.

subsection.text: “Cogeneration” means the combined generation by a facility of:

paragraph.text: electrical or mechanical power; and
energy used for industrial, commercial, heating or cooling purposes, including:

subparagraph.text: steam;
heat; and
other forms of energy.

subsection.text: “Commercial building” means a building that:

paragraph.text: is used primarily to carry on a for-profit or not-for-profit business;
is not residential; and
is not used primarily to manufacture or produce raw materials, products, or agricultural commodities.

subsection.text: “Energy audit” means:

paragraph.text: an energy audit performed for the purposes of Title VII of the Energy Policy and Conservation Act, 42 U.S.C. §§ 6201 through 6422; or
an onsite inspection of a commercial building, an industrial building, or an industrial process to determine and provide information on:

subparagraph.text: the type, quantity, and rate of energy consumption of the building or process;
maintenance and operation procedures that might reduce the energy consumption of the building or process; and
the cost of implementing an appropriate energy conservation project, a solar energy project, or both, and the savings in energy costs likely to result from the project.

subsection.text: “Energy conservation project” means a project that qualifies under § 5-447 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: “Energy project” means a project that qualifies under § 5-445 of this subtitle.
“Energy project” includes:

subparagraph.text: an energy conservation project; and
a solar energy project.

subsection.text: “Export-related financing transaction” means financing provided to a manufacturer of goods in the State, or a seller of goods or services in the State, if the goods or services are intended for sale to a foreign entity.

paragraph.text: “Facility” has the meaning stated in § 12-101 of this article.
“Facility” includes an energy project.

subsection.text: “Facility applicant” has the meaning stated in § 12-101 of this article.
“Facility user” has the meaning stated in § 12-101 of this article.
“Finance” includes refinance.
“Foreign entity” means:

paragraph.text: a person located outside the United States; or
a governmental unit of a country other than the United States.

subsection.text: “Fund” means the Industrial Development Fund established under § 5-423 of this subtitle.
“Improve” means to construct, reconstruct, equip, expand, extend, improve, install, rehabilitate, or remodel.
“Improvement” means construction, addition, alteration, equipping, expansion, extension, improvement, installation, reconstruction, rehabilitation, remodeling, or repair.

paragraph.text: “Industrial building” means a building that:

subparagraph.text: is used primarily to carry on a for-profit or not-for-profit business;
is used primarily for an industrial process; and
controls energy usage within its exterior envelope but does not have a peak design rate of energy usage of less than:

sub-subparagraph.text: 3.5 B.T.U. per hour per square foot; or
1 watt per square foot of floor area.

paragraph.text: “Industrial building” does not include a commercial building or a residential building.

subsection.text: “Industrial process” means:

paragraph.text: a process used to produce or manufacture goods or products; or
the storage or shipment of materials, goods, or products.

subsection.text: “Public body” has the meaning stated in § 12-101 of this article.
“Public port” has the meaning stated in § 12-101 of this article.
“Retail establishment” means an establishment that sells goods or services to the ultimate user or consumer for personal use rather than business use.
“Solar energy project” means a project that qualifies under § 5-448 of this subtitle.

section.text: This subtitle shall be liberally construed to accomplish its purposes.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: unemployment conditions exist in many areas of the State;
the acquisition and improvement of facilities are essential to relieve this unemployment and establish a balanced economy in the State;
the health, safety, welfare, and right of gainful employment of residents throughout the State will be promoted by the acquisition and improvement of facilities;
the control or abatement of environmental pollution in the State, including noise pollution, is necessary to:

subparagraph.text: protect the health, safety, and welfare of the residents of the State;
protect natural resources;
retain and attract industry and commercial enterprises; and
promote economic development;

paragraph.text: public ports in the State are valuable assets and any improvements to these ports that increase the import and export of waterborne commerce will directly benefit residents throughout the State;
businesses need greater access to capital markets; and
the availability of financial assistance under this subtitle will promote the economic development of the State.

subsection.text: The purposes of this subtitle are to:

paragraph.text: relieve unemployment in the State;
encourage the increase of industry and commerce and a balanced economy in the State;
help retain and attract industry and commerce through measures including:

subparagraph.text: port development;
the control, reduction, or abatement of environmental pollution; and
the utilization and disposal of wastes;

paragraph.text: promote economic development;
protect natural resources and encourage resource recovery;
encourage the creation and expansion of day care facilities in the State; and
promote the health, safety, and welfare of residents throughout the State.

subsection.text: There is a Maryland Industrial Development Financing Authority in the Department.
The Authority is a body politic and corporate and is an instrumentality of the State.
The exercise by the Authority of power under this subtitle is the performance of an essential governmental function.

paragraph.text: The Authority consists of the following nine members:

subparagraph.text: seven members appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate; and
as ex officio members:

sub-subparagraph.text: the Secretary; and
the Treasurer or the Comptroller, as the Governor designates.

paragraph.text: An ex officio member may designate a representative to serve on the Authority.

subsection.text: The appointed members shall:

paragraph.text: have substantial experience in business or economic development; and
reflect the geographic, racial, ethnic, and gender makeup of the State.
The term of an appointed member is 5 years.
The terms of the appointed members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Authority on October 1, 2008.
At the end of a term, an appointed member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove an appointed member with or without cause.
The members of the Authority are also the members of the Maryland Economic Development Assistance Authority under § 5-306 of this title.
The members of the Authority may act concurrently in their capacities as members of the Authority and of the Maryland Economic Development Assistance Authority.
The members of the Authority shall carry out the powers and duties of the Authority under this subtitle whether acting:

paragraph.text: concurrently as members of the Authority and the Maryland Economic Development Assistance Authority; or
as members of either authority alone.
From among its members, the Authority shall elect a chair and a vice chair.
The Executive Director serves as secretary of the Authority.

subsection.text: The Authority shall determine the manner of election of officers and their terms of office.

paragraph.text: Five members of the Authority are a quorum.
An affirmative vote of at least four members is needed for the Authority to act.

subsection.text: The Authority shall determine the times and places of its meetings.
A member of the Authority:

paragraph.text: is not entitled to compensation as a member of the Authority; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.
With the approval of the Secretary, the Authority shall appoint an Executive Director.
The Executive Director serves at the pleasure of the Authority, with the concurrence of the Secretary.
The position of Executive Director is a special appointment under the State Personnel and Management System.

subsection.text: The Executive Director is the chief administrative officer of the Authority.
The Executive Director shall:

paragraph.text: direct and supervise the administrative affairs and technical activities of the Authority;
attend the meetings of the Authority;
record the minutes of the proceedings of the Authority;
approve all accounts for salaries, per diem payments, and allowable expenses of the Authority, its employees, and its consultants;
approve all expenses incidental to the operation of the Authority;
in cooperation with the Department, submit to the Authority reports and recommendations related to proposed financial assistance under this subtitle; and
perform the other duties that the Secretary or the Authority requires to carry out this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Executive Director is the resident agent of the Authority for the receipt of service made in accordance with the Maryland Rules.
The Authority may employ a staff in accordance with the State budget.
The Authority shall appoint and remove all personnel in accordance with the State Personnel and Pensions Article.
The Authority may:

paragraph.text: adopt bylaws for the conduct of its business;
adopt a seal;
maintain offices in the State;
sue and be sued in its own name;
retain consultants;
use the services of other governmental agencies;
in accordance with the purposes of this subtitle, contract for and accept a loan or grant from the federal government or the State, a local government, or any of their units or instrumentalities;

acquire, improve, manage, operate, dispose of, or otherwise deal with property, take assignments of rentals and leases, and make contracts, leases, agreements, and arrangements that are necessary or incidental to the performance of the Authority’s duties, on the terms and conditions that it may consider advisable;
acquire or receive assignment of a document executed, obtained, or delivered in connection with financial assistance under this subtitle;

subject to any outstanding agreement the Authority makes under this subtitle, make a covenant or other agreement regarding the Authority’s insurance funds, establish within them accounts to carry out this subtitle, and allocate revenue and receipts among the accounts;

fix, charge, and collect a premium, fee, cost, or other expense related to financial assistance under this subtitle, including an application fee, commitment fee, program fee, finance charge, and publication fee;

authorize the chair, vice chair, or executive director to perform, on behalf of the Authority, a duty or prescribe, specify, determine, or approve a detail, document, procedure, or a matter that the Authority, in its sole discretion, determines appropriate to carry out this subtitle; and
do all things necessary or convenient to carry out the powers granted by this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Authority shall:

paragraph.text: keep records of its funds and accounts; and
ensure that its funds and accounts are audited annually.

subsection.text: In its internal functions, the Authority shall purchase office space, supplies, facilities, materials, equipment, and professional services in accordance with the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Authority exercises its powers and performs its duties subject to the authority of the Secretary.

section.text: The Authority may adopt regulations to carry out this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Authority may approve, or may authorize the Executive Director to approve, the form of an agreement by the Authority under this subtitle.
Any money that the Authority pays under an agreement the Authority makes under this subtitle shall be payable as and when the Authority determines in its sole discretion.

section.text: A finding by the Authority, including a finding as to the public purpose of an action taken under this subtitle, and the appropriateness of that action to serve the public purpose, is conclusive in a proceeding involving the validity or enforceability of:

paragraph.text: an agreement the Authority enters into under this subtitle;
a bond; or
any security relating to item (1) or (2) of this section.

section.text: Even though a determination of the Authority about financial assistance is subject to the Maryland Public Ethics Law, the existence of a conflict of interest or a violation of the Maryland Public Ethics Law does not affect:

paragraph.text: the validity of a finding or determination made under this subtitle;
the enforceability of an agreement that the Authority makes under this subtitle; or
the validity or enforceability of a bond that the Authority issues.

section.text: A member of the Authority, a person executing a bond or agreement of the Authority under this subtitle, or an employee of the Authority, the Department, or the State is not:

paragraph.text: personally liable on a bond or agreement of the Authority; or
subject to personal liability or accountability arising from the issuance, execution, or delivery of a bond or agreement of the Authority.

section.text: On or before December 31 of each year, the Authority shall submit a report on its conditions and operations to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly and the chair of the Joint Audit Committee.
If the Authority dissolves, title to its property vests in the State.
There is an Industrial Development Fund.
The Fund shall be used:

paragraph.text: for the purposes described in Part VI and §§ 5-430, 5-431, and 5-438 of this subtitle; and
to pay expenses of the Authority, including expenses:

subparagraph.text: for administrative, legal, actuarial, and other services;
related to:

sub-subparagraph.text: issuance or insurance of bonds and authorized purpose obligations; and
funding of reserves; or

subparagraph.text: of providing other financial assistance under this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Fund is a continuing, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to reversion under § 7-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: money appropriated in the State budget to the Fund;
premiums, fees, and any other money received by the Authority with respect to financial assistance provided by the Authority from the Fund;
proceeds from the sale, lease, or other disposition of property of the Authority;
interest received from linked deposits made from the Linked Deposit Program under Part VI of this subtitle; and
any other money made available under this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Treasurer shall:

paragraph.text: invest the money in the Fund in the same manner as other State money may be invested; and
credit any investment earnings to the Fund.

subsection.text: Any net investment earnings of the Fund, beyond those necessary to further the purposes of this subtitle, may not benefit a person other than the State.
The Authority shall send a written request to the Board of Public Works for additional money if:

paragraph.text: the Authority and the Secretary find that more money is needed to keep the reserves of the Fund at an adequate level; and
the Secretary consents to the request.

subsection.text: The Board of Public Works may disburse the requested amount from the General Emergency Fund.

section.text: With the consent of the Secretary, the Authority may pay to the Treasurer, to the credit of the General Fund, money that the Authority determines exceeds the amount necessary to meet:

paragraph.text: the obligations of the Authority under this subtitle; and
the requirements of this subtitle.

section.text: Each year the Treasurer shall report to the Authority on the:

paragraph.text: status of the Fund;
market value of the assets in the Fund as of the date of the report; and
earnings from investments of the Fund during the period covered by the report.

subsection.text: If the requirements of this section are satisfied, and subject to § 5-432 of this subtitle, the Authority may use the Fund to:

paragraph.text: insure the payment of any of the principal of, redemption or prepayment premiums or penalties on, and interest on:

subparagraph.text: bonds; and
any instrument executed, obtained, or delivered in connection with the issuance and sale of bonds; and

paragraph.text: pay or insure the payment of fees or premiums for insurance, guarantees, or other credit support in connection with financial assistance under this subtitle.

subsection.text: Based on factors it considers relevant, the Authority shall determine, in its sole discretion, that the economic impact of the transaction will be substantial.
The Authority shall find:

paragraph.text: that the acquisition or improvement of a facility will not result in:

subparagraph.text: the removal from one county to another county of the business operations of the facility user; or
the abandonment of a facility in the State; or

paragraph.text: if the acquisition or improvement will result in removal or abandonment, that the acquisition or improvement will:

subparagraph.text: discourage the facility user from leaving the State; or
preserve the competitive position of the facility user in its industry.

subsection.text: The Authority shall find that the Authority will not be required, except on default, to operate, service, or maintain the facility.
The bonds or instruments shall be secured in a manner that the Authority approves.
Financial assistance from the Fund provided under this section may not exceed an aggregate amount of $7,500,000 for a single facility.
If the requirements of this section are satisfied, and subject to § 5-432 of this subtitle, the Authority may use the Fund to:

paragraph.text: insure the payment of any of the principal of, redemption or prepayment premiums or penalties on, and interest on authorized purpose obligations; and
pay or insure the payment of fees or premiums for insurance, guarantees, or other credit support in connection with financial assistance under this subtitle.

subsection.text: Based on factors it considers relevant, the Authority shall determine, in its sole discretion, that the economic impact of the transaction will be substantial.
The Authority shall find:

paragraph.text: that the transaction will not result in:

subparagraph.text: the removal from one county to another county of the business operations of any person who benefits from the transaction; or
the abandonment of the business operations in the State of any person who benefits from the transaction; or

paragraph.text: if the transaction will result in removal or abandonment, that the transaction will:

subparagraph.text: discourage the business from leaving the State; or
preserve the competitive position of the business in its industry.

subsection.text: Financial assistance under this section may only be used in connection with a retail establishment if the Authority determines, in its sole discretion, that the financial assistance will accomplish the purposes of this subtitle.
The Authority shall find that the Authority will not be required, except on default, to operate, service, or maintain any business.
The authorized purpose obligations shall be secured in a manner that the Authority approves.
Financial assistance from the Fund provided under this section may not exceed an aggregate amount of $2,500,000 for a single transaction.
The aggregate amount of insurance provided under this section for a single authorized purpose obligation may not exceed:

paragraph.text: for an export-related financing transaction, 90% of the total of the principal of, redemption or prepayment premiums or penalties on, and interest on, the authorized purpose obligation; or

for a transaction other than an export-related financing transaction, 80% of the total of the principal of, redemption or prepayment premiums or penalties on, and interest on, the authorized purpose obligation.

section.text: The portion of the aggregate principal amount of bonds and authorized purpose obligations that the Fund insures at any time may not exceed 5 times the Fund balance.
Financial assistance under this subtitle is:

paragraph.text: subject to the provisions of Title 20 of the State Government Article concerning discrimination and unlawful practices; and
not subject to Title 17, Subtitle 1 of the State Finance and Procurement Article (Security for construction projects).

subsection.text: The Authority may issue and sell bonds in accordance with Title 12, Subtitle 1 of this article (Maryland Economic Development Revenue Bond Act) and this subtitle to accomplish the purposes of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The Authority may issue its bonds without the consent of any other unit of State government, any proceedings, or the occurrence of any conditions, other than those expressly required by this subtitle.

subparagraph.text: Before the Authority issues bonds, the Authority shall notify the Board of Public Works of its intention to issue the bonds up to a stated amount.
The Board of Public Works may coordinate the issuance of the bonds with any issuance of bonds of the State or its units or instrumentalities.

paragraph.text: The failure of the Authority to notify the Board of Public Works under paragraph (2)(i) of this subsection does not affect the validity or enforceability of bonds, findings or determinations, or agreements of the Authority.

When the Authority issues bonds, it is in the public interest that the Authority try to achieve a goal that 10% of the facility users are minority business enterprises as defined in § 14-301 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

The failure of the Authority to achieve the goal set out under paragraph (1) of this subsection does not affect in any way the validity or enforceability of bonds, findings or determinations, or agreements of the Authority.
This subsection does not apply to insurance that the Authority provides.
A bond the Authority issues and the interest on the bond are limited obligations of the Authority.
Except for bond anticipation notes and notes in the nature of commercial paper, the principal of, premium, and interest on a bond are payable solely from:

subparagraph.text: money from the financing of a facility; and
other money made available to the Authority.

paragraph.text: Bonds and the interest on them:

subparagraph.text: are not debts or charges against the general credit or taxing powers of the State, the Department, the Authority, or any other public body within the meaning of any constitutional or charter provision or statutory limitation; and
may not give rise to any pecuniary liability of the State, the Department, the Authority, or any other public body.

paragraph.text: A bond may state on its face that the bond:

subparagraph.text: is issued under Title 12, Subtitle 1 of this article (Maryland Economic Development Revenue Bond Act) and this subtitle; and
is not a debt to which the faith and credit of the State, the Department, the Authority, or any other public body is pledged.

subsection.text: Bonds that the Authority issues are exempt from State and local taxes as provided in § 12-116 of this article.
Facilities financed with the proceeds of bonds that the Authority issues are not subject to the requirements of any law regarding competitive bidding.

The Authority may authorize the Executive Director of the Authority to approve, on behalf of the Authority, financial assistance under § 5–431 of this subtitle not exceeding the aggregate amount of $250,000 for a single transaction.
An approval by the Executive Director under this section:

paragraph.text: is subject to concurrence of the Secretary, the Secretary’s designee, or the chair of the Authority;
shall comply with the requirements of this subtitle; and
is binding on the Authority.

section.text: In conjunction with financial assistance under this subtitle, the Authority may:

paragraph.text: accept an option to acquire an equity interest in a business enterprise; and
exercise, in its sole discretion, the option using money from the Fund.

subsection.text: The Authority may set premiums and fees for financial assistance under this subtitle in its sole discretion.
The premiums and fees shall be payable in the amounts, at the time, and in the manner that the Authority requires in its sole discretion.
The premiums and fees may vary in amount among approvals for financial assistance under this subtitle and at different stages of the financial assistance.

The Authority may not charge a premium for insurance if the Authority determines that, at the time the insurance is approved, the facility or business for which the Authority provides insurance is located in a qualified distressed county.
A determination by the Authority under subsection (a) of this section for a facility or business is effective for as long as the financial assistance is in effect.
Insurance on bonds or authorized purpose obligations provided before July 1, 2000, shall continue as obligations of the Authority and are authorized under this subtitle.
Financial assistance that the Authority approves, but that is not closed before July 1, 2000, is authorized under this subtitle.
Bonds issued by the Maryland Energy Financing Administration shall continue after December 31, 2001, as obligations of the Authority and are authorized under this subtitle.
Loan guarantees that the Department provided from the former Day Care Loan Guarantee Fund shall continue as obligations of the Authority and are authorized under this subtitle.

Deposit agreements between the Department and a lender under the former Maryland Enterprise Incentive Deposit Fund Program shall continue as obligations of the Authority and are authorized under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The Authority shall participate in financial assistance programs for energy projects provided by the federal Energy Security Act, P.L. 96-294.
For purposes of that Act, the Authority is a “person” as defined in:

subparagraph.text: 42 U.S.C. § 8802, concerning the financing of biomass energy, municipal solid waste, and alcohol fuels projects; and
30 U.S.C. § 1511, concerning the financing of geothermal energy projects.

subsection.text: For purposes of the federal Public Utility Regulatory Policies Act of 1978, the Authority is a “nonprofit organization” as defined in 16 U.S.C. § 2708 and used in 16 U.S.C. §§ 2702 and 2703, concerning small-scale hydropower projects.

paragraph.text: In this section the following words have the meanings indicated.

subparagraph.text: “Renewable fuel” means gaseous, liquid, or solid fuel from any organic matter and its by–products.
“Renewable fuel” includes fuel from:

sub-subparagraph.text: an agricultural crop, agricultural waste, or agricultural residue;
wood, wood waste, or wood residue;
animal waste;
aquatic plants;
sewage or sewage sludge;
municipal, industrial, or commercial waste;
any mixture of any of these substances with inorganic refuse from a public or private municipal waste collection system or similar disposal system; or
any combination of items 1 through 7 of this item.

subparagraph.text: “Renewable fuel” does not include fossil fuel.

paragraph.text: “Transportation facility” means a transportation facility that is used exclusively to transport fuel produced by a fuel production facility to:

subparagraph.text: a storage facility;
a pipeline connection to an existing pipeline or processing facility; or
an area near the fuel production facility.

subsection.text: A project qualifies as an energy project if it consists of:

paragraph.text: an energy conservation project;
a solar energy project;
the construction of a facility to produce solar energy equipment;
the construction of a facility or portion of a facility to:

subparagraph.text: produce renewable fuel; and
burn renewable fuel, or a mixture of renewable fuel with other materials, to generate:

sub-subparagraph.text: heat;
mechanical power;
electricity, including by cogeneration; or
other useful forms of energy;

paragraph.text: the conversion of any facility to use renewable fuel;
the expansion or improvement of a facility that increases its capacity or efficiency to use renewable fuel;
the acquisition and improvement of equipment for use in a facility specified in items (4) through (6) of this subsection;
the acquisition or improvement of land for a facility specified in items (4) through (6) of this subsection;
the purchase, construction, or installation of a facility or equipment to use groundwater as a heat source for a heating system or as a heat sink for an air conditioning system;
the purchase, construction, or installation of a facility or equipment to develop and use the natural heat of the earth for direct use or to generate electricity;
the purchase, construction, and installation of a hydroelectric facility at an existing dam that:

subparagraph.text: uses the water power potential of the dam; and
has no more than 30 megawatts of installed capacity;

paragraph.text: the construction of a fuel production facility for commercial production of a gaseous, liquid, or solid fuel, or of a combination of them, that:

subparagraph.text: is produced by chemical or physical transformation of coal or mixtures of coal and other materials;
can be used as a substitute for petroleum or natural gas, or any of their derivatives, including chemical feedstocks; and
includes only:

sub-subparagraph.text: the fuel production facility, including the equipment, plant, supplies, and other materials associated with the fuel production facility;
the land and mineral rights required directly for use in connection with the fuel production facility;
any other facility or equipment to be used in the extraction of a mineral for use directly and exclusively in the fuel production facility that is necessary to the project and is:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: colocated with or located in the immediate vicinity of the fuel production facility; or
if not colocated or located in accordance with item A of this item:
a coal mine in the case that no other reasonable source of coal is available to the project; or
incidental to the project; and

sub-subparagraph.text: any transportation facility, electric power plant, electric transmission line, or other facility that is:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: for the exclusive use of the project;
incidental to the project; and
necessary to the project;

paragraph.text: the conversion of a facility from using petroleum–based fuel to coal or to a mixture of coal and other materials as a fuel; or
the construction of a facility to burn coal using innovative technology that increases the efficiency of the combustion process.

subsection.text: In awarding financial assistance under this subtitle for an energy project, the Authority shall consider whether the energy project would:

paragraph.text: reduce the consumption of petroleum and other energy sources;
increase the energy supply available in the State;
increase employment and economic activity in the State;
use sound technology and be economically feasible;
minimize harm to the environment; and
make the most use of federal financial assistance programs for energy projects.

subsection.text: The Authority shall:

paragraph.text: promote programs of financial assistance for energy projects established under this subtitle;
inform consumers, the private sector, and financial institutions about these programs and actively seek their participation;
develop and disseminate descriptions of its programs of financial assistance for energy projects; and
serve as a clearinghouse for information on federal and State programs of financial assistance for energy projects.

section.text: A project involving a commercial building, an industrial building, or an industrial process qualifies as an energy conservation project if it consists of:

paragraph.text: the purchase, installation, or modification of an installation that is designed primarily to reduce the consumption of energy, including:

subparagraph.text: caulking or weather stripping;
insulating the building structure or a system in the building;
a storm window or door, a multiglazed window or door, a heat-absorbing or heat-reflecting window or door system, glazing, a reduction in glass area, or another window or door system modification;
an automatic energy control system;
equipment that is associated with an automatic energy control system and that is required to operate a variable steam, hydraulic, or ventilation system;
the replacement or modification of a lighting system to increase energy efficiency;
an energy recovery system;
a cogeneration system;
a system for processing or converting the waste products of the industrial process to steam, electricity, heat, or other useful form of energy;
an improvement to the industrial process that reduces the energy requirements for each unit of output;
a modification of a furnace or utility plant and distribution system including:

sub-subparagraph.text: a replacement burner, furnace, or boiler or any combination of them that increases the energy efficiency of the heating system;
a device for modifying a flue opening that increases the energy efficiency of the heating system; and
an electrical or mechanical furnace ignition system that replaces a standing gas pilot light; or

subparagraph.text: any other energy conservation improvement that the Authority determines by regulation to be appropriate and consistent with this subtitle; or

paragraph.text: a planning or technical service or an energy audit, if the service or audit is related to or undertaken with the installation, or the modification of an installation of an item specified in item (1) of this section.
