subsection.text: A project qualifies as a solar energy project if it:

paragraph.text: is an addition, alteration, or improvement to a commercial building or industrial building; and
is designed to reduce the energy requirements of the building by using:

subparagraph.text: wind energy;
energy from a wood-burning appliance; or
solar energy of:

sub-subparagraph.text: the active type based on mechanically forced energy transfer;
the passive type based on convective, conductive, or radiant energy transfer; or
a combination of these types.

subsection.text: A solar energy project may include:

paragraph.text: a solar process heat device;
a solar electric device; and
an earth-sheltered building in which the sheltering substantially reduces the consumption of energy by the building.

subsection.text: In this part the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Applicant” means the eligible business applying for fixed asset financing assisted by a linked deposit.
“Eligible business” means a for-profit business that:

paragraph.text: is located in a qualified distressed county;

is in good standing with each State regulatory authority with jurisdiction over the business of the applicant, including the State Workers’ Compensation Commission, the Department of Assessments and Taxation, and the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation; and
employs 500 or fewer employees.
“Fixed asset financing” means a commercial loan to finance:

subparagraph.text: the acquisition or improvement of all or part of a building;
the acquisition or improvement of the land for the building if not already owned by the applicant; or
the acquisition or improvement of equipment.

paragraph.text: “Fixed asset financing” does not include refinancing an existing debt.

subsection.text: “Lender” means a financial institution that:

paragraph.text: is eligible to make commercial loans;
is a public depository of State funds;
agrees to receive linked deposits under this part; and
is insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

subsection.text: “Linked deposit” means a deposit that the Authority places with a lender that earns interest below the prevailing market rate for equivalent deposits made with the lender at the time of the deposit.
“Program” means the Linked Deposit Program established under § 5-452 of this subtitle.

section.text: There is a Linked Deposit Program in the Department.

subsection.text: The purpose of the Program is to stimulate economic and employment growth in rural areas of the State with high unemployment.

paragraph.text: The Program shall assist eligible businesses to obtain a loan at below market rates.
An eligible business may use a Program loan to acquire land, buildings, and equipment.
An acquisition made by an eligible business with a Program loan shall be used to create or retain employment opportunities in a rural area.

section.text: The Authority may place a linked deposit with a lender in accordance with this part.

subsection.text: To obtain fixed asset financing under this part, an eligible business shall apply to a lender for fixed asset financing.
Fixed asset financing under this part may not exceed $500,000 for an eligible business.
In addition to the information that the lender requires in its standard loan application, the applicant shall provide to the lender, in a form that the Authority prescribes:

paragraph.text: a certification, with supporting documentation, that the applicant is an eligible business; and
a description of the number and kinds of jobs to be created or retained as a result of providing the linked deposit.

subsection.text: On conditional approval of a fixed asset financing loan application under this part, the lender shall forward the loan package to the Authority.

In addition to any other information the Authority reasonably requires to carry out the purposes of this part, the linked deposit loan package shall include the information required of the applicant under § 5-455(c) of this subtitle.
By forwarding the loan package to the Authority, the lender is not representing to the Authority that information in the loan package that relates to the applicant is accurate or valid.

section.text: In determining whether to accept a linked deposit loan package, the Authority shall confirm the eligibility of the applicant and consider:

paragraph.text: the number and kinds of jobs to be created or retained as a result of providing the linked deposit;
the amount of the loan;
the amount of money in the Fund and the amount committed to linked deposits;
whether the availability of linked deposit financing is essential for the economic feasibility of the acquisition;
the economic needs of the area in which the eligible business is located;
the financial feasibility of the loan; and
other factors that the Authority considers relevant.

section.text: If the Authority accepts a linked deposit loan package forwarded from a lender, the Authority and the lender shall make an agreement that sets the amount of, the term of, and the schedule for payment of the principal of and interest on the linked deposit.

On receiving linked deposit approval from the Authority, the lender shall issue a loan commitment to the applicant that provides that the interest rate on the financing will be below the prevailing market rate to the same extent and for as long as interest earned on the linked deposit is below interest earned on other equivalent deposits with the lender at the time of the deposit.

subsection.text: A fixed asset financing loan assisted by a linked deposit is not a debt of the State or a pledge of the credit of the State.

The Authority and, in accordance with § 5-521 of the Courts Article, the Department and the State are not liable to a lender for payment of the principal or interest on a fixed asset financing loan assisted by a linked deposit under this part.
A person may not knowingly make or cause a false statement or report to be made in an application or document submitted to the Authority.
A person may not knowingly make or cause a false statement or report to be made to influence an action of the Authority:

paragraph.text: on an application for financial assistance under this subtitle; or
affecting financial assistance sought or awarded under this subtitle.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or a fine not exceeding $50,000 or both.
A person who violates this section is subject to § 5-106(b) of the Courts Article.

section.text: This subtitle may be referred to as the Maryland Industrial Development Financing Authority Act.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Authority” means the Maryland Small Business Development Financing Authority.
“Financial institution” means:

paragraph.text: a financial institution, as defined in § 1-101 of the Financial Institutions Article; and
any other lender that the Authority approves.
“Loan document” means an instrument or agreement that evidences, secures, or guarantees a loan.
“Loan document” includes a note, financing statement, mortgage, pledge, assignment, loan and security agreement, or guaranty.
“Working capital” means money used to meet the cash needs of an operating business entity.
“Working capital” does not include money used for a capital purchase.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: the inability of socially or economically disadvantaged individuals to obtain working capital is a major limitation on their opportunity to win and perform government and other contracts;

because socially or economically disadvantaged individuals frequently have been awarded government or other contracts but have lacked the working capital to post a bond, buy supplies needed to begin the work, or pay employees, these individuals have been unable to accept the contracts;
some individuals are unable to obtain government and other contracts for reasons other than the cost to the owner or the ability to perform the contract work competently;
socially or economically disadvantaged individuals frequently lack adequate capital to sustain and expand their businesses and to hire and train employees;

because high risk, problem, or uncollectible loans are not in the interest of financial institutions, financial institutions generally are reluctant to lend money to socially or economically disadvantaged individuals with insufficient records of performance;
the inability of businesses owned by socially or economically disadvantaged individuals to obtain long-term financing is a major limitation on their opportunity to survive and expand; and

the public welfare is served by promoting the viability and expansion of businesses owned by economically or socially disadvantaged individuals, retaining or increasing the employment of these individuals, and expanding the taxable base of the economy of the State.

subsection.text: The purposes of the Authority are:

paragraph.text: to assist socially or economically disadvantaged individuals to obtain adequate working capital to begin, continue, and complete projects, the majority of funding for which is provided by government entities or utilities;
to encourage socially or economically disadvantaged individuals to seek government and other contracts;
to encourage financial institutions to make loans to these individuals; and

to assist small businesses that are unable to obtain adequate business financing on reasonable terms through normal financing channels because the businesses do not meet the established credit criteria of financial institutions.

section.text: There is a Maryland Small Business Development Financing Authority in the Department.

subsection.text: The Authority consists of the following nine members:

paragraph.text: seven members appointed by the Governor;
the Secretary or the Secretary’s designee; and

subparagraph.text: the Comptroller or the Treasurer as designated by the Governor; or
the designee of the Governor’s designee.

paragraph.text: The term of an appointed member is 5 years.
The terms of appointed members are staggered as required for appointments to the Authority on October 1, 2008.
At the end of a term, an appointed member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove an appointed member for cause.
The Authority shall elect a chair, vice chair, and treasurer from among its members.
The Authority shall determine the manner of election of officers and their terms.

paragraph.text: Four members of the Authority are a quorum.
The Authority may not act on any matter unless at least four members in attendance concur.

subsection.text: The Authority shall determine the times and places of its meetings.
A member of the Authority is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.
The Authority may employ a staff in accordance with the State budget.

paragraph.text: The Executive Director is the chief administrative officer of the Authority.
With the approval of the Secretary, the Authority may:

subparagraph.text: appoint the Executive Director; or
contract with a private entity to perform the duties of the Executive Director.

subsection.text: The Executive Director serves at the pleasure of the Authority, with the concurrence of the Secretary.
In addition to any other duties set forth in this subtitle, the Executive Director shall:

paragraph.text: supervise the administrative affairs and technical activities of the Authority in accordance with its regulations and policies;
attend all meetings of the Authority;
keep minutes of all proceedings of the Authority;
approve all accounts for salaries, per diem payments, and allowable expenses of the Authority, its employees, and its consultants;
approve all expenses incidental to the operation of the Authority; and
perform any other duty that the Authority or the Secretary requires to carry out this subtitle.

section.text: A member of the Authority may not participate in any decision related to the approval of financial assistance if the member has any interest in:

paragraph.text: the applicant for the assistance; or
the financial institution seeking a guaranty or an interest subsidy or both.

subsection.text: “Authority staff” means any of the individuals who are employed by the Department to operate the programs of the Authority immediately prior to the execution by the Department of a contract under this section with the private corporation organized by any of those individuals.

paragraph.text: The Department may contract for and engage the services of some or all of the Authority staff to administer the programs of the Authority, for a period of 3 years, if the Authority staff has organized itself as a private Maryland corporation.
The Department may:

subparagraph.text: extend the termination date of the contract in effect as of September 30, 2008 to June 30, 2012, and modify that extended contract as needed; and
renew the extended contract for up to two additional 5-year terms, and modify that renewed and extended contract as needed.

paragraph.text: An extension or renewal contract shall include standards to evaluate the performance of the private contractor in rendering services under the contract.

subsection.text: In its name the corporation may use “Maryland Small Business Development Financing Agency”, “MSBDFA, Inc.”, or any close approximation of those terms.
The Authority exercises its powers and performs its duties subject to the authority of the Secretary.
The Authority may:

paragraph.text: adopt bylaws for the conduct of its business;
adopt a seal;
maintain offices in the State;
sue and be sued in its own name;
retain consultants;
use the services of governmental units;
contract for and accept, to carry out this subtitle, a loan or grant from the federal government, a political subdivision of the State, or any other source;

purchase, receive, lease as lessee, or otherwise acquire, sell, mortgage, lease as lessor, pledge, administer, dispose of, or otherwise deal with property given as collateral under a loan agreement on the terms and conditions it considers advisable;
adopt regulations necessary to carry out its powers;
acquire or take assignments of loan documents; and
do anything necessary or convenient to carry out its powers.

subsection.text: The Authority shall:

paragraph.text: in its internal functions, follow the procedures of the State that govern the purchase of office space, supplies, facilities, materials, equipment, and professional services;
keep proper records of its accounts;
keep separate records for:

subparagraph.text: the Small Business Development Contract Financing Fund under Part III of this subtitle;
the Small Business Development Guaranty Fund under Part IV of this subtitle;
the Equity Participation Investment Program Fund under Part V of this subtitle; and
the Small Business Surety Bond Fund under Part VI of this subtitle; and

paragraph.text: on or before December 31 of each year, submit a report on its condition and operations to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly.

subsection.text: In any action, service of process on the Authority shall be made by service on the Executive Director of the Authority.
Service may be made in person or by leaving a copy of the process at the office of the Executive Director with the individual in charge of the office.
Notwithstanding § 5-602(g) and (h) of this title or any other law, the following money shall be payable into the funds under this subtitle:

paragraph.text: any recovery of investments made under § 5-602 of this title that were funded by a transfer of money from the funds under this subtitle to the Enterprise Fund, including an investment in MMG Ventures LLP; and
any repayment of a grant made under § 5-602 of this title that was funded by a transfer of money from the funds under this subtitle to the Enterprise Fund.

subsection.text: The Authority shall determine the proportion of the recovery or repayment payable under subsection (a) of this section that shall be deposited into each of the funds under this subtitle.

section.text: In this part, “Fund” means the Small Business Development Contract Financing Fund.
There is a Small Business Development Contract Financing Fund.
The Authority shall use the Fund to implement this part.
The Authority shall administer the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to reversion under § 7-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Treasurer shall:

paragraph.text: invest the money in the Fund in the same manner as other State money may be invested; and
credit any investment earnings to the Fund.

subsection.text: If the Authority determines by resolution that any money in the Fund is no longer needed to meet its obligations, the Authority may authorize the Comptroller to first employ that money to pay the principal of and interest on outstanding bonds issued under any Act authorizing the issue of State general obligation bonds issued to implement this subtitle.

section.text: The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: premiums for guaranteeing loans under § 5-525(a) of this subtitle;
premiums for guaranteeing equity investments under § 5-525(b) of this subtitle;
repayments of principal of and interest on direct loans made under § 5-525(c) of this subtitle;
proceeds from the sale, disposition, lease, or rental of collateral for direct loans or loan guaranties made under § 5-525 of this subtitle; and
all other receipts of the Authority under this part.

subsection.text: If the Authority and the Secretary determine that more money is needed to keep the Fund at an adequate level, the Authority shall send a written request for the additional money to the Board of Public Works.
The Board of Public Works may pay the amount requested from the General Emergency Fund.

section.text: The Authority may use the Fund for:

paragraph.text: loan guaranties made under § 5-525(a) of this subtitle;
equity investment guaranties made under § 5-525(b) of this subtitle;
direct loans made under § 5-525(c) of this subtitle; and
expenses for administrative, legal, actuarial, and other services.
The Authority may use the Fund to guarantee a loan made to an applicant only if:

subparagraph.text: the applicant meets the requirements of this part;

the loan is to be used to perform a contract for which the majority of the funding is provided by the federal government, a state government, a local government, or a utility regulated by the Public Service Commission;
the maximum amount payable by the Authority under the guarantee does not exceed $2,000,000; and
the guaranteed loan is to be used for:

sub-subparagraph.text: working capital; or
equipment needed to perform the contract, the cost of which can be repaid from contract proceeds, if the Authority has entered into an agreement with the applicant to secure the loan or guaranty.

paragraph.text: A guaranty made by the Authority may not exceed the term of the contract, unless the Authority determines that a longer term better serves the purposes of this subtitle.
The Authority may use the Fund to guarantee a person’s proposed equity investment in the applicant only if:

subparagraph.text: the applicant meets the requirements of this part;
the amount of the equity investment to be guaranteed does not exceed the lesser of:

sub-subparagraph.text: 10% of the person’s equity investment in the applicant; or

subparagraph.text: the equity investment to be guaranteed is to be used to perform a contract for which the majority of funding is provided by the federal government, a state government, a local government, or a utility regulated by the Public Service Commission; and
the equity investment to be guaranteed is to be used for:

sub-subparagraph.text: working capital; or
equipment needed to perform the contract, the cost of which can be repaid from contract proceeds, if the Authority has entered into an agreement with the applicant to secure the guaranty.

paragraph.text: The Authority may not guarantee the equity investment of a person who:

subparagraph.text: previously held an equity investment in the applicant;
previously participated in the management of the applicant; or
in any other manner is related to:

sub-subparagraph.text: the applicant; or
any of the current stockholders, officers, or management personnel of the applicant.

paragraph.text: The Authority may use the Fund to lend money to an applicant only if:

subparagraph.text: the applicant meets the requirements of this part;
the applicant is unable to obtain money on reasonable terms through normal lending channels from another source;
the loan does not exceed $2,000,000;

the loan is to be used to perform a contract for which the majority of funding is provided by the federal government, a state government, a local government, or a utility regulated by the Public Service Commission; and
the loan is to be used for:

sub-subparagraph.text: working capital; or
equipment needed to perform the contract, if the contract proceeds can repay the cost of the equipment and if the Authority has entered into an agreement with the applicant to secure the loan.

paragraph.text: A loan that the Authority makes shall mature not later than the term of the contract, unless the Authority finds that a longer term better serves the purposes of this part.

subsection.text: In providing financial assistance under this section, the Authority shall recognize the need to serve applicants from all political subdivisions in the State.
If the applicant is an individual, to qualify for financial assistance under this part the applicant shall satisfy the Authority that:

paragraph.text: the applicant is of good moral character;
the applicant has a reputation for financial responsibility, as determined from creditors, employers, and other individuals who have personal knowledge of the applicant;
the applicant is a resident of the State or the principal place of business of the applicant is in the State; and
the applicant is unable to obtain adequate business financing on reasonable terms through normal lending channels because the applicant:

subparagraph.text: belongs to a group that historically has been deprived of access to normal economic or financial resources because of race, color, creed, sex, religion, or national origin;

has an identifiable physical handicap that severely limits the ability of the applicant to obtain financial assistance, but that does not limit the ability of the applicant to perform the contract or other activity for which the applicant would be receiving financial assistance;

has any other social or economic impediment that is beyond the control of the applicant but that does not limit the ability of the applicant to perform the contract or other activity for which the applicant would be receiving financial assistance, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: the lack of formal education or financial capacity; or
geographical or regional economic distress; or

subparagraph.text: does not meet the established credit criteria of at least one financial institution.

subsection.text: If the applicant is a business enterprise that is not a sole proprietorship, to qualify for financial assistance under this part at least 70% of the business enterprise shall be owned by individuals who meet the qualifications for an individual applicant under subsection (a) of this section.
An applicant for a loan guaranty shall have applied for and been denied a loan by a financial institution.
To apply for financial assistance from the Fund under § 5-525 of this subtitle, an applicant shall submit to the Authority an application on the form that the Authority provides.
The application shall:

paragraph.text: describe the project in detail;
itemize known and estimated costs;
specify the total amount of investment required to perform the contract;
specify the amount of funds available to the applicant without financial assistance from the Authority;
specify the amount of financial assistance requested from the Authority;
provide information that demonstrates the inability of the applicant to obtain adequate financing on reasonable terms through normal lending channels;
provide information that demonstrates the financial status of the applicant, including:

subparagraph.text: a current balance sheet;
a profit and loss statement; and
credit references; and

paragraph.text: contain any other relevant information that the Authority requires.

subsection.text: The Authority may require an applicant to provide an audited balance sheet before the Authority approves or denies the application.

The Authority may delegate the review and approval of the application information required under subsection (b)(1), (2), and (3) of this section to the Executive Director if an applicant meets all other requirements of this section.
The Authority may set the terms and conditions for a loan guaranty made under § 5-525(a) of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: If the Authority decides to lend money from the Fund to an applicant under § 5-525(c) of this subtitle, the Authority shall prepare loan documents that include:

subparagraph.text: the interest rate on the loan that equals the market rate for a conventional loan of comparable risk unless the Authority determines that a lower rate better serves the purposes of this subtitle;
a disbursement schedule that provides enough money to the applicant when the applicant needs it to perform the contract;
a requirement that the applicant and the Authority co-sign each request for an advance of money before release of the money; and
provisions for repayment of the loan.

paragraph.text: The loan documents may include any other provision that the Authority determines is necessary to secure the loan, including an assignment of or a lien on payment under the contract.

section.text: The Treasurer shall report each year to the Authority on:

paragraph.text: the status of the money invested under § 5-521 of this subtitle;
the market value of the assets in the Fund as of the date of the report; and
the interest received from investments during the period covered by the report.

subsection.text: A person may not knowingly make or cause to be made a false statement or report in an application or document submitted to the Authority under this part.
A person may not knowingly make or cause to be made a false statement or report to influence an action of the Authority under this part:

paragraph.text: on an application for financial assistance; or
affecting financial assistance whether or not the assistance has already been extended.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or a fine not exceeding $50,000 or both.

section.text: In this part, “Fund” means the Small Business Development Guaranty Fund.
There is a Small Business Development Guaranty Fund.
The Authority shall use the Fund to implement this part.
The Authority shall administer the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to reversion under § 7-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Treasurer shall:

paragraph.text: invest the money in the Fund in the same manner as other State money may be invested; and
credit any investment earnings to the Fund.

subsection.text: If the Authority determines by resolution that any money in the Fund is no longer needed to meet its obligations, the Authority may authorize the Comptroller to first apply that money to pay the principal of and interest on outstanding bonds issued under any Act authorizing the issue of State general obligation bonds issued to implement this subtitle.

section.text: The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: loans and grants from the federal government or a unit or instrumentality of the federal government;
grants and contributions of funds from the State, a political subdivision, or any other source;
premiums for guaranteeing long-term loans under § 5-540 of this subtitle;
proceeds from the sale, disposition, lease, or rental of collateral by the Authority relating to loans guaranteed under § 5-540 of this subtitle; and
all other receipts of the Authority under this part.

section.text: The Authority may use the Fund for:

paragraph.text: guaranty payments made under § 5-540(a) of this subtitle;
interest subsidy payments under § 5-540(b) of this subtitle; and
expenses for administrative, legal, actuarial, and other services.
The Authority may use the Fund to guarantee up to 80% of the principal of and interest on a long-term loan made by a financial institution to an applicant only if:

subparagraph.text: the applicant meets the requirements under § 5-541 of this subtitle and has not violated § 5-545 of this subtitle;
the loan amount is $5,000 or more and the maximum amount payable by the Authority under the guaranty does not exceed $2,000,000;
the loan is used for:

sub-subparagraph.text: working capital;
refinancing the applicant’s existing debt;
acquisition and installation of equipment;
making necessary improvements to real property that the applicant leases or owns in fee simple; or

acquiring real property that the applicant will own in fee simple if the property is to be used in the applicant’s trade or business for which the guaranty is sought and the financial institution or the Authority places a lien on the property;

subparagraph.text: the loan matures within 10 years after the closing date of the loan; and
the interest rate does not exceed the monthly weighted average of the prime lending rate prevailing in Baltimore City on unsecured commercial loans, plus 2%, as determined by the Authority.
The Authority may only approve a guaranty under this section if the Authority determines that the loan to be guaranteed will have a substantial economic impact.
To determine the economic impact of a loan, the Authority may consider:

sub-subparagraph.text: the amount of the guaranty obligation;
the terms of the loan to be guaranteed;
the number of new jobs that the loan will create; and
any other factor that the Authority considers relevant.

paragraph.text: In addition to a loan guaranty, the Authority may provide an interest subsidy for the benefit of the applicant.
The subsidy:

subparagraph.text: may be for the life of the loan;
may not exceed 4%;
shall be payable quarterly; and
shall be made to the financial institution that makes the loan that the Authority guarantees.
The subsidy may not exceed the difference between:

sub-subparagraph.text: the interest rate on the guaranteed loan; and
the discount interest rate that the Federal Reserve Bank uses.

subparagraph.text: The interest rate may not exceed the monthly weighted average of the prime lending rate that prevails in Baltimore City on unsecured commercial loans, as the Authority determines as of the date of closing, plus 2%.

paragraph.text: The subsidy may not be paid during any period in which the loan is in default.

subsection.text: In providing financial assistance under this section, the Authority shall recognize the need to serve applicants from all political subdivisions in the State.
If the applicant is a sole proprietor, to qualify for financial assistance under this part the applicant shall satisfy the Authority that:

paragraph.text: the applicant is of good moral character;
the applicant has a reputation for financial responsibility, as determined from creditors, employers, and other individuals who have personal knowledge of the applicant;
the applicant is a resident of the State or the principal place of business of the applicant is in the State; and
the applicant is unable to obtain adequate business financing on reasonable terms through normal lending channels because the applicant:

subparagraph.text: belongs to a group that historically has been deprived of access to normal economic or financial resources because of race, color, creed, sex, religion, or national origin;

has an identifiable physical handicap that severely limits the ability of the applicant to obtain financial assistance, but that does not limit the ability of the applicant to perform the contract or other activity for which the applicant would be receiving financial assistance;

has any other social or economic impediment that is beyond the control of the applicant, but that does not limit the ability of the applicant to perform the contract or other activity for which the applicant would be receiving financial assistance, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: the lack of formal education or financial capacity; or
geographical or regional economic distress; or

subparagraph.text: does not meet the established credit criteria of at least one financial institution.

subsection.text: If the applicant is not a sole proprietorship, to qualify for financial assistance under this part at least 70% of the business enterprise shall be owned by individuals who meet the qualifications for an individual applicant under subsection (a) of this section.
An applicant for a loan guaranty shall have applied for and been denied a loan by a financial institution.
To apply for financial assistance from the Fund, a financial institution shall submit to the Authority an application on the form that the Authority provides.
The application shall include:

paragraph.text: a detailed description of the proposed use of the loan proceeds, including projected cash flow analyses, marketing plans, and appraisals;
a detailed description of the funds available to the applicant;
a detailed description of the proposed loan documents to be executed by the financial institution and the applicant;
a detailed description of the property proposed as collateral for the loan and the financial institution’s certification of the property’s value;
information that demonstrates the inability of the applicant to obtain adequate financing on reasonable terms through normal lending channels;
information that demonstrates the financial status of the applicant, including:

subparagraph.text: a current balance sheet;
a profit and loss statement; and
credit references;

paragraph.text: a proposed disbursement schedule;
a proposed amortization schedule;
a detailed description of the applicant’s experience in the trade or business for which the loan and guarantee are requested;
information that shows that the applicant satisfies the requirements of § 5-541 of this subtitle; and
any other relevant information that the Authority requests.

subsection.text: The Authority may require an applicant to provide an audit report and balance sheet certified by an independent certified public accountant in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles before the Authority approves or denies the application.

section.text: A guaranty shall contain terms and conditions that the Authority determines to be appropriate.
The Treasurer shall report each year to the Authority on:

paragraph.text: the status of the money invested under § 5-537 of this subtitle;
the market value of the assets in the Fund as of the date of the report; and
the interest received from investments during the period covered by the report.

subsection.text: A person may not knowingly make or cause to be made a false statement or report in an application or document submitted to the Authority under this part.
A person may not knowingly make or cause to be made a false statement or report to influence an action of the Authority under this part:

paragraph.text: on an application for financial assistance; or
affecting financial assistance whether or not the assistance has already been extended.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 5 years or a fine not exceeding $50,000 or both.

section.text: If an applicant or financial institution violates any provision of the loan documents or ceases to meet the requirements of this part, on reasonable notice to the applicant or financial institution, the Authority may:

paragraph.text: withhold from the applicant further loan payments until the applicant complies with the documents or requirements;
withhold from the financial institution further interest subsidy payments until the financial institution complies with the loan documents or requirements; and
exercise any other remedy for which the loan documents provide.

subsection.text: In this part the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Enterprise” means a business entity proposing to carry on a business in the State that meets the requirements of § 5-526 of this subtitle.
“Enterprise” includes:

subparagraph.text: a sole proprietorship;
a partnership;
a limited partnership;
a corporation; or
a joint venture.

subsection.text: “Equity participation financing” includes investment or guaranty of investment in an enterprise.
“Existing business” means a business whose board of directors or owners approve the sale of the business to an enterprise receiving equity participation financing.

paragraph.text: “Franchise” has the meaning stated in § 14-201 of the Business Regulation Article.
“Franchise” includes only franchise offerings that are registered or exempt under the Maryland Franchise Registration and Disclosure Law.

subsection.text: “Fund” means the Equity Participation Investment Program Fund.
“Program” means the Equity Participation Investment Program.
“Qualified security” means:

paragraph.text: a note, bond, debenture, or other evidence of indebtedness;
stock or other form of equity participation;
a certificate of interest or participation in a profit-sharing agreement;
an investment contract;
a certificate of deposit for a security;
a certificate of interest or participation in a patent or patent application or in royalty or other payments under a patent or patent application; or
an interest or instrument commonly known as a “security” or a certificate for, receipt for, guaranty of, or option, warrant, or right to subscribe to or purchase a qualified security.

subsection.text: “Technology-based business” means a commercial or industrial enterprise engaged in the application of scientific knowledge to practical purposes in a particular field for a profit.
The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: franchises and technology-based businesses have proven to be a fast growing and reliable form of successful business expansion and successful new business creation;
franchises and technology-based businesses play a major role in the economy of the State and have been a continuing source of increasing tax revenues and job opportunities;
the growth of franchises, technology-based businesses, and other businesses should be encouraged and should be an integral part of the State’s economic development effort;

socially or economically disadvantaged individuals often lack adequate capital and are unable to obtain financing from financial institutions or venture capital firms to begin and develop a franchise, a technology-based business, or other type of business, or to purchase an existing business; and

promoting the creation and viability of franchises and technology-based businesses, the development of other businesses, and the purchase of existing businesses by socially or economically disadvantaged individuals is in the public interest.

subsection.text: The purposes of the Equity Participation Investment Program are to:

paragraph.text: encourage and help socially or economically disadvantaged individuals to create and develop franchises, technology-based businesses, and other businesses and acquire existing businesses in the State; and

assist small businesses that, because they do not meet the established credit criteria of financial institutions, cannot obtain adequate business financing on reasonable terms through normal financing channels.

section.text: There is an Equity Participation Investment Program in the Department.
The Authority shall administer the Program.
The Authority may:

paragraph.text: provide equity participation financing to help socially or economically disadvantaged individuals in the State create and develop franchises, technology-based businesses, and other businesses and acquire existing businesses;
buy, hold, and sell qualified securities;
prepare, publish, and distribute technical studies, reports, and other materials with or without charge; and
provide and pay for advisory services and technical assistance that are necessary or desirable to carry out the Program.

section.text: There is an Equity Participation Investment Program Fund.

subsection.text: The Authority shall administer the Fund.

paragraph.text: The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to reversion under § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Treasurer shall hold the Fund separately, and the Comptroller shall account for the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: money drawn from the Small Business Development Guaranty Fund established under Part IV of this subtitle;
money the State appropriates to the Fund;
money made available to the Fund through federal programs or private contributions;
proceeds from the sale, disposition, lease, or rental by the Authority of collateral related to equity participation financing;
premiums, fees, royalties, and repayments of principal, interest, and investments paid by and on behalf of enterprises to the Authority under the terms of equity participation financing; and
any other money made available under the Program.

subsection.text: The Authority shall use the Fund to:

paragraph.text: purchase qualified securities that an enterprise issues to provide equity participation financing as the Program allows;
provide guaranties of investments to expand the capital resources of enterprises;
purchase advisory services and technical assistance consistent with the Program;
purchase securities in which a fiduciary of the State may lawfully invest;
provide equity participation financing as the Program allows; and
pay for administrative, legal, and actuarial services that relate to the Program.

subsection.text: The Fund shall be self–sustaining and shall achieve investment returns on its portfolio in the form of:

paragraph.text: royalties from enterprises in amounts to be determined by the Authority; and
interest payments from any debt securities.

subsection.text: As needed for the Program, the Authority may withdraw from time to time up to a total of $2,000,000 from the Small Business Development Guaranty Fund and deposit the withdrawal into the Fund.

paragraph.text: The Treasurer shall invest the money of the Fund in the same manner as other State money may be invested.
Any investment earnings of the Fund shall be paid into the Fund.

subsection.text: On or before December 31 of each year, the Authority shall submit a report on the Program to the General Assembly in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article.

The Authority may provide equity participation financing under the Program only after the enterprise submits an application that contains a business plan that meets the requirements of subsection (b) of this section.
The business plan of an enterprise shall include:

paragraph.text: a description of the franchise, technology-based business, other business, or existing business and its management, product, and market;
a statement of the amount, immediacy of need, and projected use of the capital required;
a statement of the potential economic impact of the purchase;
information that relates to the satisfaction of the applicant’s requirements of § 5-557(d) and (e) of this subtitle; and
any other information the Authority requires.
Under the Program the Authority may not:

subparagraph.text: own securities representing more than 49% of the voting stock of a franchise, technology-based business, or other business or own an interest greater than 49% in a franchise, technology-based business, or other business; or
own securities representing more than 49% of the voting stock of an enterprise acquiring an existing business or own an interest greater than 49% in an enterprise acquiring an existing business.

paragraph.text: The amount of the Authority’s equity participation financing in an enterprise may not exceed:

subparagraph.text: the lesser of:

sub-subparagraph.text: $2,000,000 for a franchise; or
49% of the total initial investment in the franchise;

subparagraph.text: the lesser of:

sub-subparagraph.text: $2,000,000 for an enterprise acquiring an existing business; or
49% of the total investment in the enterprise acquiring an existing business; or

subparagraph.text: $2,000,000 for a technology-based business.

paragraph.text: Before providing equity participation financing, the Authority shall find that there is a reasonable probability that the Authority will recover its initial investment and an adequate return on investment from the equity participation financing.
The Authority’s investment shall be recoverable within:

subparagraph.text: 7 years after the equity participation financing in a franchise, an enterprise acquiring an existing business, or any other type of business; or
10 years after the equity participation financing in a technology-based business.

paragraph.text: The Authority’s recovery shall be the greater of:

subparagraph.text: the current value of the percentage of the equity investment in the enterprise; or
the amount of the initial investment in the enterprise.

paragraph.text: The value of the business entity at the time of recovery shall be determined after obtaining at least one independent appraisal of the value from an appraiser selected from a list of at least three appraisers supplied by the Authority.

subsection.text: When an enterprise applies to the Authority for equity participation financing to acquire an existing business, an enterprise or its principals shall have:

paragraph.text: an equity investment equal to at least 5% of the total cost of acquisition; and
at least 3 years of successful experience with demonstrated achievements and management responsibilities.

subsection.text: The Authority may provide equity participation financing for the acquisition of an existing business if the existing business:

paragraph.text: has been in existence for at least 5 years;
has been profitable for at least 2 of the previous 3 years;
has sufficient cash flow to service the debt and ensure adequate return of the Authority’s investment;
has the capacity for growth and job creation;
has its principal place of business in the State; and
has a strong customer base.

subsection.text: If the applicant enterprise is a sole proprietorship, to qualify for financial assistance under this part, the applicant shall satisfy the Authority that:

paragraph.text: the applicant is of good moral character;
the applicant has a reputation for financial responsibility, as determined from creditors, employers, and other individuals who have personal knowledge of the applicant;
the applicant is a resident of the State or the principal place of business of the applicant is in the State; and
the applicant is unable to obtain adequate business financing on reasonable terms through normal lending channels because the applicant:

subparagraph.text: belongs to a group that historically has been deprived of access to normal economic or financial resources because of race, color, creed, sex, religion, or national origin;

has an identifiable physical handicap that severely limits the ability of the applicant to obtain financial assistance, but that does not limit the ability of the applicant to perform the contract or other activity for which the applicant would be receiving financial assistance;

has any other social or economic impediment that is beyond the control of the applicant, but that does not limit the ability of the applicant to perform the contract or other activity for which the applicant would be receiving financial assistance, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: the lack of formal education or financial capacity; or
geographical or regional economic distress; or

subparagraph.text: does not meet the established credit or investment criteria of at least one financial institution.

subsection.text: If the applicant enterprise is not a sole proprietorship, to qualify for financial assistance under this part, at least 51% of the enterprise shall be owned by individuals who meet the qualifications for applicants under subsection (d) of this section.

section.text: The liability of the State and of the Authority in providing equity participation financing is limited to investments under the Program.

subsection.text: In this part the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Fund” means the Small Business Surety Bond Fund.
“Principal” means a small business entity that has assets, income, or employees that do not exceed limits that the Authority sets by regulation.
“Program” means the Small Business Surety Bond Program.

section.text: There is a Small Business Surety Bond Fund.

paragraph.text: The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to reversion under § 7-302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Treasurer shall hold the Fund separately, and the Comptroller shall account for the Fund.
The Treasurer shall invest the money of the Fund in the same manner as other State money may be invested.
Any investment earnings of the Fund shall be credited to the Fund.

section.text: The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: money the State appropriates to the Fund;
premiums, fees, and any other amounts the Authority receives with respect to bonding assistance it provides;
proceeds the Authority designates from the sale, lease, or other disposition of property or contracts the Authority holds or acquires; and
any other money available under the Program.

section.text: The Fund shall be used:

paragraph.text: for the purposes described in the Program; and
to pay expenses of the Authority in administering the Program.

section.text: In administering the Program, the Authority may:

paragraph.text: use the services of other governmental units;
contract for and accept loans and grants from the federal government, the State government, or a local government and their units; and
on the terms and conditions it considers advisable:

subparagraph.text: acquire, manage, operate, dispose of, or otherwise deal with property;
take assignments of rentals and leases; and
make contracts, leases, agreements, and arrangements that are necessary or incidental to the performance of its duties.

section.text: The Authority may:

paragraph.text: prescribe or approve the form of and terms and conditions in applications, guaranty agreements, or any other documents entered into by the Authority, principals, or sureties under the Program;
acquire or take assignments of documents executed, obtained, or delivered in connection with any assistance the Authority provides under the Program;
set and collect premiums, fees, charges, costs, and expenses in connection with any assistance the Authority provides under the Program;
adopt regulations to carry out the Program; and
do anything necessary or convenient to carry out its powers and the purposes of the Program.

subsection.text: The Authority may guarantee a surety up to the lesser of 90% or $5,000,000 of its loss under a bid bond, payment bond, or performance bond on a contract financed by the federal government, a state government, a local government, a private entity, or a utility that the Public Service Commission regulates.
The term of a guaranty under this part may not exceed the contract term, including:

paragraph.text: the maintenance or warranty period required by the contract; and
the period during which the surety may be liable for latent defects.

subsection.text: The Authority may vary the terms and conditions of a guaranty based on:

paragraph.text: the Authority’s history of experience with a surety; and
any other factor the Authority considers relevant.

subsection.text: The Authority may guarantee a surety up to the lesser of 90% or $1,350,000 of its loss under a bid bond, payment bond, or performance bond on a contract financed by the federal government, a state government, a local government, a private entity, or a utility that the Public Service Commission regulates.
The term of a guaranty under this part may not exceed the contract term, including:

paragraph.text: the maintenance or warranty period required by the contract; and
the period during which the surety may be liable for latent defects.

subsection.text: The Authority may vary the terms and conditions of a guaranty based on:

paragraph.text: the Authority’s history of experience with a surety; and
any other factor the Authority considers relevant.

subsection.text: The Authority may execute and perform a bid bond, performance bond, and payment bond as a surety for the benefit of a principal in connection with a contract financed by the federal government or a state government, a local government, a private entity, or a utility regulated by the Public Service Commission.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply if the sources of funding for the bonds are grants.
The bonds may not exceed $5,000,000 each.

subsection.text: Bonds are subject to the approval of the Authority based on the bond worthiness of the principal.

The Authority may execute and perform a bid bond, performance bond, and payment bond as a surety for the benefit of a principal in connection with a contract financed by the federal government or a state government, a local government, a private entity, or a utility regulated by the Public Service Commission.

paragraph.text: This subsection does not apply if the sources of funding for the bonds are grants.
The bonds may not exceed $1,000,000 each.

subsection.text: Bonds are subject to the approval of the Authority based on the bond worthiness of the principal.

The Authority may only approve a guaranty or a bond under this part if the Authority determines that the contract, for which a bond is sought to be guaranteed or issued, will have a substantial economic impact.
To determine the economic impact of a contract, the Authority may consider:

paragraph.text: the amount of the guaranty obligation;
the terms of the bond to be guaranteed;
the number of new jobs that the contract to be bonded will create; and
any other factor that the Authority considers relevant.

section.text: The Authority may establish a surety bonding line to issue or guarantee multiple bonds to a principal within preapproved terms, conditions, and limitations.

subsection.text: To qualify for financial assistance under this part the principal shall satisfy the Authority that the principal:

paragraph.text: is of good moral character or is owned by individuals of good moral character;

as determined from creditors, employers, and other individuals who have personal knowledge, is an individual with a reputation for financial responsibility or is owned by individuals, a majority of whom have a reputation for financial responsibility;
is a resident of the State or the principal place of business of the applicant is in the State; and
is unable to obtain adequate bonding on reasonable terms through normal channels.

subsection.text: To qualify for financial assistance under this part the principal shall certify to the Authority, and the Authority shall be satisfied, that:

paragraph.text: a bond is required to bid on a contract or to serve as prime contractor or subcontractor;
a bond cannot be obtained on reasonable terms and conditions without assistance from the Program; and
the principal will not subcontract more than 75% of the monetary value of the contract.

subsection.text: To apply for financial assistance from the Program under this part, a principal and, if applicable, a surety shall submit to the Authority an application on the form that the Authority provides.
The application shall include:

paragraph.text: a detailed description of the project;
an itemization of known and estimated costs;
the total investment required to perform the contract;
the working capital available to the principal;
the bonding assistance sought;
information that demonstrates the inability of the principal to obtain adequate bonding on reasonable terms and conditions through normal channels without assistance from the Program;
a current balance sheet, a profit and loss statement, and credit references about the financial status of the principal;
a schedule of the status of existing and pending contracts; and
any other relevant information the Authority requests.

subsection.text: The Authority may require an applicant to provide an audited balance sheet before the Authority approves or denies the application.
The Authority may not approve a guaranty or bond under this part for a principal that has defaulted on a loan or guaranty from the Authority unless:

paragraph.text: 2 years have passed since the time of the default; and
the principal has cured any default in any financing program administered by the Department.

subsection.text: In its sole discretion, the Authority may set:

paragraph.text: the premiums and fees for providing bonding assistance under the Program; and
the terms and conditions when the premiums and fees are payable.

subsection.text: The premiums and fees may vary in amount among transactions and at different stages of a transaction.
A determination by the Authority on premiums and fees remains effective for as long as the bonding assistance provided by the Authority is in effect.
A person may not knowingly make or cause to be made a false statement or report in an application or document submitted to the Authority under this part.
A person may not knowingly make or cause to be made a false statement or report to influence an action of the Authority under this part:

paragraph.text: on an application for assistance; or
affecting bonding assistance whether or not the assistance has been extended.

subsection.text: A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction is subject to imprisonment not exceeding 6 months or a fine not exceeding $1,000 or both.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Fund” means the Enterprise Fund established under § 5-602 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: There is an Enterprise Fund in the Department.
The Department may use the Fund to:

paragraph.text: make a grant or loan, at the rate of interest set by the Department;
provide equity investment financing for a business enterprise;
guarantee a loan, equity, investment, or other private financing to expand the capital resources of a business enterprise;
purchase advisory services and technical assistance to better support economic development; and
pay the administrative, legal, and actuarial expenses of the Department.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall manage and supervise the Fund.

paragraph.text: The Fund is a special, nonlapsing revolving fund that is not subject to reversion under § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Treasurer shall hold the Fund and the Comptroller shall account for it.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, Division II of the State Finance and Procurement Article does not apply to a service that the Department obtains that is related to the investment, management, analysis, purchase, or sale of an asset of the Department in a transaction authorized under this subtitle, including a commission related to the transfer of a share of stock in a business entity.

The Department is subject to Title 12, Subtitle 4 of the State Finance and Procurement Article for services related to the investment, management, analysis, purchase, or sale of assets of the Department in any transaction authorized under this subtitle, including commissions related to the transfer of shares of stock in a business entity.

Section 10–305 of the State Finance and Procurement Article does not apply to the sale, lease, transfer, exchange, or other disposition of real or personal property, including a share of stock in a business entity, that the Department acquires in a transaction authorized under this subtitle.
The Department shall consult with the Treasurer in connection with the proposed disposition of property that the Department acquires under this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: money appropriated by the State to the Fund;
money made available to the Fund through federal programs or private contributions;
repayment of principal of a loan made from the Fund;
payment of interest on a loan made from the Fund;
proceeds from the sale, disposition, lease, or rental by the Department of collateral related to financing that the Department provides under this subtitle;
premiums, fees, royalties, interest, repayments of principal, and returns on investments paid to the Department by or on behalf of:

subparagraph.text: a business enterprise in which the Department has made an investment under this subtitle; or
an investor providing an investment guaranteed by the Department under this subtitle;

paragraph.text: recovery of an investment made by the Department in a business enterprise under this subtitle, including an arrangement under which the Department’s investment in the business enterprise is recovered through:

subparagraph.text: a requirement that the Department receive a proportion of cash flow, commission, royalty, or payment on a patent; or
the repurchase from the Department of any evidence of financial participation, including a note, stock, bond, or debenture;

paragraph.text: repayment of a conditional grant extended by the Department; and
any other money made available to the Department for the Fund.
The Treasurer shall invest money in the Fund in the same manner as other State money.
Any investment earnings of the Fund shall be credited to the Fund.

subsection.text: Unless the Secretary determines otherwise, money in the Fund that was generated by a particular unit in the Department shall be allocated for the use of that unit.
The Department may require that all or part of a grant be repaid, with interest at a rate the Department sets, when conditions specified by the Department occur.

paragraph.text: Whenever the Department is authorized by law to make a grant, including a grant from the Economic Development Opportunities Program Account authorized under § 7–314 of the State Finance and Procurement Article, the Department may use money appropriated for the grant to make an equity investment in a business enterprise.
In making an equity investment under this subtitle, the Department may not acquire an ownership interest in an enterprise that exceeds 25%.
Within 15 years after making an equity investment under this subtitle, the Department shall divest itself of that investment.
The liability of the State and the Department in making an equity investment under this subtitle is limited to the amount of that investment.
The Department shall adopt regulations governing equity investments under this subsection that specify:

subparagraph.text: the types of business enterprises in which an investment may be made;
the basic standards an enterprise shall meet to qualify for an investment;
the amount of money available for investment; and
the criteria that the Department uses to make investment decisions.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Area” means a geographic area in one or more political subdivisions in the State described by a closed perimeter boundary.
“Business entity” means a person that operates or conducts a trade or business.
“Enterprise zone” means an area:

paragraph.text: that meets the requirements of § 5-704(a) of this subtitle and is designated as an enterprise zone by the Secretary under § 5-704(b) of this subtitle;
designated as an enterprise zone by the United States government under 42 U.S.C. §§ 11501 through 11505; or
designated as an empowerment zone or enterprise community by the United States government under 26 U.S.C. §§ 1391 through 1397F.

subsection.text: “Focus area” means an area that meets the requirements of § 5-706 of this subtitle and is designated as a focus area by the Secretary under § 5-706 of this subtitle.
“Political subdivision” means a county or municipal corporation.
“Submission date” means April 15 or October 15.

section.text: Subject to § 9-103 of the Tax - Property Article, a business entity that owns, operates, develops, constructs, or rehabilitates property intended for use primarily as single or multifamily residential property located in an enterprise zone may not benefit from an incentive or initiative under this subtitle.

subsection.text: The following political subdivisions may apply to the Secretary to designate an enterprise zone:

paragraph.text: a political subdivision for an area within that political subdivision;
with the prior consent of the municipal corporation, a county on behalf of a municipal corporation for an area in the municipal corporation; or
two or more political subdivisions jointly for an area astride their common boundaries.

subsection.text: The application shall:

paragraph.text: be in the form and manner and contain the information that the Secretary requires by regulation;
contain sufficient information to allow the Secretary to determine if the proposed enterprise zone meets the criteria in § 5-704 of this subtitle;
be submitted for a political subdivision by its chief elected officer, or if none, its governing body;

state whether the political subdivision has examined the feasibility of creating educational or training opportunities for employers and employees of business entities located or to be located in the proposed enterprise zone; and
state the standards established by the political subdivision that a business entity shall meet before receiving the incentives and initiatives under § 5-707 of this subtitle.
The Secretary may only designate an area as an enterprise zone if the area:

subparagraph.text: is in a priority funding area or meets an exception under Title 5, Subtitle 7B of the State Finance and Procurement Article; and
satisfies at least one of the requirements specified in paragraph (2) of this subsection.

paragraph.text: An area may be designated as an enterprise zone if:

subparagraph.text: the average rate of unemployment in the area, or within a reasonable proximity to the area but in the same county, for the most recent 18-month period for which data are available is at least 150% of the greater of the average rate of unemployment in either the State or the United States during that period;
the population in the area, or within a reasonable proximity to the area but in the same county, qualifies the area as a low-income poverty area;

at least 70% of the families in the area, or within a reasonable proximity to the area but in the same county, have incomes that are less than 80% of the median family income in the political subdivision that contains the area; or

the population in the area, or within a reasonable proximity to the area but in the same county, decreased by 10% between the most recent two censuses, and the political subdivision can demonstrate to the Secretary’s satisfaction that:

sub-subparagraph.text: chronic abandonment or demolition of property is occurring in the area; or
substantial property tax arrearages exist in the area.

subparagraph.text: In determining if an area meets the requirements of this subsection, the Secretary may consider the most recent census data provided by the United States Bureau of the Census or any other reliable data that is acceptable to the Secretary.

Before considering data other than the most recent census in making a determination under paragraph (2)(ii) of this subsection, the Secretary shall adopt regulations specifying alternative data that are satisfactory to the Secretary.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may establish by regulation any other requirements necessary and appropriate to carry out this subtitle.
Before designating an enterprise zone, the Secretary shall consult with the appropriate advisors.
Within 60 days after a submission date, the Secretary may designate one or more enterprise zones from among the areas described in the applications timely submitted.
The designation of an area as an enterprise zone is effective for 10 years.
The Secretary may not designate more than six enterprise zones in a calendar year.
A county may not receive more than two enterprise zones in a calendar year.

subsection.text: The designation of the Secretary is final.
At any time, a political subdivision may reapply to the Secretary to designate as an enterprise zone an area that is not designated.

paragraph.text: A political subdivision may apply to the Secretary to expand an existing enterprise zone in the same manner as the political subdivision would apply to designate a new enterprise zone.
The Secretary may grant an expansion of an enterprise zone into an area that meets the requirements of § 5-704 of this subtitle.

For purposes of § 5-704(b) of this subtitle, an expansion of an enterprise zone that does not exceed 50% of the existing geographic area of the enterprise zone does not count towards the limit on the number of enterprise zones that:

subparagraph.text: the Secretary may designate in a calendar year; or
a county may receive in a calendar year.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may grant one extraordinary expansion of an enterprise zone in the State each calendar year for an area that:

subparagraph.text: meets the requirements of § 5-704 of this subtitle; and
in the determination of the Secretary, has suffered a significant loss of economic base.

paragraph.text: For purposes of § 5-704(b) of this subtitle, an extraordinary expansion of an enterprise zone does not count towards the limit on the number of enterprise zones that:

subparagraph.text: the Secretary may designate in a calendar year; or
a county may receive in a calendar year.

subsection.text: A political subdivision may request the Secretary to designate all or part of an enterprise zone as a focus area for the lesser of:

paragraph.text: 5 years; or
the remainder of the 10-year term of the applicable enterprise zone.

subsection.text: The request may be made on or before a submission date when the political subdivision applies for the designation of a new enterprise zone or after the Secretary has designated an enterprise zone.
The Secretary may grant the request if the area is located in an enterprise zone and meets at least three of the following criteria:

paragraph.text: the average unemployment rate in the area, or within a reasonable proximity to the area but in the same county, for the most recent 18-month period for which data are available is at least 150% of the greater of the average rate of unemployment in either the State or the United States during that same period;
the population in the area, or within a reasonable proximity to the area but in the same county, has an incidence of poverty that is at least 150% of the national average;
the crime rate in the area, or within a reasonable proximity to the area but in the same county, is at least 150% of the crime rate in the political subdivision where the area is located;

the percentage of substandard housing in the area, or within a reasonable proximity to the area but in the same county, is at least 200% of the percentage of housing units in the State that are substandard, according to data from the United States Bureau of the Census or other State or federal government data the Secretary considers appropriate; or

at least 20% of the square footage of commercial property in the area, or within a reasonable proximity to the area but within the same county, is vacant, according to data from the United States Bureau of the Census or other State or federal government data the Secretary considers appropriate.

subsection.text: To the extent provided for in this section, a business entity is entitled to:

paragraph.text: the special property tax credit in § 9–103 of the Tax – Property Article;
the income tax credits in § 10–702 of the Tax – General Article; and
consideration for financial assistance from programs in Subtitle 1 of this title.

subsection.text: A business entity that moves into or locates in an enterprise zone on or after the date that the enterprise zone is designated under § 5–704 of this subtitle may benefit from the incentives and initiatives in this section if:

paragraph.text: the business entity meets the requirements and conditions of the Code section applicable to each incentive or initiative;
the respective political subdivision certifies that the business entity has complied with the standards that the subdivision submitted under § 5–703(b)(5) of this subtitle;

the business entity creates new or additional jobs or makes a capital investment to qualify for the property tax credit under § 9–103 of the Tax – Property Article and the income tax credits under § 10–702 of the Tax – General Article; and

in considering whether the business entity qualifies for financial assistance from the programs in Subtitle 1 of this title, the Secretary determines that the business entity will create new or additional jobs.

subsection.text: The incentives and initiatives provided for in this section are not available to a business entity that:

paragraph.text: was in an enterprise zone before the date that the enterprise zone is designated, except for a capital investment or expansion of its labor force that occurs on or after the enterprise zone is designated; or
is located in an enterprise zone that was designated under federal law unless the Secretary and the Board of Public Works consent to the designation.

Except as provided in § 10–702 of the Tax – General Article and § 9–103 of the Tax – Property Article, the incentives and initiatives set forth in this section are available for 10 years after the date that an area is designated an enterprise zone.

A law enacted after the enactment of this section that eliminates or reduces the benefits available to a business entity under this section does not apply to a business entity that was in an enterprise zone before the effective date of the law.

subparagraph.text: Notwithstanding subsection (d) of this section, except for a business entity certified to receive a property tax credit under § 9–103 of the Tax – Property Article for a tax year beginning before July 1, 2008, a business entity located in an enterprise zone may not receive the incentives and initiatives set forth in subsection (a)(1) and (2) of this section if the entity is located on land or within improvements owned by the federal government, the State, a county, or a municipal corporation unless the business entity has first utilized all applicable property tax exemptions under Title 7 of the Tax – Property Article, including entering into any available payment in lieu of tax agreement.
Subparagraph (i) of this paragraph does not apply to a business entity leasing land or improvements owned by the Maryland Economic Development Corporation.

paragraph.text: Notwithstanding subsection (d) of this section, a business entity located in a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone established under Subtitle 13 of this title may not receive the property tax credit under § 9–103 of the Tax – Property Article unless:

subparagraph.text: the business entity qualified for the property tax credit before the date that the BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone is designated; or
the political subdivision where the business entity is located expressly grants the property tax credit to the business entity.

subsection.text: An area that is designated an enterprize zone, empowerment zone, or enterprise community under federal law shall automatically be designated as an enterprise zone notwithstanding the limit on the number of enterprise zones that the Secretary may designate under § 5-704(b) of this subtitle.

An application by a political subdivision and the designation by the Secretary of an area as an enterprise zone constitutes the State approval that may be required to designate an area as an enterprise zone under federal law.

The Department and the Comptroller jointly shall assess each year the effectiveness of the tax credits provided to business entities in enterprise zones and focus areas in enterprise zones, including:

paragraph.text: the number and amounts of credits granted each year; and
the success of the tax credits in attracting and retaining business entities in enterprise zones and focus areas.

subsection.text: On or before December 15 of each year, the Department and the Comptroller shall submit to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly a report outlining the findings of the Department and the Comptroller and any other information of value in determining the effectiveness of the tax credits provided under § 5-707(b) of this subtitle.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Private corporation” means a Maryland corporation organized to establish, operate, and maintain a foreign trade zone under the federal Foreign Trade Zones Act.
“Private corporation” does not include a public corporation.

subsection.text: “Public corporation” means:

paragraph.text: the State;
a subdivision of the State; or
an incorporated public authority, commission, agency, or other corporate instrumentality of:

subparagraph.text: the State;
a subdivision or municipal corporation of the State; or
the State and another state.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, a public corporation or a private corporation may apply to establish, operate, and maintain a foreign trade zone in accordance with the federal Foreign Trade Zones Act.
A private corporation may not apply to establish, operate, and maintain a foreign trade zone without prior approval from the Governor and the Maryland Port Administration.

section.text: A public corporation or a private corporation that establishes, operates, and maintains a foreign trade zone under this subtitle is subject to the conditions of the federal Foreign Trade Zones Act.

A person that wishes to have a site in the State designated as a foreign trade zone shall apply for designation approval to the foreign trade zone grantee in the State that is closest to the site before applying to another foreign trade zone grantee in the State for designation approval.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Dredged material” means material that is dredged from the Chesapeake Bay or its tributaries.
“Dredged material” includes sand, silt, sediment, shell, rock, soil, and waste matter.

subsection.text: “Dredged material reuse facility” means a facility that dewaters, analyzes for contaminants, dries, and processes dredged material for reuse.
“Program” means the Dredged Material Disposal Alternatives Program under this subtitle.
“Reuse” means the recycling of dredged material for use in another product, including commercial and industrial uses.
