section.text: There is a Dredged Material Disposal Alternatives Program in the Department.

subsection.text: The purposes of the Program are to:

paragraph.text: designate innovative reuses of dredged material as a sustainable alternative in the management of dredged material disposal; and
provide financial assistance for the production and marketing of technologies that dewater, analyze for contaminants, dry, and process dredged material for reuse in an economically beneficial manner.

subsection.text: The goals of the Program are to:

paragraph.text: implement the beneficial reuse of dredged materials as a sustainable dredged material management method;
foster markets for end-use products that use dredged material as a resource;
increase public awareness of the many valuable commercial and industrial uses of dredged material and products made using dredged material; and
facilitate the reuse of at least 500,000 cubic yards of dredged material each year.

section.text: The Department shall adopt regulations to carry out this subtitle.
The Program shall:

paragraph.text: seek money from federal programs to administer the Program;

engage in public-private partnerships and provide financial assistance to foster the development, construction, and operation of dredged material reuse facilities in the State in an economically beneficial manner;
provide financial assistance to develop end-use markets for dredged material; and
promote the reuse of dredged material and market resulting products.

section.text: Financial assistance from the Program may be in the form of a loan or grant, as provided in regulations of the Department.

subsection.text: The Program is contingent on the allocation of money in the State budget to the Maryland Department of Transportation.

In accordance with the State budget, the Maryland Department of Transportation shall allocate money for the Program from the Transportation Trust Fund after elements of a long-term plan for managing dredged material, in accordance with §§ 5-1102(d)(2)(ii) and 5-1104.2(d) of the Environment Article:

paragraph.text: are operational; and
provide 20 years of placement capacity.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Service–disabled veteran” means a veteran with a disability that is service–connected, as defined in 38 U.S.C. § 101(16).

paragraph.text: “Small business employer” means an employer who employed an average of 50 or fewer employees on business days during the calendar year preceding the determination of eligibility for a loan under this subtitle.

For purposes of paragraph (1) of this subsection, all persons treated as a single employer under § 414(b), (c), (m), or (o) of the Internal Revenue Code shall be treated as a single employer under this subtitle.

section.text: Subject to the availability of funds, the Department, in consultation with the Department of Veterans Affairs, shall establish a program to provide no–interest loans under this subtitle to:

paragraph.text: small business employers of military reservists and National Guard personnel who are called to active duty;
businesses owned by military reservists and National Guard personnel who are called to active duty;
service–disabled veterans;
businesses owned by service–disabled veterans; and
businesses employing a service–disabled veteran.

section.text: Loans shall be made under this subtitle for the purposes of:

paragraph.text: providing financial support to:

subparagraph.text: a business owned by a military reservist or National Guard member who is called to active duty; or
a small business employer of a military reservist or National Guard member who is called to active duty;

paragraph.text: making the home, motor vehicle, or place of employment of a service–disabled veteran accessible to individuals with disabilities, including purchasing equipment necessary to enable a business to employ a service–disabled veteran; and
defraying other necessary expenses, as determined by the Department of Veterans Affairs, incurred by:

subparagraph.text: a business employing a service–disabled veteran as a result of the veteran’s disability;
a service–disabled veteran; or
a business owned by a service–disabled veteran.

subsection.text: A loan made under this subtitle for the purpose of providing financial support to a business owned by an individual who is called to active duty or to a small business employer of an individual who is called to active duty:

paragraph.text: may be made at any time from the individual’s receipt of orders to report to 6 months after the end of the individual’s active duty; and

shall be subject to criteria for eligibility and priority established by the Department of Veterans Affairs, including the extent to which the individual who is called to active duty is an essential employee of the business.

subsection.text: A loan made under this subtitle for the purpose of making accessible to individuals with disabilities the home, motor vehicle, or place of employment of a service-disabled veteran may be made at any time.
The Department shall administer the loan program authorized under this subtitle.
The Department of Veterans Affairs shall establish eligibility criteria for loans under this subtitle.
The Department shall adopt regulations to carry out this subtitle.
The Department of Veterans Affairs may adopt regulations concerning eligibility criteria for loans under this subtitle.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: // EFFECTIVE UNTIL JUNE 30, 2020 PER CHAPTER 269 OF 2006 //

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the Maryland Rural Broadband Coordination Board established under Title 13, Subtitle 5 of this article.
“Fund” means the Rural Broadband Assistance Fund established under § 5–1102 of this subtitle.

section.caption: IN EFFECT
section.text: // EFFECTIVE UNTIL JUNE 30, 2020 PER CHAPTER 269 OF 2006 //

subsection.text: There is a Rural Broadband Assistance Fund in the Department.
The purpose of the Fund is to assist in the establishment of broadband communication services in rural and underserved areas of the State.
The Department shall administer the Fund.

paragraph.text: The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to reversion under § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Treasurer shall hold the Fund separately, and the Comptroller shall account for the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: money appropriated in the State budget to the Fund;

money appropriated in the State budget to the Maryland Economic Development Assistance Fund under Subtitle 3 of this title for the purpose of assisting in the establishment of broadband communication services in rural and underserved areas of the State;
federal money allocated or granted to the Fund; and
any other money from any source accepted for the benefit of the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund may be used only for planning, construction, and maintenance of broadband communication services and equipment in rural and underserved areas and related activities.

paragraph.text: The Treasurer shall invest the money in the Fund in the same manner as other State money may be invested.
Any investment earnings of the Fund shall be credited to the General Fund of the State.

subsection.text: The Department shall make payments from the Fund within 30 days after notice of a decision of the Board under § 13–504(3) of this article.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Fund” means the Maryland Not–For–Profit Development Center Program Fund established under § 5–1204 of this subtitle.

“Not–for–profit entity” means a corporation incorporated in the State, or otherwise qualified to do business in the State, that has been determined by the Internal Revenue Service to be exempt from taxation under § 501(c)(3), (4), or (6) of the Internal Revenue Code.
“Program” means the Maryland Not–For–Profit Development Center Program established under § 5–1202 of this subtitle.
“Qualifying not–for–profit entity” means a not–for–profit entity:

paragraph.text: that has annual revenues not greater than $750,000;
that has been in existence for not more than 10 years; and
whose principal purpose is providing health, education, environmental, agricultural, or social services through community–based programs.

subsection.text: There is a Maryland Not–For–Profit Development Center Program in the Department.
The Program shall foster, support, and assist the economic growth and revitalization of qualifying not–for–profit entities in the State by providing training and technical assistance services.

section.text: The Program shall provide assistance to qualifying not–for–profit entities, including:

paragraph.text: operation of an information exchange governing current and new technical information and data about all aspects of not–for–profit management, including:

subparagraph.text: not–for–profit start–up;
budgeting and financial management;
facilities development and management;
board development;
organizational development and strategic planning;
marketing;
federal and State contracting and grant making;
individual, corporate, and foundation fund–raising;
volunteer management;
personnel management;
federal and State tax law and regulations;
federal and State law and regulations governing charitable solicitations;
federal and State regulations applicable to licensing or accreditation;
federal and State financing programs; and
information technology; and

paragraph.text: individual consultation and technical assistance to any qualifying not–for–profit entity that requests the service, including assistance on any of the subjects identified in item (1) of this section.
There is a Maryland Not–For–Profit Development Center Program Fund in the Department.
The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to reversion under § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Fund consists of:

subparagraph.text: money appropriated in the State budget to the Fund; and

all other money accepted for the benefit of the Fund, including an additional $50 fee to be paid for the processing of articles of incorporation of a nonstock corporation in accordance with § 1–203 of the Corporations and Associations Article.

subsection.text: The purpose of the Fund is to provide grant money to support the operations of the Program consistent with this subtitle.
The Department shall designate at least one private not–for–profit entity to receive grants from the Maryland Not–For–Profit Development Center Program Fund to implement the Program.
In selecting a designee, the Department shall consider and give priority to organizations that:

paragraph.text: have experience in providing the scope of assistance and services required under § 5–1203 of this subtitle to qualifying not–for–profit entities in the State;
demonstrate the capacity to provide the assistance and services required under § 5–1203 of this subtitle on a statewide basis; and
demonstrate current expenditures that:

subparagraph.text: are equal to at least three times the amount of funding received under this section; and
have been received from other sources for the provision of assistance and services of the type required under § 5–1203 of this subtitle to not–for–profit entities in the State.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Area” means a geographic area within one or more political subdivisions within the State described by a closed perimeter boundary.
“BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone” means an area that:

paragraph.text: meets the requirements of § 5–1303 of this subtitle; and
is designated as a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone by the Secretary under § 5–1304 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: “Enterprise zone” has the meaning stated in § 5–701 of this title.
“Political subdivision” means any county or municipal corporation.
“Submission date” means the date the Secretary receives an application from a political subdivision for designation of a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone.
“Tax increment financing bonds” means bonds issued by:

paragraph.text: a political subdivision under Title 12, Subtitle 2 of this article; or
Baltimore City under Article II, § 62 of the Charter of Baltimore City.

subsection.text: The following political subdivisions may apply to the Secretary to designate a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone:

paragraph.text: a political subdivision for an area within that political subdivision;
with the prior consent of the municipal corporation, a county on behalf of a municipal corporation for an area in the municipal corporation; or
two or more political subdivisions jointly for an area astride their common boundaries.

subsection.text: The application shall:

paragraph.text: be in the form and manner and contain the information that the Secretary requires;
contain sufficient information to allow the Secretary to determine if the proposed BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone meets the criteria in § 5–1303 of this subtitle;
be submitted for a political subdivision by its chief elected officer, or if none, its governing body; and

state whether the political subdivision has examined the feasibility of creating educational or training opportunities for employers and employees of business entities located or to be located in the proposed BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone.

subsection.text: After the Secretary’s receipt of an application for designation of an area as a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone or expansion of an existing zone under § 5–1305 of this subtitle, the Secretary shall notify the members of the county delegation to the General Assembly for each county in which a zone is proposed to be located.
The Secretary may only designate an area as a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone if the area:

paragraph.text: is located within a priority funding area as defined by Title 5, Subtitle 7B of the State Finance and Procurement Article;
is served by a public or community water and sewer system or planned to be served by a public or community water and sewer system under the approved 10–year water and sewer plan;
is designated for mixed use development that includes residential uses as part of the mix of land uses by the political subdivision; and

has an average density of at least 3.5 units per acre, calculated in accordance with § 5–7B–03 of the State Finance and Procurement Article, in that part of the area designated by the political subdivision for residential use or development.

subsection.text: An area shall receive priority consideration for designation as a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone under this section if the area is within one–half mile of a present or planned:

paragraph.text: MARC station along the Penn, Camden, or Brunswick lines;
Baltimore Metro Subway station;
Baltimore MTA Light Rail station; or
Metrorail system station in the State.

subsection.text: An area may receive priority consideration for designation as a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone under this section if the area is of strategic importance to the economic development interests of a county.
The Secretary shall consider the following factors in determining whether to designate an area as a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone:

paragraph.text: whether the area’s designation as a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone is consistent with the political subdivision’s comprehensive plan;
whether the area contains brownfields sites that are capable of redevelopment;
whether the political subdivision has targeted the area for revitalization as provided for in the political subdivision’s comprehensive plan or in another plan or ordinance;
the relationship of the area to a BRAC installation or how the area is impacted by BRAC;
the availability, cost, and condition of business facilities;
the number and age of abandoned structures;
the number and age of substandard structures;
the income of residents relative to the State or regional median incomes, including the number of persons who receive public assistance or are unemployed;
the extent of unemployment and the ability to upgrade the social and economic conditions of the area;
the need for financing for small businesses to upgrade the social and economic conditions of the area;
any plans and financial commitments of local jurisdictions to undertake improvements in the proposed area;
a political subdivision’s participation in revitalization activities including whether the area has been designated an enterprise zone;
the presence of a special taxing district, a historic district listed on the National Register of Historic Places, or a local historic district;
support from community or business organizations;
other revitalization projects undertaken in the proposed area;
a political subdivision’s participation in workforce readiness programs;
a political subdivision’s participation in the creation of affordable and workforce housing options for residents;

whether the political subdivision has acted to provide for the adequate protection and conservation of vital natural resource areas and agricultural areas within the political subdivision’s comprehensive plan or in another local government plan or ordinance;
the presence of sensitive areas, as defined in § 1–101 of the Land Use Article;
a political subdivision’s provision of a breadth of transportation options to improve accessibility and land use that supports transit ridership, walking, and bicycle use; and
the fiscal impact of the designation of the BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone on the State.

Within 60 days after a submission date, the Secretary, after receiving a recommendation of the Smart Growth Subcabinet, may designate one or more BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zones from among the areas described in the applications timely submitted.

The designation of an area as a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone is effective for 10 years, beginning on the date the first property in the BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone becomes a qualified property, as defined in § 2–222 of the Tax – Property Article.
The Secretary may not designate more than six BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zones in a calendar year.
A county may not receive more than two BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zones.
The precise location and boundaries of a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone may be determined only on application to and approval by the Secretary.

subsection.text: The designation of the Secretary is final.
At any time, a political subdivision may reapply to the Secretary to designate as a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone an area that is not designated.

paragraph.text: This subsection applies only to a political subdivision that is authorized under § 7–211.3 of the Tax – Property Article to enter into a payment in lieu of tax agreement with a private developer for federal enclave property.

The Secretary may not designate a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone in a county until, in the judgment of the Secretary, the political subdivision has entered into good faith negotiations for a payment in lieu of tax agreement with all private developers of federal enclave property.

A political subdivision may apply to the Secretary to expand an existing BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone in the same manner as the political subdivision would apply to designate a new BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone.
The Secretary may grant an expansion of a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone into an area that meets the requirements of § 5–1303 of this subtitle.

For purposes of § 5–1304(a) of this subtitle, an expansion of a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone that does not exceed 50% of the existing geographic area of the BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone does not count towards the limit on the number of BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zones that:

subparagraph.text: the Secretary may designate in a calendar year; or
a county may receive.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may grant an extraordinary expansion of a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone in the State each calendar year for an area that:

subparagraph.text: meets the requirements of § 5–1303 of this subtitle; and
in the determination of the Secretary, is of strategic importance to the economic development interests of the county in which the BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone is located.

paragraph.text: For purposes of § 5–1304(a) of this subtitle, an extraordinary expansion of a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone does not count towards the limit on the number of BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zones that:

subparagraph.text: the Secretary may designate in a calendar year; or
a county may receive.

paragraph.text: The Secretary may not grant more than two extraordinary expansions in the State during a single calendar year.

subsection.text: Benefits are available to political subdivisions with BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zones as provided in this section.

paragraph.text: A political subdivision that receives designation of an area as a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone may receive amounts as provided in § 2–222 of the Tax – Property Article.
Amounts received by a political subdivision as provided in § 2–222 of the Tax – Property Article:

subparagraph.text: shall be used to pay for infrastructure improvements in the BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone; and
may be used for the repayment of bonds, including tax increment financing bonds, issued by the political subdivision for infrastructure improvements in the BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone.

subsection.text: Political subdivisions and business entities may receive priority consideration for financial assistance for projects or operations in a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone from:

paragraph.text: programs in:

subparagraph.text: the Department;
the Department of Housing and Community Development; or
the Department of Planning; or

paragraph.text: any other appropriate State programs.

subsection.text: The benefits set forth in this section are available for 10 years after the date that the first property in the BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone becomes a qualified property, as defined in § 2–222 of the Tax – Property Article.

The Department shall adopt regulations to carry out the provisions of this subtitle and to specify criteria and procedures for the application, approval, and monitoring the eligibility for the benefits under this subtitle.

On or before October 15 of each year, a political subdivision with a BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone designation shall submit a report to the Department that assesses the effectiveness of the benefits provided to the BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone in attracting and retaining businesses within the BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zone.
On or before December 15 of each year, the Department shall:

paragraph.text: assess the effectiveness of the benefits provided to the BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zones in attracting and retaining businesses within BRAC Revitalization and Incentive Zones; and

submit to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly a report outlining the findings of the Department and any other information of value in determining the effectiveness of the benefits under this subtitle.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Central services” means the performance of central management or administrative functions.
“Central services” includes:

subparagraph.text: general management;
accounting;
computer tabulating;
data processing;
purchasing;
transportation or shipping;
advertising;
legal services;
financial services; and
research and development.

subsection.text: “Company headquarters” means a facility where the majority of a business entity’s financial, personnel, legal, and planning functions are handled on a regional or national basis.
“Full-time position” means a position requiring an employee to work at least 840 hours during at least 24 weeks in a 6-month period.
“Qualified employee” means an employee filling a qualified position.

section.text: The General Assembly intends that the tax exemption under § 11-227 of the Tax - General Article:

paragraph.text: increase the film production activity in the State;
bring economic benefits to the State; and
generate increased employment opportunities in the State.

section.text: To receive the tax exemption provided under § 11-227 of the Tax - General Article for a film production activity, a film producer or a film production company shall first have a certification of eligibility for the tax exemption from the Department.

The Department and the Comptroller jointly shall adopt regulations defining a film production activity, tangible personal property, and taxable services used directly in connection with a film production activity under § 11-227 of the Tax - General Article.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Credit year” means the taxable year in which a qualified business entity claims the credit allowed in accordance with § 6–304(a) of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: “Qualified business entity” means a person conducting or operating a trade or business in the State that is certified in accordance with § 6–303 of this subtitle as qualifying for the tax credit under this subtitle.
For a person engaged in a business activity described in § 6–303(b)(2)(xiii) of this subtitle, “qualified business entity”:

subparagraph.text: includes a person owning or operating the multi–use facility in which the entertainment, recreation, cultural, or tourism–related activities are operated; and
does not include any separate entity that leases retail space at the facility.

paragraph.text: “Qualified position” means a position that:

subparagraph.text: is full–time and of indefinite duration;
pays at least 150% of the federal minimum wage;
is located in the State;
is newly created as a result of the establishment or expansion of a business facility in a single location in the State; and
is filled.

paragraph.text: “Qualified position” does not include a position that is:

subparagraph.text: created when an employment function is shifted from an existing business facility of a business entity in the State to another business facility of the same business entity if the position is not a net new job in the State;
created through a change in ownership of a trade or business;
created through a consolidation, merger, or restructuring of a business entity if the position is not a net new job in the State;
created when an employment function is contractually shifted from an existing business entity to another business entity in the State if the position is not a net new job in the State; or
filled for a period of less than 12 months.

paragraph.text: For a person engaged in a business activity described in § 6–303(b)(2)(xiii) of this subtitle, “qualified position” does not include any position other than a position engaged in:

subparagraph.text: the operation of entertainment, recreation, cultural, or tourism–related activities within the multi–use facility; or
management, marketing, building maintenance, hotel services, or security for the multi–use facility.

subsection.text: “Revitalization area” means:

paragraph.text: an enterprise zone designated by the Secretary under § 5–704 of this article;
an enterprise zone designated by the United States government under 42 U.S.C. §§ 11501 through 11505;
an empowerment zone or enterprise community designated by the United States government under 26 U.S.C. §§ 1391 through 1397F; or
a sustainable community, as defined in § 6–301 of the Housing and Community Development Article.

subsection.text: “State priority funding area” means:

paragraph.text: a municipal corporation;
Baltimore City;
a sustainable community, as defined in § 6–301 of the Housing and Community Development Article;
an enterprise zone designated by the Secretary under § 5–704 of this article;
an enterprise zone designated by the United States government under 42 U.S.C. §§ 11501 through 11505;
those areas of the State located between Interstate Highway 495 and the District of Columbia;
those areas of the State located between Interstate Highway 695 and Baltimore City;
no more than one area in a county designated by the county as a priority funding area under § 5–7B–03(c) of the State Finance and Procurement Article; and

that portion of the Port Land Use Development Zone, as defined in § 6–501 of the Transportation Article, that has been designated as an area appropriate for growth in a county comprehensive master plan.

section.text: The General Assembly intends that the purpose of the job creation tax credit authorized under this subtitle is to increase the number of new jobs in the State by encouraging:

paragraph.text: the expansion of existing private sector enterprises; and
the establishment or attraction of new private sector enterprises.
The Secretary or the Secretary’s designee shall certify a person as a qualified business entity if the person meets the requirements of this section.

A person may not be certified as a qualified business entity unless the person notifies the Department of its intent to seek certification before hiring any qualified employees to fill the qualified positions necessary to meet the requirements of subsection (b)(1) of this section.

subsection.text: To be eligible for a tax credit under this subtitle, a person shall establish or expand a business facility in the State that:

paragraph.text: during any 24-month period creates at least:

subparagraph.text: 60 qualified positions;

30 qualified positions if the aggregate payroll for the qualified positions is greater than a threshold amount equal to the product of multiplying 60 times the State’s average annual salary, as determined by the Department; or
25 qualified positions if the business facility established or expanded is located in a State priority funding area; and

paragraph.text: is primarily engaged in:

subparagraph.text: manufacturing or mining;
transportation or communications;
agriculture, forestry, or fishing;
research, development, or testing;
biotechnology;
computer programming, information technology, or other computer-related services;
central services for a business entity engaged in financial services, real estate services, or insurance services;
the operation of central administrative offices;
the operation of a company headquarters other than the headquarters of a professional sports organization;
the operation of a public utility;
warehousing;
business services, if the business facility established or expanded is located in a State priority funding area; or
entertainment, recreation, cultural, or tourism-related activities in a multi-use facility located within a revitalization area if the facility:

sub-subparagraph.text: generates a minimum of 1,000 new full-time equivalent filled positions in a 24-month period; and
is not primarily used by a professional sports franchise or for gaming.

subsection.text: To be certified as a qualified business entity for a tax credit under this subtitle, a person shall submit to the Department an application that specifies:

paragraph.text: the effective date of the start-up or expansion;
the number of full-time employees existing before the start-up or expansion and the payroll of the existing employees;
the number of qualified positions created and qualified employees hired and the payroll of the new qualified employees; and
any other information that the Department requires by regulation.

subsection.text: When determining whether a business facility is engaged in a qualifying activity described in subsection (b)(2) of this section, the Department shall consider the definitions set forth in the North American Industry Classification System.
The Department may require that any information provided under subsection (c) of this section be verified by an independent auditor that the qualified business entity selects.

paragraph.text: A qualified business entity may claim a tax credit in the amount determined under this section.

A qualified business entity shall submit to the appropriate State units, with the tax return on which the credit is claimed, certification from the Department that the business entity has met the requirements of this subtitle and is eligible for the credit.
Except as provided in this section, the credit earned under this section:

subparagraph.text: for qualified employees working in a facility not located in a revitalization area, is the lesser of:

sub-subparagraph.text: $1,000 multiplied by the number of qualified employees employed by the qualified business entity during the credit year; and
2.5% of the wages paid by the qualified business entity during the credit year to the qualified employees; and

subparagraph.text: for qualified employees working in a facility located in a revitalization area, is the lesser of:

sub-subparagraph.text: $1,500 multiplied by the number of qualified employees employed by the qualified business entity during the credit year; and
5% of the wages paid by the qualified business entity during the credit year to the qualified employees.

paragraph.text: The credit earned by a qualified business entity under this subtitle may not exceed $1,000,000 for any credit year.
The credit earned under subsection (b) of this section shall be taken over a 2-year period, with one-half of the credit amount allowed each year beginning with the credit year.
The same credit cannot be applied more than once against different taxes by the same taxpayer.

If the credit allowed under this subtitle exceeds the total tax otherwise due from a qualified business entity in a taxable year, the qualified business entity may apply the excess as a credit for succeeding taxable years until the earlier of:

subparagraph.text: the full amount of the excess is used; or
the expiration of the 5th taxable year from the credit year.

paragraph.text: The credit under this subtitle may not be carried back to a preceding taxable year.

subsection.text: If, during any of the 3 years after the credit year, the number of qualified positions of the qualified business entity falls more than 5% below the average number of qualified positions that existed during the credit year on which the credit was computed, the credit shall be recaptured as follows:

paragraph.text: the credit shall be recomputed and reduced by the percentage reduction of the number of qualified employees;
the recomputed credit shall be subtracted from the amount of credit previously allowed; and

the qualified business entity shall pay the difference as taxes payable to the State for the taxable year in which the number of qualified positions falls more than 5% below the average number of qualified positions during the credit year.

subsection.text: If, during any of the 3 years after the credit year, the average number of qualified positions falls below the applicable threshold number of positions required under § 6-303(b)(1) of this subtitle, all credits earned shall be recaptured.

paragraph.text: During the 3 taxable years after the credit year, a qualified business entity shall provide any information required by the Department in regulation to verify that the qualified business entity is not subject to subsection (a) or (b) of this section.
The Department may require that any information provided under this subsection be verified by an independent auditor that the qualified business entity selects.

subsection.text: The Comptroller or other appropriate unit shall share with the Department any information received from a qualified business entity about eligibility for a credit allowed under this subtitle.

Information that is received under subsection (a) of this section is subject to the confidentiality requirements established by statute or regulation that apply to the Comptroller or unit that receives the information.

section.text: On or before December 31 of each year, the Department shall report to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly on the business entities certified as eligible for job creation tax credits in the preceding fiscal year.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, the Secretary shall adopt regulations to carry out this subtitle.
The Comptroller shall adopt regulations to provide for the computation, carryover, and recapture of the credit under § 10-704.4 of the Tax - General Article.
The State Department of Assessments and Taxation shall adopt regulations to provide for the computation, carryover, and recapture of the credit under §§ 8-214 and 8-411 of the Tax - General Article.
The Insurance Commissioner shall adopt regulations to provide for the computation, carryover, and recapture of the credit under § 6-114 of the Insurance Article.
Subject to subsection (b) of this section, this subtitle and the tax credit authorized under it shall terminate on January 1, 2020.
After termination of this subtitle:

paragraph.text: a business entity may be considered for eligibility for the tax credit authorized under this subtitle based on positions filled before termination of this subtitle, provided that the other requirements of the subtitle are satisfied; and
tax credits earned may be allowed ratably over a 2–year period, may be carried forward, and are subject to recapture in accordance with § 6–305 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Eligible economic development project” means an economic development project that:

paragraph.text: establishes or expands a business facility within a qualified distressed county; and
is approved for a project tax credit or a start–up tax credit in accordance with this subtitle.
“Eligible project cost” means the cost and expense a qualified business entity incurs to acquire, construct, rehabilitate, install, or equip an eligible economic development project.
“Eligible project cost” includes:

subparagraph.text: the cost of:

sub-subparagraph.text: obligations for labor and payments made to contractors, subcontractors, builders, and suppliers;
acquiring land, rights in land, and costs incidental to acquiring land or rights in land;
contract bonds and insurance needed during the acquisition, construction, or installation of the project;
test borings, surveys, estimates, plans, specifications, preliminary investigations, environmental mitigation, supervision of construction, and other architectural and engineering services;
performing duties required by or consequent to the acquisition, construction, and installation of the project;
installing water, sewer, sewer treatment, gas, electricity, communications, railroads, and similar utilities; and
bond insurance, letters of credit, or other forms of credit enhancement or liquidity facilities;

subparagraph.text: the interest cost before and during the acquisition, construction, installation, and equipping of the project, and for up to 2 years after project completion; and
legal, accounting, financial, printing, recording, filing, and other fees and expenses incurred to finance the project.

paragraph.text: “Eligible start–up cost” means a qualified business entity’s cost to furnish and equip a new location for ordinary business functions.
“Eligible start–up cost” includes:

subparagraph.text: the cost of computers, nonrecurring costs of fixed telecommunications equipment, furnishings, and office equipment; and
expenditures for moving costs, separation costs, and other costs directly related to moving from outside of the State to a location in a qualified distressed county.

subsection.text: “Project tax credit” means a tax credit for eligible project costs allowed under § 6–403 of this subtitle.
“Qualified business entity” means a person that:

subparagraph.text: conducts or operates a trade or business in the State; or
operates in the State and is exempt from taxation under § 501(c)(3) or (4) of the Internal Revenue Code; and

paragraph.text: is certified in accordance with § 6–402 of this subtitle as qualifying for a project tax credit or a start–up tax credit under this subtitle.
“Qualified position” means a position that:

subparagraph.text: is a full–time position and is of indefinite duration;
pays at least 150% of the federal minimum wage;
is in a qualified distressed county;
is newly created because a business facility begins or expands in one location in a qualified distressed county; and
is filled.

paragraph.text: “Qualified position” does not include a position that is:

subparagraph.text: created when an employment function is shifted from an existing business facility of a business entity in the State to another business facility of the same business entity if the position is not a net new job in the State;
created through a change in ownership of a trade or business;
created through a consolidation, merger, or restructuring of a business entity if the position is not a net new job in the State;
created when an employment function is contractually shifted from an existing business entity in the State to another business entity if the position is not a net new job in the State; or
filled for a period of less than 12 months.

subsection.text: “Start–up tax credit” means a tax credit for eligible start–up costs allowed under § 6–404 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: To qualify for a project tax credit or a start-up tax credit, a person shall be certified by the Secretary as meeting the requirements of this subtitle and as being eligible for the tax credit.

The Secretary may not certify a person as a qualified business entity unless the person notifies the Department of its intent to seek certification before hiring any qualified employees to fill the qualified positions necessary to satisfy the employment threshold under subsection (b)(2) of this section.

subsection.text: To be eligible for a project tax credit or a start-up tax credit, a person shall:

paragraph.text: establish or expand a business facility that:

subparagraph.text: is located in a qualified distressed county; and

sub-subparagraph.text: is located in a priority funding area under § 5-7B-02 of the State Finance and Procurement Article; or
is eligible for funding outside of a priority funding area under § 5-7B-05 or § 5-7B-06 of the State Finance and Procurement Article;

paragraph.text: during any 24-month period, create at least 25 qualified positions at the new or expanded business facility; and
be primarily engaged at the new or expanded business facility in any combination of:

subparagraph.text: manufacturing or mining;
transportation or communications;
filmmaking, resort business, or recreational business;
agriculture, forestry, or fishing;
research, development, or testing;
biotechnology;
computer programming, information technology, or other computer-related services;
central services for a business entity engaged in financial services, real estate services, or insurance services;
the operation of central administrative offices;
the operation of a company headquarters other than the headquarters of a professional sports organization;
the operation of a public utility;
warehousing; or
other business services.

subsection.text: To be certified as a qualified business entity for a project tax credit or a start-up tax credit, a person shall submit to the Secretary an application that specifies:

paragraph.text: the effective date of the start-up or expansion;
the number of full-time employees before the start-up or expansion and the payroll of the existing employees;
the number of qualified positions created and qualified employees hired and the payroll of the new qualified employees; and
any other information that the Secretary requires by regulation.

subsection.text: The Secretary may require any information required under this section to be verified by an independent auditor that the qualified business entity selects.

paragraph.text: A qualified business entity may claim a project tax credit for the cost of an eligible economic development project in a qualified distressed county if the total eligible project cost for the eligible economic development project is at least $500,000.
A qualified business entity is not entitled to a project tax credit for a cost incurred before notifying the Department of its intent to seek certification as qualifying for the project tax credit.

Subject to the limitation in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the project tax credit allowed under this section is the lesser of $5,000,000 and the total eligible project cost for the eligible economic development project, less the amount of the credit previously taken for the project in prior taxable years.

Except as provided in subsections (e) and (f) of this section, the project tax credit allowed in a taxable year may not exceed the State tax for that year on the qualified business entity’s income generated by or arising out of the eligible economic development project, as determined under subsections (c) and (d) of this section.
This subsection does not apply to a person subject to taxation under Title 6 of the Insurance Article.
The State tax for the taxable year on a qualified business entity’s income generated by or arising out of an eligible economic development project equals the difference between:

subparagraph.text: the State tax without regard to this subtitle; and
the State tax on the qualified business entity’s Maryland taxable income reduced by the amount of its net income attributable to the eligible economic development project.

paragraph.text: If an eligible economic development project is a totally separate facility, net income attributable to the project shall be determined under the separate accounting method reflecting only the gross income, deductions, expenses, gains, and losses that are directly attributable to the facility and the overhead expenses apportioned to the facility.
If the eligible economic development project is an expansion to a previously existing facility:

subparagraph.text: net income attributable to the entire facility shall be determined under the separate accounting method reflecting only the gross income, deductions, expenses, gains, and losses that are directly attributable to the facility and the overhead expenses apportioned to the facility; and

net income attributable to the eligible economic development project shall be determined by apportioning the net income of the entire facility, as calculated under item (i) of this paragraph, to the eligible economic development project by a formula approved by the Comptroller or the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.

paragraph.text: If the Comptroller or the State Department of Assessments and Taxation is satisfied that the nature and activities of a qualified business entity make it impractical to use the separate accounting method, the qualified business entity shall determine net income from the eligible economic development project using an alternative method approved by the Comptroller or the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.

subsection.text: A qualified business entity that is subject to taxation under Title 6 of the Insurance Article may not claim the project tax credit for the taxable year in which the project is placed in service or for the next 4 taxable years.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, if the eligible project cost for the eligible economic development project exceeds the State tax on the qualified business entity’s income generated by or arising out of the project for the taxable year in which the project is placed in service, the qualified business entity may apply any excess as a project tax credit for succeeding taxable years against the State tax on the qualified business entity’s income generated by or arising out of the project until the earlier of:

subparagraph.text: the full amount of the excess is used; or
the expiration of the 14th taxable year following the taxable year in which the project is placed in service.
A qualified business entity may claim a prorated share of the credit under this subsection if:

sub-subparagraph.text: during any taxable year after the qualified business entity is certified for the tax credit, the number of qualified positions filled by the qualified business entity falls below 25, but does not fall below 10; and
the qualified business entity has maintained at least 25 qualified positions for at least 5 years.

subparagraph.text: The prorated share of the credit is calculated based on the number of qualified positions filled for the taxable year divided by 25.

paragraph.text: Subject to the limitation in paragraph (4) of this subsection and subject to § 6–405 of this subtitle, this subsection applies to any taxable year after the 4th but before the 15th taxable year following the taxable year in which the project is placed in service.
A qualified business entity other than a person subject to taxation under Title 6 of the Insurance Article may:

subparagraph.text: apply any excess of eligible project costs for the eligible economic development project over the cumulative amount used as a project tax credit for the taxable year and all prior taxable years as a tax credit against the State tax for the taxable year on the qualified business entity’s income other than income generated by or arising out of the project; and

claim a refund in the amount, if any, by which the unused excess exceeds the State tax for the taxable year on the qualified business entity’s income other than income generated by or arising out of the project.

paragraph.text: A qualified business entity that is subject to taxation under Title 6 of the Insurance Article may:

subparagraph.text: apply any excess of eligible project costs for the eligible economic development project over the cumulative amount used as a project tax credit for the taxable year and all prior taxable years as a tax credit against the premium tax imposed for the taxable year; and
claim a refund in the amount, if any, by which the unused excess exceeds the premium tax for the taxable year.

paragraph.text: For any taxable year, the total amount used as a project tax credit and claimed as a refund under this subsection may not exceed the amount of tax that the qualified business entity is required to withhold for the taxable year from the wages of qualified employees under § 10–908 of the Tax – General Article.

subparagraph.text: A qualified business entity may claim a prorated share of the credit under this subsection if:

sub-subparagraph.text: during any taxable year after the qualified business entity is certified for the tax credit, the number of qualified positions filled by the qualified business entity falls below 25, but does not fall below 10; and
the qualified business entity has maintained at least 25 qualified positions for at least 5 years.

subparagraph.text: The prorated share of the credit is calculated based on the number of qualified positions filled for the taxable year divided by 25.

subsection.text: A qualified business entity shall attach the certification required under § 6–402 of this subtitle to the tax return on which the project tax credit is claimed.

paragraph.text: A qualified business entity that locates in a qualified distressed county may claim a start-up tax credit in the amount provided in subsection (b) of this section.
A qualified business entity is not entitled to a start-up tax credit for a cost incurred before notifying the Department of its intent to seek certification as qualifying for the start-up tax credit.

subsection.text: The start-up tax credit allowed under this section for each taxable year equals the least of:

paragraph.text: the qualified business entity’s total eligible start-up cost associated with establishing or expanding a business facility in the qualified distressed county, less the amount of the credit previously taken for the project;
the product of multiplying $10,000 times the number of qualified employees employed at the new or expanded business facility; or

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, if the start–up tax credit allowed under subsection (b) of this section for the taxable year in which a qualified business entity locates in a qualified distressed county exceeds the total tax otherwise due from the qualified business entity for that taxable year, the qualified business entity may apply the excess as a credit for succeeding taxable years until the earlier of:

subparagraph.text: the full amount of the excess is used; or
the expiration of the 14th taxable year following the taxable year in which the qualified business entity locates in a qualified distressed county.
A qualified business entity may claim a prorated share of the credit under this subsection if:

sub-subparagraph.text: during any taxable year after the qualified business entity is certified for the tax credit, the number of qualified positions filled by the qualified business entity falls below 25, but does not fall below 10; and
the qualified business entity has maintained at least 25 qualified positions for at least 5 years.

subparagraph.text: The prorated share of the credit is calculated based on the number of qualified positions filled for the taxable year divided by 25.

paragraph.text: Subject to the limitation in paragraph (3) of this subsection and subject to § 6–405 of this subtitle, this subsection applies to any taxable year after the 4th but before the 15th taxable year following the taxable year in which the qualified business entity locates in a qualified distressed county.

A qualified business entity may claim a refund in the amount, if any, by which the qualified business entity’s eligible start–up cost exceeds the cumulative amount used as a start–up tax credit for the taxable year and all prior taxable years.

For any taxable year, the total amount claimed as a refund under this subsection may not exceed the amount of tax that the qualified business entity is required to withhold for the taxable year from the wages of qualified employees under § 10–908 of the Tax – General Article.

subparagraph.text: A qualified business entity may claim a prorated share of the credit under this subsection if:

sub-subparagraph.text: during any taxable year after the qualified business entity is certified for the tax credit, the number of qualified positions filled by the qualified business entity falls below 25, but does not fall below 10; and
the qualified business entity has maintained at least 25 qualified positions for at least 5 years.

subparagraph.text: The prorated share of the credit is calculated based on the number of qualified positions filled for the taxable year divided by 25.

subsection.text: A qualified business entity shall attach the certification required under § 6-402(a) of this subtitle to the tax return on which the start-up tax credit is claimed.

section.text: If the pay for the majority of the qualified positions created from the establishment or expansion of a business facility is at least 250% of the federal minimum wage, §§ 6-403(f) and 6-404(d) of this subtitle apply beginning with the taxable year after the 2nd taxable year that follows the taxable year when the qualified business entity locates in a qualified distressed county.
A refund payable to a qualified business entity under § 6-403(f) or § 6-404(d) of this subtitle reduces:

paragraph.text: the income tax revenue from corporations if the qualified business entity is a corporation subject to the income tax under Title 10 of the Tax - General Article;
the income tax revenue from individuals if the qualified business entity is:

subparagraph.text: an individual subject to the income tax under Title 10 of the Tax - General Article; or
an organization exempt from taxation under § 501(c)(3) or (4) of the Internal Revenue Code; and

paragraph.text: insurance premium tax revenues if the qualified business entity is subject to taxation under Title 6 of the Insurance Article.

section.text: The Secretary shall adopt regulations to specify criteria and procedures for application and approval of projects for the tax credit under this subtitle.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Affiliate” means:

subparagraph.text: a person who, directly or indirectly, beneficially owns, controls, or holds power to vote 15% or more of the outstanding voting securities or other voting ownership interests of a venture firm or an insurance company; or

a person, 15% or more of whose outstanding voting securities or other voting ownership interests is directly or indirectly beneficially owned, controlled, or held with power to vote by a venture firm or an insurance company.

paragraph.text: “Affiliate” does not include an insurance company that becomes a purchaser in accordance with an allocation of investment tax credits under the Program solely by reason of the allocation.

subsection.text: “Allocation amount” means the total amount of tax credits allocated to a purchaser.
“Allocation date” means the date on which tax credits are allocated to a purchaser under § 6–513 of this subtitle.
“Authority” means the Maryland Venture Fund Authority established under § 6–504 of this subtitle.
“Designated capital” means the amount of money that a purchaser invests under the Program.
“Enterprise Fund” means the Enterprise Fund under Title 5, Subtitle 6 of this article.
“Financing Authority” means the Maryland Small Business Development Financing Authority under Title 5, Subtitle 5 of this article.
“Insurance premium tax liability” means:

paragraph.text: any liability incurred by an insurance company under Title 6, Subtitle 1 of the Insurance Article as of October 1, 2011; or

if the liability referred to in item (1) of this subsection is eliminated or reduced, any other tax liability that has been imposed by the State on the insurance company as of October 1, 2011, not to exceed the amount of the liability eliminated or reduced.

subsection.text: “Premium tax credit” means a credit against insurance premium tax liability offered to a purchaser under the Program.
“Program” means the Invest Maryland Program under this subtitle.
“Purchaser” means:

paragraph.text: an insurance company that:

subparagraph.text: is authorized to do business in the State;
has insurance premium tax liability; and
contributes designated capital to purchase an allocation of premium tax credits under the Program; or

paragraph.text: a holding company that:

subparagraph.text: has at least one insurance company subsidiary authorized to do business in the State; and
is contributing designated capital on behalf of one or more of these subsidiaries.

subsection.text: “Qualified business” means a business that, at the time of the first investment in the business under the Program:

paragraph.text: has its principal business operations located in the State and intends to maintain its principal business operations in the State after receiving an investment under the Program;
has agreed to use the qualified investment primarily to:

subparagraph.text: support business operations in the State; or
in the case of a start–up company, establish and support business operations in the State;

paragraph.text: has not more than 250 employees; and
is not primarily engaged in:

subparagraph.text: retail sales;
real estate development;
the business of insurance, banking, or lending; or
the provision of professional services by accountants, attorneys, or physicians.

paragraph.text: “Qualified distribution” means a distribution or payment by a venture firm in connection with:

subparagraph.text: the reasonable costs and expenses of organizing and syndicating the venture firm, including fees paid for professional services, up to a maximum aggregate amount of $125,000;

reasonable and necessary fees paid for ongoing professional services, including legal and accounting services, related to the operation of the venture firm, up to a maximum aggregate amount of $50,000 in a single year; and
a yearly management fee in an amount that does not exceed 2.5% of the designated capital allocated to the venture firm.

paragraph.text: “Qualified distribution” does not include:

subparagraph.text: any amount paid to a purchaser or an affiliate of a purchaser; or
any costs and expenses related to lobbying or government relations.

paragraph.text: “Qualified investment” means the direct or indirect investment of cash by the Enterprise Fund or the Financing Authority in a qualified business for the purchase of any of the following:

subparagraph.text: a share of stock or other equity interest;
a debt instrument that is convertible into equity; or
an equity participation instrument such as an option or warrant.

paragraph.text: A qualified investment includes the direct or indirect investment of cash by a venture firm based on the investment criteria set forth in this subtitle.

subsection.text: “Venture firm” means a partnership, corporation, trust, or limited liability company, whether organized on a profit or a not–for–profit basis, that is certified by the Department as meeting the criteria established under § 6–518 of this subtitle.

section.text: There is a Maryland Venture Fund Authority in the Department.

subsection.text: The Authority consists of the following nine members:

paragraph.text: seven members appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate;
one member appointed by the President of the Senate; and
one member appointed by the Speaker of the House.
Of the seven members appointed by the Governor:

sub-subparagraph.text: at least four shall have experience in working with companies that have raised investment capital for seed–stage to venture–stage companies or in providing professional services to the venture capital industry; and
one of the four members selected under item 1 of this item shall have experience in higher education research and development and technology transfer projects;

subparagraph.text: at least one shall have experience as a small business owner;
at least one shall have experience as a business executive that has raised venture capital investments; and
at least one shall be a resident of a rural county in the State.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall consider the geographic diversity of the State when appointing members.

subsection.text: The members appointed by the President and the Speaker:

paragraph.text: may not be elected officials; and
shall have experience and expertise in venture capital investments.

subsection.text: Each member shall be a resident of the State.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 4 years.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed.
A member appointed by the Governor may be removed by the Governor with or without cause.
The terms of the members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Authority on July 1, 2011.

subsection.text: A member of the Authority may not have any financial interest in a purchaser, qualified business, or venture firm.
The Governor shall appoint a chair from among the members.
The Authority shall determine the manner of election of officers and their terms of office.

paragraph.text: Five members of the Authority are a quorum.
An act of the Authority must be approved by a majority vote of the members attending a meeting at which a quorum is present.

subsection.text: A member of the Authority:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Authority; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: A member of the Authority shall file a public disclosure of financial interests as required under the Maryland Public Ethics Law.

section.text: The Authority shall provide advice to and consult with the Department in connection with the administration of the Program under this subtitle.

subsection.text: All designated capital from purchasers shall be deposited into the Enterprise Fund to be invested as provided in this subtitle.
The Department shall allocate designated capital as follows:

paragraph.text: 67% to one or more venture firms to fund the making of qualified investments based on the criteria set forth in this subtitle; and
33% to the Enterprise Fund, to be allocated:

subparagraph.text: $250,000 to the Rural Maryland Council for its operational expenses;

75% of the remaining amount to fund the making of qualified investments in qualified businesses under the existing policies and procedures of the Enterprise Fund under Title 5, Subtitle 6 of this article; and

25% of the remaining amount to the Financing Authority Equity Participation Investment Program, to be invested in qualified businesses in accordance with the policies and procedures of the Financing Authority under Title 5, Subtitle 5, Part V of this article.

subsection.text: It is the goal of the State that a portion of the designated capital received under subsection (b)(2)(ii) of this section be used to make qualified investments in qualified businesses located in rural areas of the State.

As soon as practicable after the Department receives each installment of designated capital, the Department and each venture firm that has been allocated designated capital shall enter into a contract under which the allocated amount of designated capital will be transferred by the Department to the venture firm for investment as provided in this subtitle.
The Department shall secure the commitment of the purchasers in accordance with § 6–512 of this subtitle.
The Authority shall obtain the services of an independent third party to conduct a bidding process in order to secure purchasers for the Program as provided in this section.

Using the procedures adopted by the independent third party, each potential purchaser shall make a timely and irrevocable offer, subject only to the Department’s issuance to the purchaser of tax credit certificates, to make specified contributions of designated capital to the Department on the dates specified in § 6–513(a) of this subtitle.
The offer shall include:

paragraph.text: the requested amount of tax credits, which may not be less than $1,000,000;
the potential purchaser’s specified contribution for each tax credit dollar requested, which may not be less than the greater of:

subparagraph.text: 70% of the requested dollar amount of tax credits; or

the percentage of the requested dollar amount of tax credits that the Secretary, on the recommendation of the independent third party, determines to be consistent with market conditions as of the offer date; and

paragraph.text: any other information the independent third party requires.
The deadline for submission of applications for tax credits is February 1, 2012.

Each potential purchaser shall receive a written notice from the Department not later than May 1, 2012, indicating whether or not it has been approved as a purchaser and, if so, the amount of tax credits allocated.

subsection.text: The maximum amount of premium tax credits that may be allocated under this subtitle for all years in which premium tax credits are allocated is $100,000,000.
Designated capital committed by a purchaser shall be paid to the Enterprise Fund of the Department in three equal yearly installments due on June 1 of 2012, 2013, and 2014.

On receipt of each installment of designated capital, the Department shall issue to each purchaser a tax credit certificate representing a fully vested credit against insurance premium tax liability equal to one–third of the total premium tax credits allocated to the purchaser.

The Department shall issue tax credit certificates to purchasers in accordance with the bidding process selected by the independent third party on behalf of the Authority under § 6–512 of this subtitle.
The tax credit certificate shall state:

paragraph.text: the total amount of premium tax credits that the purchaser may claim;
the amount of designated capital that the purchaser has contributed in return for the issuance of the tax credit certificate;
the dates on which the tax credits will be available for use by the purchaser;
any penalties or other remedies for noncompliance;
the procedures to be used for transferring the tax credits; and
any other requirements the Department considers necessary.
A tax credit certificate may not be issued to any purchaser that fails to make a contribution of designated capital within the time the Department specifies.

A purchaser that fails to make a contribution of designated capital within the time the Department specifies shall be subject to a penalty equal to 10% of the amount of designated capital that remains unpaid, payable to the Department within 30 days after demand by the Department.

The Department may offer to reallocate the defaulted designated capital among the other purchasers, so that the result after reallocation is the same as if the initial allocation had been performed without considering the premium tax credit allocation to the defaulting purchaser.

If the reallocation of designated capital results in the contribution by another purchaser or purchasers of the amount of designated capital not contributed by the defaulting purchaser, then the Department may waive the penalty provided under this subsection.

subparagraph.text: A purchaser that fails to make a contribution of designated capital within the time specified may avoid the imposition of the penalty by transferring the allocation of tax credits to a new or existing purchaser within 30 days after the due date of the defaulted installment.

Any transferee of an allocation of tax credits of a defaulting purchaser under this section shall agree to make the required contribution of designated capital within 30 days after the date of the transfer.
The Department in its sole discretion may purchase insurance or make other financial arrangements in order to ensure the availability of the full amount of designated capital committed by purchasers.
The Department shall disclose any purchase of insurance or other similar financial arrangement under this paragraph in the annual report required under § 6–529 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Subject to the restriction in paragraph (2) of this subsection, a purchaser may claim the premium tax credit on a premium tax return filed after December 31, 2014, for a taxable year that begins on or after January 1, 2014.
In each calendar year from 2015 through 2019, a purchaser may claim up to 20% of the premium tax credit allocated to that purchaser.
The credit to be applied against insurance premium tax liability in any 1 year may not exceed the insurance premium tax liability of the purchaser for that taxable year.
Any unused credit against insurance premium tax liability may be:

subparagraph.text: carried forward indefinitely until the premium tax credits are used; and
used by the purchaser without restriction during any calendar year after 2019.

paragraph.text: On 30 days’ advance notice to the Department, premium tax credits allocated to a purchaser under this subtitle may be transferred without further restriction to any other entity that:

subparagraph.text: meets the definition of a purchaser;
is in good standing with the Maryland Insurance Administration; and
agrees to assume all of the transferor’s obligations under the Program.

subsection.text: A purchaser claiming a credit against insurance premium tax liability earned through an investment under the Program is not required to pay any additional tax as a result of claiming the credit.

A purchaser is not required to reduce the amount of premium tax included by the purchaser in connection with rate–making for any insurance contract written in the State because of a reduction in the purchaser’s insurance premium tax derived from the credit granted under this subtitle.
Subject to the approval of the Department, the Authority shall obtain the services of an independent third party to:

paragraph.text: establish application procedures for an entity to be certified as a venture firm; and
review and evaluate applications for venture firm certification under this section.

subsection.text: The independent third party selected by the Authority shall:

paragraph.text: review and evaluate the application, organizational documents, and business history of each applicant;
evaluate whether the applicant is likely to achieve the investment criteria set forth in this subtitle; and
recommend to the Authority which venture firms should receive allocations of designated capital under the Program.

On receiving the recommendations of the independent third party selected under subsection (a) of this section and subject to § 6–518 of this subtitle, the Authority shall select venture firms to receive allocations of designated capital that are consistent with the investment criteria set forth in this subtitle.

The Authority shall ensure that the venture firms receiving designated capital for investment under this subtitle make investments in the State that equal or exceed the amount of designated capital received under this subtitle.

Subject to the approval of the Department, the Authority may enter into written agreements, including partnership agreements and side agreements, that are necessary to carry out the purposes of this subtitle.

subsection.text: In selecting applicants for venture firm certification, the Authority shall consider:

paragraph.text: the management structure of the applicant, including:

subparagraph.text: the investment experience of the principals;
the applicant’s reputation in the venture firm industry and the applicant’s ability to attract co–investment capital and syndicate investments in qualified businesses in the State;
the knowledge, experience, and capabilities of the applicant in subject areas relevant to venture–stage businesses in the State; and
the tenure and turnover history of principals and senior investment professionals of the applicant;

paragraph.text: the applicant’s investment strategy, including:

subparagraph.text: the applicant’s track record of investing in venture–stage businesses;
the applicant’s history of attracting co–investment capital and syndicate investments;
the soundness of the applicant’s investment strategy and the compatibility of that strategy with business opportunities in the State; and
the applicant’s history of job creation through investment;

paragraph.text: the applicant’s commitment to making investments, that to the fullest extent possible:

subparagraph.text: create employment opportunities in the State;
lead to the growth of the State economy and qualified businesses in the State;
complement the research and development projects of State academic institutions; and
foster the development of technologies and industries that present opportunities for the growth of qualified businesses in the State; and

paragraph.text: the applicant’s commitment to the State, including:

subparagraph.text: the applicant’s presence in the State through permanent local offices or affiliation with local investment firms;
the local presence of senior investment professionals;
the applicant’s history of investing in venture–stage businesses in the State;
the applicant’s ability to identify investment opportunities through working relationships with State research and development institutions and State–based businesses;
the applicant’s relationship with other venture firms in the region;
the applicant’s history of investing in areas relevant to venture–stage businesses in the State; and
the applicant’s commitment to investing a similar or greater amount of designated capital received under this subtitle in State–based ventures and qualified businesses.

paragraph.text: An applicant shall file an application with the Department in the form required by the Department.
The application shall include the applicant’s most recent financial statements.
The Department shall begin accepting applications for certification on or before January 1, 2012.
An application for certification may not be accepted after May 1, 2012.

subsection.text: To be certified as a venture firm:

paragraph.text: the applicant must have, at the time of application, an equity capitalization, net assets, or written commitments of at least $500,000 in the form of cash or cash equivalents; and

at least two principals or persons employed to direct the investment of the designated capital of the applicant must have at least 5 years of money management experience in the venture capital or private equity sectors.

subsection.text: Not later than 90 days after an application is filed, the Secretary shall either:

paragraph.text: issue the certification; or
refuse to issue the certification and communicate in detail to the applicant the grounds for the refusal.

A business that is classified as a qualified business at the time of the first investment in the business by a venture firm, the Enterprise Fund, or the Financing Authority remains classified as a qualified business and may receive follow–on investments from a venture firm, the Enterprise Fund, or the Financing Authority.

Except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection, a follow–on investment made under this subsection is a qualified investment even though the business does not meet the definition of a qualified business at the time of the follow–on investment.

With respect to an investment by the Enterprise Fund or the Financing Authority, a follow–on investment does not qualify as a qualified investment if, at the time of the follow–on investment, the qualified business no longer has its principal business operations in the State.

subsection.text: Each venture firm shall inform the Department in writing when the venture firm requires designated capital for investment or for the payment of approved fees and expenses.
An insurance company or affiliate may not directly or indirectly:

paragraph.text: manage a venture firm;
beneficially own, through rights, options, convertible interests, or otherwise, more than 15% of the voting securities or other voting ownership interest of a venture firm; or
control the direction of investments for a venture firm.

subsection.text: Subsection (a) of this section applies whether or not the insurance company or affiliate is authorized to do business in the State.
Not later than January 31 of each year, each venture firm and the Financing Authority shall report to the Department:

paragraph.text: the amount of designated capital remaining uninvested at the end of the preceding calendar year;
all qualified investments made during the preceding calendar year, including the number of employees of each business at the time the qualified investment was made and as of December 31 of that year;

for any qualified investment in which the venture firm or the Financing Authority no longer has a position as of the end of the calendar year, the number of employees of the business as of the date the investment was terminated; and
any other information the Department requires to ascertain the impact of the Program on the economy of the State.
