subsection.text: Not later than 180 days after the end of its fiscal year, each venture firm shall provide to the Department an audited financial statement that includes the opinion of an independent certified public accountant.

Not later than 60 days after the sale or other disposition of a qualified investment, the selling venture firm or the Financing Authority shall provide to the Department a report on the amount of the interest sold or disposed of and the consideration received for the sale or disposition.
A venture firm may make a qualified distribution at any time.
To make a distribution that is not a qualified distribution, a venture firm first shall pay to the Comptroller the total amount of the designated capital allocated to the venture firm.
After the venture firm has made the payment referred to in subsection (b) of this section, any additional nonqualified distributions shall be made:

paragraph.text: 80% to the Comptroller; and
20% to the owners of the venture firm.

subsection.text: The Comptroller shall distribute all payments received under this section to the General Fund within 30 days of receipt.

section.text: Investment returns resulting from the qualified investments made under the Program by the Enterprise Fund or the Financing Authority shall be used to make additional qualified investments in qualified businesses by the Enterprise Fund or the Financing Authority.

subsection.text: In any case under the insurance law of the State in which the assets of a purchaser are examined or considered, the designated capital shall be treated as an admitted asset, subject to the same financial rating as that held by the State.
The Department shall submit the following to the Maryland Insurance Administration:

paragraph.text: the names, addresses, and amount of designated capital to be contributed and premium tax credits earned by each successful bidder within 30 days after the close of the bidding process under § 6–512 of this subtitle;
a copy of the tax credit certificate issued to each purchaser within 30 days after the issuance of the certificate under § 6–513 of this subtitle;
the occurrence of a default by a purchaser; and
the transfer of premium tax credits by a purchaser.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, Division II of the State Finance and Procurement Article does not apply to a service that the Department obtains that is related to the investment, management, analysis, purchase, or sale of an asset of the Department in a transaction authorized under this subtitle.

The Department is subject to Title 12, Subtitle 4 of the State Finance and Procurement Article for services related to the investment, management, analysis, purchase, or sale of assets of the Department in any transaction authorized under this subtitle.

Section 10–305 of the State Finance and Procurement Article does not apply to the sale, lease, transfer, exchange, or other disposition of real or personal property, including a share of stock in a business entity, that the Department acquires in a transaction authorized under this subtitle.

section.text: The Department shall administer this subtitle and may adopt regulations to carry out this subtitle.

paragraph.text: On or before January 1, 2013, and January 1 of each subsequent year, the Department shall submit a report on the implementation of the Program to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, the Senate Budget and Taxation Committee and the House Ways and Means Committee.
The Department shall publish the report on the Department’s Web site in a publicly available format.
The report published on the Web site is not required to include any proprietary or confidential information.

subsection.text: The report shall include:

paragraph.text: with respect to each purchaser of premium tax credits under the Program:

subparagraph.text: the name of the purchaser of premium tax credits;
the amount of premium tax credits allocated to the purchaser;
the amount of designated capital the purchaser contributed for the issuance of the tax credit certificate; and
the amount of any tax credits that have been transferred under § 6–514 of this subtitle;

paragraph.text: with respect to each venture firm that has received an allocation of designated capital:

subparagraph.text: the name and address of the venture firm;
the names of the individuals making qualified investments under the Program;
the amount of designated capital received during the previous year;
the cumulative amount of designated capital received;
the amount of designated capital remaining uninvested at the end of the previous calendar year;
the names and locations of qualified businesses receiving designated capital and the amount of each qualified investment;
the annual performance of each qualified investment, including the investment’s fair market value as calculated according to generally accepted accounting principles; and
the amount of any qualified distribution or nonqualified distribution taken during the prior year, including any management fee;

paragraph.text: with respect to the Enterprise Fund:

subparagraph.text: the amount of designated capital received during the previous year;
the cumulative amount of designated capital received;
the amount of designated capital remaining uninvested at the end of the preceding calendar year;
the names and locations of qualified businesses receiving designated capital and the amount of each qualified investment; and
the annual performance of each qualified investment, including the investment’s fair market value as calculated under Financial Accounting Standard 157 of the Financial Accounting Standards Board;

paragraph.text: with respect to the Financing Authority:

subparagraph.text: the amount of designated capital received during the previous year and the amount allocated to the Equity Participation Investment Program;
the cumulative amount of designated capital received;
the amount of designated capital remaining uninvested at the end of the preceding calendar year;
the names and locations of qualified businesses receiving designated capital and the amount of each qualified investment; and
the annual performance of each qualified investment, including the investment’s fair market value as calculated under generally accepted accounting principles; and

paragraph.text: with respect to the qualified businesses in which venture firms, the Enterprise Fund, or the Financing Authority have invested:

subparagraph.text: the classification of the qualified businesses according to the industrial sector and the size of the business;
the total number of jobs created in the State by the investment and the average wages paid for the jobs; and
the total number of jobs retained in the State as a result of the investment and the average wages paid for the jobs.

subsection.text: In this division the following words have the meanings indicated.
“County” means a county of the State or Baltimore City.
“Department” means the Department of Business and Economic Development.
“Person” means an individual, receiver, trustee, guardian, personal representative, fiduciary, representative of any kind, partnership, firm, association, corporation, or other entity.
“Secretary” means the Secretary of Business and Economic Development.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, “state” means:

subparagraph.text: a state, possession, territory, or commonwealth of the United States; or
the District of Columbia.

paragraph.text: When capitalized, “State” means Maryland.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the Board of Directors of the Corporation.

paragraph.text: “Bond” means a bond or note of the Corporation issued under this subtitle.
“Bond” includes:

subparagraph.text: a bond anticipation note;
a revenue anticipation note;
a grant anticipation note;
a refunding bond;
a note in the nature of commercial paper; and
any other evidence of indebtedness of the Corporation, whether a general or limited obligation.

subsection.text: “Corporation” means the Maryland Economic Development Corporation.
“Cost” includes:

paragraph.text: the purchase price of a project;
the cost to acquire any right, title, or interest in a project;
the cost of any improvement;
the amount to be paid to discharge each obligation necessary or desirable to vest title to any part of the project in the Corporation or other owner;
the cost of any property, right, easement, franchise, and permit;
the cost of labor and equipment;
financing charges;
interest before and during construction and, if the Corporation determines, for a limited period after the completion of construction;
reserves for principal and interest and for improvements;

the cost of revenue and cost estimates, engineering and legal services, plans, specifications, studies, surveys, demonstrations, and other expenses necessary or incident to determining the feasibility of an acquisition or improvement;
administrative expenses; and
other expenses as necessary or incident to:

subparagraph.text: financing a project;
acquiring and improving a project;
placing a project in operation by the Corporation or other owner, including reasonable provision for working capital; and
operating and maintaining a project.

subsection.text: “Finance” includes refinance.
“Governmental unit” means a county, municipal corporation, unit of State or local government, or other public body created under State or local law.
“Improve” means to add, alter, construct, equip, expand, extend, improve, install, reconstruct, rehabilitate, remodel, or repair.
“Improvement” means addition, alteration, construction, equipping, expansion, extension, improvement, installation, reconstruction, rehabilitation, remodeling, or repair.

paragraph.text: “Person” has the meaning stated in § 9-101 of this article.
“Person” also includes:

subparagraph.text: a person that is created, owned, or controlled by the Corporation or of which the Corporation is a member;
a for-profit or not-for-profit entity; and
a governmental unit.

paragraph.text: “Project” means any property, the acquisition or improvement of which the Board, in its sole discretion, determines by resolution will accomplish at least one of the legislative purposes listed in § 10-104(b) of this subtitle, whether or not the property:

subparagraph.text: is or will be used or operated for profit or not for profit;
is or will be located on a single site or multiple sites; or
may be financed by bonds, the interest on which is exempt from income taxation under federal law.

paragraph.text: “Project” includes:

subparagraph.text: land or an interest in land;
structures, equipment, furnishings, rail or motor vehicles, barges, and boats;
property and rights related to the property, appurtenances, rights-of-way, franchises, and easements;
property that is functionally related and subordinate to property described in this subsection; and
patents, licenses, and other rights necessary or useful in the improvement or operation of a project.

paragraph.text: “Revenues” means the income, revenue, and other money the Corporation receives from or in connection with a project, and all other income of the Corporation, subject to § 10-115(11) of this subtitle.
“Revenues” includes grants, rentals, rates, fees, and charges for the use of the services furnished or available.

section.text: This subtitle shall be liberally construed to accomplish its purposes.

A project financed under this subtitle may not include property that is eligible to be financed under Subtitle 3 of this title if any bonds issued under this subtitle to finance the property would be payable or guaranteed, directly or indirectly, by an “educational institution” or a “health care institution” as those terms are defined in § 10-301 of this title.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: the State’s economy continues to experience technological change and restructuring;
technological change may result in economic contraction and dislocation, but affords opportunities to expand productive employment and expand the State’s economy and tax base;
the establishment of a public corporation to acquire or improve projects:

subparagraph.text: serves the public interest by accomplishing one or more of the Corporation’s legislative purposes listed in subsection (b) of this section; and

complements existing State marketing programs administered by the Department and through the Department’s financial assistance programs including the Maryland Industrial Development Financing Authority and the Maryland Economic Development Assistance Authority under Title 5 of this article; and

paragraph.text: the State lacks and needs direct property development capability for economic development purposes.

subsection.text: The legislative purposes of the Corporation are to:

paragraph.text: relieve unemployment in the State;
encourage the increase of business activity and commerce and a balanced economy in the State;
help retain and attract business activity and commerce in the State;
promote economic development; and
promote the health, safety, right of gainful employment, and welfare of residents of the State.

subsection.text: The General Assembly intends that:

paragraph.text: the Corporation operate and exercise its corporate powers in all areas of the State;

without limiting its authority to otherwise exercise its corporate powers, the Corporation exercise its corporate powers to assist governmental units and State and local economic development agencies to contribute to the expansion, modernization, and retention of existing enterprises in the State as well as the attraction of new business to the State;

the Corporation cooperate with workforce investment boards, private industry councils, representatives of labor, and governmental units in maximizing new economic opportunities for residents of the State;
the Corporation accomplish at least one of the purposes listed in subsection (b) of this section and complement existing State marketing and financial assistance programs by:

subparagraph.text: owning projects;
leasing projects to other persons; or
lending the proceeds of bonds to other persons to finance the costs of acquiring or improving projects that the persons own or will own; and

paragraph.text: the Corporation not own and operate a project unless:

subparagraph.text: the Board determines by resolution that the private sector has not demonstrated serious and significant interest and development capacity to own and operate the project; or
a representative of a governmental unit requests in writing that the Corporation own and operate the project.

subsection.text: There is a Maryland Economic Development Corporation.
The Corporation is a body politic and corporate and is an instrumentality of the State.
The exercise by the Corporation of a power under this subtitle is the performance of an essential governmental function.
A Board of Directors shall manage the Corporation and exercise its powers.
The Board consists of the following 12 members:

paragraph.text: as ex officio voting members:

subparagraph.text: the Secretary; and
the Secretary of Transportation; and

paragraph.text: the following members, appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate:

subparagraph.text: two representatives of local government;
three members who are knowledgeable in real estate or commercial financing;
three members who are knowledgeable in industrial development or industrial relations; and
two members of the general public.

subsection.text: Each member of the Board shall be a resident of the State.
In appointing Board members, the Governor shall consider geographic diversity and minority representation.

paragraph.text: The term of an appointed member is 4 years.
The terms of the appointed members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on October 1, 2008.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: Before taking office, each member appointed to the Board shall take the oath required by Article 1, § 9 of the Maryland Constitution.
From among its members, the Board shall elect a chair, a vice chair, and a treasurer.
The Board shall determine the manner of election of officers and their terms of office.

paragraph.text: Seven members of the Board are a quorum.
An affirmative vote of at least seven members is needed for the Board to act.

subsection.text: The Board shall determine the times and places of its meetings.

paragraph.text: Subject to the approval of the Governor, the Board shall appoint an Executive Director.
The Executive Director serves at the pleasure of the Board.
The Board shall determine the salary of the Executive Director.
The Executive Director is the chief administrative officer of the Corporation.
The Executive Director shall manage the administrative affairs and technical activities of the Corporation in accordance with policies and procedures that the Board establishes.

subsection.text: The Executive Director, or the Executive Director’s designee, shall:

paragraph.text: attend all meetings of the Board;
act as secretary of the Board;
keep minutes of all proceedings of the Board;
approve all salaries, per diem payments, and allowable expenses of the Corporation, its employees, and its consultants;
approve any expenses incidental to the operation of the Corporation; and
perform the other duties that the Board directs in carrying out this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Board shall employ any additional professional and clerical staff as necessary to carry out this subtitle.
The Board may retain accountants, engineers, lawyers, financial advisors, or other consultants as necessary.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided in this section, in exercising its powers, the Corporation:

subparagraph.text: may carry out its corporate purposes without the consent of any State unit; and
is not subject to:

sub-subparagraph.text: Title 12, Subtitles 1 through 3 of this article;
the following provisions of the State Finance and Procurement Article:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: Title 2, Subtitles 2 (Gifts and Grants), 4 (Water and Sewerage Systems), and 5 (Facilities for the Handicapped);
Title 3 (Budget and Management);
Title 4 (Department of General Services);
Title 5A (Division of Historical and Cultural Programs);
Title 6, Subtitle 1 (Studies and Estimates);
Title 7, Subtitles 1 (State Operating Budget), 2 (Disbursements and Expenditures), and 3 (Unspent Balances);
§§ 8-127, 8-128, and 8-129 (certain restrictions on State general obligation bonds);
Title 8, Subtitle 1, Part V (State Revenue Anticipation Notes);
Title 10 (Board of Public Works - Miscellaneous Provisions); and
Division II (General Procurement Law);

sub-subparagraph.text: the following provisions of the State Government Article:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: Title 9, Subtitles 10 (State Archives and Artistic Property) and 17 (Maryland State Employees Surety Bond Committee);
§§ 10-505 and 10-507 (certain open meetings provisions); and
Title 11 (Consolidated Procedures for Development Permits); and

sub-subparagraph.text: Article 41 of the Code.

paragraph.text: The Corporation is subject to the Public Information Act.
The Corporation, its officers, and its employees are subject to the Public Ethics Law.
The officers and employees of the Corporation are not subject to:

subparagraph.text: Division II of the State Personnel and Pensions Article; or
the provisions of Division I of the State Personnel and Pensions Article that govern the State Personnel Management System.

subsection.text: The Corporation is a public body under Title 5, Subtitle 4 of this article, the Maryland Industrial Development Financing Authority Act, for purposes of applying for, receiving, and making agreements in connection with:

paragraph.text: a loan;
a grant;
insurance; or
any other form of financial assistance.

subsection.text: The Corporation is subject to the same State and local regulatory requirements as any private corporation.
A project of the Corporation is subject to the zoning and subdivision regulations of the jurisdiction where it is located.
The Corporation, its officers, and its employees are subject to Title 12, Subtitle 4 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

section.text: A finding by the Board concerning the public purpose of an action, the legislative intent expressed under this subtitle, or the appropriateness of the action in serving the public purpose and satisfying the legislative intent is conclusive in a proceeding that involves the validity or enforceability of:

paragraph.text: an agreement entered into by the Corporation under this subtitle;
a bond; or
any security relating to a bond.

subsection.text: The Corporation shall establish a system of financial accounting, controls, audits, and reports.
The fiscal year of the Corporation begins on July 1 and ends on the following June 30.
The Corporation may create and administer the accounts that it requires.
The Corporation shall deposit its money into a State or national bank or a federally insured savings and loan association that has a total paid-in capital of at least $1,000,000.
The Corporation may designate the trust department of a State bank, national bank, or savings and loan association as a depository to receive securities that the Corporation owns or acquires.

Unless an agreement or covenant between the Corporation and the holders of its obligations limits classes of investments, the Corporation may invest its money in bonds or other obligations of, or guaranteed as to principal and interest by, the United States, the State, or a governmental unit.

section.text: The Corporation may:

paragraph.text: adopt bylaws for the conduct of its business;
adopt a seal;
maintain offices at a place it designates in the State;
accept loans, grants, or assistance of any kind from the federal government, a governmental unit, or a private source;
enter into contracts and other legal instruments;
sue and be sued in its own name;

acquire, purchase, hold, lease as lessee, and use any franchise, patent, or license and real, personal, mixed, tangible, or intangible property, or any interest in property, necessary or convenient to carry out its purposes;
sell, lease as lessor, transfer, and dispose of its property or interest in property;
fix and collect rates, rentals, fees, and charges for services and facilities it provides or makes available;
with the owner’s permission, enter lands, waters, or premises to make a survey, sounding, boring, or examination to accomplish a purpose authorized by this subtitle;
further define or limit the term “revenues” defined in § 10-101 of this subtitle as the term applies to a particular project, financing, or other matter;
create, own, control, or be a member of a corporation, limited liability company, partnership, or other person, whether for-profit or not-for-profit;
exercise a power usually possessed by a private corporation in performing similar functions unless to do so would conflict with State law; and
do all things necessary or convenient to carry out the powers expressly granted by this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Corporation may:

paragraph.text: acquire, improve, develop, manage, market, maintain, lease as lessor or as lessee, and operate a project in the State;

acquire, directly or through a person or governmental unit, by purchase, gift, or devise, property, franchises, and other interests in land, including land lying under water and riparian rights, located in or outside the State as necessary or convenient to improve or operate a project, on terms and at prices that the Corporation considers reasonable;

if approved by resolution by at least a two-thirds majority of the legislative body of each governmental unit in which the property is located, acquire real property or rights or easements in real property for a project by condemnation for public use in accordance with applicable law; and
make loans to a person to:

subparagraph.text: finance all or a part of the acquisition or improvement of a project; and
refund outstanding bonds, mortgages, advances, loans, or other obligations of the person to finance all or part of the acquisition or improvement of a project.

subsection.text: The power of condemnation of the Corporation under subsection (a)(3) of this section may not exceed the power of condemnation of the governmental unit in which the property is located.
The Corporation may:

paragraph.text: borrow money and issue bonds to finance any part of the cost of a project or for any other corporate purpose of the Corporation;
secure the payment of any portion of the borrowing by pledge of or mortgage or deed of trust on property or revenues of the Corporation;

combine projects for financing, make agreements with or for the benefit of the bondholders or with others in connection with the issuance or future issuance of bonds, as the Corporation considers advisable; and
otherwise provide for the security of bonds and the rights of bondholders.

subsection.text: In addition to the powers of the Corporation under subsection (a) of this section, for the purpose of funding the purchase or condemnation by the State for public use of the property as authorized by §§ 11–520 and 11–521 of the Business Regulation Article, the Corporation may borrow money and issue bonds to finance the cost of acquiring by purchase or completing the condemnation process by the State in accordance with applicable legal standards.
The Corporation may authorize the issuance of revenue bonds by resolution.
The Corporation may issue the bonds at one time or in one or more series from time to time.
The Corporation shall determine:

paragraph.text: the date of the bonds;
the maturity dates of the bonds, which may not exceed 40 years from the date of issue;
the interest rates on the bonds;
the medium of payment of the principal of and interest on the bonds;
the form of the bonds;
the manner of executing the bonds;
the denominations of the bonds; and
the place at which the principal of and interest on the bonds will be payable, including at a bank or trust company in or outside the State.

subsection.text: An officer’s signature or facsimile signature on a bond remains valid even if the officer leaves office before the bond is delivered.

paragraph.text: Between successive holders, bonds are negotiable instruments under Title 3 of the Maryland Uniform Commercial Code.
Bonds may be registrable.
The Corporation shall sell the bonds by competitive or negotiated sale in a manner and for a price the Corporation determines to be in its best interests.
Bonds are exempt from §§ 8-206 and 8-208 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

subsection.text: Bond proceeds may be placed in escrow pending application of the proceeds to the purposes for which the bonds are issued.

section.text: Bonds are securities:

paragraph.text: in which any of the following persons may legally and properly invest money, including capital that the person owns or controls:

subparagraph.text: an officer of a governmental unit;
a bank, trust company, savings and loan association, investment company, or other person operating a banking business;
an insurance association or other person operating an insurance business;
a personal representative, guardian, trustee, or other fiduciary; and
any other person; and

paragraph.text: that may be deposited with and received by a governmental unit or any officer of the State or a governmental unit for any purpose for which the deposit of bonds or other obligations of the State is authorized by law.
This section does not prevent the Corporation from pledging its full faith and credit to the payment of a bond.

This section does not limit the ability of the State or a governmental unit to impose and collect an assessment, rate, fee, or charge to pay to the Corporation any cost, including the principal of and interest on a bond, under an agreement between the Corporation and the State or governmental unit.
A bond:

subparagraph.text: is not a debt, liability, or a pledge of the full faith and credit of the State or a governmental unit; and
is payable solely from revenues provided under this subtitle.

paragraph.text: The issuance of a bond is not directly, indirectly, or contingently a moral or other obligation of the State or a governmental unit to levy or pledge any tax or to make an appropriation to pay the bond.
Each bond shall state on its face that:

subparagraph.text: neither the State nor any governmental unit is obliged to pay the principal of or interest on the bond, except from revenues pledged to payment of the bond; and
neither the full faith and credit nor the taxing power of the State or a governmental unit is pledged to the payment of the principal of or interest on the bond.

paragraph.text: The Corporation may secure a bond by a trust agreement between the Corporation and a corporate trustee.
A corporate trustee may be any trust company or bank that has the powers of a trust company in or outside the State.
A corporation or trust company incorporated in the State may:

subparagraph.text: act as depository of bond proceeds or revenues; and
furnish an indemnity bond or pledge security that the Corporation requires.

subsection.text: The trust agreement or the resolution that provides for the issuance of a bond may:

paragraph.text: state the rights and remedies of bondholders and any trustee;
contain provisions to protect and enforce the rights and remedies of bondholders;
contain covenants stating the duties of the Corporation as to the custody, safeguarding, and application of money;
restrict the individual rights of action of bondholders;
provide for the payment of the bond proceeds and revenues to an officer, board, or depository that the Corporation determines with the safeguards and restrictions that the Corporation determines; and
provide for the method of disbursement of the bond proceeds and revenues, with the safeguards and restrictions that the Corporation determines.

subsection.text: Expenses incurred in carrying out a trust agreement may be treated as part of the cost of operation of the Corporation.
The portion of the proceeds of bonds issued to pay costs of a project may be invested in investments or other obligations that mature no later than the times when the proceeds will be needed.

paragraph.text: Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Corporation shall determine the investment of bond proceeds.
If the Corporation loans the proceeds of the bonds to a person as provided in § 10-125 of this subtitle, the loan recipient shall determine the investment of bond proceeds.

subsection.text: The Corporation or the loan recipient may apply earnings and profits on investments or other obligations:

paragraph.text: to the payment of any cost; or
in any other lawful manner.
The Corporation may issue bonds to refund outstanding bonds, including paying:

subparagraph.text: any redemption premium;
interest accrued or to accrue to the date of redemption, purchase, or maturity of the bonds; and
if considered advisable by the Corporation, any part of the cost of a project.

paragraph.text: Refunding bonds may be issued for any corporate purpose, including:

subparagraph.text: realizing savings in the effective costs of debt service, directly or through a debt restructuring;
alleviating an impending or actual default; or
relieving the Corporation of a contractual agreement that the Corporation finds to be unreasonably onerous, impracticable, or impossible to perform.

paragraph.text: The Corporation may issue refunding bonds in one or more series in an amount greater than the amount of the bonds to be refunded.

subparagraph.text: In addition to other sources of payment that the Corporation determines, refunding bonds may be payable from escrowed bond proceeds and earnings and profits on investments.
Escrowed bond proceeds and earnings and profits on investments used under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph constitute revenues of a project under this subtitle.

subsection.text: In the discretion of the Corporation, the proceeds of refunding bonds may be:

paragraph.text: applied to the purchase, retirement at maturity, or redemption of outstanding bonds on a date the Corporation determines; and
pending application under item (1) of this subsection, placed in escrow.

The Corporation may invest escrowed refunding bond proceeds in investments and other obligations, maturing on appropriate dates to assure the prompt payment of the principal of, interest on, and any redemption premium on the bonds to be refunded.

subparagraph.text: Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, the Corporation shall determine the investment of the proceeds of refunding bonds.
If the Corporation loans the proceeds of refunding bonds to a person as provided in § 10-125 of this subtitle, the loan recipient shall determine the investment of the proceeds of refunding bonds.

paragraph.text: The earnings and profits on investments or other obligations may be applied to the payment of the bonds to be refunded.

After the terms of the escrow have been fully satisfied, the balance of the proceeds and earnings and profits on investments or other obligations may be returned to the Corporation or the loan recipient for use in any lawful manner.

section.text: Except to the extent rights granted by this subtitle are restricted by resolution passed before the issuance of the bonds or by the trust agreement, a holder of a bond issued under this subtitle or a trustee under a trust agreement may sue to:

paragraph.text: protect and enforce rights under the laws of the State, the resolution, or the trust agreement; and
enforce and compel performance of duties by the Corporation or its officers that this subtitle, the resolution, or the trust agreement requires.

subsection.text: The Corporation may:

paragraph.text: lend or otherwise make available the proceeds of bonds to a person to finance costs of a project; and
enter into financing agreements, mortgages, and other instruments that it determines are necessary or desirable to evidence or secure the loan.
The lease for a project may require or authorize the lessee or another person to purchase or otherwise acquire the property for consideration that the Corporation establishes, when:

subparagraph.text: the principal of and interest on the bonds that financed the cost of the project are paid; or
provision satisfactory to the Corporation is made for their payment.

paragraph.text: Consideration required under paragraph (1) of this subsection may be nominal.

subsection.text: The Corporation may:

paragraph.text: fix and collect rates or charges for its services;
establish the terms and conditions for the services; and
contract with a person for the use of the Corporation’s services.

subsection.text: The rates or charges of the Corporation are not subject to supervision or regulation by a governmental unit.
Subject to any agreement, the Corporation may apply the rates, charges, and other revenues received by the Corporation to any lawful purpose.
Except as necessary to pay debt service or implement programs of the Corporation, the net earnings of the Corporation may not benefit a person other than the State.
The Corporation may pledge or assign:

paragraph.text: any of its revenues;
any of its rights to receive revenues;
money and securities in accounts established to secure a bond; and
a lien or security interest granted or assignment made to the Corporation.

subsection.text: A pledge or assignment:

paragraph.text: is valid and binding against any person having a claim against the Corporation in tort, contract, or otherwise, regardless of whether the person has notice of the pledge or assignment; and
has priority over the claim.

subsection.text: A resolution, trust agreement, assignment, financing agreement or other instrument that creates a lien, security interest, assignment, or pledge under subsection (a) of this section:

paragraph.text: shall be filed in the records of the Corporation; but
need not be filed or recorded elsewhere.

subsection.text: With the approval of the legislative body of each governmental unit in which a project is proposed to be located, the Board of Public Works may convey to the Corporation, for economic development purposes, any real property, including improvements, that:

paragraph.text: was transferred to the State, by gift or otherwise for substantially below market value, as a vacant or underutilized industrial facility or site;
has existed for at least 10 years; and
is at least 10 acres.

subsection.text: If a person who transfers property described in subsection (a)(1) of this section to the State owns property adjoining the transferred property, the Board of Public Works shall have the first option to purchase the adjoining property at a price determined when the original property was transferred.
Property conveyed under this section may be insured under Title 9 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the Corporation is exempt from any requirement to pay taxes or assessments on its properties or activities, or any revenue from its properties or activities.
Property that the Corporation sells or leases to a private entity is subject to State and local real property taxes from the time of the sale or lease.
The bonds of the Corporation, including the interest on the bonds, are forever exempt from all State and local taxes.
In this section, “Fund” means the Dorchester County Economic Development Fund.
There is a Dorchester County Economic Development Fund in the Corporation.

paragraph.text: The Fund is a continuing, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to reversion under § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The Corporation shall manage and administer the Fund on terms and conditions acceptable to the Corporation and the Department.
The Comptroller shall account and collect for the Fund and disburse the revenues to the trustee maintaining the Fund for the Corporation.
Any investment earnings of the Fund shall be paid into the Fund.

subsection.text: The Fund consists of revenues from the hotel surcharge imposed under § 11-102(b) of the Tax - General Article.

paragraph.text: The Fund shall be used to:

subparagraph.text: complete the Corporation project commonly known as the Chesapeake Bay Conference Center; and
satisfy the full and final settlement of pending construction claims related to the project and any bonds issued in connection with those claims.

paragraph.text: The Fund may be pledged by the Corporation to pay bonds issued to satisfy the full and final settlement of pending construction claims on the project.
As soon as practical after the close of the fiscal year, an independent certified public accountant shall audit the financial books, records, and accounts of the Corporation.
The audit shall include revenue and expense detail for each of the operating facilities of the Corporation.
The Corporation shall select an accountant to conduct the audit who:

subparagraph.text: is licensed to practice accountancy in the State;
is experienced and qualified in the accounting and auditing of public entities; and
does not have a direct or indirect personal interest in the fiscal affairs of the Corporation.

Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, on or before November 1 after each fiscal year, the accountant shall report the results of the audit, including the accountant’s unqualified opinion of the presentation of the financial position of the funds of the Corporation, individual financial detail for each of the operating facilities of the Corporation, and the results of the financial operations of the Corporation.

If the accountant cannot express an unqualified opinion, the accountant shall explain in detail the reasons for the qualifications, disclaimers, or opinions, including recommendations for changes that could make future unqualified opinions possible.

subsection.text: The State may audit the books, records, and accounts of the Corporation.

On or before October 1 of each year, the Corporation shall submit a report to the Governor, the Maryland Economic Development Commission, and, in accordance with § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly.
The report shall include a complete operating and financial statement and summarize the activities of the Corporation during the preceding fiscal year.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Authority” means the Maryland Food Center Authority.
“Bond” means a bond, note, or any other obligation issued under this subtitle.
“Center” means the Maryland Food Center.
“Costs”, with respect to a development or project, means:

paragraph.text: the purchase price;
the cost of any property, right, easement, and franchise considered necessary to construct and establish a development or project;
the cost of relocation of wholesale food dealers or tenants under § 10–212 of this subtitle;
the cost of labor, materials, and equipment, including expenses of relocating public utility facilities under § 10–210 of this subtitle;
financing charges;
interest before and during construction;

the cost of revenue and cost estimates, engineering, architectural, and legal services, plans, specifications, surveys, and other expenses necessary or incident to determining the feasibility or practicability of the construction of a development or project;
administrative expenses; and
other expenses necessary or incident to:

subparagraph.text: the financing of a development or project;
constructing and establishing a development or project; and
placing a development or project into operation.

subsection.text: “Development” means:

paragraph.text: the Center;
a commercial seafood development; and
any other multiproject food–related or agriculturally related real estate development that the Authority undertakes to further the purposes of this subtitle.
“Food” means agricultural and other edible food products and floricultural and horticultural products.
“Food” includes the following:

subparagraph.text: butter;
cheese;
eggs;
fruits;
meats;
meat products;
poultry;
seafood; and
vegetables.

paragraph.text: “Food” may be in packaged or fresh form.
“Food” shall be liberally construed.

subsection.text: “Improve” means to add, alter, construct, equip, expand, extend, improve, install, reconstruct, rehabilitate, remodel, or repair.
“Improvement” means addition, alteration, construction, equipping, expansion, extension, improvement, installation, reconstruction, rehabilitation, remodeling, or repair.

paragraph.text: “Project” means a facility, operation, or portion of a development that the Authority undertakes to further the purposes of this subtitle.
“Project” includes:

sub-subparagraph.text: a market;
a food handling, processing, storage, or distribution facility; and
a commercial seafood facility or operation;

subparagraph.text: a facility or service ancillary or appurtenant to a development or a project that the Authority determines will enhance the public convenience or attractiveness of the development or project, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: a bank;
a parking or other transportation facility;
a restaurant;
a store; and
any other commercial enterprise;

subparagraph.text: land, structures, equipment, furnishings, rail or motor vehicles, barges, and boats in a development or project;
property and rights in a development or project; and
land and facilities that are functionally related to a development or project.

subsection.text: This subtitle shall be liberally construed to accomplish its purposes.
The establishment of developments and projects under this subtitle is:

paragraph.text: for the benefit of the residents of the State and its political subdivisions; and
a public purpose.

section.text: A development or project under this subtitle may not include the development of an aquaculture development or project for the commercial raising of finfish, shellfish, or aquatic plants.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds that:

subparagraph.text: the marketing of food is a matter of public interest and the maintenance of wholesale market places is and has always been recognized as a public function;
public health and safety are adversely affected by the unsafe, obsolete, and unsanitary conditions of existing food markets;

the vast quantities of food and related food products brought annually from all parts of the United States into the wholesale markets in the State must pass through market facilities that are obsolete and inadequate to meet present needs;

the scattered locations of and difficulty of access to wholesale markets constitute an economic loss, and the obsolescence of markets is responsible for much of the high cost of food handling and for deterioration that takes place both in the wholesale markets and between the markets and the consumer’s doorstep;
modern consolidated facilities would result in an annual saving; and

there is a need for a consolidated wholesale food market in the State, and, in spite of this need, efforts on the part of the State, the City of Baltimore, the wholesale food trade, growers, and the transportation industry have failed to effect the consolidation of wholesale markets satisfactorily;
constructing, operating, and maintaining wholesale markets, and in particular a consolidated market for the State, would require the expenditure of a large sum of money; and

the financial systems of the political subdivisions of the State are not designed to undertake projects described under item (i) of this item on a not-for-profit, self-liquidating basis, and the best method of creating a market is to establish and authorize a market authority as a public corporation to:

sub-subparagraph.text: acquire land for a market development;
construct and operate a market development; and
make loans to and otherwise assist persons engaged in the wholesale food industry who want to locate in a market development;

paragraph.text: it is in the public interest to:

subparagraph.text: eliminate or correct the conditions described in item (1) of this subsection regarding the marketing of food; and
establish an economical and modern method of marketing wholesale food in the State by constructing a modern, sanitary, and accessible market development that may include:

sub-subparagraph.text: warehouse facilities used by wholesalers or retailers principally engaged in the sale of food and used for storage of food and beverages and nonfood products sold from time to time in connection with the sale of food at retail; and
any ancillary or appurtenant facility that the Authority determines will enhance the public convenience or attractiveness of the market development including:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: a bank;
a parking or other transportation facility;
a restaurant;
a store; or
any other commercial enterprise; and

subparagraph.text: there exists a need and the opportunity to capitalize on the vast resources of finfish and shellfish that can be found in the State’s coastal waters;
development of the seafood industry on the Eastern Shore could:

sub-subparagraph.text: provide an opportunity for the State to capitalize on these resources;
create new jobs; and
produce other economic benefit to the State;

subparagraph.text: a centralized seafood project is needed for the development of these resources and resulting economic benefit; and
the development of the project and these resources would be in the public interest and can best be accomplished through the Authority.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds that it is desirable that, when sufficient revenue will be derived from the operation of a project or development to amortize its cost within a reasonable period, the cost be defrayed if practicable by issuing bonds or other debt instruments payable from the revenue derived from project operations.
There is a Maryland Food Center Authority.
The Authority is a body politic and corporate and an instrumentality of the State.
The exercise by the State, a political subdivision of the State, or the Authority of a power under this subtitle is the performance of an essential governmental function.

paragraph.text: The Authority consists of 12 members.

subparagraph.text: Each member shall be a resident of the State.
One member shall reside in Howard County.

paragraph.text: Of the 12 members:

subparagraph.text: four shall be ex officio members:

sub-subparagraph.text: the Director of Agricultural Extension;
the Comptroller;
the Secretary of Agriculture; and
the Secretary of General Services; and

subparagraph.text: eight shall be outstanding residents appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.

paragraph.text: The term of an appointed member is 5 years.
At the end of a term, an appointed member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
Thirty days after giving written notice to the member, the Governor may remove an appointed member for inefficiency, neglect, or misconduct.
The member is entitled to a hearing before the Governor, if a written request for a hearing is made to the Governor no later than 10 days after receiving the notice.
If a member is removed, the Governor shall promptly appoint a successor.
From among its members, the Authority shall elect a chair and a vice chair.
The Authority shall elect a secretary–treasurer who need not be a member of the Authority.
The Authority shall meet at least quarterly.
At least 10 days before each meeting, written notice of the meeting shall be given to each member of the Authority.

subsection.text: Seven members of the Authority are a quorum.

paragraph.text: A majority vote of the members present at a meeting having a quorum is needed for the Authority to act.
An ex officio voting member may designate another individual to vote in that member’s absence.
The Authority may pay an appointed member up to $1,000 a year on a per diem basis for services.
A member of the Authority is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations.
Reimbursement and compensation under this subsection may only be paid from money provided under this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Authority shall adopt rules and regulations necessary for the conduct of its affairs.

section.text: The Authority may employ or retain officers, staff, and agents, including engineering, architectural, fiscal, and construction experts and attorneys, and set their compensation.

subsection.text: Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle, the Authority:

paragraph.text: is not subject to the following provisions of the State Finance and Procurement Article:

subparagraph.text: Title 2, Subtitles 4 (Water and Sewerage Systems) and 5 (Facilities for the Handicapped);
Title 4, Subtitles 7 (State Board of Architectural Review) and 8 (Energy);
§§ 5A-304 and 5A-305 (Historic Landmarks; certain architectural easements);
§ 7-114.1 (Archeological Costs);
§§ 8-127, 8-128, and 8-129 (Certain Restrictions on State General Obligation Debt);
Part V of Title 8, Subtitle 1 (State Revenue Anticipation Notes);
Title 10 (Board of Public Works - Miscellaneous Provisions); and
Division II of the State Finance and Procurement Article (General Procurement Laws); and

paragraph.text: may construct developments and projects without obtaining the consent of any other unit of State government and without any proceeding, the satisfaction of any condition, or the occurrence of any event.
In carrying out its duties relating to developments and projects, the Authority shall comply with Title 14, Subtitle 3 of the State Finance and Procurement Article (Minority Business Participation).

The Authority shall take affirmative steps to include minority businesses in its markets to at least the same extent as applicable to a procurement subject to Title 14, Subtitle 3 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

subsection.text: A development or project is subject to applicable State health laws and regulations of the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene and the Secretary of the Environment.
A development or project is subject to all zoning and subdivision regulations of the political subdivision in which the development or project is located.
The money of the Authority may be invested.
Any income from the investment of money of the Authority shall be credited to the Authority.
The Authority may:

paragraph.text: sue and be sued;
adopt a seal;
acquire, hold, and dispose of property for its corporate purposes;
sell, lease, or otherwise convey, in any manner that the Authority considers appropriate, any property it owns to accomplish the purposes of this subtitle;

enter into contracts and leases, including contracts or leases relating to the construction, operation, maintenance, management, and use of developments and projects, concessions, stalls, auction houses, docking facilities, and other facilities, and execute any instrument necessary or convenient, on the terms and for any corporate purpose that the Authority considers advisable;
issue bonds in accordance with this subtitle;

use the proceeds of the bonds, other money available under this subtitle, or any grant or money from the State or federal government or any of their units or instrumentalities to accomplish the purposes of this subtitle;
borrow money for a corporate purpose and mortgage or otherwise encumber its property as security for the loan;

accept gifts, contributions, or loans of money, supplies, goods, and services, and accept appropriations, allotments, and loans of money from the State or federal government, a federal corporation, a unit or instrumentality of the federal government, or a political subdivision or instrumentality of the State;
exercise a power usually possessed by a private corporation in performing similar functions unless to do so would conflict with State law;
dredge approaches and acquire, construct, maintain, equip, and operate wharves, docks, piers, and other structures, and any facilities necessary for commerce; and
do all things necessary or convenient to carry out the powers expressly granted by this subtitle.
Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Authority may delegate any power or duty it considers appropriate to a member, an officer, an agent, or an employee of the Authority.
A contract is not binding on the Authority unless it is approved or authorized by a majority of the members of the Authority.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, the Authority may adopt rules and regulations relating to:

paragraph.text: the use of streets, alleys, driveways, and docking slips on the Authority’s property;
the establishment of parking areas on the Authority’s property; and
the safety and welfare of persons using the Authority’s property.

subsection.text: The rules and regulations that the Authority adopts may not be inconsistent with the laws governing the political subdivision in which a development is located.
The Authority may acquire in its own name property, franchises, and licenses by:

paragraph.text: purchase on terms and conditions and in the manner the Authority considers appropriate; or
condemnation for public use in accordance with applicable law.

If the Authority considers it expedient to establish or construct a development or project on any land, street, alley, or public place that is owned by a political subdivision, the political subdivision may:

subparagraph.text: lease the land, street, alley, or public place to the Authority on terms agreed to by the Authority and the political subdivision; or

convey title to the land, street, alley, or public place to the Authority on payment to the political subdivision of the reasonable value of the property, as determined by the Authority and the political subdivision, in cash or bonds of the Authority at par.

Notwithstanding paragraph (1) of this subsection, a political subdivision may lease or convey to the Authority without consideration any property that is owned by the political subdivision and suitable for use by the Authority for the purposes of this subtitle.
A lease or conveyance under this paragraph requires approval by the political subdivision or, for Baltimore City, by the Board of Estimates.

paragraph.text: Before an acquisition under this subsection, the Authority, on request of a political subdivision, shall remove or relocate at the expense of the Authority any public utility facilities, whether publicly or privately owned or operated, located on the property.

subsection.text: The Authority may not acquire a site under this section for the establishment or construction of a development, or establish or construct a development on a site, unless the site is approved:

paragraph.text: for Baltimore City, by the Board of Estimates; and

for any other political subdivision, by the county commissioners, county executive, or in a charter county without a county executive, the county council, or in a municipal corporation, by its governing body.

subsection.text: The Authority need not accept and pay for any property or rights it acquires except from money provided under this subtitle.
The Authority may:

paragraph.text: develop, establish, acquire, improve, own, operate, and maintain developments and projects in the State; and
pay the cost of developments or projects, including improvements to any waterways at a development or project, from:

subparagraph.text: the proceeds of bonds;
other money available under this subtitle; or
money from the State or federal government or any of their units or instrumentalities.

subsection.text: Construction of a development may not begin unless a comprehensive study establishes that the construction and operation of the development would be economically and environmentally sound.
Except for the Center, construction of a development may not begin unless:

paragraph.text: an analysis of the economic benefits of the proposed development is submitted to the Legislative Policy Committee, in accordance with § 2-1246 of the State Government Article; and
the Legislative Policy Committee is given 45 days after receipt to comment on the proposal.
This subsection does not apply to facilities constructed on land leased or sold by the Authority to a private entity.
Before contracting to construct a facility at a development or project, the Authority shall solicit sealed bids.
All plans and any issue of bonds to finance a development or project require approval by the Board of Public Works by resolution before the bonds are sold.
All leases of real property and plans and contracts for the acquisition conveyance of real property require approval by the Board of Public Works.

subsection.text: The Authority may assist wholesale food dealers and tenants who want to locate or relocate their operations in a development or project if, in the judgment of the Authority:

paragraph.text: the wholesale food dealers and tenants will provide the greatest opportunity of success for a development or project; and
the cost of the assistance is the most likely to be recouped.

subsection.text: To assist a wholesale food dealer or tenant, the Authority may:

paragraph.text: acquire, by negotiation and purchase, the land, structures, equipment, or leases, or an interest in them, of the wholesale food dealer or tenant; and
pay the reasonable expenses of moving personal property that must be moved to locate or relocate the operations of the wholesale food dealer or tenant in a development or project.

subsection.text: The Authority may:

paragraph.text: fix and collect rates and charges for the use of the facilities of a development or project;
establish the terms and conditions for the use of the facilities; and
contract with a person for the person’s use of the facilities of a development or project.

subsection.text: The rates and charges under subsection (a) of this section shall be fixed and revised to provide appropriate revenues from a development or project, as the Authority determines.
The rates and charges under subsection (a) of this section are not subject to supervision or regulation by any other unit of the State or a political subdivision.

section.text: A political subdivision in which a development or project is located may:

paragraph.text: vacate any street, alley, or other public place necessary to ensure the proper operation of the development or project and the full use of its facilities; and

grant to the Authority the exclusive right to use the vacated street, alley, or other public place for the purpose of the development or project on terms agreed to by the Authority and the political subdivision.

section.text: Subject to the terms and conditions agreed to by the Authority and the State or the political subdivision, the State or a political subdivision in which a development or project is located may provide for:

paragraph.text: cleaning the development or project; and
removing and disposing of refuse from the development or project.
“Person” has the meaning stated in § 9-101 of this article.
“Person” also includes a public or quasi-public corporation.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (c) of this section, the Authority may provide financing to a person to accomplish the purposes of this subtitle:

paragraph.text: on property that is owned or otherwise held or controlled by the Authority or the State; or
on, under, or in property that is owned or otherwise held or controlled by any other person.
This subsection does not apply to an expenditure of money:

subparagraph.text: in connection with the acquisition of property or the preparation of plans;
to the employment of staff of the Authority; or
for other matters that customarily are preliminary to the commencement of construction.

paragraph.text: If the Authority provides financing to a person to accomplish the purposes of this subtitle, the Authority may not expend any bond proceeds to acquire or improve a facility until the Authority, with the approval of the Board of Public Works, has entered into a binding contract with the person.
The contract shall:

subparagraph.text: be secured to the satisfaction of the Board of Public Works; and
require the person to pay to the Authority or its designee:

sub-subparagraph.text: the principal of and interest on bonds sold under this subtitle as they become due;
any fiscal agency charges for paying principal and interest;
any charges or fees set by the Authority for its administrative costs and expenses; and
any premium on bonds retired by call or purchased as provided in this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Authority may charge to and equitably apportion between persons financed by the Authority under this section all or part of the Authority’s administrative costs and expenses incurred in exercising its powers and performing its duties under this subtitle.
If property is transferred by the Authority to a person financed under this section, the person shall pay any State and local property taxes that accrue after the transfer.
The Authority may authorize the issuance of federally tax-exempt or federally taxable revenue bonds by resolution.
The Authority may issue revenue bonds:

paragraph.text: to pay any part of the cost of developments or projects;
to fund a deficit in accordance with subsection (i) of this section;
to pay the cost of improvements of developments or projects in accordance with subsection (j) of this section;
to refund outstanding bonds issued under this subtitle; and
for any other purpose set forth in this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Authority may issue the bonds at one time or in one or more series from time to time.
The Authority shall determine:

paragraph.text: the dates of the bonds;
the maturity dates of the bonds, which may not exceed 40 years from the date of their issue;
the interest rates on the bonds;
the medium of payment of the principal of and interest on the bonds;
interest payment dates on the bonds, which shall occur twice in every 12 months;
the form of the bonds;
the manner of executing the bonds;
the denominations of the bonds; and
the places at which the principal of and interest on the bonds will be payable, including a bank or trust company in or outside the State.

subsection.text: The bonds may be redeemed before maturity at the option of the Authority at the prices and under terms and conditions that the Authority sets before the bonds are issued.
An officer’s signature or facsimile on a bond remains valid even if the officer leaves office before the bond is delivered.

paragraph.text: The Authority shall sell the bonds either by competitive or negotiated sale in a manner and for a price that the Authority determines to be in its best interests.
The bonds are exempt from §§ 8-206 and 8-208 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
Before it prepares definitive revenue bonds, the Authority may issue temporary revenue bonds meeting the requirements of this section that are exchangeable for definitive revenue bonds when issued.
The Authority may replace bonds that are mutilated, lost, or destroyed.
The Authority may issue replacement bonds or bonds exchanged for temporary revenue bonds without:

subparagraph.text: another proceeding; or
the satisfaction of any other condition.

paragraph.text: If the proceeds of the bonds are less than the amount required for the purpose for which the bonds were authorized, the Authority may issue additional bonds to fund the amount of the deficit.
Unless otherwise provided in the resolution authorizing the issuance of bonds or in the trust agreement, the additional bonds are:

subparagraph.text: considered to be of the same issue as the first issue; and
entitled to payment from the same funds as the first issue, without preference or priority of the bonds of the first issue.

paragraph.text: The resolution authorizing the issuance of bonds may provide for the issuance of additional bonds to pay the cost of any necessary improvements.
The additional bonds:

subparagraph.text: may be limited in amount by the resolution or trust agreement;
shall be considered part of the first issue authorized by the resolution; and
shall be issued under the restrictions and limitations provided by the resolution or trust agreement.

section.text: Bonds are securities:

paragraph.text: in which any of the following persons may legally and properly invest money, including capital that the person owns or controls:

subparagraph.text: an officer or unit of the State or a political subdivision;
a bank, trust company, savings and loan association, investment company, or other person conducting a banking business;
an insurance company, insurance association, or other person conducting an insurance business;
a personal representative, guardian, trustee, or other fiduciary; and
any other person; and

paragraph.text: that may be deposited with and received by a unit of the State or a political subdivision for any purpose for which the deposit of bonds or other obligations of the State is authorized by law.

subsection.text: A bond is not a debt or a pledge of the faith and credit of the State or a political subdivision, and is payable solely from development or project revenues as provided in accordance with this subtitle.

Each bond shall state on its face that the Authority, the State, and a political subdivision of the State are not obliged to pay the principal of or interest on the bond except from the development or project revenues pledged to the payment of the bond.

paragraph.text: The Authority may secure a bond by a trust agreement between the Authority and a corporate trustee.
A corporate trustee may be any trust company or bank that has the powers of a trust company in or outside the State.

subsection.text: The trust agreement or the resolution that provides for the issuance of a bond may:

paragraph.text: provide for the protection and enforcement of rights and remedies of bondholders, including covenants setting forth the duties of the Authority in relation to:

subparagraph.text: acquisition, improvement, maintenance, operation, and insurance of the development or project; and
custody, safeguarding, and application of money;

paragraph.text: provide for the rights and remedies of bondholders and of the trustee;
restrict the individual right of action by bondholders as is customary in trust agreements securing bonds of corporations;
provide for the deposit of the proceeds of the sale of bonds and the revenue of a development or project with an officer, board, or depositary that the Authority designates as custodian; and
provide for the method of disbursing the proceeds and revenues with safeguards and restrictions that the Authority determines.
Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection and § 10-222 of this subtitle, a trust agreement may pledge or assign revenues to be received from the development or project.
No portion of a development or project may be conveyed or mortgaged without the express consent of the Board of Public Works.

subsection.text: The trust agreement may authorize the use of money realized from the sale or disposition of any of the property of a development or project to pay principal of and interest on the bonds.
Expenses incurred in carrying out a trust agreement may be treated as part of the cost of maintenance, repair, and operation of a development or project.
A bank or trust company incorporated in the State may act as a depositary of the proceeds of the bonds or the revenues and furnish indemnity bonds or pledge securities as required by the Authority.
The Authority shall apply the proceeds of the bonds for the purposes for which the bonds are authorized.

paragraph.text: The Authority shall set aside a sufficient amount of the revenues derived from a development or project in a sinking fund or other similar fund at regular intervals to the extent required in the trust agreement or resolution.
The sinking fund is pledged to paying:

subparagraph.text: the principal of and the interest on the bonds as they become due; and
the redemption or purchase price of bonds retired by call or purchase as specified in the trust agreement or resolution.

subsection.text: To the extent provided in the trust agreement or resolution, the Authority may exclude from the amount to be deposited in the sinking fund the revenues that may be necessary or convenient:

paragraph.text: to pay for maintenance, repair, and operation of a development or project;
for reserves; and
for improvements to a development or project.
The lien of the pledge of revenues under subsection (b) of this section is valid and binding from the time the pledge is made.
The lien of the pledge is valid and binding against each party with a claim against the Authority in tort, contract, or otherwise, regardless of whether the party has notice of the lien.

section.text: The Authority may authorize the issuance of a single issue of revenue bonds by resolution for the combined purposes of:

paragraph.text: paying the cost of improvements of developments or projects; and
refunding bonds.

section.text: Except to the extent rights granted by this subtitle are restricted by resolution passed before the issuance of the bonds or by the trust agreement, a holder of a bond issued under this subtitle, or of any attached coupons, or a trustee under a trust agreement may sue to:

paragraph.text: protect and enforce a right under the laws of this State, the resolution, or the trust agreement; and

enforce the performance of duties by the Authority, the State, or a political subdivision or officer or any of them that this subtitle or the trust agreement requires, including fixing, charging, and collecting of rates and charges to use facilities that are subject to the resolution or trust agreement.

subsection.text: The Authority may pledge or assign:

paragraph.text: any of its revenues;
its rights to receive its revenues;
money or securities in accounts established to secure a bond; or
a lien or security interest granted or assignment made to the Authority.
A pledge or assignment under subsection (a) of this section is valid and binding from the time the pledge or assignment is made.
A lien, security interest, or assignment under subsection (a) of this section:

subparagraph.text: attaches immediately to the revenues or property pledged and then received by the Authority, without any physical delivery or further act; and
is valid and binding against any person having a claim against the Authority, regardless of whether the person has notice of the pledge, and without the recording or filing of an instrument.

subsection.text: Subject to § 10-217(e) of this subtitle, the Authority is exempt from taxation or assessments on any part of a development or project, the Authority’s activities in operating and maintaining a development or project, and revenues from a development or project.
The bonds of the Authority, including the interest on the bonds, are forever exempt from State and local taxes.
The Legislative Auditor:

paragraph.text: may conduct a fiscal and compliance audit of the accounts and transactions of the Authority yearly or every 2 years; and
shall advise officials of the Authority whether the audit will be yearly or every 2 years.

subsection.text: The Authority shall pay the cost of the fiscal part of the post audit examination.
Each year, the Authority shall submit a report to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly.
The report shall include a financial statement covering the operations of developments during the preceding fiscal year.

section.text: This subtitle may be cited as “The Maryland Food Center Authority Act”.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Authority” means the Maryland Health and Higher Educational Facilities Authority.

paragraph.text: “Bond” means a bond issued by the Authority under this subtitle.
“Bond” includes a revenue bond, a revenue refunding bond, a note, and any other obligations.

subsection.text: “Cost”, with respect to a project financed under this subtitle, includes:

paragraph.text: the purchase price of a project;
the cost to acquire any right, title, or interest in a project;
the cost of any improvement;
the cost of any property, right, easement, and franchise;
the cost of demolition, removal, or relocation of structures;
the cost of acquiring land to which the structures may be moved;
the cost of equipment;
financing charges;
interest before and during construction and, if the Authority determines, for a limited period after the completion of construction;
reserves for principal and interest and for improvements;

the cost of revenue and cost estimates, architectural, engineering, financial, and legal services, plans, specifications, studies, surveys, and other expenses necessary or incident to determining the feasibility of improving a project; and
other expenses as necessary or incident to:

subparagraph.text: financing a project;
acquiring and improving a project; and
placing a project in operation.

subsection.text: “Educational institution” means an institution of higher education or a noncollegiate educational institution.
“Finance” includes refinance.

paragraph.text: “Health care institution” means an institution in the State that is operated by a person, a local government, or, subject to paragraph (3) of this subsection, the State, is available to the public, and is:

subparagraph.text: a not–for–profit hospital as defined under § 19–301 of the Health – General Article that:

sub-subparagraph.text: is licensed as a hospital by the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene under § 19–318 of the Health – General Article; or

has obtained a certificate of need issued by the Maryland Health Care Commission under § 19–120 of the Health – General Article, but is not licensed as a hospital by the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene under § 19–318 of the Health – General Article;

subparagraph.text: a not–for–profit related institution as defined under § 19–301 of the Health – General Article that is licensed as a related institution by the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene under § 19–318 of the Health – General Article;
a combination of institutions listed in items (i) and (ii) of this paragraph;
except as provided in paragraph (3) of this subsection:

sub-subparagraph.text: a not–for–profit comprehensive health center that provides outpatient primary health services available to the general public; or
a not–for–profit life care or continuing care community that provides self–contained residence facilities for the retired or elderly;

subparagraph.text: any combination of health care entities listed in item (iv) of this paragraph;

an entity affiliated or associated with an institution listed in items (i) through (v) of this paragraph, if the Authority determines by resolution that the financing of a project for the entity serves the public purpose of that institution; or
a not–for–profit health service plan that holds a certificate of authority and provides health insurance policies or contracts in the State in accordance with the Insurance Article.

paragraph.text: “Health care institution” includes a not–for–profit corporation organized to construct or acquire an institution under paragraph (1) of this subsection.

“Health care institution” does not include a facility described in paragraph (1)(iv) of this subsection that is owned and operated by the State, except for the following facilities if approved by the Board of Public Works and the Joint Audit Committee:

subparagraph.text: a not–for–profit comprehensive health center that is a medical or health care facility of the University System of Maryland; or
a not–for–profit life care or continuing care community that provides self–contained residence facilities for the retired or elderly.

paragraph.text: For purposes of this subsection the facilities of the University of Maryland Medical System Corporation are not considered to be owned and operated by the State.

subsection.text: “Improve” means to add, alter, construct, equip, expand, extend, improve, install, reconstruct, rehabilitate, remodel, or repair.
“Improvement” means addition, alteration, construction, equipping, expansion, extension, improvement, installation, reconstruction, rehabilitation, remodeling, or repair.

paragraph.text: “Institution of higher education” means an educational institution in the State that:

subparagraph.text: by law or charter:

sub-subparagraph.text: is a public or not–for–profit educational institution; and
is authorized to provide:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: a program of education beyond the high school level and award a bachelor’s or advanced degree; or
a program of 2 or more years’ duration that is accepted for full credit toward a bachelor’s degree; and

subparagraph.text: meets the standards and regulations that the Maryland Higher Education Commission prescribes, and is authorized to issue a certificate, diploma, or degree under Title 12 of the Education Article.
