agree, not later than the date of the Authority’s bond issuance as authorized under § 10-628 of this subtitle, to pay:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: an additional $12,100,000; and
all actual acquisition and capital costs of construction of the Hippodrome Performing Arts facility to the extent the costs exceeded $60,000,000; and

sub-subparagraph.text: agree that any savings from acquisition or capital costs on completion of the Hippodrome Performing Arts facility shall be paid to the Authority.

subsection.text: The Authority shall secure a written agreement with the University System of Maryland, as approved by the Board of Public Works, under which the University System of Maryland agrees to transfer to the Authority fee title to the property known as the Hippodrome Theatre, 12 North Eutaw Street, described in the Baltimore City land records in Liber S.E.B. 6259, Folio 38.
The Authority shall secure a written agreement with an Authority affiliate, as approved by the Board of Public Works, by which the Authority affiliate agrees:

paragraph.text: to market, promote, and operate or contract, subject to the approval of the Authority, for the marketing, promotion, and operation of the Hippodrome Performing Arts facility;

to maintain and repair or contract, subject to the approval of the Authority, for the maintenance and repair of the Hippodrome Performing Arts facility so as to keep the Hippodrome Performing Arts facility in first class operating condition;

to pay to the Authority for the duration of any bonds issued as authorized under § 10-628 of this subtitle an amount equal to $2 per ticket sold for admission to the Hippodrome Performing Arts facility; and

to be solely responsible for all expenditures relating to the operation, maintenance, and repair of the Hippodrome Performing Arts facility that may be incurred, including the amount by which expenditures exceed revenues.

subsection.text: Except as allowed by § 10-639 of this subtitle, to finance site acquisition and construction of any segment of a Montgomery County Conference facility, the Authority shall comply with this section.

The Authority shall provide to the fiscal committees of the General Assembly, at least 90 days before seeking approval of the Board of Public Works for each bond issue or other borrowing, a comprehensive financing plan for the relevant segment of the facility including the effect of the financing plan on financing options for other segments of the facility.
The Authority shall obtain the approval of the Board of Public Works of the proposed bond issue and the financing plan.
The Authority shall secure a lease or other written agreement with Montgomery County, as approved by the Board of Public Works, under which:

paragraph.text: Montgomery County agrees to contribute $13,196,000 for the capital costs of construction of the Montgomery County Conference Center not later than the date of the Authority’s bond issuance as authorized under § 10-628 of this subtitle;
the Authority agrees to:

subparagraph.text: issue bonds as authorized under § 10-628 of this subtitle; and
contribute $20,304,000 of the proceeds from the sale of the bonds for the capital costs of the construction of the Montgomery County Conference Center;

paragraph.text: Montgomery County and the Authority agree that if the actual capital costs for the construction of the Montgomery County Conference Center are less than $33,500,000, the savings shall be allocated:

subparagraph.text: one-half to the Authority; and
one-half to Montgomery County;

paragraph.text: Montgomery County and the Authority agree that if the actual capital costs for the construction of the Montgomery County Conference Center are more than $33,500,000, the excess shall be shared:

subparagraph.text: one-half by the Authority; and
one-half by Montgomery County;

paragraph.text: Montgomery County agrees to purchase the land for the Montgomery County Conference site as defined in § 10-601 of this subtitle, on which the Montgomery County Conference Center will be constructed;

Montgomery County and the Authority each own a 50% leasehold interest as tenants in common in the Montgomery County Conference facility for the duration of any bonds issued as authorized under § 10-628 of this subtitle; and

Montgomery County and the Authority agree not to sell, assign, mortgage, pledge, or encumber the Montgomery County Conference facility, or any leasehold interest in the facility, without the prior consent of the other, except for liens in favor of the Authority’s bondholders.

subsection.text: The Authority shall secure a deed, lease, or written agreement with Montgomery County, as approved by the Board of Public Works, authorizing the Authority to:

paragraph.text: design, construct, and equip, or contract for the design, construction, and equipping of, the Montgomery County Conference facility; and
pledge the Montgomery County Conference facility and the Montgomery County Conference site or the leasehold interest in the facility as security for the Authority’s bonds.

subsection.text: The Authority shall secure a written agreement with Montgomery County, as approved by the Board of Public Works:

paragraph.text: in which Montgomery County agrees:

subparagraph.text: to market, promote, and operate or contract for the marketing, promotion, and operation of the Montgomery County Conference facility in a manner that maximizes the facility’s economic return to the community; and

to maintain and repair or contract for the maintenance and repair of the Montgomery County Conference facility so as to keep the Montgomery County Conference facility in first class operating condition; and

paragraph.text: that includes provisions that:

subparagraph.text: protect the respective investments of the Authority and Montgomery County in the Montgomery County Conference facility;
require Montgomery County to contribute to a capital improvement reserve fund in an amount sufficient to keep the conference center in first class operating condition;

require Montgomery County to be solely responsible for all expenditures relating to the operation of the Montgomery County Conference facilities that may be incurred, including the amount by which expenditures exceed revenues;
allow Montgomery County to keep all operating profits resulting from the operation of the Montgomery County Conference facility each year;
provide for remedies on default, including the right of the Authority, if a material default by Montgomery County is not corrected after a reasonable notice and cure period, to:

sub-subparagraph.text: immediately assume responsibility for maintenance and repairs of the Montgomery County Conference facility; and
offset the costs of the maintenance and repairs against other amounts owed by the Authority to Montgomery County, whether under the operating agreement with Montgomery County or otherwise;

subparagraph.text: authorize the Authority to select, through a cooperative procurement agreement, a contractor to develop, design, construct, operate, and manage the Montgomery County Conference facility during the period that the bonds issued by the Authority for the Montgomery County Conference facility are outstanding;
allow for the establishment of a board of directors to manage the Montgomery County Conference facility;
provide that the board of directors may include representatives of the Authority, Montgomery County, the private developer, and the community; and
provide that, unless action is taken to create a legal entity, the board of directors is not a separate legal entity.

subsection.text: The Authority shall secure an agreement among Montgomery County, the Authority, and a private developer, as approved by the Board of Public Works, that provides for:

paragraph.text: the acquisition, construction, and operation of a hotel adjacent to the Montgomery County Conference facility; and
a capital commitment from the developer for the hotel and, as appropriate, shared facilities.

subsection.text: Except as allowed by § 10–639 of this subtitle, to finance site acquisition and construction of any segment of an Ocean City Convention facility, the Authority shall comply with this section.

The Authority shall provide to the fiscal committees of the General Assembly, at least 90 days before seeking approval of the Board of Public Works for each bond issue or other borrowing, a comprehensive financing plan for the relevant segment of the facility, including the effect of the financing plan on financing options for other segments of the facility.
The Authority shall obtain the approval of the Board of Public Works of the proposed bond issue and the financing plan.
The Authority shall secure a lease or other written agreement with Ocean City, as approved by the Board of Public Works, under which:

paragraph.text: Ocean City agrees to:

subparagraph.text: issue bonds not later than the date of the Authority’s bond issuance as authorized under § 10–628 of this subtitle; and
contribute $14,700,000 of the proceeds from the sale of the bonds for the capital costs of the expansion of the Ocean City Convention Center;

paragraph.text: the Authority agrees to:

subparagraph.text: issue bonds as authorized under § 10–628 of this subtitle; and
contribute $14,700,000 of the proceeds from the sale of the bonds for the capital costs of the expansion of the Ocean City Convention Center;

paragraph.text: Ocean City and the Authority agree that if the actual capital costs of the expansion of the Ocean City Convention Center are less than $29,400,000, the savings shall be allocated:

subparagraph.text: one–half to the Authority; and
one–half to Ocean City;

paragraph.text: Ocean City agrees to provide the Ocean City Convention site, as defined in § 10–601 of this subtitle, for the expansion and renovation of the Ocean City Convention facility;

Ocean City and the Authority shall each own a 50% leasehold interest as tenants in common in the improvements comprising the existing Ocean City Convention Center and the Ocean City Convention Center expansion for the duration of any bonds issued as authorized under § 10–628 of this subtitle and for 20 years thereafter; and

Ocean City and the Authority agree not to sell, assign, mortgage, pledge, or encumber the Ocean City Convention facility, or any leasehold interest in the facility, without the prior consent of the other, except for liens in favor of their respective bondholders.

subsection.text: The Authority shall secure a deed, lease, or written agreement with Ocean City, as approved by the Board of Public Works, authorizing the Authority to:

paragraph.text: design, construct, and equip, or contract for the design, construction, and equipping of the Ocean City Convention facility expansion; and
pledge the Ocean City Convention facility and the Ocean City Convention site or the leasehold interest in the facility as security for the Authority’s bonds.
The Authority shall secure a written agreement with Ocean City, as approved by the Board of Public Works:

subparagraph.text: in which Ocean City agrees to:

sub-subparagraph.text: subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, market, promote, and operate the Ocean City Convention facility in a manner that maximizes the facility’s economic return;
maintain and repair the facility so as to keep it in first class operating condition; and
be solely responsible for all operating deficits and capital improvements:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: before the completion of the expanded and renovated Ocean City Convention facility; and
20 years after the repayment of the Ocean City Convention facility bonds issued by the Authority; and

subparagraph.text: that includes provisions that:

sub-subparagraph.text: protect the respective investment of the Authority and Ocean City;
require:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: the Authority to contribute one–half and Ocean City to contribute one–half to operating deficits; and

the Authority and Ocean City each to contribute $50,000 each year to a capital improvement reserve fund, for the period beginning on the completion of the expanded and renovated Ocean City Convention facility and continuing during the period that the Ocean City Convention facility bonds issued by the Authority are outstanding and for 20 years thereafter; and

sub-subparagraph.text: provide for remedies on default, including the right of the Authority, if a material default by Ocean City is not corrected after a reasonable notice and cure period, to:

sub-sub-subparagraph.text: immediately assume responsibility for maintenance and repairs of the Ocean City Convention facility; and
offset the costs of the maintenance and repairs against other amounts owed by the Authority to Ocean City, whether under the operating agreement with Ocean City or otherwise.

paragraph.text: Paragraph (1)(i)1 of this subsection may not be construed to require gambling activities in the Ocean City Convention facility.

subsection.text: Except as allowed by § 10-639 of this subtitle, to finance acquisition and construction of any segment of a sports facility, the Authority shall comply with this section.
The Authority shall provide certification to the Legislative Policy Committee and the Board of Public Works, supported by a detailed report, that the Authority has attempted:

paragraph.text: to maximize private investment in the sports facility proposed to be financed; and
with respect to a baseball or football stadium, to maximize the State’s ability to ensure that the professional baseball and football franchises will remain permanently in the State.

subsection.text: The Authority shall provide to the fiscal committees of the General Assembly, at least 90 days before seeking approval of the Board of Public Works for each bond issue or other borrowing, a comprehensive financing plan for the relevant segment of the facility, including the effect of the financing plan on financing options for other segments of the facility and anticipated revenues from private investment.
The Authority shall obtain the approval of the Board of Public Works of the proposed bond issue and the financing plan.
The Authority shall secure, as approved by the Board of Public Works:

paragraph.text: with respect to site acquisition and the construction of a baseball stadium, a long-term lease for a major league professional baseball team; or
subject to § 10-617 of this subtitle, with respect to site acquisition and the construction of a football stadium:

subparagraph.text: a franchise for a National Football League team; and
a long-term lease that includes a provision requiring the football team that leases the stadium to agree to reimburse the Authority:

sub-subparagraph.text: for $24,000,000 in stadium construction costs, including the construction, fitting out, and furnishing of the private suites that are part of the football stadium; and
on the terms and conditions determined by the Authority.

section.text: A financial institution, investment company, insurance company or association, or a personal representative, guardian, trustee, or other fiduciary, may legally invest any money belonging to it or within its control in any bonds issued by the Authority.

subsection.text: The Authority is exempt from any requirement to pay taxes or assessments of any kind.
The principal of and interest on bonds, and any income derived from the bonds, including profits made in their sale or transfer, are forever exempt from all State and local taxes.
There is a Baltimore Convention Financing Fund.

paragraph.text: The Baltimore Convention Fund is a continuing, nonlapsing fund that shall be available in perpetuity to implement this subtitle concerning Baltimore Convention facilities.
The Authority shall:

subparagraph.text: use the Baltimore Convention Fund as a revolving fund for carrying out this subtitle concerning Baltimore Convention facilities; and
pay any and all expenses from the Baltimore Convention Fund that are incurred by the Authority related to the Baltimore Convention facility.

paragraph.text: To the extent considered appropriate by the Authority, the receipts of the Baltimore Convention Fund shall be pledged to and charged with the following relating to the Baltimore Convention facility:

subparagraph.text: the payment of debt service on Authority bonds;
all reasonable charges and expenses related to Authority borrowing; and
the management of Authority obligations.

paragraph.text: The pledge shall be effective as provided in § 10–634 of this subtitle and any applicable Authority resolution.

subsection.text: The Baltimore Convention Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: funds appropriated for deposit to the Baltimore Convention Fund;
proceeds from the sale of bonds concerning the Baltimore Convention facility;
revenues collected or received from any source under this subtitle related to Baltimore Convention facilities; and
any additional money made available from any public or private sources for the purposes established for the Baltimore Convention Fund.
The Treasurer shall invest the money of the Baltimore Convention Fund in the same manner as other State funds.
Any investment earnings shall be credited to the Baltimore Convention Fund.
No part of the Baltimore Convention Fund may revert or be credited to the General Fund or any special fund of the State.

subsection.text: There is a Camden Yards Financing Fund.

paragraph.text: use the Camden Yards Fund as a nonlapsing, revolving fund for implementing this subtitle concerning sports facilities and other facilities at Camden Yards;
pay all expenses and make all expenditures related to Camden Yards facilities from the Camden Yards Fund; and

transfer the sum of $24,000,000 to the Public School Construction Fund established under § 7–326 of the State Finance and Procurement Article by making an annual payment of $2,400,000 beginning in fiscal year 2001 and ending in fiscal year 2010.
To the extent considered appropriate by the Authority, the receipts of the Camden Yards Fund shall be pledged to and charged with the following relating to sports facilities:

subparagraph.text: the payment of debt service on Authority bonds;
all reasonable charges and expenses related to Authority borrowing; and
the management of Authority obligations.

paragraph.text: The pledge shall be effective as provided in § 10–634 of this subtitle and any applicable Authority resolution.

subsection.text: The Camden Yards Fund consists of:

paragraph.text: proceeds from the sale of bonds related to sports facilities;
revenues collected or received from any source under this subtitle related to Camden Yards facilities;
any other revenues related to Camden Yards facilities, under the jurisdiction of the Authority;
admissions and amusement tax revenues distributed to the Authority under the Tax – General Article;
any additional revenue, gift, donation, or other funding source authorized by law related to Camden Yards facilities; and
payments by Baltimore City under subsection (f) of this section.
The Treasurer shall invest the money of the Camden Yards Fund in the same manner as State funds.
Any investment earnings shall be credited to the Camden Yards Fund.
No part of the Camden Yards Fund may revert to or be credited to the General Fund or any special fund of the State.

subsection.text: Baltimore City shall pay $1,000,000 each year into the Camden Yards Fund for the purposes of debt service and other forms of obligation by the Authority.

section.text: This subtitle may be cited as the Maryland Stadium Authority Act.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the Board of Trustees of the Maryland Venture Capital Trust.
“Investor” means a person or governmental entity that invests money in the Maryland Venture Capital Trust.

paragraph.text: “Seed capital financing” means financing provided to a business during the initial stages of its development.
“Seed capital financing” includes financing for a business:

subparagraph.text: to finish research and development of a product;
to develop marketing plans; and
to provide for initial facilities, inventory, and working capital.

subsection.text: “Trust” means the Maryland Venture Capital Trust.
“Venture capital fund” means an investment fund that provides capital to a business at any stage of its development before the business makes a public offering of stock.
The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: small businesses are a major source of new jobs and innovations in the State;
the State’s research capacity could spur innovation in new and existing businesses to create and maintain jobs in the State; and
an inadequate supply of seed capital financing and venture capital funds has limited the commercialization of research and development in the State.

subsection.text: The General Assembly intends for the Trust to:

paragraph.text: help fill the gap in the State’s economy caused by the inadequate supply of seed capital financing and venture capital funds; and
stimulate the commercialization of research and development to create and sustain businesses throughout the State.

section.text: This subtitle shall be liberally construed to accomplish its purposes.

subsection.text: There is a Maryland Venture Capital Trust.
The Trust is a body politic and corporate and is an instrumentality of the State.
There is a Board of Trustees of the Trust.

paragraph.text: The Board consists of seven members appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate.
Of the seven members:

subparagraph.text: four shall represent the investors and have been recommended to the Governor by the investors;
at least one shall have expertise in venture capital financing; and
at least one shall have experience as a small business owner.

paragraph.text: Each member shall be a resident of the State.
The Governor shall consider geographic diversity of the State when appointing members of the Board.
The term of a member is 4 years.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on October 1, 2008.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
The Governor may remove a member with or without cause.

subsection.text: The Governor shall appoint a chair from among the Board members.

paragraph.text: A majority of the members then serving on the Board is a quorum.
A majority vote of the members present at a meeting having a quorum is needed for the Board to act.

subsection.text: A member of the Board:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Board; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

subsection.text: The Board:

paragraph.text: shall manage the Trust; and
exercises all of the corporate powers of the Trust.

subsection.text: The Trust is:

paragraph.text: exempt from the General Procurement Law provisions of Division II of the State Finance and Procurement Article; but
subject to Title 12, Subtitle 4 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

subsection.text: The Trust is exempt from the provisions of Division I of the State Personnel and Pensions Article that govern the State Personnel Management System.
The Trust may:

paragraph.text: solicit and accept for investment in the Trust money from any source including not more than $2,000,000 in appropriations from the State;
enter into agreements with the investors that set forth the terms governing the investment of money in the Trust by the investors;

by preparing and publishing requests for proposals, solicit offerings by venture capitalists and venture capital funds that meet the purposes and requirements of the Trust, which shall be set forth in the requests for proposals;
subject to § 10-708 of this subtitle, select the venture capital funds in which to invest money from the Trust;
retain investment earnings that exceed the investment earnings that the Trust must pay to investors; and
take any action necessary to carry out the powers expressly granted by this subtitle.
The Trust may not accept a cumulative investment of more than $15,000,000 from the State Retirement and Pension System.
The Trust may not accept a cumulative investment of more than $5,000,000 from any other single investor.

section.text: The Board shall give preference to venture capital fund proposals that:

paragraph.text: provide financing predominately to businesses that conduct a substantial amount of business in the State;
require venture capital funds to match the money invested by the Trust with money invested by private investors on at least a 1 to 3 ratio; and
ensure that a majority of the money that the Trust invests is for seed capital financing in the State.

section.text: Seed capital financing may not exceed $1,000,000 for a single business.
A debt, claim, obligation, or liability of the Trust is not a debt, claim, obligation, or liability of the State or a unit or instrumentality of the State or a pledge of the State’s credit.
The Trust is exempt from taxation by the State and local governments.

subsection.text: Each year, an independent auditor approved by the State shall audit the books and records of the Trust.
At its discretion, the State may audit the books and records of the Trust.
The Trust shall pay the expense of an audit conducted under this section.

On or before October 1 of each year, the Trust shall submit a report to the Governor, the Maryland Economic Development Commission, and, subject to § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly.
The report shall include a complete operating and financial statement covering the operations of the Trust and summarize the activities of the Trust for the preceding fiscal year.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Administration” means the Maryland Energy Administration.
“Board” means the Board of Directors of the Center.

paragraph.text: “Bond” means a bond issued by the Center under this subtitle.
“Bond” includes a revenue bond, a revenue refunding bond, a note, and any other obligation, whether a general or limited obligation of the Center.

subsection.text: “Center” means the Maryland Clean Energy Center.
“Clean energy” includes:

paragraph.text: solar photovoltaic technology;
solar heating;
geothermal;
wind;
biofuels;
ethanol;
other qualifying biomass as defined in § 7–701 of the Public Utilities Article;
ocean, including energy from waves, tides, currents, and thermal differences;
a fuel cell that produces energy from biofuels, ethanol, or other qualifying biomass;
energy efficiency and conservation;

any other technology or service that the Center determines will contribute directly or indirectly to the production of energy from renewable or sustainable sources, or to the improvement of efficiency in the use of energy; and
deployment of any of the technologies or services listed in items (1) through (11) of this subsection.

subsection.text: “Cost”, with respect to a project financed under this subtitle, includes:

paragraph.text: the purchase price of a project;
the cost to acquire any right, title, or interest in a project;
the cost of any improvement;
the cost of any property, right, easement, and franchise;
the cost of demolition, removal, or relocation of structures;
the cost of acquiring land to which the structures may be moved;
the cost of equipment;
financing charges;
interest before and during construction and, if the Center determines, for a limited period after the completion of construction;
reserves for principal and interest and for improvements;

the cost of revenue and cost estimates, architectural, engineering, financial, and legal services, plans, specifications, studies, surveys, and other expenses necessary or incident to determining the feasibility of improving a project; and
other expenses as necessary or incident to:

subparagraph.text: financing a project;
acquiring and improving a project; and
placing a project in operation.

subsection.text: “Director” means the Director of the Administration.
“Executive Director” means the Executive Director of the Maryland Clean Energy Center.
“Finance” includes refinance.
“Governmental unit” means:

paragraph.text: a county;
a municipal corporation;
a State unit;
a local unit; or
any other public body or unit established in accordance with a State or local law, ordinance, or resolution.

subsection.text: “Improve” means to add, alter, construct, equip, expand, extend, improve, install, reconstruct, rehabilitate, remodel, or repair.
“Improvement” means addition, alteration, construction, equipping, expansion, extension, improvement, installation, reconstruction, rehabilitation, remodeling, or repair.

paragraph.text: “Project” means any property, the acquisition or improvement of which the Board, in its sole discretion, determines by resolution will accomplish at least one of the purposes listed in § 10–802(b) of this subtitle, whether or not the property:

subparagraph.text: is or will be used or operated for profit or not for profit;
is or will be located on a single site or multiple sites; or
may be financed by bonds, the interest on which is exempt from income taxation under federal law.

paragraph.text: “Project” includes:

subparagraph.text: land or an interest in land;
structures, equipment, furnishings, rail or motor vehicles, barges, and boats;
property and rights related to property, appurtenances, rights–of–way, franchises, and easements;
property that is functionally related and subordinate to a project; and
patents, licenses, and other rights necessary or useful in the improvement or operation of a project.

paragraph.text: “Revenues” means the income, revenue, and other money the Center receives from or in connection with a project, and all other income of the Center.
“Revenues” includes grants, rentals, rates, fees, and charges for the use of the services furnished or available.
“Trust agreement” means an agreement entered into by the Center to secure a bond.
“Trust agreement” may include a bond contract, bond resolution, or other contract with or for the benefit of a bondholder.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: the United States as a whole, and the State in particular, are facing increased energy costs based on many factors, including rising fuel costs, limited investment in generation and transmission facilities, and a complex combination of market–based and other regulatory mechanisms that balance environmental, economic, health, and welfare interests;

continued exclusive reliance on traditional forms of electricity supply entrenches the State’s dependence on fossil fuels, working against the State’s policy of decreasing greenhouse gas production, as evidenced by the State’s accession to the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative;

“clean energy”, a broad term that includes a wide and varied mixture of strategies and techniques to produce useful energy from renewable and sustainable sources in a manner that minimizes fossil fuel use and harmful emissions, and to increase the efficient use of energy derived from all sources, offers many different opportunities for residents of the State to succeed in entrepreneurial and other commercial activity, to the overall economic and environmental benefit of the entire State, as measured in improved air and water quality, moderated energy expenditures, and increased State and local tax receipts;

many individuals and businesses in the State possess talents and interest in the clean energy technology sector, which may form the basis for encouraging development and deployment of sustainable and renewable energy technologies in the State, the nation, and the world;

the State will benefit from a targeted effort to establish and incubate clean energy industries in the State, including financial assistance, information sharing, and technical support for entrepreneurs in the manufacture and installation of clean energy technology; and

it is in the public interest to establish a public corporation to undertake the tasks of promoting clean energy industries in the State, developing incubators for those industries, providing financial assistance, and also providing information sharing and technical assistance.

subsection.text: The purposes of this subtitle are to:

paragraph.text: encourage the development of clean energy industries in the State;
encourage the deployment of clean energy technologies in the State;
help retain and attract business activity and commerce in the clean energy technology industry sector in the State;
promote economic development; and
promote the health, safety, and welfare of residents of the State.

subsection.text: The General Assembly intends that:

paragraph.text: the Center operate and exercise its corporate powers in all areas of the State;

without limiting its authority to otherwise exercise its corporate powers, the Center exercise its corporate powers to assist governmental units and State and local economic development agencies to contribute to the expansion, modernization, and retention of existing enterprises in the State as well as the attraction of new business to the State;
the Center cooperate with private industries and local governments in maximizing new economic opportunities for residents of the State; and
the Center accomplish at least one of the purposes listed in subsection (b) of this section and complement existing State marketing and financial assistance programs by:

subparagraph.text: owning projects;
leasing projects to other persons; or
lending the proceeds of bonds to other persons to finance the costs of acquiring or improving projects that the persons own or will own.

subsection.text: This subtitle shall be liberally construed to carry out its purposes.
This subtitle may not be construed to limit or restrict the duties, programs, or authority of the Maryland Energy Administration.
There is a Maryland Clean Energy Center.
The Center is a body politic and corporate and is an instrumentality of the State.
The exercise by the Center of the powers conferred by this subtitle is the performance of an essential governmental function.
The purposes of the Center are to:

paragraph.text: promote economic development and jobs in the clean energy industry sector in the State;
promote the deployment of clean energy technology in the State;
serve as an incubator for the development of clean energy industry in the State;
collect, analyze, and disseminate industry data; and
provide outreach and technical support to further the clean energy industry in the State.

subsection.text: The Center shall coordinate with the Maryland Energy Administration and may not duplicate the programs or activities of the Administration without consent of the Administration.
A Board of Directors shall manage the Center and exercise its corporate powers.
The Board consists of the following nine members:

paragraph.text: the Director, or the Director’s designee; and
eight members appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate:

subparagraph.text: two representing the not–for–profit clean energy research sector of the State;
two with expertise in venture capital financing;
two representing clean energy industries in the State; and
two members of the general public.

subsection.text: A member of the Board shall reside in the State.
In making appointments to the Board, the Governor shall consider:

paragraph.text: diversity; and
all geographic regions of the State.

subsection.text: A member of the Board:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Board; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.
The term of an appointed member is 4 years and begins on July 1.
The terms of the appointed members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members on October 1, 2008.
At the end of a term, an appointed member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: The Governor may remove an appointed member for incompetence, misconduct, or failure to perform the duties of the position.

section.text: From among its members, the Board shall elect a chair, a vice chair, and a treasurer.

subsection.text: The Board shall determine the times and places of its meetings.

paragraph.text: A majority of the appointed and qualified members of the Board is a quorum.
The Board may act with an affirmative vote of a majority of the appointed and qualified members of the Board.
The Board shall establish an Advisory Committee.
The Advisory Committee consists of individuals that the Board considers will assist the Center in studying and developing policies to further the purposes of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Board may establish other committees as appropriate.

paragraph.text: The membership of a committee may include individuals who are not Board members.
The Board may establish the term and manner of selection of the membership of a committee.
Subject to the approval of the Governor, the Board shall appoint an Executive Director.
The Executive Director serves at the pleasure of the Board.
The Board shall determine the salary of the Executive Director.
The Executive Director is the chief administrative officer of the Center.
The Executive Director shall manage the administrative affairs and technical activities of the Center in accordance with policies and procedures that the Board establishes.

subsection.text: The Executive Director, or the Executive Director’s designee, shall:

paragraph.text: attend all meetings of the Board;
act as secretary to the Board;
keep minutes of all proceedings of the Board;
approve all salaries, per diem payments, and allowable expenses of the Center, its employees, and its consultants;
approve any expenses incidental to the operation of the Center; and
perform the other duties that the Board directs in carrying out this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Attorney General is the legal advisor to the Center.
With the approval of the Attorney General, the Center may retain any necessary lawyers.

section.text: The Center may retain any necessary accountants, engineers, financial advisors, or other consultants.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsections (b), (c), and (e) of this section, the Center is exempt from:

paragraph.text: Title 10 and Division II of the State Finance and Procurement Article; and
§§ 10–505 and 10–507 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: The Center is subject to the Public Information Act.
The Board and the officers and employees of the Center are subject to the Public Ethics Law.
The officers and employees of the Center are not subject to the provisions of Division I of the State Personnel and Pensions Article that govern the State Personnel Management System.
The Center, its Board, and employees are subject to Title 12, Subtitle 4 and Title 14, Subtitle 3 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.

The Center is a public body under Title 5, Subtitle 4 of this article, the Maryland Industrial Development Financing Authority Act, for purposes of applying for, receiving, and making agreements in connection with:

paragraph.text: a loan;
a grant;
insurance; or
any other form of financial assistance.

section.text: A finding by the Board concerning the public purpose of an action, the legislative intent expressed under this subtitle, or the appropriateness of the action in serving the public purpose and satisfying the legislative intent is conclusive in a proceeding that involves the validity or enforceability of:

paragraph.text: an agreement entered into by the Center under this subtitle;
a bond; or
any security relating to a bond.

subsection.text: The Center shall establish a system of financial accounting, controls, audits, and reports.
The fiscal year of the Center begins on July 1 and ends on the following June 30.
The Center may create and administer the accounts that it requires.
The Center shall deposit its money into a State or national bank or a federally insured savings and loan association that has a total paid–in capital of at least $1,000,000.
The Center may designate the trust department of a State bank, national bank, or savings and loan association as a depository to receive securities that the Center owns or acquires.

Unless an agreement or covenant between the Center and the holders of its obligations limits classes of investments, the Center may invest its money in bonds or other obligations of, or guaranteed as to principal and interest by, the United States, the State, or a governmental unit.

paragraph.text: The Executive Director and each other officer authorized by the Center may:

subparagraph.text: allow copies to be made of the minutes and records of the Center; and
certify records under seal showing that the copies are true copies.

paragraph.text: A person may rely on the certified record.

subsection.text: The records of the Center are public records subject to reasonable inspection.

section.text: The Center may:

paragraph.text: adopt bylaws for the conduct of its business;
adopt a seal;
maintain offices at a place it designates in the State;
accept loans, grants, or assistance of any kind from the federal or State government, a local government, a college or university, or a private source;
enter into contracts and other legal instruments;
sue or be sued;
acquire, purchase, hold, lease as lessee, and use:

subparagraph.text: a franchise, patent, or license;
any real, personal, mixed, tangible, or intangible property; or
an interest in the property listed in this item;

paragraph.text: sell, lease as lessor, transfer, license, assign, or dispose of property or a property interest that it acquires;
fix and collect rates, rentals, fees, royalties, and charges for services and resources it provides or makes available;
create, own, control, or be a member of a corporation, limited liability company, partnership, or other entity, whether operated for profit or not for profit;
exercise power usually possessed by a private corporation in performing similar functions unless to do so would conflict with State law; and
do all things necessary or convenient to carry out the powers granted by this subtitle.

section.text: The Center may make grants to or provide equity investment financing for clean energy technology–based businesses.
The Center may:

paragraph.text: acquire, develop, improve, manage, market, license, sublicense, maintain, lease as lessor or lessee, or operate a project in the State to carry out its purposes;

acquire, directly or indirectly, from a person or governmental unit, by purchase, gift, or devise any property, rights–of–way, franchises, easements, or other interests in land, including submerged land and riparian rights:

subparagraph.text: as necessary or convenient to improve or operate a project to carry out its purposes; and
on the terms and at the prices that it considers reasonable; and

paragraph.text: enter into a project with a manufacturer to carry out its purposes.

section.text: The Center may:

paragraph.text: borrow money and issue bonds to finance any part of the cost of a project or for any other corporate purpose of the Center;
secure the payment of any portion of the borrowing by pledge of or mortgage or deed of trust on property or revenues of the Center;

combine projects for financing, make agreements with or for the benefit of the bondholders or with others in connection with the issuance or future issuance of bonds, as the Center considers advisable; and
otherwise provide for the security of bonds and the rights of bondholders.

subsection.text: The Center shall serve as a clearinghouse for information and materials that may be pertinent to clean energy technology, education, and deployment in the State, for persons engaged in the clean energy industry as developers, manufacturers, and installers, as well as for consumers and financial institutions, including information on available federal, State, and private financial assistance and technical assistance.
The Center may:

paragraph.text: cooperate with and provide assistance to local governments, instrumentalities, and research entities in the State; and

coordinate clean energy technology development, education, and deployment activities with programs of the federal government and of governmental units and public and private entities in and outside the State.

section.text: The Center is exempt from State and local taxes.
The books and records of the Center are subject to audit:

paragraph.text: at any time by the State; and
each year by an independent auditor that the Office of Legislative Audits approves.

subsection.text: On or before October 1 of each year, the Center shall report to the Governor, the Administration, and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly.
The report shall include a complete operating and financial statement covering the Center’s operations and a summary of the Center’s activities during the preceding fiscal year.
In this part the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Financial assistance” means a grant, loan, credit enhancement, or similar assistance.
“Program” means the Maryland Clean Energy Technology Incubator Program.
There is a Maryland Clean Energy Technology Incubator Program.
The Center shall administer the Program.

section.text: The purpose of the Program is to promote entrepreneurship and the creation of jobs in clean energy technology–related industry by establishing and operating effective incubators throughout the State that provide adequate physical space designed, and programs intended, to increase or accelerate business success in the field of clean energy technology.

subsection.text: To carry out the purposes of the Program, the Center shall award financial assistance under this part.
The Center shall consult with the Administration, the Department, and other appropriate governmental units in the development of the Program.

section.text: The Center may award financial assistance using money provided by the federal government, the State, a governmental unit, or any person.

subsection.text: After consulting with the Director, the Center shall adopt standards to award financial assistance.
The standards shall authorize the award of financial assistance to:

paragraph.text: support the development and use of best practices in the incubation process;
provide strategic planning, needs assessments, and feasibility studies; or
help acquire or improve new or expanded space or improve existing space for an incubator, including providing or helping another with:

subparagraph.text: acquisition of land;
acquisition of architectural or engineering services;
payment of administrative costs;
development or upgrading of communications infrastructure;
acquisition of furnishings or equipment; or
acquisition of other items associated with tenant build–out.

section.text: The Center may award financial assistance to:

paragraph.text: a local government;
an agency, instrumentality, or not–for–profit corporation that the local government designates;
a public or private college or university;
the Maryland Economic Development Corporation; or
a not–for–profit entity operating an incubator in the State.

subsection.text: A recipient of financial assistance under § 10–834(b)(3) of this subtitle shall provide matching funds or in–kind contributions for the project at least equal to the financial assistance awarded.
The Center may waive the requirement of subsection (a) of this section for good cause shown.

section.text: Unless two–thirds of the membership of the Board approve, the Center may not award financial assistance within a single county under § 10–834(b)(3) of this subtitle that exceeds a total of $1,000,000 in a single fiscal year.

paragraph.text: The Center may periodically:

subparagraph.text: issue bonds for any corporate purpose, including operating expenses;
refund those bonds;
purchase its bonds with any funds available; and
hold, pledge, cancel, or resell bonds.

paragraph.text: By resolution, the Board may authorize the chair, vice chair, one of its members, or a committee of its members to determine, provide for, or approve any matters relating to bonds that the Board considers appropriate including:

subparagraph.text: specifying, determining, prescribing, and approving matters, documents, and procedures that relate to the authorization, sale, security, issuance, delivery, and payment of and for the bonds;
creating security for the bonds;
providing for the administration of bond issues; and
taking other actions it considers appropriate concerning the bonds.

paragraph.text: The power granted in paragraph (2) of this subsection is in addition to powers conferred on the Board by this subtitle and does not limit any power of the Board under this subtitle.

subparagraph.text: Subject to subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, the Board may authorize the Executive Director to take any of the actions described in paragraph (2) of this subsection.

If the Board authorizes the Executive Director to take any of the actions described in paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Board shall prescribe limits within which the Executive Director may exercise discretion.

paragraph.text: Except as otherwise provided by the Center, each issue of its bonds is a general obligation of the Center payable from any revenues or moneys of the Center that are available and not otherwise pledged.
The provisions of paragraph (1) of this subsection are subject to any agreements with:

subparagraph.text: holders of particular bonds pledging any particular revenues or moneys; and
any participating institution.

subsection.text: For each issue of its bonds, the Center shall pass a resolution that:

paragraph.text: specifies and describes the project for which the proceeds of the bond issuance are intended;
generally describes the public purpose and the financing transaction to be accomplished;
specifies the maximum principal amount of the bonds that may be issued by the Center; and
imposes any terms or conditions on the issuance and sale of the bonds that the Center considers appropriate.

subsection.text: Subject to any provision for their registration, bonds are negotiable instruments for all purposes regardless of whether they are payable from a special fund.

paragraph.text: The bonds may be:

subparagraph.text: serial bonds;
term bonds; or
both in the discretion of the Center.

paragraph.text: Subject to any delegation under subsection (a)(2) of this section, the resolution authorizing bonds may provide:

subparagraph.text: the dates of the bonds;
the maturity dates of the bonds;
the interest rates on the bonds;
the time at which the bonds will be payable;
the denominations of the bonds;
whether the bonds will be in a coupon or registered form;
any registration privileges of the bonds;
the manner of execution of the bonds;
the place at which the bonds will be payable; and
any terms of redemption of the bonds.

paragraph.text: The bonds shall mature within a period not to exceed 50 years after their date.
The bonds shall be payable in United States currency.

subsection.text: The bonds may be sold by competitive or negotiated sale at a price determined by the Center.
Pending preparation of the definitive bonds, the Center may issue interim receipts or certificates that will be exchanged for definitive bonds.

paragraph.text: A trust agreement authorizing bonds may contain provisions that are part of the contract with the bondholders.
The provisions may include:

subparagraph.text: pledging the following to secure payment of bonds, subject to any existing agreements with bondholders:

sub-subparagraph.text: the full faith and credit of the Center;
the full faith and credit of a participating institution;
revenues of a project;
a revenue–producing contract the Center has made with a person or public entity; or
the proceeds of the sale of bonds;

subparagraph.text: the rentals, fees, and other charges, the amounts to be raised in each year, and the use and disposition of the revenues;
the setting aside of reserves and sinking funds and their disposition;
limits on the right of the Center or its agents to restrict and regulate the use of a project;
limits on the purpose to which the proceeds of sale of bonds may be applied;
limits on issuing additional bonds, the terms under which additional bonds may be issued and secured, and refunding outstanding bonds;
the procedure to amend or abrogate the terms of a contract with bondholders and the requirements for consent;
limits on the amount of project revenues to be expended for operating, administrative, or other expenses of the Center;
the acts or omissions that constitute default by the Center and the rights and remedies of the bondholders in the event of a default;
the conveyance or mortgaging of a project and its site to secure the bondholders; and
creation and disposition of a collateral fund, instead of conveyance or mortgage, for the purpose of securing the bondholders.

subsection.text: The members of the Board and a person executing the bonds may not be held liable personally on the bonds.
The Center may secure bonds by a trust agreement.
The corporate trustee under a trust agreement may be a trust company or a bank that has the powers of a trust company in or outside the State.
In addition to the provisions described in § 10–840(h) of this subtitle, the trust agreement may contain:

paragraph.text: either:

subparagraph.text: a provision conveying or mortgaging all or a portion of the project; or
a provision creating a collateral account;

paragraph.text: other provisions that the Center considers reasonable and proper for the security of bondholders; and
a provision that restricts the individual right of action by bondholders.

subsection.text: An expense incurred in carrying out the trust agreement or a resolution may be treated as part of the cost of the operation of a project.

section.text: Bonds are securities:

paragraph.text: in which any of the following persons may legally and properly invest money, including capital that the person owns or controls:

subparagraph.text: an officer or unit of the State or a political subdivision;
a bank, trust company, savings and loan association, investment company, or other person conducting a banking business;
an insurance company, insurance association, or other person conducting an insurance business;
a personal representative, guardian, trustee, or other fiduciary; and
any other person; and

paragraph.text: that may be deposited with and received by a unit of the State or a political subdivision for any purpose for which the deposit of bonds or obligations of the State is authorized by law.

subsection.text: A bond:

paragraph.text: is not:

subparagraph.text: a debt or liability of the State or a political subdivision of the State; or
a pledge of the faith and credit of the State or a political subdivision of the State; and

paragraph.text: is payable solely from money available in accordance with this subtitle.

subsection.text: Each bond shall state on its face that:

paragraph.text: the State and its political subdivisions are not obliged to pay the bond or the interest on the bond except from revenues of the project or the portion of the project for which the bond is issued; and
the faith, credit, and taxing power of the State and its political subdivisions are not pledged to pay the principal of or the interest on the bond.

subsection.text: The issuance of bonds does not directly, indirectly, or contingently obligate the State or its political subdivisions:

paragraph.text: to levy or pledge a tax to pay the bonds; or
to make an appropriation to pay the bonds.

subsection.text: This section does not prevent the Center from pledging its full faith and credit to pay bonds.
The Center may:

paragraph.text: fix and collect rates, rents, fees, and charges for the use of a project and for the services furnished or to be furnished by a project; and
contract with a person or governmental entity to exercise its authority under this section.

subsection.text: The rates, rents, fees, and charges established by the Center under this section shall be fixed and adjusted so that the aggregate amount of the rates, rents, fees, and charges from the project, when added to other available money, is sufficient to:

paragraph.text: pay for maintaining, repairing, and operating the project;
pay the principal of and the interest on the bonds that the Center issued for the project as they become due and payable; and
create and maintain reserves required or provided for in a trust agreement.

subsection.text: The rates, rents, fees, and charges established by the Center under this section are not subject to supervision or regulation by any unit of the State other than the Center.

paragraph.text: Any pledge of revenues and other money under § 10–840(h) of this subtitle is valid and binding from the time the pledge is made.

subparagraph.text: The revenue or money that the Center pledges and receives is subject immediately to the lien of the pledge.
Neither physical delivery of the revenue or money nor any other act is required to validate the lien.

paragraph.text: The lien of the pledge is valid and binding against each party with a claim against the Center in tort, contract, or otherwise, regardless of whether the party has notice of the lien.

subsection.text: The trust agreement and any other agreement or lease creating a pledge under this section need not be filed or recorded, except in the records of the Center.
Proceeds from the sale of bonds and other revenues received under this subtitle are trust funds to be held and applied solely as provided in this subtitle.

paragraph.text: Each officer, bank, or trust company that receives money from the Center under this subtitle shall act as trustee of the money and shall hold and apply the money for the purposes specified under this subtitle.
The officer, bank, or trust company holding money is subject to:

subparagraph.text: any regulation adopted under this subtitle; and
the trust agreement securing the bonds.

paragraph.text: The Center may issue bonds to refund outstanding bonds of the Center, including paying:

subparagraph.text: any redemption premium;
interest accrued or to accrue to the date of redemption, purchase, or maturity of the bonds; and
if considered advisable by the Center, any part of the cost of acquiring or improving a project.

paragraph.text: Refunding bonds may be issued for any corporate purpose, including:

subparagraph.text: realizing savings in the effective costs of debt service, directly or through a debt restructuring; or
alleviating a potential or actual default.

subsection.text: A refunding bond that the Center issues under this section shall be issued in the same manner and is subject to this subtitle to the same extent as any other bond.

paragraph.text: The Center may issue refunding bonds in one or more series in an amount greater than the amount of the bonds to be refunded.

subparagraph.text: In addition to other sources of payment that the Center determines, refunding bonds may be payable from escrowed bond proceeds and earnings and profits on investments.
Escrowed bond proceeds and earnings and profits on investments used under subparagraph (i) of this paragraph constitute revenues of a project under this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Center may issue negotiable bond anticipation notes in anticipation of the sale of bonds for any corporate purpose.
Bond anticipation notes issued under this section shall be issued in the same manner as bonds.
Bond anticipation notes issued under this section and the resolution authorizing them may contain any provisions, conditions, or limitations that may be included in a trust agreement.
The Center may issue bond anticipation notes to pay any other bond anticipation notes.
Bond anticipation notes shall be paid from:

paragraph.text: revenues of the Center;
money available and not otherwise pledged; or
the proceeds of the sale of the bonds in anticipation of which the notes were issued.

subsection.text: The Center shall convey title to a project and release collateral in accordance with this section when the following conditions are met:

subparagraph.text: the principal of and interest on bonds issued to finance the project, including any refunding bonds, have been fully paid and retired; or
adequate provision has been made to fully pay and retire the bonds;

paragraph.text: all other conditions of the trust agreement have been satisfied; and
the lien of the trust agreement has been released.

subsection.text: On satisfaction of the conditions under subsection (a) of this section, the Center promptly shall execute any deeds, conveyances, releases, and documents and take any other action necessary to convey title to the project to the participating institution and release collateral free of all liens and encumbrances created through the Center.
A bondholder, a holder of any coupons attached to bonds, or a trustee under a trust agreement securing the bonds may sue to:

paragraph.text: protect and enforce rights under the laws of the State or a trust agreement; and

enforce and compel the performance of duties by the Center or its officer, employee, or agent that this subtitle or a trust agreement requires, including fixing and collecting rates, rents, fees, and charges that the trust agreement requires.

subsection.text: The rights under this section are subject to any trust agreement.
The Center, its agent, or its lessee is not required to pay a tax or assessment on:

paragraph.text: a project or property that it acquires or uses under this subtitle; or
the income from that project or property.

subsection.text: The principal of and interest on bonds, the transfer of bonds, and any income derived from the bonds, including profits made in their sale or transfer, are forever exempt from all State and local taxes.

section.text: This subtitle may be cited as the “Maryland Clean Energy Center Act”.
In this subtitle, “Council” means the Maryland Military Installation Council.
There is a Maryland Military Installation Council.

subsection.text: The Council consists of the following members:

paragraph.text: three members selected by the President of the Senate of Maryland to represent community interests, of which:

subparagraph.text: one shall be a member of the Senate; and
two shall be citizens representing communities adjacent to military installations;

paragraph.text: three members selected by the Speaker of the House of Delegates to represent community interests, of which:

subparagraph.text: one shall be a member of the House of Delegates; and
two shall be citizens representing communities adjacent to military installations;

paragraph.text: the Secretary, or the designee of the Secretary;
the Secretary of Transportation, or the designee of the Secretary of Transportation;
the Secretary of the Environment, or the designee of the Secretary of the Environment;
the Secretary of Planning, or the designee of the Secretary of Planning;
the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, or the designee of the Secretary of Veterans Affairs;
the Adjutant General of the Maryland National Guard, or the designee of the Adjutant General;
the President of the Southern Maryland Navy Alliance;
the President of the Army Alliance;
the President of the Indian Head Defense Alliance;
the President of the Maritime Alliance;
the President of the Fort Detrick Alliance;
the President of the Fort Meade Alliance;
the President of the Andrews Business and Community Alliance; and
five members selected by the Governor.
The President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Delegates shall each appoint three members representing community interests to serve as members of the Council.
The chair may appoint:

subparagraph.text: additional members who are presidents of other military base advocacy groups that are not–for–profit organizations and recognized by the Department; and
ex officio members as necessary to address specific issues, including a representative of the Maryland National Guard.

paragraph.text: The term of an appointed member is 4 years.
The terms of the appointed members are staggered as required by the terms provided for appointed members of the Council on July 1, 2010.

subsection.text: A member of the Council:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Council; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, as provided in the State budget.

section.text: The Governor shall designate the chair of the Council.
The Department shall provide staff support to the Council.
The Council shall make reasonable efforts to:

paragraph.text: identify the public infrastructure and other community support necessary to improve the mission efficiencies and for the development and expansion of existing military installations in the State;
identify the existing and potential impacts of encroachment on military installations in the State;
identify potential State and community actions that may minimize the impacts of encroachment and enhance the long–term potential of military installations;

identify opportunities for collaboration among military contractors, local governments, the State, academic institutions, and military departments to enhance the economic potential of military installations and the economic benefits of military installations to the State;
review State policies, including funding and legislation, to identify actions necessary to provide State and local government support to the mission of each military installation in the State; and

research how other jurisdictions have addressed the issues regarding encroachment and partnership formation, with an emphasis on the most recent edition of the joint publication of the National Governors Association Center for Best Practices and the United States Department of Defense entitled “Practical Guide to Compatible Civilian Development Near Military Installations”.

section.text: On or before December 31 of each year, the Council shall report its findings and recommendations to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

paragraph.text: “Authority” means a corporation incorporated in accordance with this subtitle to act as a local redevelopment authority in accordance with criteria set by the United States Department of Defense or its military services under the federal Defense Base Closure and Realignment Act of 1990.
“Authority” does not include:

subparagraph.text: Bainbridge Development Corporation;
Holabird Working Group/Baltimore Development Corporation (BDC); or
PenMar Development Corporation.

subsection.text: “Board” means the Board of Directors of an authority.

paragraph.text: “Bond” means a bond or note issued on behalf of an authority under this subtitle.
“Bond” includes:

subparagraph.text: a bond anticipation note;
a revenue anticipation note;
a grant anticipation note;
a refunding bond;
a note in the nature of commercial paper; and
any other evidence of indebtedness issued on behalf of the authority, whether a general or limited obligation of the authority.

subsection.text: “Cost” includes:

paragraph.text: the purchase price of a project;
the cost to acquire any right, title, or interest in a project;
the amount to be paid to discharge each obligation necessary or desirable to vest title to any part of a project in the authority or other owner;
the cost of any improvement;
the cost of any property, right, easement, franchise, and permit;
the cost of labor and equipment;
financing charges;
interest before and during construction and, if the authority determines, for a limited period after the completion of construction;
reserves for principal and interest and for improvements;

the cost of revenue estimates, engineering and legal services, plans, designs, specifications, surveys, investigations, demonstrations, studies, estimates of cost, and other expenses necessary or incident to determining the feasibility of an acquisition or improvement;
administrative expenses; and
other expenses necessary or incident to:

subparagraph.text: financing a project;
acquiring and improving a project;
placing a project in operation, including reasonable provision for working capital; and
operating and maintaining a project.

subsection.text: “Finance” includes refinance.
“Improve” means to add, alter, construct, equip, expand, extend, improve, install, reconstruct, rehabilitate, remodel, or repair.
“Improvement” means addition, alteration, construction, equipping, expansion, extension, improvement, installation, reconstruction, rehabilitation, remodeling, or repair.

paragraph.text: “Person” has the meaning stated in § 9-101 of this article.
“Person” also includes a political subdivision.

“Project” means an undertaking to establish economic activity under this subtitle on property to be conveyed to an authority by the United States Department of Defense or a military service, whether or not a facility or property used or useful in connection with the undertaking:

subparagraph.text: is or will be used for profit or not for profit;
is located on a single site or multiple sites; or
may be financed by bonds, the interest on which is exempt from taxation under federal law.

paragraph.text: “Project” includes:

subparagraph.text: property and rights related to the property, appurtenances, rights-of-way, franchises, and easements;
structures, equipment, and furnishings;
property that is functionally related and subordinate to the project; and
patents, licenses, and other rights necessary or useful in the improvement or operation of a project.

paragraph.text: “Revenues” means the income, revenue, and other money an authority receives from or in connection with a project.
“Revenues” includes grants, rentals, rates, fees, and charges for the use of the services furnished or available.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: the economy of the State and its local governments will be greatly impacted by the closure or realignment of any military installation through any base realignment or closing action;
although a closure or realignment will result in economic contraction and dislocation, it also affords opportunities to expand productive employment and expand the State’s economy and tax base;
for this reason, the General Assembly enacted the Maryland Military Installation Strategic Planning Council Act; and
the establishment of State–chartered public corporations to develop military installations slated for closure or realignment in the State would:

subparagraph.text: serve the public interest;
complement existing State marketing programs administered by the Department through:

sub-subparagraph.text: its Division of Business Development; and
financial assistance programs such as those of the Maryland Economic Development Assistance Authority and Fund and the Maryland Industrial Development Financing Authority; and

subparagraph.text: serve as an additional means to achieve the mission of the Maryland Military Installation Council.

subsection.text: The General Assembly intends that:

paragraph.text: an authority structure its projects to accelerate the transfer of facilities and sites from the federal government into productive reuse of the facilities and sites to maximize economic opportunities for the residents of the State; and

this subtitle be a template for the structure, authorization, and operation of each authority accepted by the Office of Economic Adjustment of the United States Department of Defense to perform the tasks required when land is transferred from the federal government to an authority in accordance with the federal Defense Base Closure and Realignment Act of 1990.

section.text: This subtitle is self-executing and fully authorizes the Secretary to create a local redevelopment authority.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall execute and file proposed articles of incorporation of an authority with the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.
The proposed articles of incorporation shall state:

paragraph.text: the name of the authority;
that the authority is formed under this subtitle;
the names, addresses, and terms of office of the first members of the Board of the authority;
the location of the principal office of the authority;
the purposes for which the authority is formed; and
the powers of the authority, subject to the restrictions or limitations on the powers of the authority under this subtitle.

subsection.text: Acceptance of the articles for record by the State Department of Assessments and Taxation is conclusive evidence of the formation of the authority.

paragraph.text: The Board may amend the articles of incorporation.
Any amendment to the articles of incorporation shall be filed with the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.

subsection.text: An authority is a body politic and corporate and is an instrumentality of the State once the State Department of Assessments and Taxation accepts the articles of incorporation for record.
The exercise by an authority of a power under this subtitle is the performance of an essential governmental function.
A Board of Directors shall manage the affairs of the authority and exercise all of the powers of the authority.
The Board consists of the following members:

paragraph.text: as ex officio members:

subparagraph.text: the Secretary, or the designee of the Secretary;
the Secretary of General Services, or the designee of the Secretary of General Services;
the Secretary of Planning, or the designee of the Secretary of Planning; and
the president of the military alliance of each county in which the facility is located;

if the facility is located in one county, the executive director, or equivalent officer, of the county economic development unit and two other members appointed by the governing body of the county in which the facility is located; or

if the facility is located in more than one county, the executive director, or equivalent officer, of the economic development unit of each county and one other member appointed by the governing body of each county; and

paragraph.text: as nonvoting, ex officio members:

subparagraph.text: the Executive Director of the Maryland Economic Development Corporation;
the Executive Director of the authority; and
the Director of Transitional Services of the State Department of Human Resources.

paragraph.text: The term of a member of the Board appointed under subsection (b)(2) of this section is 4 years.
The terms of appointed members shall be staggered.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed.

section.text: From among its members, the Board shall elect a chair, a vice chair, and a treasurer.
A majority of the voting Board members serving at the time is a quorum.

paragraph.text: The Board shall establish a finance committee.
The treasurer of the Board chairs the finance committee and oversees the finances of the authority.
The Board may establish other committees as appropriate.
The membership of a committee may include individuals who are not Board members.
The Board shall appoint the Executive Director of the authority.
The Executive Director serves at the pleasure of the Board.
The Board shall determine the salary of the Executive Director.
The Executive Director is the chief operating officer of the authority.
The Executive Director shall manage the administrative affairs and technical activities of the authority in accordance with policies and procedures that the Board establishes.

subsection.text: The Executive Director shall:

paragraph.text: attend all meetings of the Board;
act as secretary to the Board;
keep minutes of the proceedings of the Board;
approve salaries, per diem payments, allowable expenses of the authority and its employees or consultants, and any expenses incidental to the operation of the authority; and
perform the other duties that the Board directs in carrying out this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Board shall approve additional professional and clerical staff as necessary to carry out this subtitle.
The Board may retain accountants, engineers, lawyers, financial advisors, or other consultants as necessary to carry out this subtitle.
Except as otherwise provided in this section, in exercising its corporate powers, the authority:

paragraph.text: may carry out its corporate purposes without obtaining the consent of any State unit; and
is not subject to the following provisions of the State Finance and Procurement Article:

subparagraph.text: Title 2, Subtitles 2 (Gifts and Grants), 4 (Facsimile Signatures and Seals), and 5 (Facilities for Handicapped);
Title 3 (Budget and Management);
Title 4 (Department of General Services);
Title 6, Subtitle 1 (Revenues: Studies and Estimates);
Title 7, Subtitles 1 (State Operating Budget), 2 (Disbursements and Expenditures), and 3 (Unspent Balances);
Title 8, Subtitle 1 (General Obligation Debt);
Title 10 (Board of Public Works - Miscellaneous Provisions); and
Division II (General Procurement Law).

paragraph.text: The authority and its committees are subject to the Open Meetings Act.
The authority is subject to the Public Information Act.

subsection.text: The officers and employees of the authority are subject to the Maryland Public Ethics Law.
The officers and employees of the authority are not subject to:

paragraph.text: Division II of the State Personnel and Pensions Article; or
the provisions of Division I of the State Personnel and Pensions Article that govern the State Personnel Management System.

subsection.text: The authority is subject to the same State and local regulations and regulatory requirements as any private corporation.
A project of the authority is subject to the zoning and subdivision regulations of the political subdivision where the project is located.
The authority shall establish a system of financial accounting, controls, audits, and reports.
The fiscal year of the authority begins on July 1 and ends on the following June 30.
The authority may establish any accounts that it requires.
The authority shall deposit its money into a State or national bank or a federally insured savings and loan association in the State that has a total paid-in capital of at least $1,000,000.
The authority may designate the trust department of a State or national bank or of a savings and loan association as a depository to receive securities that the authority owns or acquires.

Unless an agreement limits classes of investments, the authority may invest its money in bonds or other obligations of, or guaranteed as to principal and interest by, the United States, a unit of the United States, the State, or a political subdivision of the State.

section.text: The authority may:

paragraph.text: adopt bylaws for the conduct of its business;
adopt a seal;
maintain offices in the State;
