accept loans, grants, or assistance of any kind from the federal or State government, a local government, or a private source;
enter into contracts and other legal instruments;
sue and be sued in its own name;

acquire, purchase, hold, lease as lessee, and use any franchise, patent, or license and real, personal, mixed, tangible, or intangible property, or any interest in property, necessary or convenient to carry out its purposes;
sell, lease as lessor, transfer, and dispose of its property or interest in property;
fix and collect rates, rentals, fees, and charges for services and facilities the authority provides or makes available;
with the owner’s permission, enter land, waters, or premises to make a survey, sounding, boring, or examination to accomplish a purpose authorized by this subtitle;

exercise a power usually possessed by a private corporation in performing similar functions, unless to do so would conflict with State law or unless the action or decision of the authority would impose liability on the State or any county; and
do all things necessary or convenient to carry out the powers expressly granted by this subtitle.

section.text: The authority may:

paragraph.text: acquire, improve, develop, manage, market, lease as lessor or lessee, operate, and maintain a project; and

acquire, either directly or by or through an agreement with the United States Department of Defense or a military service, by purchase or otherwise, any property, rights, rights-of-way, franchises, easements, and other interests in land, including land lying under water and riparian rights located in or outside the State as necessary or convenient to improve or operate a project on terms and at prices that the authority considers to be reasonable.

section.text: The authority may:

paragraph.text: borrow money to finance costs of a project or for any other corporate purpose of the authority;
mortgage or otherwise encumber its property or revenues for the loan; and
combine projects for financing.

section.text: To carry out this subtitle, the Maryland Economic Development Corporation may issue bonds from time to time on behalf of the authority to finance costs of a project.
An obligation of the authority is not a debt, liability, or pledge of the full faith and credit of the State or any county.

subsection.text: The authority may:

paragraph.text: lend or otherwise make available its net revenue to finance costs of a project; and
enter into a financing agreement, mortgage, or other instrument that it determines is necessary or desirable to evidence or secure the loan.

subsection.text: A lease of property of the authority may require or authorize the lessee or another person, on conveyance of the property to the authority, to purchase or otherwise acquire the property for consideration that the authority establishes.
The authority may:

paragraph.text: fix and collect rates or charges for its services;
establish the terms and conditions for the services; and
contract with a person for the provision of the services of the authority.

subsection.text: The rates or charges of the authority are not subject to supervision or regulation by any other unit of the State or by a political subdivision of the State.
Subject to any agreement, the authority may apply its revenues to any lawful purpose.

Except as necessary to pay an obligation or to implement programs of the authority, the net revenue of the authority may not benefit a person other than the county or counties in which the facility is located.

Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the authority is exempt from any requirement to pay any taxes or assessments on its properties, activities, or any revenue from its properties or activities.
Property that the authority sells or leases to a private entity is subject to State and local property taxes from the time of the sale or lease.

paragraph.text: As soon as practical after the close of the fiscal year, an independent certified public accountant shall audit the financial books, records, and accounts of the authority.
The finance committee of the authority shall select an accountant to conduct the audit who:

subparagraph.text: is licensed to practice accountancy in the State;
is experienced and qualified in the accounting and auditing of public bodies; and
does not have a direct or indirect interest in the fiscal affairs of the authority.

Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, the accountant shall report the results of the audit, including the accountant’s unqualified opinion on the presentation of the financial position and the results of the financial operations of the authority.

If the accountant cannot express an unqualified opinion, the accountant shall explain in detail the reasons for the qualifications, disclaimers, or opinions, including recommendations of changes that could make future unqualified opinions possible.

subsection.text: The State may audit the books, records, and accounts of the authority.
On or before October 1 of each year, the authority shall submit a report to:

paragraph.text: the Governor;
the governing body of each county in which the facility is located;
the Department; and
in accordance with § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly.

subsection.text: The report shall include a complete operating and financial statement and a summary of the activities of the authority during the preceding fiscal year.

section.text: This subtitle may be cited as the Maryland Local Military Installation Redevelopment Authority Act.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the Board of Directors of the Corporation.

paragraph.text: “Bond” means a bond or note issued on behalf of the Corporation.
“Bond” includes:

subparagraph.text: a bond anticipation note;
a revenue anticipation note;
a grant anticipation note;
a refunding bond;
a note in the nature of commercial paper; and
any other evidence of indebtedness issued on behalf of the Corporation, whether a general or limited obligation of the Corporation.

subsection.text: “Corporation” means the Bainbridge Development Corporation.
“Cost” includes:

paragraph.text: the purchase price of a project;
the cost to acquire any right, title, or interest in a project;
the amount to be paid to discharge each obligation necessary or desirable to vest title to any part of a project in the Corporation or other owner;
the cost of any improvement;
the cost of any property, right, easement, franchise, and permit;
the cost of labor and equipment;
financing charges;
interest before and during construction and, if the Corporation determines, for a limited period after the completion of construction;
reserves for principal and interest and for improvements;

the cost of revenue estimates, engineering and legal services, plans, designs, specifications, surveys, investigations, demonstrations, studies, estimates of cost, and other expenses necessary or incident to determining the feasibility of an acquisition or improvement of a project;
administrative expenses; and
other expenses necessary or incident to:

subparagraph.text: financing a project;
acquiring, improving, and marketing a project;
placing a project in operation, including reasonable provision for working capital; and
operating and maintaining a project.

subsection.text: “County Commissioners” means the Board of County Commissioners of Cecil County.
“Finance” includes refinance.
“Improve” means to add, alter, construct, equip, expand, extend, improve, install, reconstruct, rehabilitate, remodel, or repair.
“Improvement” means addition, alteration, construction, equipping, expansion, extension, improvement, installation, reconstruction, rehabilitation, remodeling, or repair.

paragraph.text: “Person” has the meaning stated in § 9-101 of this article.
“Person” also includes a political subdivision.

“Project” means an undertaking to establish economic activity on property conveyed to the Corporation known as the Bainbridge Naval Training Center, including the historic Tome School for Boys, at Port Deposit, Maryland, whether or not a facility or property used or useful in connection with the undertaking may be financed by bonds, the interest on which is exempt from taxation under federal law.
“Project” includes:

subparagraph.text: property and rights related to the property, appurtenances, rights-of-way, franchises, and easements;
infrastructure, equipment, and furnishings;
property that is functionally related and subordinate to a project; and
patents, licenses, and other rights necessary or useful in the construction or operation of a project.

paragraph.text: “Revenues” means:

subparagraph.text: the income, revenue, and other money the Corporation receives from or in connection with a project; and
all other income of the Corporation.

paragraph.text: “Revenues” includes grants, rentals, rates, fees, and charges for the use of services furnished or available.

subsection.text: There is a Bainbridge Development Corporation.
The Corporation is a body politic and corporate and is an instrumentality of the State.
The exercise by the Corporation of a power under this subtitle is the performance of an essential governmental function.
A Board of Directors shall manage the affairs of the Corporation and exercise all of the powers of the Corporation.
The Board consists of the following 15 members:

paragraph.text: eight members appointed by the County Commissioners as follows:

subparagraph.text: two members recommended by the Mayor and Town Council of Port Deposit;
two members recommended by the State legislative delegation of Cecil County; and
four members at large;

paragraph.text: the Director of the Cecil County Department of Economic Development; and
six nonvoting ex officio members as follows:

subparagraph.text: the Secretary, or the designee of the Secretary;
the Secretary of General Services, or the designee of the Secretary of General Services;
the Executive Director of the Maryland Economic Development Corporation;
the Director of the Maryland Historical Trust;
the President of the County Commissioners; and
the Mayor of Port Deposit.

paragraph.text: The term of a member of the Board appointed under subsection (b)(1) of this section is 4 years.
The terms of appointed members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Board on October 1, 2008.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed.

section.text: From among its members, the Board shall elect a chair, a vice chair, and a treasurer.

subsection.text: Five members of the Board are a quorum.
An affirmative vote of at least five members is needed for the Board to act.

paragraph.text: Subject to the approval of the County Commissioners, the Board shall appoint an Executive Director.
The Executive Director serves at the pleasure of the Board.
The Board shall determine the salary of the Executive Director.
The Executive Director is the chief administrative officer of the Corporation.
The Executive Director shall manage the administrative affairs and technical activities of the Corporation in accordance with policies and procedures that the Board establishes.

subsection.text: The Executive Director, or the Executive Director’s designee, shall:

paragraph.text: attend all meetings of the Board;
act as secretary to the Board;
keep minutes of the proceedings of the Board;
approve salaries, per diem payments, allowable expenses of the Corporation and its employees or consultants, and any expenses incidental to the operation of the Corporation; and
perform the other duties that the Board directs in carrying out this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Board shall approve additional professional and clerical staff as necessary to carry out this subtitle.
The Board may retain accountants, engineers, lawyers, financial advisors, or other consultants as necessary to carry out this subtitle.
Except as otherwise provided in this section, in exercising its corporate powers, the Corporation:

paragraph.text: may carry out its corporate purposes without obtaining the consent of any other State unit; and
is not subject to:

subparagraph.text: the following provisions of the State Government Article:

sub-subparagraph.text: §§ 10–505 and 10–507 (Open Meetings); and
Title 11 (Consolidated Procedures for Development Permits); and

subparagraph.text: the following provisions of the State Finance and Procurement Article:

sub-subparagraph.text: Title 2, Subtitles 2 (Gifts and Grants), 4 (Facsimile Signatures and Seals), and 5 (Facilities for Handicapped);
Title 3 (Budget and Management);
Title 4 (Department of General Services);
§ 5A–304 (Maryland Historical Trust Property Acquisition);
Title 6, Subtitle 1 (Revenues: Studies and Estimates);
Title 7, Subtitles 1 (State Operating Budget), 2 (Disbursements and Expenditures), and 3 (Unspent Balances);
Title 8, Subtitle 1 (General Obligation Debt);
Title 10 (Board of Public Works – Miscellaneous Provisions); and
Division II (General Procurement Law).

subsection.text: The Corporation is subject to the Public Information Act.
The officers and employees of the Corporation are subject to the Maryland Public Ethics Law.
The officers and employees of the Corporation are not subject to:

paragraph.text: Division II of the State Personnel and Pensions Article; or
the provisions of Division I of the State Personnel and Pensions Article that govern the State Personnel Management System.

subsection.text: The Corporation is subject to the same State and local regulatory requirements as any private corporation.
A project of the Corporation is subject to the zoning and subdivision regulations of the political subdivision where the project is located.
The Corporation shall establish a system of financial accounting, controls, audits, and reports.
The fiscal year of the Corporation begins on July 1 and ends on the following June 30.
The Corporation may establish any accounts that it requires.
The Corporation shall deposit its money into a State or national bank or a federally insured savings and loan association in the State that has a total paid-in capital of at least $1,000,000.
The Corporation may designate the trust department of a State or national bank or of a savings and loan association as a depository to receive securities that the Corporation owns or acquires.

Unless an agreement limits classes of investments, the Corporation may invest its money in bonds or other obligations of, or guaranteed as to principal and interest by, the United States, the State, or a unit or political subdivision of the State.

section.text: The Corporation may:

paragraph.text: adopt bylaws for the conduct of its business;
adopt a seal;
maintain an office at the Bainbridge Naval Training Center;
accept loans, grants, or assistance of any kind from the federal or State government, a local government, or a private source;
enter into contracts and other legal instruments;
sue and be sued in its own name;

acquire, purchase, hold, lease as lessee, and use any franchise, patent, or license and real, personal, mixed, tangible, or intangible property, or any interest in property, necessary or convenient to carry out its purposes;
sell, lease as lessor, transfer, and dispose of its property or interest in property;
fix and collect rates, rentals, fees, and charges for services and facilities it provides or makes available;
with the owner’s permission, enter land, waters, or premises to make a survey, sounding, boring, or examination to accomplish a purpose authorized by this subtitle;
exercise a power usually possessed by a private corporation in performing similar functions, unless to do so would conflict with State law; and
do all things necessary or convenient to carry out the powers expressly granted by this subtitle.

section.text: The Corporation may:

paragraph.text: acquire, improve, develop, manage, market, lease as lessor or lessee, operate, and maintain any project at the Bainbridge Naval Training Center; and

acquire, either directly or by or through an agreement with the United States Navy, by purchase, gift, or devise, any property, rights, rights-of-way, franchises, easements, and other interests in land, including land lying under water and riparian rights located in or outside the State as necessary or convenient to improve or operate a project on terms and at prices that the Corporation considers reasonable.

section.text: The Corporation may:

paragraph.text: borrow money to finance costs of a project or for any other corporate purpose of the Corporation;
secure the payment of the borrowing by pledge of or mortgage or deed of trust on property or revenues of the Corporation; and
combine projects for financing.

section.text: To carry out this subtitle, the Maryland Economic Development Corporation may issue bonds from time to time on behalf of the Bainbridge Development Corporation to finance costs of a project.
An obligation of the Corporation is not a debt, liability, or pledge of the full faith and credit of the State.
The Corporation may:

paragraph.text: lend or otherwise make available its net revenue to finance costs of a project; and
enter into a financing agreement, mortgage, or other instrument that it determines is necessary or desirable to evidence or secure the loan.

subsection.text: The Corporation may:

paragraph.text: fix and collect rates or charges for its services;
establish the terms and conditions for the services; and
contract with a person for the provision of the services of the Corporation.

subsection.text: The rates or charges of the Corporation are not subject to supervision or regulation by any other unit of the State or by a political subdivision of the State.
Subject to any agreement, the Corporation may apply its revenues to any lawful purpose.
Except as necessary to pay an obligation or to implement programs of the Corporation, the net revenue of the Corporation may not benefit a person other than Cecil County.

Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the Corporation is exempt from any requirement to pay any taxes or assessments on its properties, activities, or any revenue from its properties or activities.
Property that the Corporation sells or leases to a private entity is subject to State and local property taxes from the time of the sale or lease.
The Board shall establish a Bainbridge Development Advisory Board.
The Advisory Board consists of:

paragraph.text: a representative of the County Commissioners;
the State legislative delegation of Cecil County;
a representative of the Mayor of Port Deposit;
a representative of the Town Council of Port Deposit;
the President of Cecil Community College;
the Superintendent of the Cecil County Public Schools;
the Coordinator of the Lower Susquehanna Heritage Greenway; and
other individuals the Board of Directors selects.
As soon as practical after the close of the fiscal year, an independent certified public accountant shall audit the financial books, records, and accounts of the Corporation.
The Corporation shall select an accountant to conduct the audit who:

subparagraph.text: is licensed to practice accountancy in the State;
is experienced and qualified in the accounting and auditing of public bodies; and
does not have a direct or indirect personal interest in the fiscal affairs of the Corporation.

Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, the accountant shall report the results of the audit, including the accountant’s unqualified opinion on the presentation of the financial position and the results of the financial operations of the Corporation.

If the accountant cannot express an unqualified opinion, the accountant shall explain in detail the reasons for the qualifications, disclaimers, or opinions, including recommendations of changes that could make future unqualified opinions possible.

subsection.text: The State may audit the books, records, and accounts of the Corporation.
On or before October 1 of each year, the Corporation shall submit a report to:

paragraph.text: the Governor;
the County Commissioners;
the Department; and
in accordance with § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly.

subsection.text: The report shall include a complete operating and financial statement covering the operations of the Corporation during the preceding fiscal year and a summary of the activities of the Corporation during the preceding fiscal year.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds that establishing a State public corporation to develop Fort Ritchie would:

paragraph.text: serve the public interest; and
complement existing State marketing programs administered by the Department through:

subparagraph.text: its Division of Business Development; and
financial assistance programs such as those of the Maryland Economic Development Assistance Authority and Fund and the Maryland Industrial Development Financing Authority.

subsection.text: To further the purposes of this subtitle, the General Assembly intends that the Corporation:

paragraph.text: structure its projects in a manner that accelerates the transfer of facilities and sites into productive use in the private sector; and
cooperate with the County Commissioners in maximizing new economic opportunities for the residents of the State.

In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Authority” means an industrial development authority established in accordance with § 12-105 of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: “Bond” means a revenue bond, note, or other instrument, certificate, or evidence of obligation that is issued and sold by a public body under this subtitle to finance a facility or to refund an outstanding bond.
“Bond” includes:

subparagraph.text: a bond anticipation note; and
a note in the nature of commercial paper.

subsection.text: “Chief executive” means the president, chair, mayor, county executive, or any other chief executive officer of a public body.

“Facility” means any land or an interest in land, structure, working capital, equipment, or other property, or any combination of them, the acquisition or improvement of which the legislative body of a county or municipal corporation, the board of directors of an authority, or the Maryland Industrial Development Financing Authority, in its sole discretion, determines by resolution will accomplish one or more of the legislative purposes listed in § 12-103(b) of this subtitle.

“Facility applicant” means a person, public or private corporation, or other entity, whether for-profit or not-for-profit, that, by letter of intent or similar agreement with a public body, requests the public body to participate in financing a facility under this subtitle for use by a facility user.

paragraph.text: “Facility user” means a person, public or private corporation, or other entity, whether for-profit or not-for-profit, that owns, leases, or uses all or part of a facility.
“Facility user” may include a facility applicant.

subsection.text: “Finance” includes refinance.

paragraph.text: “Finance board” means a unit or instrumentality of a county or municipal corporation that is authorized by statute or charter to issue and sell bonds of the county or municipal corporation.
“Finance board” does not include the legislative body of a county or municipal corporation.

subsection.text: “Improve” means to add, alter, construct, equip, expand, extend, improve, install, reconstruct, rehabilitate, remodel, or repair.
“Improvement” means addition, alteration, construction, equipping, expansion, extension, improvement, installation, reconstruction, rehabilitation, remodeling, or repair.
“Public body” means:

paragraph.text: a county;
a municipal corporation;
an authority; or
the Maryland Industrial Development Financing Authority.
“Public port” means the public ports and harbors on the Chesapeake Bay or the Isle of Wight Bay and their tributaries in the State.
“Public port” includes:

subparagraph.text: the Baltimore Harbor (the Patapsco River and its tributaries north and west of North Point and Bodkin Point);
the Port of Cambridge (the south side of the Choptank River between Hambrook’s Bar and the Emerson C. Harrington Bridge); and
the Port of Crisfield (the Little Annemessex River east of James Island).

subsection.text: This subtitle shall be liberally construed to accomplish its purposes.
A facility is not a capital project of a public body within the meaning of any statutory or charter provision.
This subtitle does not authorize a county or municipal corporation to acquire a facility by eminent domain.
The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: conditions of unemployment exist in many areas of the State;
the acquisition and improvement of facilities are essential to relieve this unemployment and to establish a balanced economy in the State;

the present and prospective health, happiness, safety, right of gainful employment, and general welfare of the residents of the State will be promoted by the acquisition and improvement of facilities;
the control or abatement of pollution of the environment of the State, including noise pollution, is necessary to:

subparagraph.text: retain existing industry and commerce in and attract new industry and commerce to the State;
protect the health, welfare, and safety of the residents of the State;
protect the natural resources of the State; and
encourage the economic development of the State; and
the public ports of the State are assets of value to the entire State;
the residents of the entire State benefit directly from the waterborne commerce that the public ports attract and service; and
any improvement of public ports that increases their export and import commerce will benefit the residents of the entire State.

subsection.text: The legislative purposes of this subtitle are to:

paragraph.text: relieve conditions of unemployment in the State;
encourage the increase of industry and commerce and a balanced economy in the State;

assist in the retention of existing industry and commerce in, and the attraction of new industry and commerce to, the State through, among other things, the development of ports, the control or abatement of environmental pollution, and the use and disposal of waste;
promote economic development;
protect natural resources and encourage resource recovery; and
promote the health, welfare, and safety of the residents of the State.

section.text: It is the policy of the State to allow the exercise of the powers granted by this subtitle even though the activities authorized may displace or limit free economic competition.

subsection.text: To accomplish one or more of the legislative purposes listed in § 12-103(b) of this subtitle, the legislative body of a county or municipal corporation may adopt a resolution to create an industrial development authority in accordance with this subtitle.
A resolution adopted under subsection (a), (f), or (g) of this section:

paragraph.text: is administrative in nature;
is not subject to referendum; and
in a county or municipal corporation that has a publicly elected chief executive, is subject to approval by the chief executive.

subsection.text: Subsection (a) of this section is self-executing and fully authorizes a county or municipal corporation to establish an authority, notwithstanding any other statutory or charter provision.
A resolution adopted under subsection (a) of this section shall include proposed articles of incorporation of the authority that state:

paragraph.text: the name of the authority, which shall be “Industrial Development Authority of (name of the incorporating county or municipal corporation)”;
that the authority is formed under this subtitle;
the names, addresses, and terms of office of the initial members of the board of directors of the authority;
the address of the principal office of the authority;
the purposes for which the authority is formed; and
the powers of the authority subject to the limitations on the powers of an authority under this subtitle.

The chief executive of the incorporating county or municipal corporation, or any other official designated in the resolution establishing the authority, shall execute and file the articles of incorporation of the authority for record with the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.

When the State Department of Assessments and Taxation accepts the articles of incorporation for record, the authority becomes a body politic and corporate and an instrumentality of the incorporating county or municipal corporation.
Acceptance of the articles of incorporation for record by the State Department of Assessments and Taxation is conclusive evidence of the formation of the authority.
By resolution, the legislative body of the incorporating county or municipal corporation may adopt an amendment to the articles of incorporation of the authority.
Articles of amendment may contain any provision that lawfully could be contained in articles of incorporation at the time of the amendment.
The articles of amendment shall be filed for record with the State Department of Assessments and Taxation.
The articles of amendment are effective as of the time the State Department of Assessments and Taxation accepts the articles for record.
Acceptance of the articles of amendment for record by the State Department of Assessments and Taxation is conclusive evidence that the articles have been lawfully and properly adopted.

Subject to the provisions of this section and any limitations imposed by law on the impairment of contracts, the incorporating county or municipal corporation, in its sole discretion, by resolution may:

subparagraph.text: set or change the structure, organization, procedures, programs, or activities of the authority; or
terminate the authority.

paragraph.text: On termination of an authority:

subparagraph.text: title to all property of the authority shall be transferred to and vest in the incorporating county or municipal corporation; and
all obligations of the authority shall be transferred to and assumed by the incorporating county or municipal corporation.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (4) of this subsection, the board of directors of an authority consists of five members appointed by the legislative body of the incorporating county or municipal corporation.
Appointment procedures shall be provided in the resolution establishing the authority.

subparagraph.text: In a county or municipal corporation that has a publicly elected chief executive, the chief executive shall submit nominations for the initial board members.
The chief executive may nominate more than one individual for an initial board member position.

paragraph.text: An officer or employee of the incorporating county or municipal corporation may not be appointed to the board but, if provided by resolution, may serve as an ex officio, nonvoting member of the board.

subparagraph.text: The initial five members of the board of directors of an authority shall be appointed for staggered terms, ranging from 1 to 5 years, respectively, beginning on the date the State Department of Assessments and Taxation accepts the articles of incorporation of the authority for record.
Except as provided for initial board members, the term of an appointed member is 5 years.

paragraph.text: At the end of a term, an appointed member continues to serve until a successor is appointed.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed.

subparagraph.text: In a county or municipal corporation that has a publicly elected chief executive, the chief executive shall submit nominations for vacancies on the board.
The chief executive may nominate more than one individual for a vacancy.

paragraph.text: A member may be removed at any time with or without cause.
Procedures for removal shall be those provided in the resolution establishing the authority or a subsequent resolution.
From among its members, the board shall elect a chair and other officers.
An ex officio member may hold any office other than chair.
Three voting members of the board are a quorum.
The board may act on a resolution only by the affirmative vote of at least three voting members.

subsection.text: A member of the board:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the board; but
shall be reimbursed for expenses incurred in performing the member’s duties.

subsection.text: The board shall exercise its powers by resolution.
The board of directors of an authority shall govern the authority.

Except as otherwise provided in this subtitle or the resolution establishing the authority, the procedures of the incorporating county or municipal corporation control any matter relating to the internal administration of the authority.

section.text: Except as necessary to pay debt service or implement the public purposes or programs of the incorporating county or municipal corporation, the net earnings of an authority may benefit only the incorporating county or municipal corporation and may not benefit any person.

paragraph.text: Except as limited by its articles of incorporation, an authority has all the powers set forth in this subtitle.
An authority may:

subparagraph.text: receive money from its incorporating county or municipal corporation, the State, other governmental units, or not–for–profit organizations;
charge fees for its services;
have employees and consultants as it considers necessary; and
use the services of other governmental units.

subsection.text: For the purposes of this subtitle, each county and municipal corporation has all the powers granted in this subtitle to an authority, including the power to make loans to private enterprises competing with enterprises not receiving the loans.

subparagraph.text: An authority shall operate and exercise its powers solely to accomplish one or more of the legislative purposes of this subtitle.
The incorporating county or municipal corporation may use the authority’s exercise of its powers to accomplish one or more of the legislative purposes.

paragraph.text: An authority or an incorporating county or municipal corporation may exercise its powers regardless of any effect on economic competition.
The powers granted to a county or municipal corporation under paragraph (2) of this subsection do not:

subparagraph.text: grant to the county or municipal corporation powers in any substantive area not otherwise granted to the county or municipal corporation under other public general or public local law;
restrict the county or municipal corporation from exercising any power granted to the county or municipal corporation under other public general or public local law or otherwise;

authorize the county or municipal corporation, or the officers of the county or municipal corporation, to engage in an activity that is beyond the power granted under other public general or public local law or otherwise; or
preempt or supersede the regulatory authority of a unit of State government under a public general law.

paragraph.text: The incorporating county or municipal corporation is not precluded from directly exercising the powers granted to an authority under this subtitle after the establishment of the authority.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any limitation of law, a public body may issue and sell bonds periodically to accomplish the legislative purposes of this subtitle.

paragraph.text: A public body may issue and sell bonds to:

subparagraph.text: subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, finance the costs of the acquisition or improvement of a facility for a facility user, including working capital;
refund outstanding bonds;
pay the costs of preparing, printing, selling, and issuing the bonds;
fund reserves; and
pay the interest on the bonds in the amount and for the period the public body considers reasonable.
A public body may not issue bonds to acquire working capital unless the bonds are secured by a letter of credit or an interest in property.
Working capital acquired by issuing bonds may not exceed 25% of the principal amount of the bonds.

paragraph.text: Bonds are limited obligations and are not a pledge of the faith and credit or taxing power of the public body.
Bonds issued by an authority are issued on behalf of the public body that established the authority.
Bonds issued by the Maryland Industrial Development Financing Authority:

subparagraph.text: are issued on behalf of the State; and
shall be issued in accordance with the Maryland Industrial Development Financing Authority Act, Title 5, Subtitle 7 of this article.

paragraph.text: A bond:

subparagraph.text: may be in bearer form;
may be registrable as to principal alone or as to both principal and interest; and
is a “security” as defined by § 8-102 of the Commercial Law Article, whether or not the bond is one of a class or series or is divisible into a class or series of instruments.
A bond shall be signed by the chief executive or by an officer designated by resolution of the public body.
A bond may be executed by facsimile signature in accordance with § 2-303 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The seal of the public body shall be affixed to the bond and attested by the clerk or similar administrative officer of the public body designated by resolution.
An officer’s signature or countersignature on a bond or coupon remains valid even if the officer leaves office before the bond is delivered.
Except as provided in subparagraph (ii) of this paragraph, a bond shall mature not later than 30 years after its date of issue.
If a bond is secured by a mortgage insured by a unit of the federal government, the bond shall have a term of maturity that does not exceed the term of the insurance.

paragraph.text: A public body may acquire or improve a facility with bond proceeds:

subparagraph.text: by leasing the facility to a facility user;
by selling the facility to a facility user under an installment sale agreement;
by lending bond proceeds to a facility user to be used to finance a facility; or
in any other manner that the public body considers appropriate to accomplish the legislative purposes of this subtitle.

The lease of a facility under this subtitle may authorize or require the facility user to acquire the facility on payment of the principal of and interest on the bonds applicable to the facility user.
The consideration for the acquisition of the facility may be nominal.

subsection.text: For each issue of its bonds, the legislative body of a county or municipal corporation, the board of directors of an authority, or the Maryland Industrial Development Financing Authority, shall adopt a resolution that:

paragraph.text: specifies and describes the facility;
generally describes the public purpose to be served and the financing transaction;
specifies the maximum principal amount of the bonds that may be issued; and
imposes terms or conditions on the issuance and sale of bonds it considers appropriate.
The legislative body of a county or municipal corporation, the board of directors of an authority, or the Maryland Industrial Development Financing Authority, by resolution, may:

subparagraph.text: specify, determine, prescribe, and approve matters, documents, and procedures that relate to the authorization, sale, security, issuance, delivery, and payment of and for the bonds;
create security for the bonds;

provide for the administration of bond issues through trust or other agreements with a bank or trust company that cover a countersignature on a bond, the delivery of a bond, or the security for a bond; and
take other action it considers appropriate concerning the bonds.

paragraph.text: The legislative body of a county or municipal corporation, the board of directors of an authority, or the Maryland Industrial Development Financing Authority may authorize a designee to exercise the powers provided under paragraph (1) of this subsection.
A designee may be:

subparagraph.text: a finance board, which shall act by resolution;
the chief executive, who shall act by executive order or otherwise; or
any other appropriate administrative officer, who shall act by order or otherwise with the approval of the chief executive.

paragraph.text: Subject to the limitations of this subtitle and the limitations the legislative body prescribes by resolution, a chief executive or an administrative officer acting under a resolution of a legislative body shall exercise the authority granted:

subparagraph.text: to accomplish the legislative purposes of this subtitle; and
to accomplish the public purposes of the resolution that the legislative body adopts.

paragraph.text: A resolution or trust agreement may contain a pledge or assignment of revenues received from the financing of a facility.
The lien of the pledge or assignment made is valid and binding against a person with a claim against the public body, whether or not the person has notice of the lien.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other public general or public local law, a public body need not file or record a resolution, trust agreement, lease, installment sale agreement, loan agreement, or other instrument that it adopts or makes under this subtitle, except in the records of the public body.
A resolution adopted under this section:

paragraph.text: is administrative in nature;
is not subject to procedures required for legislative acts;
is not subject to referendum; and
in a county or municipal corporation that has a publicly elected chief executive, is subject to approval by the chief executive.

subsection.text: This authorization is self-executing, and fully authorizes a public body to issue and sell bonds, notwithstanding any other statutory or charter provision.

paragraph.text: Bonds shall be sold in the manner, at competitive or negotiated sale, and on the terms at, above, or below par, that the public body considers best.
A contract to acquire or improve a facility may provide that payment shall be made in bonds.

subsection.text: A bond is not subject to the limitations of Article 31, §§ 9, 10, and 11 of the Code.

paragraph.text: A bond and the interest on a bond are limited obligations of the public body.
Except for bond anticipation notes and notes in the nature of commercial paper, the principal of, premium, and interest on a bond are payable solely from:

subparagraph.text: money from the financing of a facility; or
other money made available to the public body.

paragraph.text: Bonds and the interest on them:

subparagraph.text: are not debts or charges against the general credit or taxing powers of a public body within the meaning of any constitutional or charter provision or statutory limitation; and
may not give rise to any pecuniary liability of an issuing public body.

paragraph.text: A bond may state on its face that the bond:

subparagraph.text: is issued under this subtitle; and
is not a debt to which the public body’s faith and credit is pledged.

subsection.text: On default in the payment of the principal of or interest on a bond, a court with jurisdiction:

paragraph.text: may appoint a receiver or take other appropriate action to provide for the payment of the bond; and
shall apply any available revenue as this subtitle or a resolution adopted under this subtitle provides.

section.text: A finding by the legislative body of a county or municipal corporation, the board of directors of an authority, or the Maryland Industrial Development Financing Authority as to the public purpose of an action taken under this subtitle, and the appropriateness of that action to serve the public purpose, is conclusive in a proceeding involving the validity or enforceability of a bond, or security for a bond, issued under this subtitle.

Instead of the procedures under this subtitle, a municipal corporation, by charter amendment adopted under Article 23A of the Code, or a charter county, by charter amendment adopted under Article XI-A of the Maryland Constitution, may provide for the issuance of revenue bonds under the terms and conditions that the municipal corporation or charter county considers appropriate to achieve the legislative purposes of this subtitle.
The principal of and interest on bonds, the transfer of bonds, and any income derived from the bonds, including profits made in their sale or transfer, are forever exempt from State and local taxes.

subsection.text: This section applies to a lease or contract under which:

paragraph.text: the State or a unit of the State will be an initial user or occupant of a facility financed by bonds issued under this subtitle; or
a facility financed by bonds issued under this subtitle will be built on property owned by the State.

subsection.text: The State or a unit of the State may not enter into a lease or contract that is subject to this section and that forms a part of the security for bonds issued under this subtitle unless:

paragraph.text: the Legislative Policy Committee has authorized the facility as being consistent with the capital budget; and
the Board of Public Works specifically has approved the bond issue for that facility.

section.text: This subtitle may be cited as the Maryland Economic Development Revenue Bond Act.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.

“Adjusted assessable base” means the fair market value of real property that qualifies for a farm or agricultural use under § 8–209 of the Tax – Property Article, without regard to the agricultural use assessment for the property as of January 1 of the year preceding the effective date of the resolution creating the development district under § 12–203 of this subtitle.
“Assessable base” means the total assessable base, as determined by the Supervisor of Assessments, of all real property subject to taxation in a development district.

paragraph.text: “Assessment ratio” means a real property tax assessment ratio, however designated or calculated, that is used under applicable general law to determine the assessable base.
“Assessment ratio” includes the assessment percentage specified under § 8–103(c) of the Tax – Property Article.

subsection.text: “Bond” means a revenue bond, note, or other similar instrument issued in accordance with this subtitle by:

paragraph.text: a political subdivision; or
the revenue authority of Prince George’s County.

subsection.text: “Chief executive” means the president, chair, mayor, or other chief executive officer of a political subdivision or the revenue authority of Prince George’s County.
“Development” includes new development, redevelopment, revitalization, and renovation.
“Development district” means a contiguous area designated by a resolution.
“Issuer” means a political subdivision or the revenue authority of Prince George’s County that issues a bond under this subtitle.

“MEDCO obligation” means a bond, note, or other similar instrument that the Maryland Economic Development Corporation issues under authority other than this subtitle to finance the cost of infrastructure improvements located in or supporting a transit–oriented development or a State hospital redevelopment.
“Original assessable base” means the assessable base as of January 1 of the year preceding the effective date of the resolution creating the development district under § 12–203 of this subtitle.
“Original full cash value” means the dollar amount that is determined by dividing the original assessable base by the assessment ratio used to determine the original assessable base.
“Original taxable value” means for any tax year the dollar amount that is:

paragraph.text: the adjusted assessable base, if an adjusted assessable base applies; or
in all other cases, the lesser of:

subparagraph.text: the product of multiplying the original full cash value by the assessment ratio applicable to that tax year; and
the original assessable base.

subsection.text: “Political subdivision” means a county or a municipal corporation.
“State hospital redevelopment” means any combination of private or public commercial, residential, or recreational uses, improvements, and facilities that:

paragraph.text: is part of a comprehensive coordinated development plan or strategy involving:

subparagraph.text: property that was occupied formerly by a State facility, as defined in § 10–101 of the Health – General Article, or a State residential center, as defined in § 7–101 of the Health – General Article; or

property that is adjacent or reasonably proximate to property that was occupied formerly by a State facility, as defined in § 10–101 of the Health – General Article, or a State residential center, as defined in § 7–101 of the Health – General Article;

paragraph.text: in accordance with design development principles, maximizes use of the property by those constituencies it is intended to serve; and
is designated as a State hospital redevelopment by:

subparagraph.text: the Smart Growth Subcabinet established under § 9–1406 of the State Government Article; and
the local government or multicounty agency with land use and planning responsibility for the relevant area.

subsection.text: “Tax increment” means for any tax year the amount by which the assessable base as of January 1 of the preceding tax year exceeds the original taxable value divided by the assessment ratio used to determine the original taxable value.
“Tax year” means the period from July 1 of a calendar year through June 30 of the next calendar year.
“Transit–oriented development” has the meaning stated in § 7–101 of the Transportation Article.

paragraph.text: This subtitle is self-executing.
A political subdivision need not amend its charter to exercise the powers granted by this subtitle.

subsection.text: This subtitle does not apply in Baltimore City.
Before issuing bonds, the governing body of the political subdivision shall:

paragraph.text: designate by resolution a contiguous area within its jurisdiction as a development district;
receive from the Supervisor of Assessments a certification of the amount of the original assessable base, or if applicable, the adjusted assessable base; and
pledge that until the bonds are fully paid, or a longer period, the real property taxes in the development district shall be divided as follows:

subparagraph.text: the portion of the taxes that would be produced at the current tax rate on the original taxable value shall be paid to the respective taxing authorities in the same manner as taxes on other property are paid; and

the portion of the taxes on the tax increment that normally would be paid into the general fund of the political subdivision shall be paid into the special fund established under § 12-208 of this subtitle and applied in accordance with § 12-209 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The establishment by a county of a development district that is wholly or partly in a municipal corporation shall also require a resolution approving the development district by the governing body of the municipal corporation.
Notwithstanding any limitation of law, an issuer may issue bonds from time to time to finance the development of an industrial, commercial, or residential area.
To issue bonds under this subtitle, the governing body of a political subdivision shall adopt an ordinance that:

paragraph.text: describes the proposed undertaking; and
states:

subparagraph.text: that the governing body has complied with §§ 12-203 and 12-208(c) and (d) of this subtitle;
the maximum principal amount of the bonds; and
the maximum rate of interest on the bonds.

subsection.text: The ordinance may specify the following for bonds issued to carry out the financing of the proposed undertaking:

paragraph.text: the principal amount;
the rate of interest;
the manner and terms of sale;
the time of execution, issuance, and delivery;
the form and denomination;
the manner in which, and the times and places at which principal and interest shall be paid;
conditions for redemption before maturity; or
other provisions consistent with this subtitle that the governing body of the political subdivision determines are necessary or desirable.

subsection.text: The revenue authority of Prince George’s County may issue bonds in accordance with an ordinance adopted by the governing body of Prince George’s County.
The ordinance may specify the items listed in subsection (c) of this section or may authorize:

paragraph.text: the finance board to specify those items by resolution or ordinance; or
the chief executive to specify those items by executive order.

Except as provided in paragraph (2) of this subsection, neither an ordinance authorizing the bonds nor an ordinance, resolution, or executive order issued, passed, or adopted under this section may be subject to referendum because of any other State or local law.
An ordinance that authorizes the pledge of the full faith and credit of a political subdivision to the payment of principal and interest on a bond is subject to any applicable right to referendum.

subsection.text: A bond:

paragraph.text: may be in bearer form;
may be registrable as to principal alone or as to both principal and interest; and
is a “security” under § 8-102 of the Commercial Law Article, whether or not the bond is one of a class or series or is divisible into a class or series of instruments.
A bond shall be signed manually or in facsimile by the chief executive of the issuer.
An officer’s signature or facsimile signature on a bond remains valid even if the officer leaves office before the bond is delivered.
The clerk or other similar administrative officer of the issuer shall attest to and affix to each bond the seal of the issuer.

subsection.text: A bond shall mature not later than 40 years after the date of issue.

paragraph.text: The issuer may sell bonds at competitive or negotiated sale in any manner and on any terms that it considers best.
A contract to acquire property may provide that payment shall be made in bonds.
Bonds are exempt from Article 31, §§ 9, 10, and 11 of the Code.

subsection.text: Bonds shall be payable from the special fund established under § 12–208 of this subtitle.
The governing body of the political subdivision or the issuer may:

paragraph.text: pledge its full faith and credit or other assets and revenues to pay the bonds; and
establish a sinking fund or a debt service reserve fund for the bonds.

subsection.text: The assets and revenues pledged under subsection (b)(1) of this section may include any amount that the political subdivision may receive from the State under § 2–222 of the Tax – Property Article.
Bond proceeds may be used only:

paragraph.text: to buy, lease, condemn, or otherwise acquire property, or an interest in property:

subparagraph.text: in the development district; or
needed for a right–of–way or other easement to or from the development district;

paragraph.text: for site removal;
for surveys and studies;
to relocate businesses or residents;
to install utilities, construct parks and playgrounds, and for other needed improvements including:

subparagraph.text: roads to, from, or in the development district;
parking; and
lighting;

paragraph.text: to construct or rehabilitate buildings for a governmental purpose or use;
for reserves or capitalized interest;
for necessary costs to issue bonds; and
to pay the principal of and interest on loans, advances, or indebtedness that a political subdivision incurs for a purpose specified in this section.
In addition to the purposes listed in subsection (a) of this section, the proceeds from bonds that Prince George’s County or the revenue authority of Prince George’s County issues may be used:

subparagraph.text: for convention, conference, or visitors’ centers;
to maintain infrastructure improvements and convention, conference, or visitors’ centers;
to market development district facilities and other improvements; and
for the purpose of encouraging redevelopment in those areas listed in paragraph (2) of this subsection, to install infrastructure improvements, including:

sub-subparagraph.text: streets;
parking structures of any type whether for public or private use;
utilities;
street lights;
stormwater management and storm drain facilities;
fencing;
noise walls;
retaining walls;
trails;
sidewalks;
pedestrian and vehicular bridges; and
park facilities.

paragraph.text: The purpose of the authority granted by paragraph (1)(iv) of this subsection is to encourage redevelopment in:

subparagraph.text: revitalization areas designated by the county;
mixed use centers;
blighted areas; and
the Developed Tier, growth corridors, and growth centers, as defined in the county General Plan.

paragraph.text: In addition to the purposes listed in subsection (a) of this section, the proceeds from bonds that a municipal corporation issues may be used for the purpose of encouraging redevelopment in those areas listed in paragraph (2) of this subsection, to install infrastructure improvements, including:

subparagraph.text: streets;
parking structures of any type whether for public or private use;
utilities;
street lights;
stormwater management and storm drain facilities;
fencing;
noise walls;
retaining walls;
trails;
sidewalks;
pedestrian and vehicular bridges; and
park facilities.

paragraph.text: The purpose of the authority granted by paragraph (1) of this subsection is to encourage redevelopment in:

subparagraph.text: revitalization areas designated by a county or municipal corporation;
mixed use centers;
blighted areas; and
developed areas and growth areas, as defined in a county or municipal corporation land use plan.

subsection.text: The governing body of a political subdivision may adopt a resolution creating a special fund for a development district even though no bonds:

paragraph.text: have been issued for the development district; or
are outstanding at the time of adoption.

subsection.text: The taxes allocated to the special fund in accordance with § 12-203(a)(3)(ii) of this subtitle shall be deposited in the special fund while the resolution that created the special fund remains in effect.

Other than tax revenues received from residential properties in Prince George’s County, the tax collected under § 12-203(a)(3)(ii) of this subtitle is not considered a tax of the political subdivision for the purposes of any constant yield limitation or State or local restriction.
State real property taxes may not be paid into the special fund.

Subject to subsection (c) of this section, the special fund for the development district may be used for any of the following purposes as determined by the governing body of the political subdivision:

paragraph.text: a purpose specified in § 12–207 of this subtitle;
accumulated to pay debt service on bonds to be issued later;

payment or reimbursement of debt service, or payments under an agreement described in subsection (b) of this section, that the political subdivision is obliged under a general or limited obligation to pay, or has paid, on or relating to bonds issued by the State, a political subdivision, or the revenue authority of Prince George’s County if the proceeds were used for a purpose specified in § 12–207 of this subtitle; or
payment to the political subdivision for any other legal purpose.

Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the political subdivision that has created a special fund for a development district may pledge under an agreement that amounts deposited to the special fund shall be paid over to secure payment on MEDCO obligations.
The agreement shall:

subparagraph.text: be in writing;
be executed by the political subdivision making the pledge, the Maryland Economic Development Corporation, and the other persons that the governing body of the political subdivision determines; and
run to the benefit of and be enforceable on behalf of the holders of the MEDCO obligations secured by the agreement.

subsection.text: If bonds are outstanding with respect to a development district, the special fund may be used as described in subsection (a) of this section in any fiscal year only if:

paragraph.text: the balance of the special fund exceeds the unpaid debt service payable on the bonds in the fiscal year; and
the special fund is not restricted so as to prohibit the use.

subsection.text: The issuance of bonds pledging the full faith and credit of the political subdivision shall comply with appropriate county or municipal charter requirements.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the governing body of a political subdivision that is not the issuer may pledge under an agreement that its property taxes levied on the tax increment shall be paid into the special fund for the development district.
The agreement shall:

subparagraph.text: be in writing;
be executed by the governing bodies of the issuer and the political subdivision making the pledge; and
run to the benefit of and be enforceable on behalf of any bondholder.

subsection.text: The governing body of Prince George’s County may also pledge hotel rental tax revenues to the special fund.

The governing body of a political subdivision, including the issuer, may pledge by or under a resolution, including by an agreement with the issuer, as applicable, that alternative local tax revenues generated within, or that are otherwise determined to be attributable to, a development district that is a transit–oriented development or a State hospital redevelopment be paid, as provided in the resolution, into the special fund to:

paragraph.text: secure the payment of debt service on bonds or MEDCO obligations; or
be applied to the other purposes stated in § 12–209 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The principal amount of bonds, interest payable on bonds, the transfer of bonds, and income from bonds, including profit made in the sale or transfer of bonds, are exempt from State and local taxes.
If a political subdivision leases as a lessor its property within a development district:

paragraph.text: the property shall be assessed and taxed in the same manner as privately owned property; and
the lease shall require the lessee to pay taxes or payments in lieu of taxes on the assessed value of the entire property and not only on the assessed value of the leasehold interest.

section.text: This subtitle does not authorize a county or a municipal corporation to acquire property by eminent domain.
This subtitle may be cited as the Tax Increment Financing Act.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Bond” means a bond, note, or other similar instrument that a political subdivision issues under this subtitle.
“Chief executive” means the president, chair, mayor, county executive, or any other chief executive officer of a political subdivision.
“Designated blighted area” means an area designated under § 12-303 of this subtitle.
“Financed area” means the geographic portion of a designated blighted area for which the proceeds of a bond are to be used under § 12-303 of this subtitle.
“Political subdivision” means a county or municipal corporation.
To issue a bond, a political subdivision shall adopt an ordinance or resolution that:

paragraph.text: describes the proposed undertaking to be financed by the bond proceeds;
requires compliance with § 12-303 of this subtitle before the bond is issued; and
specifies the maximum principal amount of the bond.

subsection.text: As the political subdivision considers appropriate to effect the financing of the proposed undertaking, the ordinance or resolution may:

paragraph.text: specify the items listed in subsection (c) of this section;
authorize the finance board of the political subdivision to specify those items by resolution or ordinance; or
authorize the chief executive of the political subdivision to specify those items by executive order.

subsection.text: For each issuance of a bond, the political subdivision may specify:

paragraph.text: the principal amount;
the interest rate or, for floating or variable rates of interest, the method to determine the interest rate;
the manner and terms of sale, including whether by competitive or negotiated sale;
the time of execution, issuance, and delivery;
the form and denomination;
the source, manner, times, and places to pay principal or interest;
conditions for redemption before maturity;
the actions taken to comply with § 12-307 of this subtitle;
the purposes for which proceeds may be spent;
the source of security; and
other provisions that the governing body of the political subdivision determines are necessary or desirable to effect the financing of the proposed undertaking.

subsection.text: Before a political subdivision issues a bond, the political subdivision shall pass an ordinance or administrative resolution that:

paragraph.text: designates an area in the political subdivision as a designated blighted area based on the substantial presence of:

subparagraph.text: excessive vacant land on which structures were previously located;
abandoned or vacant buildings;
substandard structures;
delinquencies in real property tax payments; or
similar factors that the political subdivision determines indicate blight;

paragraph.text: designates the financed area for which the proceeds of the bond are to be used; and
adopts a redevelopment plan for the designated blighted area.

Before a county may designate a blighted area or financed area that lies wholly or partly in a municipal corporation, the municipal corporation shall consent to the designation of the part of the area that is within the municipal corporation.
Before a municipal corporation may designate a blighted area or financed area, the county that contains the area shall consent to the designation.
Consent under this subsection shall be made by ordinance or administrative resolution.

subsection.text: A political subdivision that issues a bond as a qualified redevelopment bond under the Internal Revenue Code shall comply with federal law in determining:

paragraph.text: the designated blighted area and the financed area to which the bond relates; and
any other designated blighted areas in the political subdivision.

subsection.text: The General Assembly intends that general obligation debt may be incurred by issuing bonds if the purposes for the debt include the purposes for issuing bonds under this subtitle.

Subject to subsections (c) and (d) of this section, a political subdivision may issue bonds to finance the redevelopment of a designated blighted area in accordance with the procedures of the political subdivision for authorization to sell and issue bonds.
A bond issued in accordance with an ordinance or resolution that pledges the full faith and credit of a political subdivision is subject to:

paragraph.text: any applicable requirements of the Constitution and the political subdivision’s charter and laws on referendum for the issuance of general obligation debt; and
each limitation imposed by public general law, public local law, or charter on general obligation debt of the political subdivision.
This subsection does not apply to a county that is subject to Article 25A or Article 25B of the Code.

A county may not issue bonds that are secured by the full faith and credit of the county unless the amount of bonds to be issued by the county under this subtitle is first authorized by the General Assembly.

subsection.text: Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, the ordinance or resolution described in § 12-303 of this subtitle may provide that a bond may be secured and made payable from any combination of:

paragraph.text: a pledge of the full faith and credit of the political subdivision and payable by taxes of general applicability;
an increase in real property tax revenues that is attributable to increases in assessed value in designated blighted areas resulting from carrying out the purposes for which the bond is issued;
revenues of the project or undertaking for which the bond is issued;
proceeds of bonds; or
other money that may be legally made available to pay the bond.

subsection.text: A bond issued by Baltimore City may not be secured under subsection (a)(2) of this section.
The ordinance or resolution described in § 12-308 of this subtitle may provide that bond proceeds may be spent on any combination of:

paragraph.text: the following redevelopment purposes in a designated blighted area:

subparagraph.text: acquisition of real property by the political subdivision;
clearing and preparing the real property;
rehabilitating the real property; and
relocating occupants of the real property;

paragraph.text: other purposes that the local jurisdiction determines to be incidental, necessary, or appropriate to the redevelopment of the designated blighted area, including construction of new structures or the enlargement of existing structures; and
expenses of preparing, printing, selling, and issuing bonds, and funding reserves and interest on the bonds, in the amounts and for the time that the political subdivision considers reasonable.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (c) of this section, money from the federal government, the State, or otherwise legally available for the purposes described in subsection (a) of this section may be spent for any of those purposes.
Expenditures under this section shall first be authorized in accordance with applicable laws.
By written agreement with the issuer of a bond, a political subdivision that is not the issuer may:

paragraph.text: pledge to the payment of the bond any real property tax revenues attributable to increases in assessed value increase of property in designated blighted areas resulting from carrying out the purposes for which the bond is issued; and
make covenants about real property taxes and other charges in a designated blighted area as it considers appropriate.

subsection.text: An agreement made under this section may be for the benefit and be enforceable on behalf of any bondholder.
A bond:

paragraph.text: may be in bearer form;
may be registrable as to principal alone or as to both principal and interest; and
is a “security” under § 8-102 of the Commercial Law Article, whether or not the bond is one of a class or series or is divisible into a class or series of instruments.
A bond shall be signed manually or in facsimile by the chief executive of the political subdivision.
An officer’s signature or facsimile signature on a bond remains valid even if the officer leaves office before the bond is delivered.
The seal of the political subdivision shall be affixed to the bond and attested by the clerk or other similar administrative officer of the political subdivision.
A bond shall mature not later than 40 years after the date of issue.
Bonds may be issued as serial bonds or term bonds with provisions for a mandatory sinking fund or other annual principal redemption beginning not later than 3 years after the date of issue.
A bond shall be sold in the manner, at public or private (negotiated) sale, and on the terms at, above, or below par, as the political subdivision considers best.
A contract to acquire property may provide that payments shall be made in bonds.
A bond is not subject to Article 31, §§ 9, 10, and 11 of the Code.

subsection.text: A bond, the transfer of a bond, the interest payable on a bond, the income derived from a bond, and the profit realized on sale or exchange of a bond are exempt from State and local taxes.
A political subdivision may issue bonds under this subtitle without regard to their federal tax status.

section.text: For purposes of an action involving the validity or enforceability of a bond or security for a bond, a finding by a political subdivision is conclusive as to:

paragraph.text: the public purpose of an action taken under this subtitle; and
any other matter relating to the issuance of a bond.

section.text: This subtitle does not authorize a political subdivision to acquire property by eminent domain.
This subtitle may be cited as the Redevelopment Bond Act.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the board of directors of a district corporation.
“Commercial tenant” means a lessee or other lawful occupant, other than the owner, of nonexempt property within a district.
“District” means a business improvement district established under this subtitle.
“District corporation” means a business improvement district corporation formed in accordance with this subtitle.
“Members of the district” means owners of nonexempt property in the district.
“Nonexempt property” means nonresidential real property that is not exempt from paying real property taxes.

section.text: The legislative purposes of this subtitle are to:

paragraph.text: provide for the creation of business improvement districts; and

promote the general welfare of the residents, employers, employees, property owners, commercial tenants, consumers, and the general public within the geographic area of the business improvement districts.

subsection.text: Subject to a public hearing under § 12–408 of this subtitle and to accomplish one or more of the legislative purposes listed in § 12–402 of this subtitle, the legislative body of a county or municipal corporation may adopt a local law to create a business improvement district in accordance with this subtitle.
Subsection (a) of this section is self–executing and fully authorizes a county or municipal corporation to establish a district, notwithstanding any other statutory or charter provision.
A local law adopted under subsection (a) of this section shall include:

paragraph.text: the name of the district corporation;
that the district corporation is formed under this subtitle;
the names, addresses, and terms of office of the initial members of the board of directors of the district corporation;
the address of the principal office of the district corporation;
the purposes for which the district is formed;
the powers of the district, subject to the limitations on the powers of districts under this subtitle; and
if applicable, articles of incorporation of the district corporation.

subsection.text: A board of directors shall govern the district corporation.

paragraph.text: Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the board of a district corporation consists of five members appointed by the members of the district.
Appointment procedures shall be provided in the local law establishing the district.

subsection.text: From among its members, the board shall elect a chair and other officers.

paragraph.text: Three voting members of the board are a quorum.
The board may act on a resolution only by the affirmative vote of at least three voting members.

subsection.text: A member of the board:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the board; but
shall be reimbursed for expenses incurred in performing the member’s duties.

subsection.text: The board shall exercise its powers by resolution.
The board shall file an annual report with the governing body of the county or municipal corporation that includes:

paragraph.text: a financial statement for the preceding year;
a proposed operating budget for the current fiscal year;
any proposed revisions to the business plan; and
a narrative statement or chart showing the results of operations in comparison to stated goals and objectives.

section.text: The net earnings of a district corporation may benefit only the district corporation.

paragraph.text: Except as limited by its articles of incorporation, a district corporation has all the powers set forth in this subtitle.
A district corporation may:

subparagraph.text: receive money from its incorporating county or municipal corporation, the State, other governmental units, or not for profit organizations;
charge fees for its services;
have employees and consultants as it considers necessary; and
use the services of other governmental units.

subsection.text: A district corporation shall operate and exercise its powers solely to accomplish one or more of the legislative purposes of this subtitle.
The owners of nonexempt property who seek to establish a district corporation shall submit appropriate documentation as described in subsection (b) of this section to:

paragraph.text: the governing body of the county in which the proposed district is located; and
if the proposed district is located within a municipal corporation, the governing body of the municipal corporation.

subsection.text: The appropriate documentation required under subsection (a) of this section shall contain:

paragraph.text: a statement setting forth:

subparagraph.text: the proposed name and address of the district corporation; and
the street address of each owner of nonexempt property within the proposed district;

paragraph.text: a statement expressing the intent to establish a district corporation that is signed by at least 80% of the owners of the total number of parcels of nonexempt property in the geographic area of the proposed district;
a proposed 3–year business plan that contains:

subparagraph.text: the goals and objectives of the proposed district;
the annual proposed business improvement district tax for the proposed district’s common operations and the formula used to determine each member’s district tax; and
the maximum amount and the nature of start–up costs incurred before the district’s establishment;

paragraph.text: a tax assessor’s map of the geographic area of the proposed district;
a list of the proposed initial board of the proposed district corporation;
the proposed articles of incorporation and the bylaws of the district corporation;
for all nonexempt property within the proposed district:

subparagraph.text: the name and mailing address of each owner; and
the most recent assessed value; and

paragraph.text: a list of the names and addresses of all commercial tenants within the geographic area of the proposed district.

subsection.text: Within 45 days after receiving all appropriate documentation under subsection (b) of this section, the governing body of a county or municipal corporation shall schedule a public hearing on the application.

At least 21 days before the public hearing, the governing body of a county or municipal corporation shall publish notice of the public hearing in a newspaper of general circulation within the geographic area of the proposed district.
At least 21 days before the public hearing, the owners of nonexempt property who seek to establish a district shall send notice of the public hearing and a summary of the application to:

paragraph.text: each owner of nonexempt property within the proposed district; and
each commercial tenant within the proposed district.

subsection.text: Before the public hearing, the application shall be made available for review during normal business hours in at least one location in the proposed district.

Within 10 days after the public hearing, if the governing body of the county or municipal corporation determines that the needs of the district meet the purposes of this subtitle, the governing body shall authorize the district in accordance with § 12–403 of this subtitle.

Within 10 days after the authorization by the governing body of the county or municipal corporation of the district, the district corporation shall provide the governing body of the county or municipal corporation with a preliminary business improvement district tax roll.
