paragraph.text: The governing body of the county or municipal corporation shall impose a business improvement district tax to provide funds for the operation of the district.
The governing body of the county or municipal corporation shall impose on members of the district the district tax at a rate specified by the board and approved by the governing body.
The tax imposed under this subsection may not count against a county or municipal corporation tax cap.

subsection.text: The district tax shall be collected in the same manner as real property taxes are collected and distributed each quarter to the district.
A district shall reimburse the governing body of a county or municipal corporation for the costs incurred in collecting the district tax.

section.text: An established district may expand the geographic area of the district if:

paragraph.text: a petition for inclusion is submitted from at least 80% of the owners of the total number of parcels of nonexempt property in the geographic area proposed for inclusion in the district;
the petition under item (1) of this subsection is accepted by a majority vote of the board of the district corporation; and
the appropriate documents, as applicable, are submitted under § 12–407 of this subtitle and a hearing is held under § 12–408 of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The governing body of a county or municipal corporation in which a district is established under this section shall:

paragraph.text: review the effectiveness and desirability of continuing the district every 3 years from the time the district is authorized by local law under § 12–403 of this subtitle; and
develop policies and procedures for evaluating the desirability of continuing the district if requested by owners of nonexempt property in the district.

subsection.text: If the continuing existence of the district is not approved by the governing body:

paragraph.text: the district shall cease to exist as directed by the governing body; and
the district corporation shall continue its existence only as long as necessary to terminate operation in a reasonable manner.

subsection.text: Notwithstanding any other provision of law, Montgomery County may make an equity investment through the county’s Economic Development Fund in a company that is located in Montgomery County or that agrees to relocate its business to Montgomery County.
The proceeds of an equity investment made under subsection (a) of this section may be used for:

paragraph.text: working capital;
salaries;
marketing materials;
acquisition of inventory, equipment, or real property;
construction;
renovation;
leasehold improvements; or
research and development.

subsection.text: The county may not acquire an ownership interest exceeding 25% of any enterprise.

paragraph.text: The terms of an equity investment approved by the county shall be set forth in a funding agreement.
A funding agreement made under paragraph (1) of this subsection shall prohibit the county from:

subparagraph.text: participating in the selection of the management of the company;
engaging in oversight of the operation of the company; or
assuming any present or future liability of the company.

paragraph.text: At the county’s discretion, a funding agreement made under paragraph (1) of this subsection may consist of:

subparagraph.text: an investment agreement;
a limited partnership agreement;
a preferred stock purchase agreement; or
other documents that the county may require.

subsection.text: Notice of each equity investment made by Montgomery County under subsection (a) of this section shall be posted in a readily accessible and clearly identified location on the Montgomery County government website within 5 days after the date on which the county initiates the equity investment transaction.
In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Act” means the federal Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965.
“Commission” means the federal Appalachian Regional Commission.
“Program” means the federal Appalachian Regional Development Program.
The Department may:

paragraph.text: coordinate and cooperate with any unit of the federal government to implement the Act in the State;
enter into contracts and agreements under the Act;
spend money for any purpose related to the Act, including for highways, natural resources, agriculture, education, training, health, and welfare; and
do all things necessary and proper to carry out the Act.

If any unit of the federal government offers to the State services, equipment, supplies, materials, or money as a gift or grant to implement the Program, the State, acting through the Governor and Department, may accept the offer.

If the Governor and Department accept the offer of a gift or grant under paragraph (1) of this subsection, the Governor and Department may authorize a unit of the State or a political subdivision to receive and use the gift or grant.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (b) of this section, the Governor shall be a member of the Commission.

paragraph.text: The Governor may designate an individual who is a member of the Governor’s cabinet or personal staff to serve as a member of the Commission on the Governor’s behalf.
The Governor’s designee serves at the pleasure of the Governor.
The Governor’s designee shall receive compensation as provided in the State budget.
The Governor’s designee is entitled to reimbursement for expenses as provided under the Standard State Travel Regulations.

subsection.text: The Governor or the Governor’s designee may:

paragraph.text: certify a local development commission to the Commission; and
perform any act necessary to carry out the provisions of this subtitle or the Act.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Board” means the Southern States Energy Board.
“Compact” means the Southern States Energy Compact.

section.text: The Southern States Energy Compact is entered into by this State with other states legally joining the compact in accordance with its terms, in the form substantially as follows:

The party states recognize that the proper employment and conservation of energy and employment of energy–related facilities, materials, and products, within the context of a responsible regard for the environment, can assist substantially in the industrialization of the South and the development of a balanced economy for the region. They also recognize that optimum benefit from and acquisition of energy resources and facilities require systematic encouragement, guidance, and assistance from the party states on a cooperative basis. It is the policy of the party states to undertake such cooperation on a continuing basis; it is the purpose of this compact to provide the instruments and framework for such a cooperative effort to improve the economy of the South and contribute to the individual and community well–being of the region’s people.

subsection.text: There is hereby created an agency of the party states to be known as the “Southern States Energy Board” (hereinafter called the board). The board shall be composed of three members from each party state, one of whom shall be appointed or designated in each state to represent the governor, the state senate, and the state house of delegates, respectively. Each member shall be designated or appointed in accordance with the law of the state which the member represents and serving and subject to removal in accordance with such law. Any member of the board may provide for the discharge of the member’s duties and the performance of the member’s functions thereon (either for the duration of the membership or for any lesser period of time) by a deputy or assistant, if the law of the member’s state makes specific provision therefore. The federal government may be represented without vote if provision is made by federal law for such representation.

Each party state shall be entitled to one vote on the board, to be determined by majority vote of each member or member’s representative from the party state present and voting on any question. No action of the board shall be binding unless taken at a meeting at which a majority of all party states are represented and unless a majority of the total number of votes on the board are cast in favor thereof.
The board shall have a seal.

The board shall elect annually, from among its members, a chairman, vice–chairman, and a treasurer. The board shall appoint an executive director who shall serve at its pleasure and who shall also act as secretary, and who, together with the treasurer, shall be bonded in such amounts as the board may require.

The executive director, with the approval of the board, shall appoint and remove or discharge such personnel as may be necessary for the performance of the board’s functions irrespective of the civil service, personnel or other merit system laws of any of the party states.

The board may establish and maintain, independently or in conjunction with any one or more of the party states, a suitable retirement system for its full–time employees. Employees of the board shall be eligible for Social Security coverage in respect of old–age and survivors insurance provided that the board takes such steps as may be necessary pursuant to federal law to participate in such program of insurance as a governmental agency or unit. The board may establish and maintain or participate in such additional programs of employee benefits as may be appropriate.

The board may borrow, accept, or contract for the services of personnel from any state of the United States or any subdivision or agency thereof, from any interstate agency, or from any institution, person, firm or corporation.

The board may accept for any of its purposes and functions under this compact any and all donations, and grants of money, equipment, supplies, materials, and services (conditional or otherwise) from any state or the United States or any subdivision or agency thereof, or interstate agency, or from any institution, person, firm, or corporation, and may receive, utilize and dispose of the same.

The board may establish and maintain such facilities as may be necessary for the transacting of its business. The board may acquire, hold, and convey real and personal property and any interest therein.

The board shall adopt bylaws, rules, and regulations for the conduct of its business, and shall have the power to amend and rescind these bylaws, rules, and regulations. The board shall publish its bylaws, rules, and regulations in convenient form and shall file a copy thereof, and shall also file a copy of any amendment thereto, with the appropriate agency or officer in each of the party states.

The board annually shall make to the governor of each party state, a report covering the activities of the board for the preceding year, and embodying such recommendations as may have been adopted by the board, which report shall be transmitted to the legislature of said state. The board may issue such additional reports as it may deem desirable.

The board shall submit to the executive head or designated officer or officers of each party state a budget of its estimated expenditures for such period as may be required by the laws of that jurisdiction for presentation to the legislature thereof.

Each of the board’s budgets of estimated expenditures shall contain specific recommendations of the amount or amounts to be appropriated by each of the party states. One half of the total amount of each budget of estimated expenditures shall be apportioned among the party states in equal shares; one quarter of each such budget shall be apportioned among the party states in accordance with the ratio of their populations to the total population of the entire group of party states based on the last decennial federal census; and one quarter of each such budget shall be apportioned among the party states on the basis of the relative average per–capita income of the inhabitants in each of the party states based on the latest computations published by the federal census–taking agency. Subject to appropriation by their respective legislatures, the board shall be provided with such funds by each of the party states as are necessary to provide the means of establishing and maintaining facilities, a staff of personnel, and such activities as may be necessary to fulfill the powers and duties imposed upon and entrusted to the board.

The board may meet any of its obligations in whole or in part with funds available to it under Article II (h) of this compact provided that the board takes specific action setting aside such funds prior to the incurring of any obligation to be met in whole or in part in this manner. Except where the board makes use of funds available to it under Article II (h) hereof, the board shall not incur any obligation prior to the allotment of funds by the party jurisdictions adequate to meet the same.

The board shall keep accurate accounts of all receipts and disbursements. The receipts and disbursements of the board shall be subject to the audit and accounting procedures established under its bylaws. However, all receipts and disbursements of funds handled by the board shall be audited yearly by a qualified public accountant and the report of the audit shall be included in and become part of the annual report of the board.
The accounts of the board shall be open at any reasonable time for inspection.

The board may establish such advisory and technical committees as it may deem necessary, membership on which to include but not be limited to private citizens, expert and lay personnel, representatives of industry, labor, commerce, agriculture, civic associations, medicine, education, voluntary health agencies, and officials of local, state and federal government, and may cooperate with and use the services of any such committees and the organizations which they represent in furthering any of its activities under this compact.
The board shall have the power to:
ascertain and analyze on a continuing basis the position of the South with respect to energy, energy–related industries, and environmental concerns.
encourage the development, conservation, and responsible use of energy and energy–related facilities, installations, and products as part of a balanced economy and healthy environment.
collect, correlate, and disseminate information relating to civilian use of energy and energy–related materials and products.
conduct, or cooperate in conducting, programs of training for state and local personnel engaged in any aspect of:

paragraph.text: energy, environment, and application of energy, environmental, and related concerns to industry, medicine, or education or the promotion or regulation thereof.

the formulation or administration of measures designed to promote safety in any matter related to the development, use, or disposal of energy and energy–related materials, products, installations, or wastes.

subsection.text: organize and conduct, or assist and cooperate in organizing and conducting, demonstrations of energy product, material, or equipment use and disposal and of proper techniques or processes for the application of energy resources to the civilian economy or general welfare.
undertake such nonregulatory functions with respect to sources of radiation as may promote the economic development and general welfare of the region.
study industrial, health, safety, and other standards, laws, codes, rules, regulations, and administrative practices in or related to energy and environmental fields.

recommend such changes in, or amendments or additions to the laws, codes, rules, regulations, administrative procedures and practices or ordinances of the party states in any of the fields of its interest and competence as in its judgment may be appropriate. Any such recommendation shall be made through the appropriate state agency with due consideration of the desirability of uniformity but shall also give appropriate weight to any special circumstance which may justify variations to meet local conditions.
prepare, publish and distribute (with or without charge) such reports, bulletins, newsletters or other materials as it deems appropriate.

cooperate with the United States Department of Energy or any agency successor thereto, any other officer or agency of the United States, and any other governmental unit or agency or officer thereof, and with any private persons or agencies in any of the fields of its interest.

act as licensee of the United States government or any party state with respect to the conduct of any research activity requiring such license and operate such research facility or undertake any program pursuant thereto.

ascertain from time to time such methods, practices, circumstances, and conditions as may bring about the prevention and control of energy and environmental incidents in the area comprising the party states, to coordinate the nuclear, environmental, and other energy–related incident prevention and control plans and the work relating thereto of the appropriate agencies of the party states and to facilitate the rendering of aid by the party states to each other in coping with energy and environmental incidents. The board may formulate and, in accordance with need from time to time, revise a regional plan or regional plans for coping with energy and environmental incidents within the territory of the party states as a whole or within any subregion or subregions of the geographic area covered by this compact.

To the extent that the board has not undertaken an activity or project which would be within its power under the provisions of Article V of this compact, any two or more of the party states (acting by their duly constituted administrative officials) may enter into supplementary agreements for the undertaking and continuance of such an activity or project. Any such agreement shall specify its purpose or purposes; its duration and the procedure for termination thereof or withdrawal therefrom; the method of financing and allocating the costs of the activity or project; and such other matters as may be necessary or appropriate. No such supplementary agreement entered into pursuant to this article shall become effective prior to its submission to and approval by the board. The board shall give such approval unless it finds that the supplementary agreement or the activity or project contemplated thereby is inconsistent with the provisions of this compact or a program or activity conducted by or participated in by the board.

Unless all of the party states participate in a supplementary agreement, any cost or costs thereof shall be borne separately by the states party thereto. However, the board may administer or otherwise assist in the operation of any supplementary agreement.

No party to a supplementary agreement entered into pursuant to this article shall be relieved thereby of any obligation or duty assumed by said party state under or pursuant to this compact, except that timely and proper performance of such obligation or duty by means of the supplementary agreement may be offered as performance pursuant to the compact.

subheading1.text: Article VII. Other Laws and Relationships.

subsection.text: Nothing in this compact shall be construed to:

permit or require any person or other entity to avoid or refuse compliance with any law, rule, regulation, order or ordinance of a party state or subdivision thereof now or hereafter made, enacted or in force.

limit, diminish, or impair jurisdiction exercised by the United States Department of Energy, any agency successor thereto, or any other federal department, agency or officer pursuant to and in conformity with any valid and operative act of Congress.
alter the relations between and respective internal responsibilities of the government of a party state and its subdivisions.

permit or authorize the board to exercise any regulatory authority or to own or operate any nuclear reactor for the generation of electric energy; nor shall the board own or operate any facility or installation for industrial or commercial purposes.

subheading1.text: Article VIII. Eligible Parties, Entry into Force and Withdrawal.

subsection.text: Any or all of the states of Alabama, Arkansas, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maryland, Mississippi, Missouri, North Carolina, Oklahoma, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Virginia, West Virginia, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, and the United States Virgin Islands shall be eligible to become party to this compact.

As to any eligible party state, this compact shall become effective when its legislature has enacted the same into law: Provided that it shall not become initially effective until enacted into law by seven states.

Any party state may withdraw from this compact by enacting a statute repealing the same, but no such withdrawal shall become effective until the governor of the withdrawing state shall have sent formal notice in writing to the governor of each other party state informing said governors of the action of the legislature in repealing the compact and declaring an intention to withdraw.

The provisions of this compact and of any supplementary agreement entered into hereunder shall be severable and if any phrase, clause, sentence or provision of this compact or such supplementary agreement is declared to be contrary to the constitution of any participating state or of the United States or the applicability thereof to any government, agency, person, or circumstance is held invalid, the validity of the remainder of this compact or such supplementary agreement and the applicability thereof to any government, agency, person or circumstance shall not be affected thereby. If this compact or any supplementary agreement entered into hereunder shall be held contrary to the constitution of any state participating therein, the compact or such supplementary agreement shall remain in full force and effect as to the remaining states and in full force and effect as to the state affected as to all severable matters. The provisions of this compact and of any supplementary agreement entered into pursuant hereto shall be liberally construed to effectuate the purposes thereof.
The three members of the board from the State are as follows:

paragraph.text: one member appointed by the Director of the Maryland Energy Administration, with the approval of the Governor;
one member of the House of Delegates, appointed by the Speaker of the House; and
one member of the Senate of Maryland, appointed by the President of the Senate.
The term of the member appointed under subsection (a)(1) of this section expires at the end of the term of the appointing Governor.
The term of a member appointed under subsection (a)(2) or (3) of this section expires at the end of the term of that General Assembly.

section.text: In accordance with Article III(a) of the compact, the board shall submit its budgets of estimated expenditures to the Governor for presentation to the General Assembly.

Any supplementary agreement entered in accordance with Article VI of the compact that requires the expenditure of money or the assumption of an obligation to expend money may not become effective as to the State before the General Assembly makes an appropriation for it.
The units and officers of the State and its political subdivisions may cooperate with the board in the furtherance of any of its activities under the compact.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Council” means the Baltimore Metropolitan Council.
“Region” means the area that includes all of Anne Arundel County, Baltimore City, Baltimore County, Carroll County, Harford County, and Howard County.
There is a Baltimore Metropolitan Council.
The Council:

paragraph.text: is a body politic and corporate; and
is not a unit of State government.

subsection.text: The purposes of the Council are to:

paragraph.text: serve as a forum for local officials and their representatives to identify and address problems in the region;
provide a central source of information and coordination for fashioning responses to needs in the region; and
assist local jurisdictions in developing regional policies, prioritizing regional infrastructure needs, and developing regional strategies.

subsection.text: The Council consists of:

paragraph.text: one member appointed by the County Executive of Anne Arundel County;
one member appointed by the Mayor of Baltimore City;
one member appointed by the County Executive of Baltimore County;
one member appointed by the County Commissioners of Carroll County;
one member appointed by the County Executive of Harford County;
one member appointed by the County Executive of Howard County; and
other members as the Council Charter provides.
A member appointed under subsection (a)(1) through (6) of this section serves at the pleasure of the appointing authority.
A member appointed under subsection (a)(7) of this section serves as the Council Charter provides.

section.text: As provided in the Council Charter, the Council shall elect a chair from among its members.

paragraph.text: The Council shall meet at least quarterly at the times and places that it determines.
A majority of the members of the Council is a quorum.
An action of the Council is not effective unless approved by majority vote of all members of the Council.

subsection.text: A member of the Council:

paragraph.text: may not receive compensation as a member of the Council; but
is entitled to reimbursement for reasonable expenses.

section.text: The Council may employ a staff.

subsection.text: The Council may:

paragraph.text: adopt a seal;
sue or be sued, subject to the limitations of Title 5, Subtitle 3 of the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article;
adopt a charter, bylaws, rules, and guidelines to carry out its purposes;
acquire, hold, lease, use, encumber, transfer, or dispose of property;
enter into a contract and execute any instrument necessary or convenient to carry out its purposes;
exercise any corporate power granted to a corporation under the Corporations and Associations Article;
serve, with the State Department of Transportation, as a metropolitan planning organization for federal funding and certification; and
do all things necessary or convenient to carry out the powers granted by this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Council Charter shall include provisions for the admission and withdrawal of Council members under § 13-303(a)(7) of this subtitle.

section.text: The Council may accept from any private or public source a contribution or grant of money or property.

subsection.text: There is a Baltimore Metropolitan Council Advisory Board.
The Advisory Board consists of:

paragraph.text: the Anne Arundel County Executive and the Chair of the Anne Arundel County Council or the Chair’s designee;
the Mayor of Baltimore and the President of the Baltimore City Council or the President’s designee;
the Baltimore County Executive and the Chair of the Baltimore County Council or the Chair’s designee;
two members of the Board of County Commissioners of Carroll County;
the Harford County Executive and the President of the Harford County Council or the President’s designee;
the Howard County Executive and the Chair of the Howard County Council or the Chair’s designee; and
other members as the Council Charter provides.

subsection.text: As provided in the Council Charter, the Advisory Board shall elect a chair from among its members.

section.text: In this subtitle, “Council” means the Rural Maryland Council.
There is a Rural Maryland Council.

The Council is a State rural development council that brings together members of the public and representatives of public sector entities and private sector organizations to address collaboratively problems and challenges facing rural communities in the State.
The Council is an independent unit in the Executive Branch of State government that is placed under the State Department of Agriculture for administrative and budgetary purposes.

subsection.text: The membership of the Council is open to any resident of the State who has an interest in improving the quality of life in rural areas of the State and chooses to join the Council.
The Council shall include:

paragraph.text: the Governor or the Governor’s designee;
as determined under the bylaws of the Council:

subparagraph.text: representatives from local, State, and federal agencies that serve rural interests; and
representatives from private sector organizations, including rural-based for-profit and not-for-profit organizations and rural client groups; and

paragraph.text: as nonvoting members:

subparagraph.text: one member of the Senate of Maryland from each of the three rural regions of the State, appointed by the President of the Senate;
one member of the House of Delegates from each of the three rural regions of the State, appointed by the Speaker of the House; and
one member of the Senate of Maryland or the House of Delegates representing Harford County, appointed jointly by the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House.

subsection.text: From among its members, the Council shall elect each year a chair and one or more vice chairs.
The Council shall adopt bylaws for the conduct of its business.

section.text: The Council shall establish an Executive Board.

subsection.text: The Executive Board shall include:

paragraph.text: the chair of the Council;
the Governor or the Governor’s designee;
the Secretary or the Secretary’s designee;
the Secretary of Agriculture or the designee of the Secretary of Agriculture;
the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene or the designee of the Secretary of Health and Mental Hygiene;
the Secretary of Housing and Community Development or the designee of the Secretary of Housing and Community Development;
the Secretary of Natural Resources or the designee of the Secretary of Natural Resources;
the Director of the University of Maryland Cooperative Extension Service or the Director’s designee;
two representatives of the Maryland Municipal League, selected from rural regions of the State;
two representatives of the Maryland Association of Counties, selected from rural regions of the State;
one representative of each of the rural regional planning and development councils in the State;
one representative of each of the resource, conservation, and development councils in the State;
one or more representatives of units of the federal government;
one representative from Garrett County, Allegany County, or Washington County;
one representative from Carroll County or Frederick County;
one representative from Calvert County, Charles County, or St. Mary’s County;
one representative from Cecil County or Harford County;
one representative from Dorchester County, Somerset County, Wicomico County, or Worcester County;
one representative of the private for-profit sector;
one representative of the not-for-profit sector;
no more than six representatives of statewide not-for-profit organizations with a rural focus;
two at-large members, selected by the membership of the Council; and
as nonvoting members, the senators and delegates appointed to the Council under § 13-405(b)(3) of this subtitle.

subsection.text: Members of the Executive Board shall be selected and serve in accordance with the bylaws of the Council.
The Council may expand the membership of the Executive Board through the bylaws of the Council.
The chair of the Council is the chair of the Executive Board.

section.text: After a consensus of opinion has emerged, the Executive Board shall make recommendations on programmatic or regulatory matters of concern to rural communities.
With the consent of the Executive Board, the chair may establish subcommittees or working committees consisting of members of the Council and interested parties to address or study specific issues.

subsection.text: The Council shall employ an Executive Director.
The Executive Director:

paragraph.text: is responsible for the daily operations of the Council; and
shall help develop policy recommendations for consideration by the Council or the Executive Board.

subsection.text: The Executive Director serves at the pleasure of the Executive Board.
The State Department of Agriculture shall provide the Council with necessary staff support and resources, including office space.
Each unit in the Executive Branch of State government shall participate in the deliberations of the Council and work with the Council on matters relating to the unit.
The Attorney General is the legal advisor to the Council.

section.text: The Council is exempt from:

paragraph.text: Division I of the State Personnel and Pensions Article;
Division II of the State Finance and Procurement Article, except as otherwise provided in § 11-203(b) of the State Finance and Procurement Article; and
Title 10, Subtitle 1 of the State Government Article.

subsection.text: The Governor shall include in the budget of the State Department of Agriculture funding for the Council.

The Secretary of Agriculture shall include without revision the budget request of the Council in the budget request of the State Department of Agriculture that is provided to the Department of Budget and Management.

The Council may undertake any activity that addresses issues and concerns of rural areas of the State as long as the activity is not inconsistent with provisions of the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002 regarding the National Rural Development Partnership and state rural development councils, 7 U.S.C. § 2008m.
The Council may:

paragraph.text: maintain a principal office at a location in the central region of the State that is accessible to the rural public;
employ, as regular employees or as independent contractors, staff that the Council considers necessary in accordance with the Council budget;
enter into contracts;
accept grants and other assistance from the federal government, other units of State government, local governments, or a private source; and
do all things necessary or convenient to carry out its purpose.

section.text: The Council shall publish and submit an annual report of its activities to the Governor and, in accordance with § 2-1246 of the State Government Article, to the General Assembly.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Commissioners” means the Board of County Commissioners of Calvert County, Charles County, or St. Mary’s County, respectively.
“Council” means the Tri-County Council for Southern Maryland.
“Executive Director” means the Executive Director of the Council.
“Plan” means a regional plan that the Council prepares for the region.
“Region” means Calvert, Charles, and St. Mary’s counties.
There is a Tri–County Council for Southern Maryland.

paragraph.text: The Council is a tax–exempt body politic and corporate.
The Council is an independent unit that the Governor may not place in a principal department.
The Council is a cooperative planning and development unit for the region.
The purposes of the Council are to:

subparagraph.text: foster the physical, economic, and social development of the region; and
use effectively the assistance provided to the region by the State.

paragraph.text: The Council initiates and coordinates plans and projects for the development of human and economic resources of the region as a southern Maryland planning and development unit.

subsection.text: The Council consists of:

paragraph.text: the members of the General Assembly representing the region, as voting members;
the commissioners of Calvert, Charles, and St. Mary’s counties, as voting members;
one voting member appointed by the president of the Southern Maryland Municipal Association;
one voting member at large from each county, appointed by the commissioners of the county with the concurrence of the members of the General Assembly representing the county;
one nonvoting member from each county, appointed jointly by the economic development commission and the planning and zoning commission of the county; and
one nonvoting member appointed by the Department and the Department of Planning.
An ex officio member is a member only during the member’s term of office.
A member at large serves at the pleasure of the elected members who represent the same county.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed.
Except for an ex officio member, a member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed.

section.text: The Council shall elect a chair from among its members.

subsection.text: The Council shall establish committees to conduct its work.
The membership of a committee may include individuals who are not Council members or elected officials.

section.text: A member of the Council is not entitled to compensation as a member of the Council.

paragraph.text: The Council shall appoint an Executive Director qualified by training and experience.
The Executive Director is the chief administrative and planning officer and technical advisor of the Council.

subsection.text: The Executive Director serves at the pleasure of the Council.
The Council shall establish the powers and duties of the Executive Director.
The Executive Director is entitled to the compensation that the Council sets.

section.text: The Attorney General is the legal advisor to the Council.

subsection.text: The Council may employ a staff and retain professional consultants.
The Council shall:

paragraph.text: determine the powers and duties of the staff; and
set the compensation of the staff.
The Executive Director shall appoint and remove the staff of the Council.
The Executive Director may contract for professional or consultant services.

subsection.text: The Executive Director may make agreements with local planning units in the region for temporary transfer or joint use of staff.

section.text: The Council has the immunity from suit provided in § 5-505 of the Courts Article.

subsection.text: The State and Calvert, Charles, and St. Mary’s counties may jointly finance the Council and its activities.

paragraph.text: The State may provide financial support to the Council to assist in carrying out the activities of the Council.

subparagraph.text: On or before August 1 of each year, the Council shall submit its proposed work programs and operating budget for the following fiscal year to the Department.
The submission shall include supporting schedules to show how the budget is financed, and to provide for review and recommendations.
After review, the Department shall forward the submission and any recommendations to the Department of Budget and Management for consideration.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall include in the State budget for the following fiscal year an appropriation to partially support the Council.
The county commissioners of Calvert, Charles, and St. Mary’s counties shall appropriate money each year for the Council to foster cooperative planning and development in the region as follows:

subparagraph.text: Calvert County - $7,000;
Charles County - $9,000; and
St. Mary’s County - $9,000.

paragraph.text: Calvert, Charles, and St. Mary’s counties may appropriate any other money for the Council as they consider necessary and appropriate.

subsection.text: The Council may accept additional money from any other public or private source.
The Council may operate in the region.
The Council may:

paragraph.text: adopt a seal;
sue;
adopt bylaws and rules for the conduct of its business;
enter into contracts and agreements;
borrow money and accept advances, loans, grants, contributions, and any other form of assistance from the federal government, the State, or other public or private source;
give any required security;

include in any contract for financial assistance with the federal government any reasonable and appropriate condition imposed under federal law that is not inconsistent with the purposes of this subtitle; and
execute any instrument and act as necessary, convenient, or desirable to carry out its powers and the purposes of this subtitle.

subsection.text: The Council shall publish its rules.

section.text: The Council may:

paragraph.text: prepare studies of the region’s resources with respect to existing and emerging problems of industry, commerce, transportation, population, housing, agriculture, public services, local governments, and any other matters relevant to regional planning;

subparagraph.text: collect, process, and analyze at regular intervals the social and economic statistics for the region that are necessary to planning studies; and
make the results available to the public;

paragraph.text: participate with other governmental units, educational institutions, and private organizations in the coordination of the research activities; and
provide information to:

subparagraph.text: units and instrumentalities of the federal, State, and local governments; and
the public, in order to:

sub-subparagraph.text: foster public awareness and understanding of the objectives of the plan and the functions of regional and local planning; and
stimulate public interest and participation in the orderly, integrated development of the region.

paragraph.text: The Council shall cooperate with other units of State government.
The Council shall submit for approval each plan or project of the Council in which the State units have a statutory function or responsibility.

subsection.text: The Council may:

paragraph.text: cooperate with and provide planning assistance to local governments, instrumentalities, and planning units in the region; and
coordinate regional area planning with:

subparagraph.text: planning activities of the State and of the local governmental units, including special districts, in the region and neighboring areas; and
programs of the federal government.

section.text: The Council shall prepare, adopt, and periodically revise a general development plan for the region that embodies the policy recommendations of the Council.
The objectives of the plan are to:

paragraph.text: guide a coordinated, adjusted, efficient, and economic development of the region in a manner that will best promote the health, safety, order, convenience, prosperity, and welfare of the residents of the region in accordance with present and future needs and resources;
provide for patterns of urbanization and the uses of land and resources for trade, industry, recreation, forestry, agriculture, and tourism;
create conditions favorable to the development of human resources;
identify the public interest and the necessity for public action and intergovernmental cooperation and coordination in the region; and
coordinate with efforts of the private sector in the region.

section.text: The plan shall include:

paragraph.text: a statement of the objectives, standards, and principles sought to be expressed in the plan;

recommendations for the most desirable pattern and intensity of general land use in the region in the light of the best available information concerning natural environmental factors, the present and prospective economic and demographic basis of the region, and the relation of land use in the region to land use in adjoining areas;

recommendations for the general circulation pattern for the region including land, water, and air transportation and communication facilities, used for movement within the region or to and from adjoining areas;

recommendations on the need for and proposed general location of public and private works and facilities that, because of their function, size, extent, or for any other reason, are of a regional rather than a purely local concern;
recommendations for the long-range programming and financing of capital projects and facilities;
recommendations for meeting housing needs of existing and prospective immigrant population of the region;

recommendations for the development of programs and improvements in the region for health services, manpower planning, employment opportunity, education, elimination of poverty, and law enforcement; and
any other appropriate recommendations on current and impending problems that may affect the region.
The Council shall hold a public hearing before adopting all or part of the plan.

At least 60 days before the public hearing, the Council shall submit the plan to the Department of Planning and to the local planning commissions and governing bodies of each political subdivision in the region.
The Council shall publish notice of the hearing in newspapers of general circulation in each county in the region, at least once each week for 3 weeks before the hearing.

subsection.text: On or before the date of the hearing:

paragraph.text: the Department of Planning may recommend to the Council changes needed in the plan to conform it to State plans and policies; and
each local planning commission and governing body of each political subdivision in the region may make recommendations to the Council on the effect of the plan in the political subdivision.

subsection.text: The Council shall reevaluate the plan for the development of the region at least every 4 years, after the election of State and local officials.

section.text: The Council may amend the plan in the same manner that it adopts the original plan.
After the Council adopts the plan, the Council may not establish a policy or take an action that does not conform to the plan.

subsection.text: The Council may review:

paragraph.text: any application that a political subdivision in the region makes to a unit of the State or federal government for a loan or grant for a project; and
a local plan, proposal for a project, or ordinance that may have an impact outside the boundary of the political subdivision or in the region.

subsection.text: Before applying to a unit of the State or federal government for a loan or grant for a project, a political subdivision in the region shall submit the application to the Council for its review.
The Council shall forward its findings and determinations to the referring political subdivision and to the appropriate State or federal unit.

section.text: If the Council has adopted a plan for the region:

paragraph.text: a governmental unit in the region may not adopt a plan, or amendment to a plan, having a regional impact until the plan is referred to the Council for its consideration, review, and recommendations; and

a road, park, public way, public building, or other development that is regional in nature or affects an area greater than a single unit of government may not be constructed or authorized in the region until the proposed location and its extent are referred to the Council for consideration, review, and recommendations.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Commissioners” means the Board of County Commissioners of Allegany County, Garrett County, or Washington County, respectively.
“Council” means the Tri–County Council for Western Maryland.
“Executive Director” means the Executive Director of the Council.
“Member county” means each county in the region that pays annual dues that the Council sets.
“Plan” means a regional plan that the Council prepares for the region.
“Region” means Allegany, Garrett, and Washington counties.
There is a Tri-County Council for Western Maryland.

paragraph.text: The Council is a tax-exempt body politic and corporate.
The Council is an independent unit that the Governor may not place in a principal department.
The Council is a cooperative regional planning and development unit for the region.
The purposes of the Council are to:

subparagraph.text: foster the physical, economic, and social development of the region; and
use effectively the assistance provided to the region by the State.

paragraph.text: The Council initiates and coordinates plans and projects for the development of human and economic resources of the region as a western Maryland planning and development unit.

subsection.text: The Council consists of the following 26 members:

paragraph.text: two commissioners from each member county;
the Director of Economic Development from each member county;
two mayors from each member county or their representatives, appointed by the respective chapters of the Maryland Municipal League for each member county;
the chair of each member county’s legislative delegation to the House of Delegates, or the chair’s designee;
the two members of the Senate of Maryland representing the member counties in Districts 1 and 2;
six private citizens, two from each member county, who are:

subparagraph.text: appointed by their respective commissioners;
not listed under paragraph (1), (2), (3), (4), or (5) of this subsection; and
neither elected officials nor employees of a unit of local government.

paragraph.text: A member who qualifies because of the member’s elected or appointed position is a member of the Council only during the member’s term of office in the elected or appointed position.
A member appointed:

subparagraph.text: under subsection (a)(3) of this section, serves at the pleasure of the commissioners for the county that the member represents;
under subsection (a)(4) of this section, shall reside in the member county that the member represents; and
under subsection (a)(6) of this section:
serves at the pleasure of the commissioners who appointed the member; and
has the same term as the commissioners who appointed the member.

paragraph.text: At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
Except for an ex officio member, a member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: There is an Executive Committee of the Council.
The Executive Committee consists of the Chair, Vice–Chair, and Secretary/Treasurer of the Council.

paragraph.text: On a rotating basis, a commissioner member of the Council from each member county shall serve as the Chair, Vice–Chair, and Secretary/Treasurer, respectively.
The term of each officer is 1 year.

subsection.text: The Council shall establish committees to conduct its work.
The membership of a committee may include individuals who are not Council members or elected officials.

section.text: A member of the Council is not entitled to compensation as a member of the Council.

paragraph.text: The Council shall appoint an Executive Director qualified by training and experience.
The Executive Director is the chief administrative and planning officer and regular technical advisor of the Council.

subsection.text: The Executive Director serves at the pleasure of the Council.

paragraph.text: The Council shall establish the powers and duties of the Executive Director.
The Executive Director appoints and removes the staff of the Council.

subsection.text: The Executive Director is entitled to the compensation that the Council sets.

section.text: With the consent of the Attorney General, the Council may:

paragraph.text: select and retain its own counsel; or
use the Attorney General as its legal counsel.

subsection.text: The Council may employ a staff and retain professional consultants.
The Council shall:

paragraph.text: determine the powers and duties of the staff; and
set the compensation of the staff.

subsection.text: The Executive Director may contract for professional or consultant services.
The Executive Director may make agreements with local planning or economic development units in the region for temporary transfer or joint use of staff.

section.text: The Council has the immunity from suit provided in § 5-506 of the Courts Article.

paragraph.text: Each year the State shall appropriate money to the Council in the State budget.
The State allocation is contingent on the commitment of the participating counties to contribute matching amounts equal to the amount disbursed by the State.

subparagraph.text: On or before August 1 of each year, the Council shall submit its proposed work programs and operating budget for the following fiscal year to the Department.
The submission shall include supporting schedules to show that the budget is financed and to provide for review and recommendations.
After review, the Department shall forward the submission and any recommendations to the Department of Budget and Management for consideration.

paragraph.text: The Department shall:

subparagraph.text: review, approve, and confirm the counties’ commitments; and
include with its budget request the budget request for the Council.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall include in the State budget for the following fiscal year an appropriation to partially support the Council.
The State and Allegany, Garrett, and Washington counties may jointly finance the Council and its activities.
The commissioners of Allegany, Garrett, and Washington counties shall appropriate money each year to the Council to foster cooperative planning and development in the region.
Allegany, Garrett, and Washington counties may appropriate any other money for the Council as they consider necessary and appropriate.
Other political subdivisions, including special districts, may appropriate money to the Council as they consider necessary and appropriate.

subsection.text: The Council may use additional money from any other public or private source.

paragraph.text: The Council may operate in the region.
Association with the Council is open to all counties, municipal corporations, and special districts in the region.

subsection.text: The Council may:

paragraph.text: adopt a seal;
sue;
adopt bylaws and rules for the conduct of its business;
enter into contracts or agreements;
borrow money and accept advances, loans, grants, contributions, and any other form of assistance from the federal government, the State, or other public or private source;
give any required security;

include in any contract for financial assistance with the federal government any reasonable and appropriate condition imposed under federal laws that is not inconsistent with the purposes of this subtitle;
execute any instrument and act as necessary, convenient, or desirable to carry out its powers and the purposes of this subtitle; and
monitor, coordinate, and facilitate the activities and policies of any additional programs serving the region, except those subject to State or federal designation.

subsection.text: The Council shall:

paragraph.text: adopt bylaws governing the procedures and policies of its membership; and
publish its rules.

section.text: The Council may:

paragraph.text: prepare studies of the region’s resources with respect to existing and emerging problems of industry, commerce, transportation, population, housing, agriculture, public services, local governments, and any other matter relevant to regional planning;

subparagraph.text: collect, process, and analyze at regular intervals the social and economic statistics for the region that are necessary to planning studies; and
make the results available to the public;

paragraph.text: participate with other governmental units, educational institutions, and private organizations in the coordination of the research activities;
provide information to:

subparagraph.text: units and instrumentalities of the federal, State, and local governments; and
the public, in order to:

sub-subparagraph.text: foster public awareness and understanding of the objectives of the plan and the functions of regional and local planning; and
stimulate public interest and participation in the orderly, integrated development of the region.

subsection.text: The Council may:

paragraph.text: cooperate with and provide planning assistance to local governments, instrumentalities, and planning units in the region; and
coordinate regional area planning with:

subparagraph.text: planning activities of the State and of the local governmental units, including special districts, in the region and neighboring areas; and
programs of the federal government.

section.text: The Council shall prepare, adopt, and periodically revise a general development plan for the region that embodies the policy recommendations of the Council.
The objectives of the plan are to:

paragraph.text: guide a coordinated, adjusted, efficient, and economic development of the region in a manner that will best promote the health, safety, order, convenience, prosperity, and welfare of the residents of the region in accordance with present and future needs and resources;
provide for patterns of urbanization and the uses of land and resources for trade, industry, recreation, forestry, agriculture, and tourism;
create conditions favorable to the development of human resources;
identify the public interest and the necessity for public action and intergovernmental cooperation and coordination in the region;
coordinate with the efforts of the private sector in the region;
recognize any State comprehensive planning and development activities;
reflect the plans and programs of the participating governmental units; and
take into account economic and demographic factors, conditions, and trends that are relevant to the future development of the region.

section.text: The plan shall include:

paragraph.text: a statement of the objectives, standards, and principles sought to be expressed in the plan;

recommendations for the general circulation pattern for the region including land, water, and air transportation and communication facilities used for movement within the region or to and from adjoining areas;

recommendations on the need for and proposed general location of public and private works and facilities that because of their function, size, extent, or for any other reason are of a regional rather than a purely local concern;
recommendations for the long-range programming and financing of capital projects and facilities;
recommendations for meeting housing needs of existing and prospective immigrant population of the region;
recommendations for the development of programs and improvements in the region for health services, manpower planning, employment opportunity, education, elimination of poverty, and law enforcement;
the identification of issues that need to be resolved between local governments and make appropriate recommendations concerning these issues;
the promotion of regional concerns; and
any other appropriate recommendations on current and impending problems that may affect the region.
The Council shall hold a public hearing before adopting all or part of the plan.

At least 60 days before the public hearing, the Council shall submit the plan to the Department of Planning and to the local planning commissions, and the governing body of each political subdivision in the region.
The Council shall publish notice of the hearing in newspapers of general circulation in each county in the region, at least once each week for 3 weeks before the hearing.

subsection.text: On or before the date of the hearing:

paragraph.text: the Department of Planning may recommend to the Council changes needed in the plan to conform it to State plans and policies; and
each local planning commission and governing body of each political subdivision in the region may make recommendations to the Council on the effect of the plan in the political subdivision.

subsection.text: The Council shall reevaluate the plan for the development of the region at least every 4 years.
The Council may amend the plan in the same manner that it adopts the original plan.
The Council need not follow the procedure used to adopt the original plan in order to revise the plan as necessary and appropriate for a statistical and informational update.

section.text: After the Council adopts the plan, the Council may not establish any policy or take an action that does not conform to the plan.
The Council may review:

paragraph.text: any application that a political subdivision in the region makes:

subparagraph.text: to a unit of the State or federal government for a loan or grant for projects; or
through the State Clearinghouse for Intergovernmental Assistance in the Department of Planning; and

paragraph.text: a local plan, proposal for a project, or ordinance that may have an impact outside the boundary of the political subdivision or in the region.

section.text: In this part, “Bureau” means the Western Maryland Regional Tourism Bureau.

subsection.text: There is a Western Maryland Regional Tourism Bureau in the Council.
The purposes of the Bureau are to:

paragraph.text: develop advertising and marketing programs to disseminate information about the region;
stimulate tourism in the region;
encourage the development of the region’s recreational areas and facilities;
promote business and job opportunities in the region through tourism;
develop public awareness of the heritage and history of the region;
coordinate and facilitate special events programming for the region;
serve as a liaison between the region’s tourism industry, the Governor, the Department, other units of State government, private organizations, and the General Assembly; and
advise the Governor, the Department, and the General Assembly on programs affecting the tourism industry.

subsection.text: The Executive Board of the Bureau consists of the following 15 members:

paragraph.text: from Allegany County:

subparagraph.text: two members appointed by the commissioners;
two members appointed by the county Chamber of Commerce; and

paragraph.text: The members of the Executive Board serve the terms set in the bylaws of the Bureau.
After the initial appointment of the Executive Board, the qualifications and appointment of members are subject to the bylaws of the Bureau.

section.text: A member of the Executive Board of the Bureau:

paragraph.text: is not entitled to compensation as a member of the Executive Board; but
is entitled to reimbursement for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations.

subsection.text: The Bureau may establish officers, procedures, and voting requirements.
The Bureau may employ a staff in accordance with its bylaws.

section.text: As the Executive Board decides, the budget of the Bureau may consist of private memberships and public contributions.

subsection.text: The Bureau may establish a private, not-for-profit corporation to assist the Bureau.
Subject to the Corporations and Associations Article, the Bureau shall determine the powers and duties of the corporation.
The Bureau may:

paragraph.text: set the number of members of the Board of Directors of the corporation;
set a procedure to elect and remove directors;
set the compensation of a director; and
require the corporation to report periodically to the Bureau on its activities.

subsection.text: In this subtitle the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Commissioner” means a member of the Board of County Commissioners of Somerset County or Worcester County or a member of the County Council of Wicomico County.
“Council” means the Tri-County Council for the Lower Eastern Shore of Maryland.
“Executive Director” means the Executive Director of the Council.
“Region” means Somerset, Wicomico, and Worcester counties.
There is a Tri-County Council for the Lower Eastern Shore of Maryland.

paragraph.text: The Council is a tax-exempt body politic and corporate.
The Council is an independent unit that the Governor may not place in a principal department.
The Council is a cooperative planning and development unit for the region.
The purposes of the Council are to:

subparagraph.text: foster the physical, economic, and social development of the region; and
use effectively the assistance provided to the region by the State.

paragraph.text: The Council initiates and coordinates plans and projects for the development of human and economic resources of the region as a planning and development unit for the Lower Eastern Shore.
The Council consists of the members described in this subsection.
The voting members of the Council are:

subparagraph.text: from Somerset County, the five commissioners;
from Wicomico County:

sub-subparagraph.text: the county executive; and
four members of the county council, appointed by the county council;

subparagraph.text: from Worcester County, five commissioners, appointed by the Board of County Commissioners;
three municipal elected officials, one from each county, appointed by:

sub-subparagraph.text: their respective municipal corporations; or
the Eastern Shore Municipal Association if the municipal corporations are unable to appoint a member within a reasonable time; and

subparagraph.text: if the majority of the member’s legislative district is in the region, each member of the General Assembly representing the region.

paragraph.text: The nonvoting members of the Council are:

subparagraph.text: each commissioner in the region who is not appointed under paragraph (2) of this subsection; and
each other member of the General Assembly representing the region if the majority of the member’s legislative district is not in the region.

paragraph.text: The bylaws of the Council may provide for additional members who are private individuals.

A member appointed under subsection (a)(2)(i), (ii), or (iii) of this section may designate another commissioner or a county administrator representing the same county to vote by proxy for the member when the member is absent from a meeting.
A member who designates a proxy shall inform the Executive Director in advance of the meeting.
A member who qualifies because of the member’s elected position is a member of the Council only during the member’s term of office in the elected position.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed.

subsection.text: Council membership is not an office of profit.

section.text: The Council shall elect a chair from among its members.
A member of the Council is not entitled to compensation as a member of the Council.

subsection.text: The Council may employ an executive director.
The Executive Director serves at the pleasure of the Council.

section.text: The Council may:

paragraph.text: select and retain its own legal counsel; or
use the Attorney General as its legal counsel.

subsection.text: The State and Somerset, Wicomico, and Worcester counties may jointly finance the Council and its activities.

paragraph.text: The State may provide financial support to the Council to assist in carrying out the activities of the Council.

subparagraph.text: On or before August 1 of each year, the Council shall submit its proposed work programs and operating budget for the following fiscal year to the Department.
The submission shall include supporting schedules to show how the budget is financed, and to provide for review and recommendations.
After review, the Department shall forward the submission and any recommendations to the Department of Budget and Management for consideration.

paragraph.text: The Governor shall include in the State budget for the following fiscal year an appropriation of at least $200,000 to partially support the Council.
The governing bodies of Somerset, Wicomico, and Worcester counties each year shall appropriate to the Council at least $10,000 each to foster cooperative planning and development in the region.
Other political subdivisions, including special districts, may appropriate money for the Council as they consider necessary and appropriate.

subsection.text: The Council may accept additional money from any other public or private source.

section.text: The Council may adopt bylaws and rules for the conduct of its business and to carry out its mission.
The Council shall cooperate with State and local units that have relevant statutory functions and duties.

In this subtitle, “Advisory Committee” means the Maryland Lower Eastern Shore Tourism Center Advisory Committee.
There is a Maryland Lower Eastern Shore Tourism Center Advisory Committee.

paragraph.text: The Advisory Committee consists of nine members.
Of the nine members:

subparagraph.text: three shall be from Somerset County;
three shall be from Wicomico County; and
three shall be from Worcester County.

paragraph.text: The governing body of each county shall appoint the members from that county.

subsection.text: Each member of the Advisory Committee shall be a member of the general public and reside in the county from which the member is appointed.

paragraph.text: The term of a member is 5 years.
The terms of members are staggered as required by the terms provided for members of the Advisory Committee on October 1, 2008.
At the end of a term, a member continues to serve until a successor is appointed and qualifies.
A member who is appointed after a term has begun serves only for the rest of the term and until a successor is appointed and qualifies.

subsection.text: The governing body that appointed a member may remove the member for incompetence or misconduct.

section.text: The Advisory Committee shall advise and counsel the Department on the development and operation of the Maryland Lower Eastern Shore Tourism Center.

subsection.text: The State:

paragraph.text: recognizes the declaration of the Joint Economic Committee of the Congress of the United States that broadening the ownership of capital and achieving full employment should be the twin pillars of economic policy; and
encourages the broadening of the base of capital ownership among greater numbers of the residents of the State through, as one means, the use of employee stock ownership plans.

subsection.text: The General Assembly finds that employee stock ownership plans, as defined in the Internal Revenue Code, make an important contribution toward the broadening of capital ownership, increase the income and financial security of the residents of the State, assure the residents of the State greater control of their economic futures, improve productivity and labor–management relations, contribute to the national effort to combat inflation, strengthen the free enterprise system, and put Maryland in the forefront of contemporary economic trends.

section.text: The Department, the Maryland State Office of Minority Business Enterprise, the Division of Labor and Industry of the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation, and the Public Service Commission shall summarize their efforts to promote the policies related to broadening the ownership of capital in their respective annual reports as required by law.

subsection.text: The Department shall attempt to use to the greatest extent feasible minority business enterprises to provide brokerage and investment management services for any fund established under this article consistent with minority business purchasing standards applicable to units of State government under the State Finance and Procurement Article and consistent with the fiduciary duties of the Department.
For purposes of this subsection, brokerage and investment management services shall include services relating to all allocated asset classes.

paragraph.text: To assist the Department in achieving the goal described under subsection (a) of this section, the Department shall undertake measures to remove any barriers that limit full participation by minority business enterprises in brokerage and investment management services opportunities afforded by any fund established under this article.

The measures undertaken by the Department shall include the use of a wide variety of media, including the Department’s Web site, to provide notice to a broad and varied range of potential providers about the brokerage and investment management services opportunities afforded under this article.

subsection.text: In conjunction with the Governor’s Office of Minority Affairs, the Department shall develop guidelines to assist it in identifying and evaluating qualified minority business enterprises in order to help it achieve the objective for greater use of minority business enterprises for brokerage and investment management services under this article.

On or before September 1 each year, the Department shall submit a report to the Governor’s Office of Minority Affairs and, subject to § 2–1246 of the State Government Article, the General Assembly on:

paragraph.text: the identity of the minority business enterprise brokerage and investment management services firms used by any fund established under this article in the immediately preceding fiscal year;

the percentage and dollar value of the assets under the custody of each entity that are under the investment control of minority business enterprise brokerage and investment management services firms in each allocated asset class; and
the measures the entity undertook in the immediately preceding fiscal year in accordance with subsection (c)(2) of this section.

section.text: This subtitle may be cited as the Broadened Ownership Act.

subsection.text: In this title the following words have the meanings indicated.
“Financial assistance” means a grant or loan from the Fund.
“Fund” means the Baltimore City Community Enhancement Transit–Oriented Development Fund.
“Qualified project area” means a community that is:

paragraph.text: located in Baltimore City; and
directly impacted by and within 0.5 miles of the boundary of a development that has been designated as a transit–oriented development.

subsection.text: “Qualified recipient” means an entity that is based in and serves a qualified project area and is:

paragraph.text: a not for profit community–based organization that has experience in making physical, human capital, and economic investments to rebuild communities; or
a community development corporation.

subsection.text: “Transit–oriented development” has the meaning stated in § 7–101 of the Transportation Article.
The General Assembly finds that:

paragraph.text: while State and privately funded transit–oriented development is paramount and necessary for the orderly economic development of the State, such development should be pursued in a manner that extends benefits to and minimizes negative impacts on the communities in and adjacent to the development;

in order to preserve and enhance the State’s diverse cultural fabric in communities affected by transit–oriented development, it is essential for the public and private sectors to cooperate in developing partnerships that aim to stabilize such communities;

it is most fruitful to seek community input and involvement from organizations in areas affected by transit–oriented development in order to best address the physical, cultural, and economic impacts of the development; and
fostering community–based initiatives for neighborhood stability and growth is in the public interest.

subsection.text: The purpose of this title is to promote and assist community–based initiatives that enhance neighborhood stability and economic growth in communities that are directly impacted by State– and privately funded transit–oriented development.

section.text: This title applies only in Baltimore City.

subsection.text: There is a Baltimore City Community Enhancement Transit–Oriented Development Fund.
The Fund is a special, nonlapsing fund that is not subject to § 7–302 of the State Finance and Procurement Article.
The purpose of the Fund is to promote and assist community–based initiatives in qualified project areas consistent with the purpose of this title.
The State Treasurer shall hold the Fund separately, and the Comptroller shall account for the Fund.

paragraph.text: The Fund consists of:

subparagraph.text: money appropriated in the State budget to the Fund;
proceeds of bonds that are made available for the use of the Fund, including general obligation bonds and grant anticipation revenue vehicles;
money made available for qualifying uses by the Fund from other governmental sources, including community development block grants and the Maryland Transportation Trust Fund;
contributions to the Fund made by the private developers of the relevant transit–oriented development;
ground rents or land sale proceeds in accordance with § 10–306(c)(1) of the State Finance and Procurement Article;
payments of principal of and interest on loans made under this title;
investment earnings of the Fund; and
any other money from any other source, public or private, accepted for the benefit of the Fund.

paragraph.text: Contributions to the Fund under paragraph (1)(iv) of this subsection shall be separately accounted for in the Fund so that the revenue derived from a development in a particular qualified project area shall return to a qualified recipient in that qualified project area.
Subject to paragraph (2) of this subsection, the Comptroller shall:

subparagraph.text: pay money in the Fund in annual installments to the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City; and
ensure that the money in the Fund is distributed in the manner that best accomplishes the purpose of the Fund under this title.

section.text: The Fund may be used by the Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City or awarded to a qualified recipient by the Mayor and City Council only for:

paragraph.text: operating support for or building the capacity of qualified recipients;
economic and physical improvements to the community through projects that reinvest in and revitalize the community;
the development of women–owned, minority–owned, and small businesses;
the development of recreational facilities, parks, or improvements to the natural environment;
the development and preservation of affordable and workplace housing;
expansion of school programs and capital improvements to school facilities that serve the area;
job training and workforce development; or
counseling for housing and small business development.

subsection.text: The State Treasurer shall invest the money of the Fund in the same manner as other State money may be invested.
Any investment earnings of the Fund shall be paid into the Fund.
